Progesterone Cream: Clinical Guide for Holistic Healthcare Practitioners  
Product Profile  
Bio-Identical Natural USP Micronized Progesterone Cream  delivers superior 
hormonal support through 30 mg of USP micronized/bio -identical progesterone per 
pump derived from Wild Mexican Yam in a nourishing base of natural botanicals and 
nutrients. This topical formulation provides immediate biological activity through 
enhanced transdermal delivery for both systemic and localized therapeutic effects, 
bypassing first -pass hepatic metabolism for more physiological hormone replacement.  
Clinical Applications:  
• Menopause and perimenopause symptom management  
• Premenstrua l syndrome and menstrual irregularities  
• Estrogen balance and endometrial protection  
• Bone health preservation and osteoblast stimulation  
• Thyroid function support and hormone optimization  
• Sleep quality improvement and mood stabilization  
• Male andropause and h ormonal balance support  
Zorex International Quality Advantage  
Manufacturing Excellence  
• USP Micronized Bio -Identical Form : Enhanced absorption through particle size 
reduction to 10 micrometers or less  
• Transdermal Delivery System : Bypasses first -pass metabol ism for stable 
serum levels and reduced metabolite formation  
• Wild Mexican Yam Source : Natural derivation provides bio -identical molecular 
structure  
• Precision Dosing : Pump delivery system ensures consistent 30 mg per 
application  
• Supportive Botanicals : Natur al ingredients provide complementary hormonal 
and tissue support  
Clinical Applications & Protocols  
Primary Indications

Menopause and Perimenopause Management  Progesterone functions as a 
neurosteroid with important GABA receptor modulation and estrogen -balancing effects. 
Research demonstrates 83% reduction in hot flash frequency and severity after 12 
weeks of treatment, with significant improvements in sleep architecture through 
increased slow -wave sleep and reduced nighttime awakenings.  
Premenstrual Syndrom e and Menstrual Support  Bio-identical progesterone 
addresses luteal phase deficiency and estrogen dominance symptoms. Clinical studies 
show significant reductions in irritability, mood swings, water retention, and breast 
tenderness, with effective regulati on of menstrual cycles and reduction in anovulatory 
patterns.  
Estrogen Balance and Protective Effects  Progesterone counteracts estrogen's 
proliferative effects, reducing endometrial proliferation by approximately 40% and 
modulating breast tissue activity. Research demonstrates downregulation of estrogen 
receptors and induction of enzymes that metabolize estrogens to less stimulatory forms.  
Bone Health and Metabolic Support  Direct osteoblast stimulation promotes new bone 
formation while having minimal effect s on bone resorption. Combined with estrogen 
therapy, provides 1.5% higher spinal bone density compared to estrogen alone, with 
independent bone -preserving effects even without concurrent estrogen.  
Dosing Protocols  
Premenopausal Cyclical Use : ½ to 1 pump d aily during luteal phase (days 14 -28 of 
cycle) Postmenopausal Continuous : ½ pump daily for ongoing hormonal support 
Menopausal Symptoms : ½ to 1 pump once or twice daily for vasomotor symptom 
control Estrogen Dominance : ½ pump daily with monitoring for symp tom improvement 
Male Andropause : ¼ to ½ pump daily for hormonal balance support  
Timing Considerations:  
• Apply to thin -skinned areas (inner arms, thighs, chest, abdomen) for optimal 
absorption  
• Rotate application sites to prevent skin saturation and maintain absorption  
• Evening application enhances sleep benefits through GABA receptor modulation  
• Cyclical use in premenopausal women aligns with physiological patterns  
• Upper body application sites provide more consistent absorption than lower body  
Combination Strat egies  
With Estrogen Cream : Comprehensive menopausal support and endometrial 
protection With Sympathetic Balance : Enhanced stress response and autonomic

nervous system support With D3 -5000 : Synergistic bone health and immune system 
optimization With Magnesi um Glycerophosphate Complex : Improved muscle 
relaxation and sleep quality With KI Caps : Thyroid function support and metabolic 
optimization  
Patient Assessment Guidelines  
Ideal Candidates  
• Perimenopausal and postmenopausal women with progesterone deficiency  
• Women with premenstrual syndrome and luteal phase defects  
• Patients showing signs of estrogen dominance  
• Those requiring bone health support with natural approaches  
• Women with sleep disturbances and mood -related symptoms  
• Patients on estrogen therapy requirin g endometrial protection  
• Men with andropause symptoms and hormonal imbalances  
Clinical Markers  
Hormonal Presentations:  
• Vasomotor symptoms (hot flashes, night sweats)  
• Sleep disturbances and anxiety -related symptoms  
• Premenstrual mood changes and physical sym ptoms  
• Irregular menstrual cycles or anovulatory patterns  
• Signs of estrogen dominance (breast tenderness, fluid retention)  
Metabolic Indicators:  
• Declining bone mineral density markers  
• Thyroid dysfunction with normal hormone levels  
• Fatigue and cognitive difficulties  
• Cardiovascular risk factors  
• Stress -related cortisol imbalances  
Laboratory Considerations  
• Low progesterone levels (particularly luteal phase)

• Elevated estrogen -to-progesterone ratios  
• Bone turnover markers  
• Thyroid function parameters  
• Salivary or  serum hormone panels  
Expected Clinical Outcomes  
Timeline Expectations  
Weeks 1 -2: Initial improvement in sleep quality and mood stability Weeks 2 -4: 
Reduction in vasomotor symptoms and PMS -related symptoms Weeks 4 -8: Enhanced 
menstrual cycle regulation and  estrogen balance Weeks 8 -12: Significant improvement 
in bone formation markers Months 3 -6: Optimized hormonal balance and sustained 
symptom relief Long -term : Maintained hormonal balance and protective effects  
Patient Monitoring  
• Menopausal Symptoms : Track hot flash frequency, sleep quality, and mood 
parameters  
• Menstrual Patterns : Monitor cycle regularity and symptom severity  
• Bone Health : Evaluate bone formation markers and mineral density  
• Thyroid Function : Assess symptoms and hormone efficiency  
• Safety Parameters : Monitor for appropriate hormonal balance and tissue effects  
Clinical Pearls & Practitioner Tips  
Optimizing Therapeutic Response  
Bio-Identical Advantage : Superior safety profile compared to synthetic progestins with 
reduced breast cancer and thr ombotic risk Neurosteroid Effects : GABA receptor 
modulation provides sleep and mood benefits beyond reproductive effects Site 
Rotation : Prevents skin saturation and maintains 15% higher serum levels Cyclical 
Benefits : Premenopausal women benefit from lutea l phase timing  
Troubleshooting Common Issues  
Absorption Optimization : Apply to thin -skinned areas and rotate sites for consistent 
delivery Individual Variation : Adjust dosing based on symptom response and hormone 
levels Timing Considerations : Evening appli cation enhances sleep benefits 
Combination Synergy : Enhanced efficacy when combined with appropriate estrogen 
therapy

Patient Education Points  
• Bio-identical progesterone provides safer alternative to synthetic progestins  
• Transdermal application bypasses liver metabolism for better tolerance  
• Cyclical use in premenopausal women mimics natural hormone patterns  
• Site rotation maintains optimal absorption and hormone levels  
Safety Considerations for Practice  
Contraindications  
• Known or suspected progesterone -sensitive malignancies  
• Undiagnosed abnormal vaginal bleeding  
• Severe liver disease or dysfunction  
• Active thromboembolic disorders  
• Pregnancy (unless specifically indicated for luteal support)  
Monitoring Recommendations  
• Initial Phase : Monthly assessments for fir st 3 months to monitor response  
• Maintenance : Quarterly evaluations for symptom improvement and hormonal 
balance  
• Long -term : Annual comprehensive hormone assessment and cancer screenings  
Drug Interactions  
Exercise caution with:  
• Anticoagulants (monitor for en hanced effects)  
• Sedatives (may enhance CNS depression)  
• Thyroid hormones (may affect binding proteins)  
• Corticosteroids (progesterone has anti -mineralocorticoid effects)  
Mechanisms of Action  
Neurosteroid Function  
Progesterone functions as a neurosteroid with  direct effects on GABA receptors, 
providing anxiolytic and sleep -promoting effects. Additionally influences

neurotransmitter systems and provides neuroprotective effects throughout the central 
nervous system.  
Estrogen Modulation  
Counteracts estrogen's proliferative effects through receptor downregulation and 
induction of estrogen -metabolizing enzymes. Reduces endometrial proliferation and 
modulates breast tissue activity for protective effects.  
Bone Metabolism  
Directly stimulates osteoblast activity and  new bone formation while having minimal 
effects on bone resorption. Provides complementary bone -building effects when 
combined with estrogen therapy.  
Cardiovascular Protection  
Unlike synthetic progestins, bio -identical progesterone maintains neutral or be neficial 
effects on lipid profiles and preserves endothelial function while providing mild anti -
mineralocorticoid effects.  
Product Specifications  
Formulation Details:  
• Progesterone: 30 mg per pump in USP micronized bio -identical form derived 
from Wild Mexic an Yam  
• Base: Natural botanicals, nutrients, and supportive ingredients  
Storage Requirements:  
• Store in cool, dry place away from heat and moisture  
• Protect from direct sunlight  
• Keep in original container with tight seal  
• Do not refrigerate  
Shelf Life:  3 years  from manufacture date when stored properly  
Clinical Applications by Condition  
Menopause Management  
• Mechanism : GABA receptor modulation and estrogen balance  
• Dosing : ½ to 1 pump once or twice daily continuously  
• Expected Outcome : 83% reduction in hot flashes  and improved sleep quality

• Monitoring : Vasomotor symptoms, sleep patterns, and mood assessments  
Premenstrual Syndrome  
• Mechanism : Luteal phase support and estrogen dominance correction  
• Dosing : ½ to 1 pump daily during days 14 -28 of cycle  
• Expected Outcome : Significant reduction in PMS symptoms and cycle 
regulation  
• Monitoring : Menstrual patterns, mood changes, and physical symptoms  
Estrogen Dominance  
• Mechanism : Estrogen receptor modulation and metabolic enzyme induction  
• Dosing : ½ pump daily with adjustment based on response  
• Expected Outcome : 40% reduction in endometrial proliferation and symptom 
relief  
• Monitoring : Estrogen -related symptoms and hormonal balance markers  
Bone Health Support  
• Mechanism : Direct osteoblast stimulation and bone formation  
• Dosing : ½ to 1 pump daily with site rotation  
• Expected Outcome : Enhanced bone formation markers and density 
preservation  
• Monitoring : Bone turnover markers and mineral density assessments  
Research Foundation  
Key Supporting Studies  
• 83% reduction in hot flash frequency with 12 -week progesterone therapy  
• Improved sleep architecture with increased slow -wave sleep and reduced 
awakenings  
• 40% reduction in endometrial proliferation when combined with estrogen  
• 1.5% higher spinal bone density when combined with estrogen therapy  
• Superior safety profile compared to synthetic progestins for breast and 
cardiovascular risk  
Safety Advantages

Bio-identical progesterone demonstrates significantly fewer adverse effects than 
synthetic progestins, with reduced breast cancer risk, neutral car diovascular effects, 
and excellent metabolic profile. Site rotation enhances absorption consistency.  
The product recommendations and clinical information provided are based on research 
and formulation expertise developed by Zorex International concerning i ts products.

SIGN -U-SPRAY: Clinical Guide for Holistic Healthcare Practitioners  
Product Profile  
SIGN -U-SPRAY  delivers comprehensive sinonasal support through a therapeutic nasal solution 
containing 10 -15 parts per million of 99% pure colloidal silver along with a 140 -mcg proprietary 
blend of zinc sulfate, potassium iodide, vitamin A palmitate, vitamin D3, lauric  & caprylic acids, 
and boron. This specialized formula addresses multiple aspects of sinus health including 
microbial balance, mucosal integrity, and local immune function through direct nasal application 
with superior targeting compared to oral interventi ons.  
Clinical Applications:  
• Acute sinusitis and sinus infections  
• Chronic rhinosinusitis and recurrent sinus conditions  
• Nasal congestion and sinus pressure  
• Preventive care during high -risk periods  
• Biofilm disruption in chronic sinus conditions  
• Mucosal suppo rt and epithelial integrity  
• Post -viral sinus complications  
Zorex International Quality Advantage  
Manufacturing Excellence  
• 99% Pure Colloidal Silver : Optimal particle size and concentration for antimicrobial 
efficacy with excellent safety profile  
• Synergisti c Nutrient Complex : Essential vitamins and minerals that support mucosal 
health and immune function  
• Medium -Chain Fatty Acids : Natural antimicrobial compounds with selective activity 
against pathogens  
• Fine -Mist Delivery : Ensures even distribution throughout  nasal passages for optimal 
therapeutic contact  
• Sterile Formulation : Rigorous quality testing ensures microbial purity critical for nasal 
applications  
Clinical Applications & Protocols

Primary Indications  
Acute Sinusitis Management  Sign-U-Spray provides di rect antimicrobial action against bacterial, 
viral, and fungal pathogens commonly involved in acute sinus infections. The colloidal silver and 
iodine components offer broad -spectrum antimicrobial effects, while zinc enhances local 
immune function and viral  defense mechanisms. Clinical research demonstrates significant 
reductions in symptom severity and duration with topical antimicrobial preparations.  
Chronic Rhinosinusitis Support  For chronic sinus conditions, the formulation addresses biofilm 
formation th at protects pathogenic organisms from conventional treatments. The combination 
of colloidal silver and medium -chain fatty acids effectively penetrates biofilm matrices while 
vitamins A and D support mucosal regeneration in chronically inflamed tissues.  
Nasal Congestion Relief  The anti -inflammatory properties of the nutrient complex help reduce 
mucosal edema and improve nasal airflow without the rebound effects associated with 
sympathomimetic decongestants. The formulation addresses both inflammatory and inf ectious 
components of nasal obstruction.  
Preventive Applications  Regular use during high -risk periods maintains antimicrobial activity 
and enhances mucosal defense mechanisms, reducing incidence and severity of respiratory 
infections during viral seasons o r challenging environmental conditions.  
Dosing Protocols  
Standard Application : 1-2 sprays in each nostril twice daily Acute Sinusitis : 1-2 sprays in each 
nostril 3 -4 times daily for 7 -10 days, then reduce to standard dosing Chronic Conditions : 1-2 
sprays i n each nostril twice daily for ongoing maintenance Preventive Protocol : 1 spray in each 
nostril twice daily during high -risk periods Post -Treatment : Continue standard dosing for 3 -5 
days after symptom resolution  
Timing Considerations:  
• Clear nasal passages by blowing nose prior to application for optimal penetration  
• Shake container well before each use to ensure proper dispersion  
• Insert nozzle into nostril and squeeze while inhaling gently through nose  
• Morning and evening applications provide sustained antim icrobial coverage  
• Avoid late evening use if initial applications cause temporary nasal stimulation  
Combination Strategies

With Immune Plus : Enhanced systemic immune support during acute sinus infections With 
Complete Kare Spray : Comprehensive antimicrobial  support for both topical and systemic 
applications With C -1000 : Antioxidant support and enhanced immune function during sinus 
infections With Kleen Mouth : Complete upper respiratory antimicrobial protocol for throat and 
sinus involvement  
Patient Assessmen t Guidelines  
Ideal Candidates  
• Acute bacterial or viral sinusitis  
• Chronic rhinosinusitis with or without nasal polyps  
• Recurrent sinus infections  
• Nasal congestion of infectious or inflammatory origin  
• Patients seeking alternatives to conventional decongestant s 
• Individuals with compromised sinus drainage  
• Prevention -focused patients during high -risk periods  
Clinical Markers  
Acute Presentations:  
• Nasal congestion with purulent discharge  
• Facial pain or pressure over sinus areas  
• Reduced sense of smell (hyposmia/anos mia)  
• Post -nasal drip with throat irritation  
• Fever and malaise with sinus symptoms  
Chronic Indicators:  
• Persistent nasal obstruction lasting >12 weeks  
• Chronic post -nasal drip  
• Facial pressure or headaches  
• Recurrent acute exacerbations  
• Poor response to conventional treatments

Laboratory Considerations  
• Nasal culture for chronic or recurrent infections  
• Complete blood count if systemic involvement suspected  
• Inflammatory markers (CRP , ESR) for chronic conditions  
• Allergy testing for underlying allergic rhiniti s 
• CT imaging for chronic sinusitis evaluation  
Expected Clinical Outcomes  
Timeline Expectations  
Days 1 -3: Initial improvement in nasal congestion and antimicrobial action Days 4 -7: Significant 
reduction in sinus pressure and discharge Weeks 1 -2: Resolution  of acute symptoms and 
improved nasal airflow Weeks 2 -4: Enhanced mucosal healing and reduced inflammation Long -
term : Improved sinus function and reduced recurrence with preventive use  
Patient Monitoring  
• Symptom Resolution : Track reduction in congestion, pressure, and discharge  
• Nasal Airflow : Monitor improved breathing and reduced obstruction  
• Discharge Quality : Assess changes from purulent to clear mucus  
• Functional Improvement : Evaluate restored sense of smell and comfort  
• Recurrence Prevention : Monitor red uced frequency of sinus infections  
Clinical Pearls & Practitioner Tips  
Optimizing Therapeutic Response  
Direct Delivery Advantage : Nasal application provides superior local concentrations compared 
to oral treatments Multi -Modal Action : Combined antimicrobia l, anti -inflammatory, and 
mucosal support mechanisms Biofilm Penetration : Colloidal silver and fatty acids effectively 
disrupt protective bacterial matrices Safety Profile : Excellent tolerance with minimal risk of 
rebound congestion  
Troubleshooting Common Issues  
Initial Nasal Sensitivity : Temporary tingling or mild burning is normal initially; reduces with 
continued use Incomplete Response : Ensure proper application technique and adequate 
frequency for acute conditions Chronic Cases : May require 2 -4 weeks o f consistent use for

optimal biofilm disruption Technique Issues : Educate patients on proper nozzle insertion and 
gentle inhalation during application  
Patient Education Points  
• Proper application technique is crucial for therapeutic effectiveness  
• Initial mild nasal sensation indicates active antimicrobial contact  
• Consistent use is important for biofilm disruption in chronic conditions  
• Safe for long -term use without risk of dependency or rebound effects  
Safety Considerations for Practice  
Contraindications  
• Known hypersensitivity to silver, iodine, or other formulation components  
• Severe nasal structural abnormalities preventing proper application  
• Active nosebleeds or significant nasal trauma  
• Children under 4 years of age without direct supervision  
Monitoring R ecommendations  
• Initial Use : Assess tolerance and proper application technique at first follow -up 
• Acute Conditions : Weekly evaluation during active treatment phase  
• Chronic Management : Monthly assessments for ongoing therapeutic response  
• Long -term Use : Quart erly reviews for patients using preventively  
Drug Interactions  
Exercise caution with:  
• Other nasal medications (space applications by 15 -30 minutes)  
• Thyroid medications (due to iodine content, though minimal absorption expected)  
• Zinc supplements (consider t otal daily zinc intake)  
• Nasal corticosteroids (may reduce with improved symptoms)  
Mechanisms of Action  
Antimicrobial Activity

Colloidal silver disrupts microbial cell membranes and metabolic processes while zinc interferes 
with viral entry and replication.  Potassium iodide provides broad -spectrum germicidal 
properties through protein denaturation and membrane disruption.  
Biofilm Disruption  
The combination of colloidal silver and medium -chain fatty acids effectively penetrates the 
protective exopolysaccharide matrix that shields bacterial communities in chronic infections, 
enhancing access for immune cells and other therapeutic agents.  
Mucosal Support  
Vitamins A and D alongside zinc support epithelial regeneration and barrier function through 
enhanced cell differentiation, junction protein expression, and cellular repair processes critical 
for healthy sinus function.  
Immunomodulation  
Multiple components modulate local immune responses, enhancing protective immunity while 
limiting excessive infl ammatory responses that contribute to tissue damage and symptom 
severity.  
Product Specifications  
Formulation Details:  
• Colloidal Silver: 10 -15 parts per million (99% pure)  
• Zinc Sulfate: Bioavailable zinc for immune and epithelial support  
• Potassium Iodide: A ntimicrobial iodine source  
• Vitamin A Palmitate: Esterified vitamin A for mucosal integrity  
• Vitamin D3: Fat -soluble vitamin for immune modulation  
• Lauric & Caprylic Acids: Medium -chain fatty acids with antimicrobial properties  
• Boron: Trace element for anti -inflammatory support  
Storage Requirements:  
• Store in cool, dry place away from heat and moisture  
• Protect from direct sunlight and extreme temperatures  
• Keep container tightly closed when not in use

• Do not refrigerate  
Shelf Life:  2 years from manufacture date when stored properly  
Clinical Applications by Condition  
Acute Bacterial Sinusitis  
• Mechanism : Direct antimicrobial action against bacterial pathogens  
• Dosing : 1-2 sprays each nostril 3 -4 times daily for 7 -10 days  
• Expected Outcome : Rapid reduction in purulent  discharge and facial pressure  
• Monitoring : Symptom severity, discharge quality, and duration of illness  
Viral Upper Respiratory Infections  
• Mechanism : Zinc inhibits viral replication while silver provides broad antiviral activity  
• Dosing : 1-2 sprays each nostril 2 -3 times daily at symptom onset  
• Expected Outcome : Reduced symptom severity and duration of illness  
• Monitoring : Nasal congestion, post -nasal drip, and overall symptom progression  
Chronic Rhinosinusitis  
• Mechanism : Biofilm disruption and sustained an timicrobial activity with mucosal healing  
• Dosing : 1-2 sprays each nostril twice daily for extended periods  
• Expected Outcome : Improved endoscopic findings and reduced bacterial colonization  
• Monitoring : Symptom scores, nasal endoscopy findings, and quality o f life measures  
Allergic Rhinitis with Secondary Infection  
• Mechanism : Antimicrobial protection while supporting compromised mucosal barriers  
• Dosing : 1 spray each nostril twice daily during allergy seasons  
• Expected Outcome : Prevention of secondary bacterial  infections  
• Monitoring : Infection frequency, symptom severity, and nasal discharge character  
Research Foundation  
Key Supporting Evidence  
• Nasal delivery provides superior local concentrations compared to oral administration

• Multi -component formulations may offer enhanced therapeutic benefits over single -
agent preparations  
• Some clinical studies suggest zinc nasal applications may provide symptom relief in 
respiratory infections  
• Biofilm disruption is recognized as important for managing chronic sinusitis condi tions  
• Direct nasal application allows for targeted therapeutic delivery to affected tissues  
Safety Advantages  
Sign-U-Spray demonstrates excellent safety profile when used as directed, with minimal risk of 
adverse effects compared to conventional decongesta nts that can cause rebound congestion 
and mucosal atrophy with extended use. The natural antimicrobial components provide 
therapeutic benefits without the resistance concerns associated with conventional antibiotics.

We dedicate this page to two extraordinary leaders, our founders, Dr. Harry O. 
Eidenier Jr. and Harry O. Eidenier III.  Their visionary contributions have transformed 
the field of nutrition and enriched lives across the globe. Their passion, brilliance, and 
unwavering commitment to excellence continue to inspire all who had the privilege of  
knowing them.
Dr. Harry O. Eidenier Jr. was a pioneer in nutritional science and a passionate  
advocate for health and wellness. Known as the “Grandfather of Integrative Blood  
Chemistry,” he revolutionized the field by establishing functional ranges for blood 
chemistry analysis. His groundbreaking works, including the Balancing Body 
Chemistry Nutritional Protocol Manual and Blood Chemistry Manual , have become  
indispensable resources for health practitioners worldwide. Over his illustrious career, 
he played a pivotal role in formulating innovative products for renowned companies  
such as Standard Process, Biotics Research, and Zorex.  His legacy is one of dedication,  
innovation, and a profound commitment to improving the well-being of others.
Harry O. Eidenier III carried forward his family's legacy while forging his own path as 
an exceptional leader in the field of nutrition. Affectionately referred to as the “ Rain 
Man of Nutrition,” his tireless dedication to developing effective protocols and  
fostering a culture of excellence was unmatched. Harry  O's visionary leadership and 
relentless pursuit of quality inspired those around him to strive for greatness. He  
exemplified the principles of treating customers like family and delivering unparalleled  
service, values that remain at the core of our mission.
Together, Harry Jr. and Harry O.  were trailblazers who set a standard of excellence in 
the world of nutrition. Their contributions—from groundbreaking research and product  
development to their mentorship of countless individuals—have left an enduring impact 
that will guide future generations.
As we honor their legacy, we remain steadfast in our commitment to their vision. Their 
pioneering spirit, relentless pursuit of excellence, and profound care for others will 
forever inspire us to advance their mission and continue improving lives through  
nutrition.
Dr. Harry O. Eidenier Jr. and Harry O. Eidenier III —two remarkable men whose 
influence will resonate for generations to come.
We will forever be grateful for the impact you made not only on our lives but on 
countless others. We would like to thank you both for your tireless dedication,  
profound vision, and enduring contributions that have shaped our mission and  
enriched the lives of so many.DEDICATION

ABORTION 
(Threatened or Spontaneous) 
1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indicators: Common serum changes include decreased
thyroid values, deceased serum copper and ceruloplasmin, decreased proge sterone and cortisol
and increased homocysteine.
a.General endocrine insufficiency.
b.Probable B vitamin and mineral deficiency.
c.Reactive hypoglycemia (carbohydrate sensitivity).
d.Primary thyroid hypofunction (often sub-acute).
e.Thyroid hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary hypofunction.
f.Toxic element exposure.
g.Heat labile amino acid insufficiency.
h.Enterohepatic circulation dysfunction.
1.Adrenal cortical dysfunction (hyper or hypo).
J.Excess uterine mucous.
k.Progesterone insufficiency.
2.Dietary Suggestions:
a.Eliminate refined carbohydrates, hydrogenated fats and oils, processed foods,
alcohol and foods containing caffeine such as coffee, tea, cola and chocolate.
b.Increase raw foods, proteins and unre fined oils.
c.Use only pure water for drinking and cooking (no well water or water
containing fluoride or chlorine).
d.Eliminate mucous
 producing foods (gluten containing  grains and all dairy
products exce pt butter).
3.Primary Supplemental Support:
a.I
n most cases use octacosanol - As directed by the manufacturer.
b.F or  thyroid  hypofunction use Thyroi d ( ZI). TSH  > 2.5 but < 7.5 1` capsule,
TSH > 7.5 but < 12.5 use 2 capsules, >12.5 but < 20.0 use 3 capsules. Take
capsules in the am away from supplements containing calcium. Retest in 30
days after beginning supplementations. TSH > 20, refer for medical support
c.See the section  of this manual  covering  primary  and secondary  thyroid
hypofunction  for further  support. In any case add KI Caps (ZI) - 1 per day in
the a.m. B6/B1(ZI) - 1 bid, SunFlax  Complex  (ZI) 3 gel-caps daily.
d.Progesterone  insufficiency  is common  with patients  who have a history of
spontaneous  abortion  (especially  in the first trimester).  Progesterone  levels
should  be checked  and if decreased  consider  Micronized/Bio-Identical
Progesterone (ZI) 1 pump  bid.

ACIDOSIS 
(Systemic/Metabolic) 
1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indicators: Common serum changes include increased
AL T/SGPT, decreased CO2, increased LOH and increased phosphorus. With systemic acidosis
the CO2 will be decreased with the total globulin, BUN and/or phosphorus increased.
a.Diets high in refined carbohydrate, alcohol, solf drinks, and/or soft drinks.
b.Renal dysfunction.
c.Hepatic dysfunction.
d.Diabetes.
e.B vitamin, Mg, K,, and other Krebs cycle nutrient insufficiency.
2.Dietary Sugge stions: Dietary changes are very important for the patient with systemic acidosis
(generally the patient is sympathetic dominant). Supplementation without the dietary changes
indicated is often fruitless.
a.Eliminate all refined foods, dairy (except butter) and gluten containing grains.
b.Eliminate fried foods and limit red meat. Use fresh fish, lamb and skinless
poultry in lieu of pork and red meat.
d.Eliminate all hydrogenated fats and oils. Increase raw and fresh oils.
e.Eliminate all caffeine containing foods.
f.Drink at least 8 full glasses of pure water daily (no well water or city water).
g.Increase raw foods and quality proteins.
h.Consider using the Roadmap to Health diet.
3.Primary Supplemental Support:
a.C.G.F. (ZI) - For the first 10 days of treatment use 3 tid. After 10 day reduce to 2 tid
and add B6/Bl (ZI)- 1 bid.

Clinical investigation has shown that many asthma patients are suffering with  hidden bacterial 
infections (not always seen with a shift in the WBC differential or change  in the WBC total). 
Many of these patients improve rapidly on low-dose antibiotics. If low-dose antibiotics are 
needed, Saccharomyces Boulardii (ZI) should be used at 1 bid. 
Food allergy is common with asthma however, food sensitivity leading to inflammation is more 
common than IgE allergy. A food inflammation test should be completed on all asthma patients 
and they should use the Roadmap To Health diet available from Zorex International at no 
charge with a supplement order should be used. 
The incidence of intestinal parasites being nexus to  asthma is much higher than expected (see 
The
 Wonn-Asthma Controversy by Robert S. Desowitz, M.D., University of Hawaii).  
Investigation by doctors who were members  of the Balancing Body group  in the 1980s indicated 
that approximately 60~70 percent of the patients with asthma had  some type of intestinal 
parasite. Clearing the intestinal parasites revealed improvement in most of the asthmatic 
patients.
ALWAYS RULE OUT INTESTINAL PARASITES WITH ASTHMA.

ATHEROSCLEROSIS 
ARTERIOSCLEROSIS 
1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Information: The modem American diet, i.e., high in
refined carbohydrates and other fast foods is the major reason for many cases of  athero­
sclerosis/arteriosclerosis. Further, many clinicians believe,  and probably rightly so,  that the
xanthine oxida se found in processed milk is another major reason.  Common serum changes
include ALP increased, apolipoprotein A-1 decreased with apolipoprotein B increased, Lp­
PLA2 increased, cholesterol increased, HDL cholesterol decreased with LDL cholesterol
increased, HgB Ale increased, triglycerides increased, uric acid increased, lipid
fractionization test
 abnormal and BUN  increased, possibly due to HCL need.
a.Genet ic pre-disposition (Type 1 Hyperlipoproteinemia).
b.Diets high in refined carbohydrates, alcohol,  and dairy products.
c.Endocrine dysfunction (primary thyroid hypofunction, thyroid
hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary hypofunction and adrenal
cortical hyperfunction, are the most common endo crine problems).
d.Diabetes or carbohydrate sensitivity resulting in dysinsulinism.
e.Homocysteine (need for vitamin B-6, B-12,  trimethylglycine, and/orfolate).
f.An abnormal lipid fractionization test and/or the presence  of Metabolic Syndrome
either of which  indicate that atherosclerosis is probable.
2.Dietary Suggestions:
a.Eliminate all refined carbohydrates, dairy products (except butter ), gluten containing
foods, caffeine, fruit juice and alcohol.
b.Eliminate all hydrogenated fats and oils. Increase raw and fresh oils.
c.Increase protein and raw vegetables, use the  Roadmap to Health Diet
when possible.
d.Drink at least 8 full glasses of distilled water each day.  After 90 days the
distilled water
 can be discontinued in lieu of  spring water. No well water or
city water.
e.Eliminate canned food, frozen food and all processed  food.

AUTISM 
1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indication s: Common serum changes include 5-
hydroxy tryptamine increased, oxytocin decreased, ammonia increased and TSH decreased.
Although the blood chemistry indicators generally do not indicate a pancreatic problem for these
patients, reduction in fecal chymotrypsin will generally indicate a pancreatic problem. When
present, IV secretin is often helpful (see below). During the late 1970s and early 1980s, John
Upledger, D.O. (world renowned craniosacral therapist), and other physicians using the
Biochemical Blood Biopsy attempted to find a blood serum pattern consis tent with autism. They
were unsuccessful, except for finding that a great deal of the patients with autism had increased
serum ammonia. Later research published in 202 indicated that mothers who ate a high in refined
foods were many times more likely to have a child born with or, who developed ADD/ADHD
than mothers on diets low in refined foods. Hence the dietary suggestions below.
a.Pitocin (a drug used to induce birth).
b.Anesthesia and pain control drugs used during the birth process.
c.Mercury-based preservatives in vaccines or the vaccines themselves.
d.Reduced fecal chymotrypsin indicating abnormal pancreatic function.
e.Psychological or physical stress.
f.Vitamin B-12/folate deficiency.
g.Food aller gy/sensitivity.
h.Use of narcotics, tobacco, excess alcohol and/or poor diet by the mother during
pregnancy ( excess refined foods, excess use of foods high in mercury, etc.).
1.Intestinal parasites (amoebic).
J.Sub-acute viral or bacterial infection.
2.Dietary Suggestions: Although diet alone will probably not completely resolve autism,
because pancreatic dysfunction is involved in many cases, dietary changes to ensure the
following may result in patient improvement:
a.Drink plenty of pure water each day (no well or city water).
b.Eliminate gluten, dairy, refined foods, hydrogenated fats and oils, alcohol,
caffeine, fruit juice and packaged foods containing dyes, additives and/or
preservatives.
c.Increase raw and fresh food and quality proteins.
d.Increase raw oils, especially those containing DHA.
e.Rule out food allergy/sensitivity.
3.Primary Supplemental Support: Although there is no evidence that supplemental
supp01t alone will completely resolve autism. However, supplemental support coupled with
dietary changes has caused improvement. Autism is a problem requiring a
multidisciplinary approach by professionals trained in the treatment of this problem. The
supplement levels indicated below are for children, levels should be increased for adults.

BLOATING/FLATULENCE 
(Due to Biliary Dysfunction, Hypochlorhydria or

1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indicators: Common serum indicators with gall bladder
dysfunction include decreased albumin, increased ALP, increased SGPT/AL T and/or GGT,
increased bilirubin, increased cholesterol and decreased cholinesterase. Common serum
indicators with achlorhydria or hypochlorhydria include increased or decreased total globulin,
decreased phosphorus, increased BUN and increased MCV/MCH. With pancreatic dysfunction
common serum indicators include increased SGPT/ALT, increased ALP, increased SGOT/AST
and/or GGT, increased bilirubin, increased LDH, increased lipase, increased MCV and
increased triglycerides.
a.Biliary stasis/insufficiency (often secondary to hypochlorhydria).
b.Hypochlorhydria.
c.Pancreatic insufficiency (often secondary to hypochlorhydria).
d.Bacterial imbalance in the colon.
e.Food sensitivity.
f.Pain between the shoulder blades, pain over the eyes, pain in the webbing
between the right thumb and forefinger when pressure is applied, gas, bloating
and a positive Murphy's sign are all indicators of biliary stasis. Loss of taste for
meat, gas, bloating and bad breath are all indicators for HCl need. Undigested
food in the stool is a sign of pancreatic insufficiency.
2.Dietary Suggestions:
a.Drink at least 8 full glasses of pure water daily (no wel I water or city water).
b.Eliminate all hydrogenated fats and oils. Increase raw and fresh oils.

d.If hypochlorhydria is suspect, reduce red meat intake until corrected.
e.Increase raw food in the diet.
f.If food sensitivity is suspected, eliminate all dairy products, gluten, eggs, citrus
and shellfish (food allergy is a common reason for gall bladder dysfunction).

lowest possible level and monitored frequently.
g.Eliminate hydrogenated fats and oils and limit anima l fats.

1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indicators: Common serum indicators include increased

hypofunction and thyroid hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary
hypofunction are very common with adrenal cortical hyperfunction.

e.Increase raw vegetables and protein.
f.If the patient is overweight and renal function is not compromised, maintain
total daily intake of carbohydrates at not more than 60 grams. If the patient's
weight is normal or they are underweight, maintain carbohydrate intake at a
level where weight is not lost.

followed. Further information on diet can be obtained from the Roadmap To Health Diet

CERVICAL DYSPLASIA 
1.Pre-Disposing Factors  and Clinical  Indicators: Irrespective of the fact that this can be a
pre-cancerous or cancerous condition, the serum CEA, CA-125 and squamous cell
carcinoma antigen are almost always normal. Pap smear is the only reliable means of
identifying cervical dysplasia. Cervical dysplasia is characterized by the presence of abnormal
cells in the cervix, generally indicating either a pre-cancerous or cancerous condition. Most
often the problem is classified as low-grade or high-grade, depending on the severity of the cell
changes. Low-grade progresses slowly and can resolve on its own. High-grade tends to progress
quickly and can lead to cervical cancer.
a.Genital warts.
b.Abnormal bleeding.
c.Spotting after intercourse.
d.Vaginal discharge.
e.Low back pain or bowel changes.
2.Dietary  Suggestions:
a.Eliminate mucous producing food s ( dairy products and gluten).

quality proteins.
d.A v
oid soy and products containing soy.

in 3 ounces of distilled water (use a rectal syringe). Douche should be used 3
times a week along with the supplements for 30  days. A tampon soaked with Complete
Kare  Spray  (ZI)  can be used in lieu of the douche (insert immediately before the
tampon swells). At the end of 30 days, complete another Pap smear.
c.KI Caps (ZI) - 1 capsule (if the vaginal iodine is not used).
d. 8X Pancreatin (Zl) - 1 tid  on an empty stomach.
e.Immune  Plus  (ZI)  - 4 tid for one week then 2 bid.

(Increased) 
1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indicators: Cholesterol in the serum/plasma is
generated from diet and synthes is by the liver, with cholesterol enter ing the small intestine
inhibiting liver production. Levels are also influenced by insulin, thyroid hormones,
glucagon, epinephrine, other endocrine function and carbohydrate ingestion. For most
patients, lowering dietary cholesterol will generally have little effect on serum levels.
However, addressing other factors such as exercise, carbohydrate consumption, endocrine
function, caffeine consumption, smoking and hepatic/biliary function will have a far greater
effect. Common serum changes in addition to increased cholesterol include increased LDL
cholesterol with decreased HDL cholesterol, increased apolipoprotein B with decreased
apolipoprotein A-1, increased Lp-PLA2, increased lipoprotein (a), abnormal lipid
fractionization test and increased triglycerides.

of cholesterol by itself is almost never totally responsible for elevated blood
cholesterol.

hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary hypofunction and/or adrenal
cortical hyperfunction are the most common).

e.Prolonged bowel transit time.

veal in lieu of red meat.
d.Eliminate hydrogenated fats and oils. Increase raw and fresh oils.

carbohydrate intake to not more than 60 grams per day.

EDEMA 
(Water Retention) 
1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indicators: With lower limb/ankle edema, congestive
heart failure and renal involvement must be ruled out. I f congestive heart failure is suspect,
refer the patient immediately for further evaluation and treatment. One ankle only usually
indicates kidney involvement, both ankles usually indicate kidney or c ardiac involvement.
Prolonged standing usually indicates adrenal hypofunction and edema w ith sweating indicates a
salt need (Celtic Sea salt). Common serum changes include increased AL T/SGPT, AST/SOOT
and ALP, increased aldosterone, decreased albumin, increased atrial natriuretic peptide,
decreased Co2, BUN and creatinine increased with renal involvement, decreased magnesium
and potassium, increased uric acid and troponin T and I increased with cardiac involvement.

b.Food allergy/sensitivity.

nction.

sue inflammation.

c.Eliminate all hydrogenated fats and oils. Increase fresh and raw oils.
d.Increase raw vegetables and protein (raw nuts and seeds). Limit red meat to not more
than one serving per week. Use poultry, fish, lamb and veal in lieu of red meat.

GALL BLADDER DYSFUNCTION 
(Biliary Stasis) 
(Biliary Insufficiency) 
(Stones) 
1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indicators: Biliary stasis is one of the most common
problems encountered, with biliary stasis being the most common precursor to biliary calculi
(stones). Common serum indicators present with biliary stasis, benign biliary disease and gall
stones include decreased albumin, increased bilirubin, increased GGT, AL T/SGPT and
AST/SGOT, decreased cholinesterase, increased CA 19-9, CA 195 and CA 242 and decreased
WBC with a shift in the differential. With common bile duct blockage, the bilirubin, ALP, and
GGT will be high and the GGT will be higher than AST and ALT (gold standard diagnosis for
common bile duct blockage). Estrogen problems will often cause biliary stasis and vice-versa
with folate deficiency common.
a.Diets high in refined carbohydr ates, hydrogenated fats and oils, fried foods.
b.Female hormonal imbalance (thyroid, ovarian).
c.Obesity/lack of exercise.
d.Insufficient water intake.
e.Hypochlorhydria resulting in biliary insufficiency.
f.Genetic pre-disposition.
g.Food sensitivity (dairy, gluten, eggs, citrus, shellfish and night shades are the
most common allergens encountered). Fertile organic eggs do not seem to
present an allergy problem.
h.Constant running nose often indicates a need for bile salts.
2.Dietary Suggestions:
a.Eliminate all hydrogenated fats and oils. Increase raw and fresh oils.
b.Eliminate all refined carbohydrates, alcohol, processed foods, fried foods, dairy 
products ( except butter), gluten containing grains and caffeine containing foods.
c.Drink at least 8 full glasses of pure water daily (no well water or city water).
d.A void ]ettuee and foods in the cabbage family (broccoli, cabbage, kale, etc.),
until biliary function normalizes.
e.Rule out food allergy, especially eggs.

more common than hyperchlorhydria.

f.Inflammation from food allergy/sensi tivity resulting in ulceration. 
Aspirin abuse, severe trauma or chronic illness.

1.Pre-Disposing  Factors and Clinical  Indicators: When checking urine pH one sample is
generally not useful as urine pH will be more acid in the a.m. and more alkaline after meals.
Also, with bacterial infection, the urinary leukocyte esterase, nitrate, WBCs and/or bacteria will
frequently be increased. Check 6-8 samples to determine average urinary ph. Nitrate is the most
common increase.
a. Poor personal hygiene.

liminate  hydrogenated fats and oils. Increase ra w and fresh  oils.

rations:  If the genital/urinary tract infection is identified as Candida or another

1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indicators: Serum changes are variable with the above
problems, however it is quite common to find signs of hypochlorhydria (increased or
decreased total globulin, increased BUN, increased MCV!MCH and/or decreased
phosphorus), signs of atherosclerosis (increased triglycerides, increased LDL cholesterol, r
increased apolipoprotein B with decreased apolipoprotein A-1, abnormal lipid factionization
test and/or increased Lp-PLA2), signs of B vitamin and B-12 / folate defic iency as well as
signs of increased systemic acidity ( decreased Co2, increased anion gap and/or increased
MCV/MCH), signs of dehydr ation (increased HgB, HcT), vitamin D deficiency and signs of
protein malnutrition ( decreased BUN, total protein and/or total globulin). Further, a
decreased albumin is not uncommon with elderly patients and if present is a strong
indicator of reduced immune function, and also an indicator that if hospitalized for any
reason the prognosis is poor.
a.Excess refined and processed foods in the diet, the tea and toast diet
(especially if the patient is a widow/widower or is house bound).
b.Insufficient water intake.
c.Because the elderly patient often gets gas and bloating from protein ingestion,
they will avoid protein with resulting in insufficient protein intake.
d.Lack of physical exercise.
e.Psychological stress.
f.Reduced circulation of aging.
2.Dietary Suggestions: Although the following suggestions may be difficult to follow for a
geriatric patient living alone, house-bound, or on a limited income, etc., they should be
followed as closely  as possible.
a. Drink at least 8 glasses of pure water daily (no well water or city water).
b.A void refined carbohydrates, processed foods, fried foods, alcohol and caffeine.
c.A void hydrogenated fats and oils. Increase raw and fresh oils.
d.If digestive distress is present, avoid dairy products ( except butter), gluten
containing grains, and excess (more than twice a week) red meat. Use skinless
poultry, fish, veal and lamb in lieu of beef.
e.Increase raw and fresh food and quality protein.

HEMO CHROMA TOSIS/IRON OVERLOAD 
1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indicators: Although increases in the serum iron and/or
ferrit
in and a decrease in the total iron binding capacity (TIBC) are r eason to suspect
hemochromatosis or iron overload; when the percent of iron saturation is greater than 50 percent,
hemochromatosis/iron overload is almo st certain. If the patient does not respond to diet and
supplemental feeding gene testing for genetic hemochromatosis should be ordered.
a.Genetic pre-disposition.
b.Multiple blood transfusions.
c.Excess ingestion of iron from supplements, water supply, iron cooking utensils, etc.
d.Gastrointestinal permeability (inflammation) resulting in increased absorption of iron.
e.Liver, biliary or spleen dysfunction.
2.Dietary Suggestions:
a.Use only pure water for drinking or cooking (no well water or city water).
b.A void foods high in iron such as red meat, spinach, soybeans, wheat, com, and lettuce.
c.A void foods cooked in iron cooking utensils.
d.A void foods and food supplements with nutrients that enhance iron uptake such
as ascorbic acid, fructose, c itric acid, lysine, histidine, cytosine, and methionine.
e.Increase foods that inhibit iron uptake such as foods containing oxalic acid
( except spinach), phytate (grains except wheat) and foods high in dietary fiber.
3.Primary Supplementa l Support:
a.Fe-X (ZI) - 4-5 bid.
b.Multi minerals - As directed by the manufacturer.
NOTE: When genetic hemochromatosis is diagnosed, all 1st degree family members of the 
patient should be screened for the problem. Irrespective of the nexus (acquired or genetic) 
the problem is frequently silent (no symptoms); however, it will almost always result (if not 
corrected) in heart disease, liver/biliary disease, bacterial infection, dementia, 
atherosclerosis, diabetes, or stroke. If dietary and supplemental support is not immediately 
successful, patient should be referred for phlebotomy and/or deferoxamine chelation 
(phlebotomy is preferred). Retest in 50 days. If percent is still greater than 50, 
routine phlebotomy is needed.
When the percent of saturation returns to normal, recheck the iron panel in 90 days. If 
the percent of saturation is again greater than 50, this patient must be advised to give a 
pint of blood every 60-90 days (genetic or acquired).

HOMOCYSTINURIA 
(Elevated Homocysteine) 
1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indi cators: Homocysteine is a pot ent inflammatory
agent and the presence of increased homocysteine in th e serum or urine (urine is  preferred
test) should not be taken lightly. If not corrected, th e increase will  most always res ult in
atherosclerosis with subsequent cardiac/vascular problems. Laboratory chang es seen with
increased homocysteine include increased urinmy methylmalonic acid (B-12 deficiency),
decreased vitamin B-6 an d B-2 and increased plasma methionine. We do not consider
homocysteine normal until it is below the midline of the laboratory range.
a.Vitamin B-6, B-12, B-2, folic aci d or betaine anemia.
b.Atherosclerosis (result of homocystinuria.)
c.Thyroid hypofunction.
d.Genetic pre-disposition (Type IV Hyperlipoproteinemia).
2.Dietary Suggestions:
a.Increase raw and f resh foods.
b.Eliminate refined carbohydrates, processed foods, alcohol, an d caffeine.
c.Eliminate hydrogenated fats and oils. Increase raw  and fresh oils.
d.Use only pu re water for drinking and cooking (no well water or city water).
e.A void foods high in sulfur (beans, legumes and cabbage family foods) until
the problem is controlled.
3.Primary S
upplemental Support:
a.C.G.F. (Zl) - 4 tid.
b.GB Complete  (ZI) - 2-3 tid.
c.Sympathetic Balance (ZI) - 2 tid.
d.B6/B1 (ZI) - 2 bid
e.After the homocysteine normalizes use C.G.F. (ZI) and GB Complete (ZI)
at 2 each bid, should be used for long-term support.
4.Other Considerations:
Additional support will be determined by other metabolic problems associated with
homocystinuria, i.e., atherosclerosis, thyroid hypofunction, Type IV Hyperlipoproteinemia,
Syndrome-X/Metabolic Syndrome, etc. If any of these problems are present, treat as
indicate d in the secti ons of this manual covering these problems.

During the mid-l 980s, Emil Morlock, D.C. (Charter Diplomate in the ICAK) completed a 
clinical study on patients with chronic ICV problems. After dietary and structural problems 
were ruled out as the reason for the recurring ICV problems the patients were checked via stool 
analysis for intestinal parasites. Of the 14 patients checked, 9 were found to have parasites 
( common round worm). Treatment for the parasites resulted in resolution of the chronic ICV 
problems. Dr. Morlock passed away several years ago, we sincerely miss him, he was a talented 
clinician and a great friend.

LYME DISEASE 
(Borrelia burgdorferi) 
1.Pre-Disposing Factor: Lyme disease is now the most common vector-borne illness in the
U.S. It is a spirochetal infection caused by a newly recognized organism Borrelia
burgdorferu and transmitted primarily by ticks and other insects. Most experts agree that
Lyme disease is under-reported. Patients who present with Lyme disease type symptoms
(rash, fever, etc.), should also be checked for Babesia rnicroti. Serum changes include
increased ALT/SGPT, increased sedimentation rate, increased interleukin-6, increased CRP,
and increased immunoglobulin M.
2.Dietary Suggestions:
a.Drink at least 8 full glasses of pure water daily (no well water or city water).
b.Eliminate refined foods, alcohol, gluten, dairy (excep t butter) and
hydrogenated fats and oils. Increase raw and fresh foods.
3.Primary Supplemental Support:
a.During the early part of the infection a skin rash develops in majority of
patients and if the disease is localized, other significant manifestations
(arthritis, cardiac and/or nerve disease primarily) will be lacking. During
this phase, treatment with high dose antibiotics is sometimes successful.
b.If the problem is not caught or addressed properly in the early stage, late­
stage Lyme disease will usually develop. During this phase, arthritis,
cardiac disease and/or nerve disease often devel ops, and the high dose antibiotic
treatment is frequently less successful. Although the peer reviewed literature
does not reflect treatment for this problem or Babesiarnicroti with drugs ( except
quinine) designed to treat parasitic problems, clinical feedback indicates the
following supplementation is often helpful alone or with prescribed medication  for
late-stage Lyme disease.

empty stomach.

meals.

RESTLESS LEG SYNDROME (RLS) 
1.Pre-Disposing  Factor s and Clinical  Indicator s: RLS is a sensorimotor problem
characterized by various symptoms including an urge  to move the legs, as well as crawling
sensation under the skin of the legs. It can b e  primary (familial) or secondary
(acquired) and affects a wide variety of patients to include pregnancy, patients with renal
disease, iron deficiency, rheumatoid disease, and persons taking certain medications. Iron
deficiency and dopamine are considered primary deficiencies with RLS.
2.Dietary  Suggestions:  Same as those listed on the previous page. Patients should also be
instructed to increase  their exercise (walking is best).

(ZI)-  As needed  to control  iron anemia.

1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indicators: With osteoporosis, common serum changes

magnesium, decreased osteocalcin, and decreased PTH. With osteoporosis common urinary
changes include increased deoxypyridinoline, increased hydroxyproline and decreased lysine.
With Paget's, common serum changes include increased ALP with increased ALP bone
isoenzyme, increased calcium (calcium is generally decreased with osteoporosis), increased
osteocalcin (osteocalcin is generally decreased with osteoporosis) and decreased PTH. With

hydroxyproline, and, decreased lysine. Many in the healing arts believe the high incidence of
osteoporosis in females is due to the lack of estrogen after menopause, however many also
believe that one of the causative factors is a lifetime ofr educed progesterone, fluoride ingestion
and iodine deficiency.

PARASITES 
(Intestinal) 
1.Pre-Disposing Factors: Irrespective of the blood eosinophil level or the IgE level (they will
frequently be normal with an amoebic infestation), or the presence of subjective signs and
symptoms, always complete a CDSA with parasitology (GI Map-Diagnosis Solutioons) to
determine the type of parasite and the severity of the infestation. In addition to the
information gathered from a stool analysis, serum changes to include increased AST/SGOT,
decreased vitamin B-12, increased eosinophils, monocytes and/or basophils, increased
LDH, decreased HgB and/or HcT, increased WBC and increased neutrophils with decreased
lymphocytes may be present. Subjective indications can include allergy/sensitivity, skin
disorders, dry or scaly skin, dark circles under the eyes, lack of muscle tone, burning or
itching anus, chronic gas or bloating, weight gain or loss, chronic depression, ADD/ADHD,
bites nails, picks nose, deep unproductive nocturnal cough, and dull eyes with dark circles
under the eyes.
a.Improperly washed raw foods.
b.Improperly cooked fish, poultry, or meat.
c.Frequent contact with a household pet, bird, farm animals or family
member that is a carrier for the parasite.
d.Improperly purified water.
e.Hypochlorhydria.
Note: Other family members and pets should be checked if a parasite problem is discovered 
and thought to be chronic. 
2.Dietary Suggestions:
a.Use only pure  water for drinking and cooking (no  well or city water).
b.Ensure raw foods are properly washed.
c.Ensure cooked foods are properly prepared.
d.Limit mucous
 producing foods such as dairy products and gluten.
e.Increase foods high in sulfur (based on the work  of Roy Hankey,  M.D., Ph.D.).

 are still present, consider pharmacological or anti-malaria support.

full bid.

f.MSM Plus (ZI) - 1 tid.
g.Immune Plus ( ZI) - 3 tid.
h.IF THE PATIENT IS ASYMPTOMATIC BEFORE SIX WEEKS OF TREATMENT,
ENSURE THEY CONTINUE THE PROGRAM FOR 6 WEEKS!

PITUITARY (ANTERI()R) DYSFUNCTION 
The following information pertains only to anterior pituitary bypofunction. Anterior pituitary 
hyperfunction is an uncommon problem and when present, adenoma must be ruled out. With 
hyperfunction, one or more of the pituitary hormones will be elevated (especially prolactin) and 
the blood pressure will often be elevated. If anterior pituitary hyperfunction is present consider 
treatment with Mn-Zyme (BR), Magnesium Glycerophosphate (ZI) and B6/Bl (ZI). this 
protocol if a benign pituitary adenoma has been identified and add Dopa Tropic Powder (BR) 
at 1 tsp bid. 
1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indicators: Common serum chan ges
include androgens decreased, cholesterol increased, phosphorus decreased, progesterone
decreased, insulin increased, T-4 decreased, T
SH decreased below 2.5 (see a. and b.
below) and either increased or decreased cortisol.
a.Reduced thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH). Note: The subjective
indications of anterior pituitary hypofunction and thyroid hypofunction
secondary to pituitary hypofunction are similar. When in doubt, complete a serum
TSH. If the result is below 2.5, anterior  pituitary hypofunction is probable, if
the result is above 2.5, primary thyroid hypofunction is probable ( symptoms must
be present for this guide to be accurate). TSH can be below 2.5 nmmally when the
patient is on thyroid hormone replacement.
b.Patient will generally exhib it symptoms of thyroid hypofunction (weight
gain, decreased energy, hair loss, poor skin tone, headaches in the a.m. that
wear  off as the day goes on, inability to concentrate, poor memory, hearing
loss, ringing in the ears, poor  circulation, low axillary temperature,
constipation, depression, etc.).
c.Diabetes and/or carbohydrate sensitivity.
d.Toxic element exposure.
e.Biliary insufficiency resulting in reduced hormonal conjugation.
f.Manganese deficiency.
2.Dietary Suggestions:
a.Drink a
nd cook only with pure water (no well water or city water).
b.Eliminate refined carbohydrates, alcohol, processed foods and caffeine.
c.Increase raw foods and quality proteins. If the patient  is overweight
and renal  function is not compromised, limit daily  carbohydrate
intake to 60 grams or  less.
d.Eliminate dairy, gluten containi ng and fermente d food.
e.Eliminate hydrogenated fats and oils. Increase raw and fresh  oils.
Continued On The Following Page: 
195

3.Primary S upplemental Support :
a.AD Complex (ZI) - 2 bid and S.O.S. (ZI) - 2-3 tid.
b.If adrenal cortical hyperfunction is present use AD Hyper (ZI) in lieu of AD Complex
(ZI).  AD Hyper (ZI) - 2-3 midday and 2-3 in the evening, and /or  use Sympathetic
Balance (ZI) - 2 tid, and S.O.S. (ZI) -3 tid.

a.If  
 a need for DHEA can be demonstrated add DHEA - As directed by the manufacturer.

RBC, urinary and/or 
hair mineral analysis.

Thyroid hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary dysfunction can cause an increase in

1.Pre-Disposing Factors for Prostate Hypertrophy and Clinical Indicators:
Common serum indicators include increased prostate acid phosphatase, increased amylase,
increased creatinine (great er than 1.2), PSA greater than 2.0, increased monocytes,
increased LDH isoenzyme #4, increased BUN, increased uric acid and excess or
decreased testosterone (with decreased testosterone, estrogen is often increased). With
prostate adenoma the free PSA will generally be decreased with an increased total
PSA, increased prostate acid phosphatase, increased ALP bone isoenzyme, increased
CEA , increased CA 19-9, 27-29, and 549, decreased carnitine, decreased total cholesterol,
increased LDH isoenzyme #4 and #5 and increased uric acid. With male reproductive
problems/infertility common serum indicators include increased copper, increased
prolactin, decreased sperm and decreased sperm motility.
a.Food allergy/sensitivity ( dairy products [ except butter] most frequently).
b.Non-specific urinary tract infection.
c.History of venereal disease.
d.Obesity.

hypertrophy.

before a serum PSA is completed may result in a false positive (increased
above 2.0).

RENAL DYSFUNCTION 
(Nephrotic Syndrome) 
(Glomerulonephritis/Pyelonephritis) 
(Support While on Dialysis or Dialysis Pending) 
1.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indicators: Nephritis is a serious medical condition
which is the 9th leading cause of death. It can develop a few weeks after a strep infection of the
throat or skin as glomerulonephritis, or the acute form, pyelonephritis. or it can occur suddenly,
but is always more common in adult females. Common serum changes include decreased
albumin, decreased apolipoprotein A-1 with an increase in apolipoprotein B, decreased cortisol,
decreased copper, increased eosinophils, increased fibrinogen, decreased HDL cholesterol,
decreased immunoglobulin G and M, increased phosphorus, increased triglycerides, GFR
decreased, and zinc decreased. With chronic renal failure, diabetes, gout, pre-ecl ampsia,
eclampsia, SLE and glomerulonephritis, the urinary creatinine clearance will be decreased, and
the micro-albumin will beincreased.
a.Fatigue.
b.High blood pressure.
c.Diabetes.
d.SLE.
e.Edema.
f.Post strep infection.
g.Cloudy or bloody urine.
h.Polycystic kidney disease.

b.Eliminate all cirrus except lemon, dairy products, gluten, alcohol, refined
carbohydrates, processed foods and caffeine.
c.Eliminate hydrogenated fats and oils, increase raw and fresh oils.
d.Increase raw and fresh foods.
e.If infection is present and/or renal function is reduced, ensure protein intake is
monitored and the need for antibiotics is ruled out.

SLEEPAPNEA 
(Obstructive Sleep Apnea) 
(Central Sleep Apnea) 
I.Pre-Disposing Factors and Clinical Indicators: Snoring is not the same as sleep apnea,
snoring is simply a loud sound made during breathing while asleep, with no obstruction in
the airway. Obstructive sleep apnea is common and caused by a breathing obstruction which
stops air flow and causes oxygen deprivation due to complete blockage of the airways.
Central sleep apnea is less common and is a central nervous system disorder that occurs
when the brain signal telling the lungs to take in oxygen is delayed. In any case, thyroid
hypofunction must be ruled out as locus to the sleep apnea.
Central sleep apnea can be the result of any of the following:
a.Chronic respiratory disease.
b.Stroke.
c.Brain tumor.
d. Increased catecholamines.
e.Primary thyroid hypofunction.
f.Thyroid hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary hypofunction.
Obstructive sleep apnea can be the result of any of the following: 
a.Obesity.
b. Enlarged tonsils or adenoids.
c.Nasal blockage.
d.Throat muscles and/or tongue atonicity.
With both obstructive and central sleep apnea common serum changes include increased 
catecholamines, decreased thiamine, decreased magnesium, indications of thyroid 
hypofunction or hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary hypofunction, and increased 
interleukin 6. If the tonsils or adenoids are infected, swelling will generally be present and 
the WBC and differential will generally reflect infection. 
2.Dietary Suggestions:
a.Eliminate refined carbohydrates and mucous producing foods such as dairy
products ( except butter) and gluten containing grains.
b.Use on pure water for drinking and bathing (no well or city water).
c.If thyroid hypofunction or hypofunction secondary to the anterior pituitary
is present, reduce cabbage family food and millet, and support as indicated.
Continued On The Following Page: 
217

a.C.G.F. (ZI) - 3-4 tid.
b.Magnesium Glycerophosphate Complex (ZI) -At bedtime to bowel tolerance.
c.Immune Plus (ZI) -2 bid.
d.SunFlax Complex (ZI) -2  tid.
4. Other Considerations:
a.If thyroid hypofunction or hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary
hypofunction is present, support as indicated in the sections of this manual
covering those subjects. Primary thyroid hypofunction or hypofunction
secondary to anterior pituitary hypofunction are often nexus to sleep
apnea.
b.If the problem is obstructive and the sinus passages are closed, use Sign-U-
Spray (ZI) - 1 spray in each nostril tid. Also, always rule out bacterial,
fungal/yeast/mold, or viral infection in the sinus area.
c.If the tonsils or adenoids are very enlarged surgery may be needed.

Topically on wounds: (diabetic ulcers, insect bites, etc.)

Cover with a non-stick, non-absorbent bandage and tape to the skin and leave on overnight. 
Remove the bandage the following morning. 
Follow this procedure until the wound is healed. *Photograph area prior to the first application, as 
well as each time it is repeated to record progress.
S.O.S. - 3 capsules daily until the wound is completely healed. 
With redness in the wound area : Immune Plus - 3 capsules tid. A.H.F. - 3 capsules tid.
Until the wound is completely healed.

breaking apart into their component ions, and thereafter release their respective ions only at 
specific membranes within the cell. Again, the literature now supports hi s various theories on

A.H.F. (Anti -Histamine Formula): Clinical Guide for Holistic Healthcare Practitioners  
 
Product Profile  
A.H.F. (Anti -Histamine Formula)  delivers comprehensive histamine regulation through a 
unique multi -faceted approach combining 600 mg of quercetin, 288 mg of mixed 
ascorbates, 150 mg of citrus bioflavonoids, and a proprietary blend featuring alcohol -
soluble porcine liver extract (histori cally known as Anabolin), plus synergistic botanicals 
including mangosteen, elderberry, Nigella sativa, and Reishi mushroom.  
Clinical Applications:  
• Allergic conditions and seasonal sensitivities  
• Histamine intolerance and DAO deficiency  
• Upper respiratory co ngestion and symptoms  
• Excessive mucus production  
• Hepatic detoxification support  
• Inflammatory conditions with histamine involvement  
• Digestive symptoms related to histamine  
 
Zorex International Quality Advantage  
Manufacturing Excellence  
• Historical Anabolin Extract : Authentic alcohol -soluble porcine liver extract based 
on Dr. Henry Harrower's original formulation  
• Therapeutic Quercetin Dose : 600 mg per serving aligns with clinically effective 
research doses  
• Cross -Species Compatibility : Porcine -to-human molecul ar similarity for 
enhanced therapeutic benefit  
• Synergistic Botanicals : Carefully selected complementary herbs for 
comprehensive histamine support  
• Third -Party Verification : Independent testing ensures potency and purity 
consistency

Clinical Applications &  Protocols  
Primary Indications  
Allergic Conditions  The combination of quercetin, vitamin C, and supportive botanicals 
creates a comprehensive approach to allergic symptom management. Research 
demonstrates quercetin's effectiveness in mast cell stabilizatio n, reduced histamine 
production, and decreased inflammatory cytokine release, while vitamin C accelerates 
histamine degradation through enhanced diamine oxidase activity.  
Histamine Intolerance  The porcine liver extract provides natural diamine oxidase (DAO ) 
enzyme support, crucial for individuals with histamine intolerance or DAO deficiency. This 
addresses the root cause of histamine accumulation rather than simply blocking 
histamine receptors.  
Upper Respiratory Support  Multi -mechanism approach addresses re spiratory 
symptoms through quercetin's anti -inflammatory effects on bronchial epithelial cells, 
vitamin C's immune support, and elderberry's immunomodulatory properties for 
comprehensive upper respiratory management.  
Hepatic Detoxification  Supports liver f unction through multiple pathways including 
enhanced phase I and phase II detoxification, quercetin's hepatoprotective effects, and 
porcine liver extract's support for overall hepatic metabolism.  
Dosing Protocols  
Standard Allergic Support : 3 capsules three times daily between meals Acute Allergic 
Episodes : 4 capsules three times daily for 3 -5 days, then reduce to maintenance 
Histamine Intolerance : 3 capsules three times daily with consistent timing for optimal 
DAO support Seasonal Preventi on: Begin 2 -3 weeks before expected allergen exposure 
at 2 capsules twice daily Maintenance Support : 2 capsules twice daily for ongoing 
histamine regulation  
Timing Considerations:  
• Take between meals for optimal absorption of quercetin and liver extract  
• Mai ntain consistent daily schedule for histamine intolerance management  
• Consider taking with small amount of fat for enhanced quercetin bioavailability  
• Monitor individual response and adjust timing if gastrointestinal sensitivity occurs  
Combination Strategies

With Immune Plus : Enhances immune system support for comprehensive allergy 
management With 8X Pancreatin : Addresses excessive mucus production through 
complementary mechanisms With GB Complete : Supports comprehensive hepatic 
detoxification and liver funct ion With Homeopathic Allergy Formula : Provides synergistic 
symptom relief through different therapeutic approaches  
 
Patient Assessment Guidelines  
Ideal Candidates  
• Seasonal or environmental allergies  
• Food sensitivities and histamine intolerance  
• Chronic urt icaria or skin reactions  
• Upper respiratory congestion and symptoms  
• Digestive issues related to histamine  
• Individuals seeking natural antihistamine alternatives  
• Patients with liver detoxification needs  
Clinical Markers  
Allergic Presentations:  
• Sneezing, runn y nose, watery eyes  
• Skin reactions, hives, or itching  
• Respiratory congestion or wheezing  
• Digestive symptoms after eating  
• Headaches related to histamine exposure  
Histamine Intolerance Indicators:  
• Symptoms worsen with high -histamine foods  
• Alcohol intolerance  
• Medication sensitivity  
• Digestive upset with fermented foods

• Chronic fatigue or brain fog  
Laboratory Considerations  
• Elevated total IgE or specific allergen panels  
• Low diamine oxidase (DAO) levels  
• Elevated histamine levels (serum or urine)  
• Food sensitivity panels showing multiple reactions  
• Liver function markers indicating detoxification stress  
 
Expected Clinical Outcomes  
Timeline Expectations  
Hours to Days : Initial reduction in acute allergic symptoms Weeks 1 -2: Improved tolerance 
to histamine triggers and reduced reactivity Weeks 3 -4: Enhanced upper respiratory 
function and reduced congestion Weeks 4 -8: Stabilized histamine metabolism and 
improved overall tolerance Long -term : Sustained allergy management and im proved 
quality of life  
Patient Monitoring  
• Symptom Severity : Track reduction in allergic reactions and histamine symptoms  
• Trigger Tolerance : Assess improved tolerance to known allergens or histamine 
foods  
• Respiratory Function : Monitor breathing ease and red uced congestion  
• Digestive Comfort : Evaluate improvement in food -related symptoms  
• Overall Well -being : Track energy levels and general health improvements  
 
Clinical Pearls & Practitioner Tips  
Optimizing Therapeutic Response  
Consistent Timing : Maintain regul ar dosing schedule for stable histamine control Diet 
Coordination : Educate patients about histamine -rich foods during initial treatment 
Gradual Introduction : Start with lower doses for sensitive individuals Seasonal Timing : 
Begin treatment before peak alle rgen seasons for prevention

Troubleshooting Common Issues  
Initial Detox Reactions : May occur due to liver support; reduce dose temporarily 
Gastrointestinal Sensitivity : Take with small amount of food if needed Slow Response : 
Consider underlying gut health or additional allergen exposure Plateau Effect : Evaluate 
for additional histamine triggers or combination needs  
Patient Education Points  
• Natural antihistamines work differently than pharmaceutical blockers  
• Consistency is cr ucial for building histamine tolerance  
• Dietary modifications enhance supplement effectiveness  
• Individual response varies; patience during initial weeks is important  
 
Safety Considerations for Practice  
Contraindications  
• Known allergies to porcine products  
• Severe liver disease or acute hepatitis  
• Pregnancy and lactation (insufficient safety data)  
• Active bleeding disorders (quercetin may have mild anticoagulant effects)  
Monitoring Recommendations  
• Initial Phase : Weekly assessments for first month, especially fo r histamine 
intolerance  
• Maintenance : Monthly evaluations for symptom improvement and tolerance  
• Long -term : Quarterly reviews for continued appropriateness and dose 
optimization  
Drug Interactions  
Exercise caution with:  
• Anticoagulant medications (monitor INR if on warfarin)  
• Immunosuppressive drugs (may enhance immune function)  
• Liver -metabolized medications (may affect hepatic enzyme activity)

Mechanisms of Action  
Histamine Regulation  
Multiple complementary pathways address histamine metabolism: quercetin inhibits 
histamine release from mast cells and reduces histidine decarboxylase activity, vitamin C 
accelerates histamine degradation through enhanced DAO activity, and porcine liver 
extract provides natural DAO enzyme support.  
Anti -Inflammatory Activity  
Quercetin and botanicals modulate inflammatory processes through NF -κB inhibition, 
reduced pro -inflammatory cytokine production, and membrane stabilization effects that 
reduce cellular reactivity to allergens.  
Hepatic Support  
Porcine liver extract enhances p hase I and phase II detoxification pathways, while 
quercetin provides hepatoprotective effects through antioxidant action and glutathione 
system enhancement.  
Immune Modulation  
Botanical components including elderberry, Reishi, and Nigella sativa provide 
immunomodulatory effects that help regulate excessive immune responses while 
maintaining appropriate immune function.

• Proprietary Botanical Blend: Porcine liver extract, mangosteen, elderberry, Nigella 
sativa, Reishi  
• Supporting ingredients: Ammonium chloride, ani se, fennel, caraway  
Storage Requirements:

• Store in cool, dry place away from direct sunlight  
• Protect from heat and moisture  
• Keep in original container with tight seal  
• Do not refrigerate  
Shelf Life:  3 years from manufacture date when stored properly  
 
Clini cal Research Foundation  
Key Supporting Studies  
• Quercetin at 600mg daily showed significant reduction in allergic rhinitis 
symptoms comparable to conventional antihistamines  
• Vitamin C supplementation demonstrated natural antihistamine effects through 
accelerated histamine degradation  
• Porcine liver components contain natural DAO enzyme, crucial for histamine 
metabolism  
• Botanical ingredients show documented anti -inflammatory and 
immunomodulatory properties

A.H.F. incorporates the origi nal Anabolin formulation developed by Dr. Henry Harrower, 
representing decades of clinical observation and refinement in natural histamine 
management approaches.

Estrogen Cream: Clinical Guide for Holistic Healthcare Practitioners  
Product Profile  
Bio-Identical/Natural USP Micronized Estrogen Cream  delivers superior hormonal support 
through natural estriol (E -3) at 750 mcg per pump (18 mg per ounce) in a nourishing base of 
purified water, aloe vera gel, herbal extracts, and natural oils. This topical formulation provides 
bio-identical estriol, the w eakest yet most abundant of the three primary estrogens, through 
enhanced micronized delivery for both systemic and local therapeutic effects.  
Clinical Applications:  
• Menopausal symptom management and vasomotor symptoms  
• Vaginal atrophy and urogenital health  restoration  
• Immune modulation and autoimmune condition support  
• Bone health preservation and fracture prevention  
• Cardiovascular protection and endothelial function  
• Multiple sclerosis and inflammatory disorder management  
• Recurrent urinary tract infection pr evention  
Zorex International Quality Advantage

reduction to 10 micrometers or less

levels

inflammatory benefits
