• Targeted Delivery : Allows for both systemic e ffects and localized tissue benefits  
Clinical Applications & Protocols  
Primary Indications

Menopausal Symptom Management  Estriol demonstrates unique receptor binding 
characteristics with transient nuclear receptor binding and preferential membrane receptor  
activity. Research shows 85% of women experience substantial improvement in hot flash 
frequency and severity after 12 weeks of treatment, with additional benefits for sleep quality 
and mood stabilization.  
Vaginal and Urogenital Health  Topical estriol effe ctively reverses vaginal atrophy in 90 -95% of 
postmenopausal women, improving epithelial thickness, vascularization, and vaginal pH. Clinical 
studies demonstrate 65 -75% reduction in recurrent urinary tract infections through improved 
urogenital tissue inte grity and normalized vaginal flora.  
Immune Modulation and Autoimmune Support  Estriol's unique immunomodulatory effects 
include favorable cytokine profile shifts, reducing pro -inflammatory while enhancing anti -
inflammatory cytokines. Research demonstrates 8 0% reduction in gadolinium -enhancing MRI 
lesions in multiple sclerosis patients and significant reductions in disease activity markers for 
rheumatoid arthritis.  
Bone Health and Cardiovascular Protection  Transdermal estriol therapy preserves bone mineral 
density with 1.8% higher lumbar spine density after 12 months while reducing bone resorption 
markers. Cardiovascular benefits include improved lipid profiles, enhanced endothelial function, 
and reduced inflammatory markers with minimal thrombotic risk.  
Dosin g Protocols  
Menopausal Symptoms : ½ to 1 pump once daily to thin -skinned areas (chest, abdomen, inner 
arms) Vaginal Health : ½ pump applied directly to vaginal tissues daily Immune Modulation : 1 
pump twice daily for systemic immunomodulatory effects Bone Pro tection : 1 pump daily with 
rotation of application sites Combination Therapy : Use with natural progesterone for 
comprehensive hormonal balance  
Timing Considerations:  
• Apply to clean, dry skin on thin -skinned areas for optimal absorption  
• Rotate application sites to prevent skin saturation and maintain hormone levels  
• Direct vaginal application provides targeted local effects within 1 -2 weeks  
• Systemic effects typically observed after 2 -4 weeks of consistent use  
• Consider circadian hormone patterns for optimal ti ming

Unique Receptor Dynamics

Estriol binds to estrogen receptors with lower affinity than estradiol but demonstrates

Preferential effects on vaginal, cervical, and vulvar tissues compared to endometrial tissue

inflammatory marker expression while demonstrating minimal impact on clotting factors.

Dosing : Superior absorption efficiency compared to single large doses Acute Protocols : Hourly 
dosing during fever provides rapid therapeutic effects  
Troubleshooting Common Issues  
Absorption Optimization : Ensure proper timing away from food and interfering substances 
Individual Variation : Adjust dosing based on clinical response and calcium status Medication 
Interactions : Separate from antibiotics, thyro id medications, and iron supplements Tolerance 
Assessment : Monitor for hypercalcemia symptoms with intensive dosing  
Patient Education Points  
• Take consistently on empty stomach for optimal absorption  
• Superior bioavailability allows for lower elemental calcium doses  
• Rapid fever reduction effects typically seen within hours  
• Long -term bone health benefits require consistent daily use  
Safety Considerations for Practice  
Contraindications  
• Hypercalcemia or history of calcium kidney stones  
• Severe renal dysfuncti on or hyperparathyroidism  
• Digitalis therapy (monitor for enhanced drug effects)  
• Sarcoidosis or other granulomatous diseases  
Monitoring Recommendations  
• Initial Phase : Serum calcium monitoring within first month  
• Maintenance : Quarterly assessments for ongoin g optimization  
• Intensive Protocols : Enhanced monitoring during acute fever management  
Drug Interactions  
Exercise caution with:  
• Digitalis medications (enhanced cardiac effects)

• Thiazide diuretics (reduced calcium excretion)  
• Tetracycline antibiotics (reduced  antibiotic absorption)  
• Thyroid medications (reduced hormone absorption)  
• Iron supplements (mutual absorption interference)  
Mechanisms of Action  
Enhanced Cellular Penetration  
The orotate carrier system utilizes specific membrane transport mechanisms to deli ver calcium 
directly to intracellular targets, bypassing limitations of conventional ionic calcium forms.  
Superior Bioavailability  
Calcium orotate maintains structural integrity through digestive processes, achieving 
approximately 90% absorption compared to 30 -70% for conventional forms.  
Intracellular Calcium Delivery  
The Nieper transport system delivers calcium to specific cellular compartments where it's 
needed for physiological functions, enhancing therapeutic effectiveness.  
pH-Independent Absorption  
Unlike conventional calcium forms requiring specific acidic environments, calcium orotate 
absorbs consistently across varying gastrointestinal pH conditions.

Capsules or Tablets. Both KI Plus Capsules and Tablets contain 200 mcg of selenium per 
capsule or tablet. Selenium is important as it is the heart of 5’ deiodinase (combination of 2 
and 3 deiodinase). 5’ deiodinase is the enzyme that is responsible for removing one 
molecule of iodine from T-4 and adding it to T-3, thus making T-3 the active molecule.

Zinc Orotate – Each capsule contains 94 mg of fully reacted U.S. manuf actured zinc orotate 
providing 15 mg of elemental zinc. Why orotate as the mineral salt for zinc? Nieper’s orotates 
are the minerals salts of orotic acid, a natural substance found in the human body as well as 
various foods. Based on Nieper’s observations of cells in culture, he concluded, what the 
scientific information supports that orotates can pass through cell membranes intact without 
breaking apart into their component ions, and thereafter release their respective ions only at 
specific membranes within the cell. Again, the literature now supports hi s various theories on 
orotates. Zinc is required for support of immune function, especially with bacterial and viral 
infections. It is  also required for production of human growth hormone (HgH) and in the

Skin Sensitivity : Increase dilution ratio or reduce application frequency if irritation occurs Slow 
Fungal Response : Extend treatment duration as nail infections require  3-6 months for complete

resolution Incomplete Penetration : Ensure affected area is clean and dry before application for 
optimal absorption Treatment Compliance : Educate patients about expected timelines and 
importance of consistent use  
Patient Education P oints  
• Emulsified formula provides superior absorption compared to standard oregano oil 
preparations  
• Dilution is essential for safety and efficacy - never apply undiluted  
• Fungal infections require extended treatment periods for complete clearance  
• Continue treatment for 2 weeks beyond visible resolution to prevent recurrence  
Safety Considerations for Practice  
Contraindications  
• Known allergy to Lamiaceae family plants (mint, basil, sage)  
• Pregnancy and lactation (insufficient safety data)  
• Open wounds or severe ly compromised skin barrier  
• Concurrent use of photosensitizing medications  
Monitoring Recommendations  
• Initial Phase : Weekly assessment for first month to monitor tolerance and response  
• Active Treatment : Bi-weekly evaluations for infection resolution and sk in response  
• Long -term : Monthly follow -up for extended fungal treatment protocols  
Drug Interactions  
Exercise caution with:  
• Topical antibiotics (potential additive effects)  
• Photosensitizing medications (oregano oil may increase sensitivity)  
• Blood thinners (t heoretical interaction with high -dose internal use)  
• Immunosuppressive drugs (may affect treatment response)  
Mechanisms of Action  
Enhanced Bioavailability

Emulsification technology reduces particle size and creates stable suspension, significantly 
improving  absorption compared to non -emulsified preparations. The process allows for more 
effective delivery of therapeutic compounds to target tissues while reducing the concentration 
needed for efficacy.  
Antimicrobial Activity  
Primary active compounds carvacrol a nd thymol disrupt bacterial cell membranes, increasing 
permeability and causing cell death. These compounds demonstrate effectiveness against 
multidrug -resistant pathogens and show synergistic effects with conventional antimicrobial 
agents.  
Antifungal Effects  
Thymol inhibits fungal growth by interfering with cell wall synthesis and disrupting membrane 
integrity. This mechanism provides broad -spectrum antifungal activity against various Candida 
species and dermatophytes commonly associated with skin and nail infections.  
Anti -inflammatory Action  
Oregano oil components modulate inflammatory pathways through pro -inflammatory cytokine 
inhibition. The phenolic compounds serve as powerful antioxidants, neutralizing free radicals 
and reducing oxidative stress in  affected tissues.

Clinical Applications & Protocols  
Primary Indications  
Acute Immune Support  Immun e Plus provides rapid immune system activation through 
multiple pathways. Vitamin D supplementation can reduce respiratory infection risk by up to 
12% overall, with greater benefits in those with deficiency. The therapeutic doses of vitamin C, 
zinc, and vi tamin D work synergistically to enhance immune cell function during active 
challenges. Vitamin C accumulates in phagocytic cells and enhances chemotaxis, phagocytosis, 
and microbial killing.  
Seasonal Immune Protection  The formulation supports year -round im mune readiness through 
comprehensive nutritional support. Vitamin D supplementation with daily doses of 400 -1000 IU 
for up to 12 months shows protective effects against acute respiratory infections. Zinc deficiency 
affects both innate and adaptive immunity  by preventing T lymphocyte activation and B 
lymphocyte development.  
Respiratory Tract Support  Multiple nutrients in Immune Plus specifically support respiratory 
health and mucosal immunity. Vitamin C may reduce the duration of respiratory infection 
sympto ms including fever, chest pain, and chills. Zinc supplementation significantly reduces 
respiratory morbidity in children, with studies showing 20.8% vs 45.8% infection rates in 
supplemented vs placebo groups.  
Recovery and Convalescence  The comprehensive nu trient profile supports immune system 
restoration following illness or stress. Zinc is critical for T -cell development and helps the thymus 
regenerate after immune damage. The glandular extracts provide organ -specific support for 
immune tissue recovery.  
Dosing Protocols  
Maintenance Support : 1-2 capsules daily with food Acute Immune Challenge : 4-8 capsules 
daily divided into 2 -3 doses for 5 -7 days Seasonal Protection : 2 capsules daily during high -risk 
periods Recovery Support : 2-4 capsules daily for 2 -4 week s following illness 
Elderly/Immunocompromised : 2-3 capsules daily as ongoing support  
Timing Considerations:

• Divide larger doses throughout the day for optimal utilization

• Morning doses support daytime immune surveillance  
• Evening doses may enhance immune system recovery during sleep  
• Consistent daily use provides superior results compared to intermittent dosing

Orotate : Extra zinc support for individuals with documented deficiency With D3 -5000 : Higher

Patient Assessment Guidelines  
Ideal Candidates  
• Frequent respiratory infections or prolonged reco very times  
• Seasonal allergies or recurrent upper respiratory symptoms  
• High stress levels or chronic fatigue  
• Elderly patients with declining immune function  
• Post -surgical patients requiring immune support  
• Healthcare workers or those with high pathogen expos ure 
• Individuals with autoimmune conditions requiring immune modulation  
Clinical Markers  
Immune System Indicators:  
• Frequent infections (>4 respiratory infections annually)  
• Prolonged illness duration (>10 days for common cold)  
• Slow wound healing or poor tiss ue repair  
• Chronic fatigue or low energy levels  
• Recurrent oral infections or poor dental health  
Nutritional Deficiency Signs:

• Poor night vision or dry eyes (vitamin A deficiency)  
• Easy bruising or slow healing (vitamin C deficiency)  
• Muscle weakness or bone pain (vitamin D deficiency)  
• Hair loss or skin changes (zinc deficiency)  
• Compromised taste or smell (zinc deficiency)  
Laboratory Considerations  
• Serum 25(OH)D levels <30 ng/mL (vitamin D deficiency)  
• Plasma zinc levels <70 mcg/dL (zinc deficiency)  
• Low lymphoc yte count or altered T -cell subsets  
• Elevated inflammatory markers (CRP , ESR)  
• Reduced immunoglobulin levels (IgA, IgG, IgM)

Exercise caution with:

Mechanisms of Action  
Innate Immune Support  
Vitamin C enhances neutrophil ch emotaxis, phagocytosis, and microbial killing while supporting 
apoptosis and clearance of spent neutrophils. Zinc affects macrophage function, intracellular 
killing, cytokine production, and phagocytosis. Vitamin D modulates innate immune responses 
and cyt okine production.  
Adaptive Immune Enhancement  
Zinc supports T lymphocyte activation, Th1 cytokine production, and B lymphocyte 
development and antibody production. Vitamin C enhances B - and T -cell differentiation and 
proliferation through gene regulating e ffects. Thymus glandular extracts provide peptides that 
support T -cell development.  
Mucosal Barrier Function  
Vitamin A maintains epithelial integrity and supports secretory IgA production. Vitamin C 
contributes to maintaining cellular redox integrity and protects against reactive oxygen species. 
Zinc supports mucosal barrier integrity and immune surveillance.  
Anti -inflammatory Modulation  
Quercetin, Boswellia, and NAC help modulate inflammatory responses through various 
mechanisms including NF -κB inhibition  and antioxidant activity. Vitamin C protects immune cells 
from oxidative damage during respiratory burst activity and inflammatory responses.

SIGNIFICANCE  OF CHANGES  IN THE  CONCENTRATION  
OF BIOLOGICAL MARKERS  
Blood  Chemistry  
There currently is a great deal of resistance to optimum or metabolic ranges on blood chemistry and  
to conclusions developed by means of  patterning these values. We  agree with the criticism if the 
person(s) transmitting the information have related the values or patterns as absolute. No diagnostic 
procedure is absolute,  and we feel none should be used  as the sole means  of making a diagnosis. 
Blood  chemistry, irrespective of  the range used (optima! or reference), is simply a too! to be used 
with other diagnostic criteria available to the doctor.  
The guidelines or  patterns  described in this  manual are  the result of  information gathered between 
1980 and the present on over 10,000 people using what was known as the Biochemical Biopsy, a 
blood  test that used  electrophoretic  methods, colorimetric studies, atomic absorption spectroscopy, 
hormonal  studies and standard hematological  studies. This information was integrated into 
information developed from physical examination symptom histories, urinalysis hair mineral 
analysis, comprehensive stool and digestive analysis and other diagnostic criteria available to the 
doctors who partic ipated in the gathering of information.  
Many of the conclusions developed from this project are listed in this manual. As previously stated, 
although they cannot be  considered absolute and  are often empirical, we feel that when the 
guidelines  or patterns described  are present,  further investigation is warranted.
