SERUM  GLUCOSE  
Blood  Sugar,  Fasting  Blood  Sugar  (FBS),  Sugar  (Fasting)  
 
Discussion:  Glucose levels are influenced by carbohydrate intake, stress, glandular and liver 
function.  It is generally true that insulin lowers glucose levels by increasing tissue demand,  while 
hormones produced by the adrenal cortex, thyroid, pancreas, and anterior pituitary tend to increase 
blood sugar levels through their effect on the liver.  All of the  following information is predicated 
on a 12 -hour fasting sample.  
 
Related Tests:  Urinary glucose, triglycerides, cholesterol, glycated hemoglobin (Ale), blood 
insulin, glucose tolerance test (GTT), HDL, LDL and VLDL  cholesterol, fructosamine (glycated 
albumin) Co2,  anion gap, plasma glucagon, 2 -hour postprandial glucose and blood pressure.  
 
Reference Range:  Reference ranges vary from different labs however most laboratories indicate 
their reference range between 70 and 100 mg/dL.  
 
Optimum Range:  80 to 95 mg/dL.  Note:  Patients with small or deep veins, a fear of phlebotomy 
or patients having their blood drawn by an inexperienced phlebotomist may experience a slight 
increase in their fasting blood glucose.  This is based on the stress of the blood draw causing an 
increase in adrenalin production with a subsequent increase in blood glucose.  The increase should 
be confirmed or ruled out with serial checks using a glucometer.  
 
Possible  Alarm  Range:  Below  50 mg/dL  or above  300 mg/dL.  
 
Common  Causes  For Increased  Fasting  Glucose:  
 
Diabetes:  Triglycerides  increased  and often  increased  above  the cholesterol level  when  a 
Type IV Hyperlipoproteinemia is present (Metabolic Syndrome), HDL cholesterol generally 
decreased, hemoglobin Ale increased and/or fructosamine increased, urinary glucose increased, 
CO2 will be decreased with systemic acidity (common with diabetes), plas ma glucagon  increased 
(especially with non -insulin dependent  diabetes), urinary pH decreased and if renal damage is 
present the BUN, urinary micro -albumin will frequently be increased and the urinary creatinine 
clearance decreased.  Supplemental Support:  C.G.F. (ZI) - 3 tid, SunFlax Complex  (ZI) - 2 
tid, AD Hyper (ZI)  - 3 bid midday  and in the evening, S.O.S. (ZI) – 2-3 tid,  S y m p a t h e t i c  
B a l a n c e  ( Z I ) -2  t i d ,  L.P.A.  Plus (ZI) - 2 tid, Berberine HCI  (ZI) - 1 tid and  8X 
Pancreatin (ZI) - 1 tid with meals.  Also,  in many cases increasing the tissue demand for glucose 
is helpful (increased tissue demand results in lower circulating glucose levels).  This can often be 
accomplished with Heart Tissue  and Inosito l. Diet:  Use the Roadmap  To Health diet and 
ensure the patient drinks at least 8 -10 full glasses of pure water each day.

2 
 Common  Causes  For Increased  Fasting  Glucose  Continued:  
 
Thiamine Insufficiency:  Co2 decreased with  the anion gap increased and red blood cell 
thiamine decreased.  Thiamine is  one of the major nutrients required to transp01i glucose across 
the blood -brain barrier, hence when  thiamine insufficiency is  present serum glucose may be  high 
because of an inability to transport glucose to the brain.  Supplemental support and dietary 
requirements for thiamine insufficiency are listed in the section of this manual covering carbon 
dioxide. Benfotiamine (fat soluble thiamine) will cros s the blood -brain barrier more efficiently 
than other  forms.  It is available  in Zorex  International  B6/Bl,  C.G.F.,  CircuPlus  and other 
Zorex International  products.  
Dysinsulinism  (Syndrome -X/Metabolic  Syndrome ): Common chemistry changes, 
supplemental support and diet requirements for dysinsulinism are listed in the section of this 
manual covering serum triglycerides.  
 
Less  Common  Causes For Increased  Fasting Glucose:  Myocardial  infarct, brain damage, severe 
trauma, convulsions, Cushing's disease, acromegaly, severe liver disease, pancreatitis, acute phase 
reactions, adrenal cortical hyperfunction,  both hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism and  renal  
disease.  In every  case of increased  glucose,  inflammation and  mitochondrial  dysfunction  will 
be present  and is generally  nexus  to the increase.  
 
Common  Causes  For Decreased  Fasting  Glucose:  
 
Fasting Hypoglycemia:  Irrespective of  the laboratory range, anytime the  fasting glucose 
is decreased below  80 mg/dL hypoglycemia should be  suspected. However, if  the fasting glucose 
is decreased below 70  mg/dL, hypoglycemia is  almost certain.  In addition to  a decreased fasting 
glucose, LDH will frequently be decreased with fasting hypoglycemia and almost always 
decreased  with reactive hypoglycemia  (< 150). LDH activity  reflects  active exchange  of chloride  
with  glucose  and glucose  with  zinc and sodium  (glycolysis);  therefore,  LDH activity  is 
associated  with  pancreatic  function  and glucose  metabolism.  Supplemental Support : C.G.F.  
(ZI) - 2-3 qid between  meals (10:00 a.m., 3:00 p.m., two hours after supper and at bedtime ). If 
the patient is unable to tolerate these supplements on an empty stomach (between  meals)  dose with  
meals and  add one capsule  of HCL Complete  (ZI) - in the  middle of the  meal; Amino  Acid s as 
needed  to maintain normal blood sugar levels. Note:  Low blood pressure (adrenal cortical 
hypofunction  and thiamine need) is  a common finding with both fasting and reactive 
hypoglycemia. If  present, add AD Complex (ZI)  - 2 in the a.m. and 2 at noon , S.O.S. (ZI) – 2-3 
tid, and Celtic sea salt to the patient's supplemental  schedule.  Diet:  Use the Roadmap  To Health  
diet and ensure the patient  eats three meals per day, does not snack between meals and drinks at 
least 8 -10 full glasses of pure water  each day.  
Less Common Causes For Decreased Fasting Glucose:  Pancreatic tumors, extra -pancreatic 
tumors, adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease), starvation, hypofunction of the anterior 
pituitary, severe liver disease, polycystic ovary disease (PCOD), hypothyroidism, improper 
regulation of insulin with insulin dependent  diabetes, alcoholism and anorexia/bulimia .

3 
 Important  Considerations  With Abnormal  Fasting Glucose:  
 
Craving for sweets  is a common finding with both hypoglycemia and dysinsulinism 
(Metabolic Syndrome).  The craving for sweets can often be ameliorated with GB Complete  (ZI) 
- 2 tid with meals and  C.G.F. (ZI) 2 tid with meals.  
Carbohydrate sensitivity is a common finding with both decreased and increased fasting 
glucose and is  one of the most important problems that must be addressed with PMS.  
 
Food allergy testing should be initiated on any patient with increased or decreased blood 
glucose levels.  Food allergy is a common finding with both increased and decreased blood glucose 
levels.  
Quercetin bioflavonoids  (Quercetin  - ZI)  are often effective in ameliorating the ocular, 
nerve, and renal degeneration common with long -term increased blood glucose (quercetin will help 
to block glucose infiltration through the sorbitol pathway).  Quercetin is a major sparing nutrient 
for zinc.  
 
A five to six -hour glucose tolerance test (GTT) may be required to determine if the  patient 
has reactive hypoglycemia.  If required, make certain your patient has something to  record their 
subjective feelings each time blood is drawn.  Often their observations will be as important as  or, 
more  important than  the laboratory value.  For example, the  hourly value may be within the 
laboratory range, but the patient advises they were faint, nauseous, etc.  Any of these findings are  
strong indications that irrespective of  the laboratory value, the  value was  too low for the patient.  
 
A "flat curve" on a GTT is sometimes seen with hypoglycemia.  The "flat curve" is 
associated with personality disorder, hyperactivity and learning disability and may be due to a 
metal body burden.  A hair, urine or red blood cell mineral analysis should be  completed to rule 
out toxic element exposure.  
 
In general, AD Hyper (ZI) and Sympathetic Balance (ZI)  should be considered with 
increased glucose or triglycerides (adrenal cortical hyperfunction) and AD Complex (ZI) and 
S.O.S. (ZI)  should be considered with decreased glucose (adrenal cortical hypofunction).  
It is now well known that free -radical diseases (especially cancer) can proliferate more 
rapidly in  patients with increased blood sugar (systemic acidosis). Therefore, every effort should 
be made to normalize blood sugar levels in patients with cancer and other free radical diseases.  
 
Because stress (psychological and physical), carbohydrate intake and various other  factors 
will influence fasting glucose levels,  do not assume hyperglycemia or  diabetes based on  a sole  
fasting glucose  test. Conduct serial tests to confirm the  increased blood glucose and if  serial tests 
are also increased conduct a hemoglobin Ale  or fructosamine to determine long -term glucose 
control.  If the  fasting  glucose  is greater  than l 08 and  the 2-hour post-prandial  finding  is greater 
than 199, isolated challenge diabetes is probable.  Confirm with decreased DHEAs.

4 
 Important  Considerations  With  Abnormal  Fasting  Glucose  Continued:  
 
Glucose is an acute phase reactant. Therefore , poor phlebotomy will always result in 
a fasting glucose that increased above normal fasting levels.  
 
MICROALBUMIN  
Micro -albuminuria  as measured with a 24 -hour urine, 10 -hour overnight urine or spot a.m. urine 
(after initial voiding) is an excellent test to monitor diabetic renal disease including glomerular 
disease.  With this  test small losses  of protein are  detectable as  micro -albuminuria developing 10 
to 15 years after the hyperglycemia (or sooner).  With diabetes, micro -albuminuria is generally 
seen before proteinuria  becomes evident  by conventional  urinalysis.  Micro -albuminuria is one of 
the best available tests for renal disease and should be routinely accomplished along with urinary 
creatinine clearance on all diabetic patients. As indicated previously, quercetin bioflavonoids 
(AHF - ZI) and general renal support are often effective in ameliorating renal damage seen with 
increased blood glucose levels.  
 
C PEPTIDE  
 
C peptide is a peptide which is made when proinsulin is split into insulin and C peptide.  They split 
when proinsulin  is released  from the pancreas  in response to a rise in serum glucose with one C 
peptide molecule for each insulin molecule.  Test is used to determine if the diabetic patient is a 
type 1 or type 2 diabetic.  The pancreas of a type 1 diabetic is usually unable to produce insulin and 
they will have  a reduced or  non-existent  level of  C peptide.  The pancreas  of a type 2 diabetic will 
generally have  normal or increased levels of C peptide.  The reason that C peptide levels are 
measured in lieu of insulin is because insulin concentration in the portal vein ranges from two to 
ten times higher than the peripheral circulation where the blood is drawn. Fasting or reactive 
hypoglycemia with a decreased C peptide level is evidence of i nsulin abuse (dietary abuse). See 
Alc for further information on diagnostic uses of C Peptide.  
 
FRUCTOSAMINE  
Glycated  Albumin,  Glycated  Proteins  
 
Reference  Range:  0-285 umol/L  - Optimum  Range:  25-250 umol/L  
 
Fructosamine  is used to monitor glucose control over a  shorter period (14 days) versus 120 day 
(erythrocyte average) for Ale  measured at 90 days.  Normal ranges for  fructosamine vary 
considerably, however the  normal range  for children is  slightly lower  than for adults.  Because of 
the short half -life fructosamine is  useful in screening geriatrics, gestational diabetes, juvenile 
diabetes and patients with abnormal HgB levels and normal fasting glucose levels. This  test 
should not be completed on patients with decreased serum albumin levels.

5 
 GLYCATED  HEMOGLOBIN  
Fast Hemoglobins, GHB, HBal, Hemoglobin Ala, Alb, Ale,  
Glycosylated Hemoglobin  
 
Discussion:  Glycated hemoglobi n is a irreversible glucose -protein bond which extends through the 
life of the red blood cell (ten weeks or more).  Glycated  hemoglobin  values are used to assess long -
term glucose control in diabetics, especially patients with insulin dependent  diabetes who's urinary 
and fasting blood glucose levels vary significantly  from day to day.  
Related  Tests:  Serum  and urinary  glucose.  
 
Reference  Range:  The laboratory  range  is dependent  upon  methodology;  however,  most 
laboratories report the normal range at less than 5. 6 percent of the total hemoglobin.  
 
Optimum  Range:  5.0-5.6 percent  of the total hemoglobin.  
 
Possible Alarm Range:  The risk of microalbuminuria  with insulin dependent  diabetes increases 
dramatically when the hemoglobin Ale  value is  increased above 8.1 percent of  the hemoglobin.  
 
Common  Cause  For Increased  Glycated  Hemoglobin:  
 
Diabetes:  See serum  glucose.  
 
Common  Cause  for Decreased Glycated  Hemoglobin:  
 
Folate  Deficiency:  folate deficiency is common when A1x < 5.0. Consider C.G.F. (ZI).  
 
Important  Considerations  with  Increased  Glycated  Hemoglobin:  
 
Glycated hemoglobin is an excellent test for determining if the diabetic patient is using 
correct dietary controls.  Often the diabetic patient will eat correctly for a few days before they 
know blood is to be drawn so the doctor will not admonish them about their diet and resulting 
increased blood sugar level.  Irrespective of their short -term diet, the glycated hemoglobin will still 
reflect their long -term control.  
Glycated hemoglobin is useful in the evaluation of fetal risk in known diabetics who 
become pregnant.  
 
Glycated hemoglobin is a useful test for predicting the progression of retinopathy and renal 
destruction.  
 
An slightly increased Al c (5-7-5.9) found with a normal serum glucose on serial 
examinations may be due to an increase in MCV and/or MCH.

6 
  
If the Al c is increased with a normal fasting glucose, the increase may be due to an increase 
in the erythrocyte half -life. Alc is determined on glycation at 90 days however the normal  half-
life of the erythrocyte  (110-120 days)  may vary from day -to-day; therefore  if the patient's normal 
half-life is 110 days, the Al c will be lower and if the normal half -life is 130 days, the A1c  may be 
higher and in either case the fasting glucose may be normal. In these cases (normal fasting glucose 
with an abnormal Al c), fructosamine (glycated albumin) should be completed.  Glycated albumin 
(fructosamine) has a half -life of 14 days.  
 
Glycated hemoglobin (generally Ale) is an excellent test for determining long -term control 
in most diabetics; however, if the result of the Ale  test is not consistent with the clinical findings, 
a hemoglobin F test should be ordered in lieu of glycated albumin.  Measurement of glycated 
hemoglobin by affinity chromatography  (hemoglobin F)  permits better differentiation  of the degree 
of blood glucose control than hemoglobin Ale  or hemoglobin A measurements.  
If the C Peptide  is < 1.0 with the Al c <  5 . 7  T y p e  1  D i a b e t e s  i s  p r o b a b l e .  
T h e  u s e  o f  G a b a -5 0 0  ( Z I )  a n d  N i a c i n a m i d e  5 0 0  ( Z I )  w i l l  h e l p  
s t a b i l i z e  i n s u l i n  n e e d s .  
 
If the Al c is increased with normal serum glucose on serial tests, dehydration should be 
investigated (check serum and physical findings for dehydration  and check for an increased MCV ).

7 
 BLOOD  INSULIN  
Immunoreactive  Insulin  
 
Discussion:  The earliest molecule of insulin production is proinsulin which is the precursor of 
insulin.  Proinsulin as well as insulin is secreted by the pancreatic islet beta cells in response to 
glucose ingestion.  Fasting insulin levels and insulin levels drawn during a  glucose tolerance test 
(GTT) are used to determine hypoglycemia or islet cell tumor (insulinoma). Causes of fasting 
hypoglycemia can be due to islet cell tumor, drugs used for glycemic issues, alcohol use, endocrine 
hypofunction (especiall y adrenal, pituitary or thyroid), tumor(s) located in the biliary tree (outside 
the pancreas) and severe hepatic disease.  
Related  Tests:  Serum  glucose,  glycated  hemoglobin  (Ale), fructosamine  (glycated  albumin), 
glucose tolerance test (GTT) , plasma glucagon , and lipid panel.  
 
Reference  Range:  0-24.9 uIU/ml  
 
Optimum  Range:  3.0- 8.0. 
Possible  Alarm  Range:  Any level  20 percent  or more  above  the laboratory  range.  
 
Common Causes For Increased Fasting Insulin:  The most common cause of hyper­ insulinemia 
is obesity. Stimulation and inhibition tests may be required to define whether the increase is due 
to obesity or islet cell tumor. Blood insulin is also frequently increased with Cushing's syndrome, 
women on oral contraceptives, hyperthyroidism, patients on exogenous cortical steroids or  
levodopa, non -insulin dependent  diabetes, polycystic ovary disease (PCOD), essential 
hypertension, benign neoplasm of the pancreas (insulin increased/glucose decreased), Metabolic 
Syndrome/Syndrome -X and with pituitary hyperfunction  (acromegaly).  
 
Common Causes For Decreased Fasting Insulin:  Pituitary  hypofunction, anorexia nervosa, 
growth  hormone  deficiency, hypoglycemia and  with glucose tolerance  tests (GTT) when  reactive 
hypoglycemia is present.  Note:  Consideration should be given to ascertaining insulin levels 
each time blood is  drawn for  a GGT and anytime a fasting lipid panel is completed.  
 
Important  Considerations  With  Abnormal Insulin:  
 
The relationship  of fasting  glucose  to insulin  is critical  in the work -up of insulinoma.  
Criteria  for insulinoma  are a significantly  decreased  fasting glucose  with hyperinsulinism.  
 
It has been shown that pancreatic secretion of insulin is pulsatile, therefore,  to rule out 
insulinoma  it may  be necessary  to fast the patient for up to 72 hours and draw glucose and insulin 
every four hours during this period.  
 
Insulin potentiation therapy (IPT) is  currently being used by many alternative physicians 
as an effective treatment for cancer.  Further information on this  treatment can  be obtained from 
the American College for  the Advancement  in Medicine .

8 
 According to Dr. Paul Varnas and the published literature, in the first three hours after 
eating insulin is dominant and after three hours glucagon becomes dominant (glucagon helps to 
burn  the stored calories).  Therefore, if  the patient has  increased insulin and is  attempting to  lose 
weight by eating snacks between meals, they will stay insulin dominant and not lose  weight.  
Supplemental  Support  for Increased  Insulin:  C.G.F  (ZI) - 3 tid, AD Hyper (ZI)  - 2-3 bid midday,  
 and late afternoon , L.P.A. Plus (ZI) - 2 tid, 8X Pancreatin  (ZI) - 1 tid with meals., Berberine HCl  
(ZI) - 1 tid with meals,  CircuPlus  (ZI) - 3 bid and HCL  Complete  (ZI) - 1-2 in the middle of the 
meal.  If patient is sympathetic dominant add Sympathetic Balance  (ZI) – 2 tid.  
 
Supplemental  Support  for Decreased  Insulin:   8X Pancreatin  (ZI) - 1 tid with meals.  and 
C.G.F.  (ZI),  2-3 tid with meals.  
 
With  either  increased or  decreased insulin  the patient  must  eliminate all  refined  foods,  fruit juice, 
alcohol,  gluten,  casein,  and fried  foods  from their  diet. Supplementation  without dietary changes 
is usually to  no avail.  Use the Roadmap  To Health  diet available  from  Zorex  International at  no 
charge with an order.  
 
HOMOCYSTEINE  
 
Homocysteine can  be measured in  the blood and in  urine (urine is  the preferred method).  It is 
known  to cause  damage  and inflammation to  blood vessels  and increased levels  often  nexus  to 
cardio -vascular  disease, atherosclerosis, stroke and other peripheral vascular disease.  
Laboratory ranges vary with  the unit of  measurement and the fluid used (serum or urine, again 
urine  has proven  itself  to be the most  accurate  marker.  The optimal  range  for homocysteine  is 
less than  the midline  of the laboratory  range.  Supplemental support  should  include  B-12, B-9 
(folate),  B-6, riboflavin  and betaine.  These nutrients can  be found in  the following  supplemental 
support: C.G.F. (ZI) - 4 tid for 30  days then 3  tid. After the homocysteine  has returned  to 
normal (below the midline of the laboratory range ), C.G.F . (ZI) contains B -5 as P-5-P, B-12 as  
hydroxocobalamin  with the  porcine stomach parenchyma and the  intrinsic factor riboflavin in  it 
phosphorylated  form. After 45  days  on 4 tid, C.G.F. should be reduced  to 2 tid with a serial 
check of  the homocysteine  every six months.  HCL Complete  (Zl)­ (source of betaine ) at 1 
per meal should be used through the entire protocol.  If the patient displays the  subjective signs  
of HCl need  then the HCL  Complete (ZI)  should be  increased every other day to stomach 
tolerance.  If over four capsules are required to control the subjectivity of HCl need then zinc, 
thiamine and salt need should be ruled out.

9 
 PLASMA  GLUCAGON  
 
Discussion:  Glucagon is n01mally secreted by the alpha -2 cells of the pancreatic islets and exerts 
a counterbalancing effect  to insulin in the regulation of glucose  metabolism.  It exists in the  "true" 
form (3500 daltons) which is  the biologically  active form  and the  "big"  form (160,000 daltons).  
This fo1m may represent binding of the 3500 -dalton glucagon to plasma protein and rare families 
have increased amounts of  "big" glucagon circulating.  
Related  Tests:  Serum  and urinary  glucose,  blood  insulin  and glycated hemoglobin.  
 
Reference Range:  Reference ranges will vary depending upon the methodology used.  Some 
laboratories report the normal range as below 60 ng/L and some laboratories that use radio immune 
assay (RIA) rep01i the normal range at 20 -100 pg/mL.  RIA is the preferred means of measuring 
glucagon because the RIA ethanol extraction method removes the "big" glucagon, which is not 
considered biologically active.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Use the reference  range  provided  by the laboratory.  
 
Possible  Alarm  Range:  Values above 500 pg/mL are frequently  seen with glucagonomas  and 
over 75 percent of the glucagonomas  have metastasized at the time of diagnosis.  
 
Common Causes for Increased Plasma Glucagon:  Glucagonomas, diabetic ketoacidosis, stress, 
uremia, hepatic cirrhosis, acute pancreatitis, bums, trauma and in some cases hypo­ glycemia.  
Although glucagon may increase with any of these problems, the most common reason for a  
significant increase (above 500 pg/mL) is  glucagonoma . Supplemental support and dietary 
requirements for patients with diabetes can be found in the section of this manual covering serum 
glucose.  With other problems noted the supplemental su pport and dietary requirements should be 
determined by the results of the entire bioassay.  
 
Common Causes for Decreased Plasma Glucagon:  Cystic fibrosis, chronic pancreatitis and after 
the pancreas has been removed.  Supplemental support and dietary requirements for pancreatitis 
can be found in the section of this manual covering serum lipase.  With other problems noted the 
supplemental support and dietary requirements should be determined by the results of the entire 
bioassay.  
Important  Consideration  with  Abnormal  Plasma  Glucagon:  
 
After  a glucose  load,  there  is no suppression  of glucagon  in patients  with glucagonoma.  
 
See Blood  Insulin  for the relationship  between insulin  and glucagon.

10 
 SERUM  AMYLASE  
1,4 alpha -D Glucanohydrolase  
 
Discussion:  Amylase is a group of enzymes mainly from the exocrine pancreas and to a lesser 
degree from the salivary glands. Serum amylase is  often a useful assay method for patients with 
acute pancreatitis who  present within two  hours  of the onset of  acute  pain;  however, serum lipase 
provides better sensitivity and specificity than serum amylase.  
 
Related  Tests:  Serum  lipase,  total bilirubin,  alkaline  phosphatase,  SOOT/AST,  SGPT/ALT, 
GOT, triglycerides,  cholesterol, serum glucose, monocytes and serum trypsin.  
Reference  Range:  40-140 U/L 
 
Optimum  Range:  31-110 U/L 
 
Possible  Alarm  Range:  Over  three  times  the upper  limit  of the laboratory  range  indicates  a 
significant problem is present.  
Common Cause  For Increased Serum Amylase:  The most  common cause  for increased serum 
amylase is pancreatitis, however specificity is poor (oxalate and citrate depress results and 
increased triglycerides can  falsely decrease results).  Serum  amylase should always  be confirmed 
with serum lipase and other tests.  Supplemental support and dietary requirements for patients 
with pancreatitis can be  found in  the section of  this manual covering serum lipase.  
 
Less Common Causes For Increased Serum Amylase:  Mumps or other salivary lesions, 
perforated peptic ulcer (with or without pancreatic involvement), intestinal obstruction, biliary 
tract disease usually including stones, appendicitis, diabetic acidosis, trauma, bums, and extra­ 
pancreatic cancers (especia lly esophagus, lung and ovary).  
 
Common Causes  For Decreased Serum Amylase:  Protein  malnutrition, severe  hepatic  disease 
and alcoholism.  
Important  Considerations  With  Abnormal  Serum  Amylase:  
 
Isoenzymes of  serum amylase can be  completed by most specialty laboratories; however, 
they are expensive. This test quantifies amylase of salivary origin and amylase of pancreatic origin.  
Although expensive, the isoenzymes of amylase are useful in assessing the decrease in pancreatic 
function for children over five years of age who have cystic fibrosis (determine need for pancreatic 
enzyme replacement).  
 
Macroamylase  is a high molecular weight material that  represents amylase that  has been 
complexed to a high molecular weight protein such as immunoglobulin.  It is seen with high serum 
amylase and low urine amylase and may be present in normal and abnormal patients. 
Macroamylase has little clinical significance; however, it  can be increased with HIV infection.

11 
 SERUM  LIPASE  
Triacylglycerol  Acylhydrolase  
 
Discussion:  Lipase, a  glycoprotein, is  an enzyme produced by  the pancreas.  It is increased with 
pancreatitis.  Serum lipase is  superior  to serum amylase in  both sensitivity and  specificity for  the 
diagnosis of pancreatitis, but both tests can be useful.  Lipase is generally normal with patients 
who have elevated serum amylase due to peptic ulcer, salivary problems, inflammatory bowel 
disease and  intestinal obstruction; however,  it is always increased with pancreatitis.  
 
Related Tests:  Serum amylase, total bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase,  SGOT/AST,  SGPT/ALT, 
GGTP, triglycerides, cholesterol, serum glucose and serum trypsin.  
 
Reference  Range:  0-59 U/L 
 
Optimum  Range:  5-46 U/L 
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Over  twice  the upper  limit  of the laboratory  ranges.  
 
Common  Cause  For Increased  Lipase:  
 
Pancreatitis:  SGPT/ALT increased, alkaline phosphatase increased (both alkaline 
phosphatase and SGPT/ALT are more increased with biliary pancreatitis than with alcoholic 
pancreatitis), serum amylase increased, SGOT/AST increased, serum bilirubin increased, tri­ 
glycerides will be  increased, MCV increased,  calcium decreased, fecal chymotrypsin decreased, 
CA 19 -9, CA 50 and CA 242 increased.  Supplemental Support:  Although the following 
supplement program can be effective, acute pancreatitis is a serious problem that should be 
diagnosed and  treated by a qualified doctor.  Hospitalization  and LV.  feeding are  often required. 
8X Pancreatin (ZI)  - 4 at the beginning of symptoms and  then 1 qid with meals, GI Complex 
(ZI) - 3 tid with meals, C.G.F. (ZI)  - 2 tid with meal and Parathyroid Tissue – as directed by 
the manufacturer.  After the patient is asymptomatic reduce  these supplements by 50  percent and  
add HCL  Complete (ZI)  - 1-2 tid in the middle of  the meal, increase every other day to stomach 
tolerance.  I f  m o r e  t h a n  4  c a p s u l e s  a r e  n e e d  t o  c o n t r o l  s u b j e c t i v e  
i n di c a t i o n ,  r u l e  o u t  z i n c ,  t h i a m i n e  a n d  s a l t  n e e d . Diet:  Use the Roadmap 
To Health diet and ensure any fruits and vegetables the patient is allowed are lightly steamed. 
Increase pure  water intake to  at least 8 -10 full glasses  daily.  Note:  If the patient does  not 
respond immediately to  supplementation and diet, they should be referred for medical 
care.  
Less  Common Causes  For Increased  Lipase:  Pancreatic  cancer,  alcoholism,  anorexia  nervosa, 
ulcers, gallstones, biliary obstruction, renal failure and bone fracture.  
 
Common Causes For  Decreased Lipase:  Viral hepatitis (lack  of bile salts results in  the failure 
to activate pancreatic lipase  in the intestinal lumen),  cancer  of the pancreas, protein  malnutrition, 
necrosis of the liver and extra -hepatic  biliary obstruction.

12 
 Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  Serum  Lipase:  
 
Food allergy/sensitivity – conside r is a common finding with chronic and acute pancreatitis. 
For other sensitivities or allergies use AHF (ZI) - 3-4 bid.  
 
With  most  cases  of pancreatitis,  biliary  dysfunction  and/or  obstruction  is also present.  
It is important to make certain of sufficient calcium and magnesium intake with either 
chronic or acute pancreatitis (calcium and magnesium are almost always decreased).  
Irrespective of the scientific literature, it has been our experience that toxic element 
exposure, pesticides, other xenobiotics, and inoculations can be locus to pancreatitis.  
An excellent way  to differentiate pancreatitis  from  peptic ulcer,  salivary problems, severe 
bowel inflammation  and intestinal obstruction is to complete a serum amylase  and a serum lipase. 
With pancreatitis both serum amylase and lipase are generally  increased however, with the other 
problems noted lipase will generally be normal with an  increased amylase.  
 
According to  the original research recorded by Henry Harrower, M.D.  in Practical Endo­ 
crinology,  parathyroid dysfunction is  common with pancreatic problems. Our clinical experience 
reflects Dr. Harrower's original research. Consider Parathyroid Tissue – as directed by the 
manufacturer.  
 
Anytime pancreatic insufficiency is  present, reduced  fat-soluble vitamin absorption 
must be assumed.  Consider taking vitamins a, e, d & k supplements.

13 
 SERUM  CHOLESTEROL  
 
Discussion:  Cholesterol is a steroid normally found in all body cells and plasma.  Most of the 
information relative to  increased or  decreased cholesterol can  be extrapolated to  triglycerides.  In 
general, cholesterol is  increased in most endocrine or  organ hypofunction and decreased in most 
endocrine and organ hyperfunction.  See the section of  this manual covering lipid electrophoresis 
for more information on  cholesterol.  Note:  Patient condition at  the time of the blood drawing is 
very important. There should be no  change in  diet for 3  weeks prior to  the test, their body weight 
should be stable, and they should be fasting (nothing but water for th e 12 hours preceding the test). 
Fasting is not as important with cholesterol as it is with triglycerides; but since they are generally 
drawn together fasting becomes an important issue.  Posture may also be  significant in that 
cholesterol may be from 10 to 15 percent lower after 20 minutes in the recumbent position and 
increases of up to 5 percent are possible if  the tourniquet is  applied for more than 2 minutes during 
the draw.  Emotional and physical stress can  also influence cholesterol levels (cholesterol  is an 
acute phase reactant) therefore, when stress is present, cholesterol is generally increased above the 
patient's normal level.  
Related Tests:  Serum triglycerides, HDL/LDLNLDL cholesterol, lipid fractionization, serum 
glucose, hemoglobin A le, fructosamine, apolipoprotein A -1, B and E, lipoprotein (a), plasma 
glucagon, blood insulin, the thyroid panel and salivary, serum, or urinary cortisol.  
Reference  Range:  0-20 years  of age: 100-169 mg/dL  
21-99 years  of age: 100-199 mg/dL  
 
Optimum  Range:  150-220 mg/dL.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Although  only a fraction  of the  patients  with serum  cholesterol  above 
275 mg/dL have coronary artery disease, values above 275 mg/dL require immediate attention.  
 
Common  Causes  for Increased  Serum  Cholesterol:  
 
Coronary  Artery  Disease:  See the section  of this manual  covering  HDL  cholesterol.  
 
Diabetes:  See the  section of  this manual  covering  serum  glucose.  
 
Primary  Thyroid  Hypofunction  or Hypofunction  Secondary  to Anterior  Pituitary  
Hypofunction:  See the section of this manual covering thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH).  
 
Less  Common  Causes  for Increased  Serum  Cholesterol:  Adrenal  cortical  dysfunction,  Type 
II, II -A, II -B, III and V Hyperlipoproteinemia, alcoholism, liver necrosis, pancreatitis, renal 
disease, and hypertension.  
Note:  For most patients lowering dietary cholesterol will generally have little  effect on decreas­ 
ing serum  cholesterol. Addressing other  factors  such as exercise, caffeine consumption, smoking, 
obesity, excessive carbohydrate consumption, endocrine and liver/biliary function will have a 
greater effect on lowering cholesterol than lowering cholesterol  in the diet.

14 
 Common  Causes  for Decreased  Serum  Cholesterol:  
 
Thyroid  Hyperfunction  and/or  Anterior Pituitary  Hyperfunction:  See the section of 
this manual covering thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH).  
 
Viral  Hepatitis:  See the section  of this manual  covering  the liver transaminases.  
 
Hyperparathyroidism:  See the section of  this manual  covering  serum calcium.  
 
Less Common Causes for Decreased Serum Cholesterol:  Depression including postpartum 
depression, several types of cancer, Crohn's disease, cirrhosis of the liver, Celiac disease and 
sometimes with vegetarian diets.  
Note:  A great deal has been spoken and written concerning the evils of increased cholesterol  
However, little  has been  reported concerning  decreased cholesterol.  Decreased cholesterol can  be 
normal for a vegetarian and some people with a genetic predisposition to decreased cholesterol. 
Using electrophoretic studies, hormonal panels, glycoprotein electrophoresis, the CBC with 
differential and other bioassay, we were able to  confirm on over 500 cases that were later diagnosed 
with neoplasm, that decreased cholesterol for  a patient who historically had normal or increased 
cholesterol was a strong diagnostic indicator for neoplasm.  This was especially true when the 
lymphocyte percentage was below 20 percent and the serum albumin was below 4.0 g/dL.  When 
cholesterol is considered correctly (functionally) as not only a risk factor for coronary artery 
disease, but  also as  a precursor to  hormone production, as  a protective coating on cells, membranes, 
and organisms and as  a cell recognition factor in  the immune process, one can see why cholesterol  
is as dangerous low as it is high.  
Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  Serum  Cholesterol:  
 
Biliary stasis may occur with increased serum cholesterol (cholesterol content of the bile 
is too high). With most cases this problem is diagnosed with subjective indicators. For 
supplemental support, subjective indicators and diet requirements see the section of this manual 
covering GOT.  
In the absence of free radical pathology, genetic predisposition and vegan diets. The 
following nutrients can be used to increase serum cholesterol  for a  healthy person: Manganese 
– as directed by the manufacturer.  SunFlax Complex (ZI)  - 2 bid and Immune Plus (ZI) – 1 tid.  
 
After the predisposing factors (diet, endocrine dysfunction, lack of exercise, obesity, 
liver/biliary dysfunction, etc.) have been  addressed and you feel the  serum cholesterol is  still too 
high, the following nutrients are often successful in decreasing serum cholesterol and LDL  
cholesterol:  Niacin 250 (ZI)  - 1 daily, increase slowly to 1 tid (take with 1 or 2 tablespoons of 
apple sauce to reduce  flushing) SunFlax Complex (ZI)  - 2 tid, S.O.S. (ZI)  –1 tid. , and C.G.F.  
(ZI)- 3 tid.

15 
 Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  Serum  Cholesterol  Continued:  
 
Cholesterol in the plasma is generated from the diet and from synthesis by the liver. 
Cholesterol entering the small intestine inhibits liver production.  Cholesterol levels are also 
influenced by insulin, thyroid hormones, glucagon, epinephrine, other adrenal and pituitary 
hormones and by carbohydrate ingestion.  The catecholamines , glucagon and cortisol, cause 
increased  release of cholesterol  into the blood stream, hence the elevated lipids seen with patients 
who are stressed.  
 
As indicated previously, serum cholesterol decreased below the patient's historical average 
(without intervention) is a common sign of developing or frank neoplasm, especially if the  albumin 
is decreased below 4.0 g/dL and the lymphocyte percentage is below 20 percent.  
 
If the patient  must  be placed  on one of the statin  drugs  or Red Yeast  Rice to 
decrease  serum  cholesterol,  ensure  the patient  is placed  on Coenzyme Q10 – as directed by the 
manufacturer  (statin  or Red Yeast  Rice taken  in the evening)  and hepatic/biliary  support  is 
initiated  –GB Complete  (ZI) - 2 tid. 
 
To increase  cholesterol  to bile  conversion  along  with GB Complete  (ZI) add 
Magnesium Taurinate  (ZI),  C 1000 (ZI) and 8X Pancreatin (ZI).  
 
See the section of  this manual covering lipid electrophoresis  for further information 
on serum cholesterol.

16 
 HIGH  DENSITY  LIPOPROTEIN  CHOLESTEROL  
Alpha  1 Lipoprotein  Cholesterol,  HDL,  HDLC,  HDL  Cholesterol  
 
Discussion:  HDL is a class of heterogeneous  particles of varying density and size containing lipid 
and protein.  It includes cholesterol, triglycerides,  phospholipids and apoproteins. Phospho­  lipids 
predominate in HDL. HDL functions in the transport of cholesterol to the liver for metabolism to 
bile acids, hence it is thought of as the "good" form of cholesterol.  HDL levels must be viewed in 
relation to  the total cholesterol and LDLNLDL cholesterol.  Within reason, if the cholesterol  is 
high, but the HDL is also high and the LDL  is normal , the patient is consid­ ered to be well 
protected.  When the total cholesterol  is 180 mg/dL or less, a decreased  HDL is not considered to 
be a strong independen t diagnostic indicator for coronary artery disease and atherosclerosis. For 
further information on HDL cholesterol see the section of the manual covering lipid 
electrophoresis.  
 
Related  Tests:  Total serum  cholesterol,  LDL/VLDL  cholesterol,  triglycerides, apolipoprotein 
A-1, B and E, lipoprotein  (a), lipid fractionization, serum glucose, hemoglobin Ale,  fructosamine, 
plasma glucagon, C -reactive protein, the thyroid panel and salivary, serum or urinary cortisol.  
 
Reference  Range:  Above  40 mg/dL  
 
Optimum  Range:  Males - above  55 mg/dL.  Females  - above  60 mg/dL.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  If the total  serum  cholesterol  is above  180 and the HDL  cholesterol  is 
below 40 mg/dL this represents a strong coronary risk factor.  
 
Common  Causes  For Decreased  HDL  Cholesterol:  
 
Thyroid  Hyperfunction:  See TSH.  
 
Diabetes:  See glucos  
Essential Hypertension:  Serum albumin frequently decreased, alkaline phosphatase 
increased, plasma aldosterone increased, anti -diuretic hormone decreased, renin can be  decreased, 
increased or normal, apolipoprotein  A-1 decreased, apolipoprotein B increased, atrial natriuretic 
peptide increased, total serum cholesterol increased, serum creatinine increased, endothelin -1 
increased, glucose frequently increased, ionized calcium decreased, LDLNLDL cholesterol 
increased, lipoprotein (a) increased, serum potassium and magnesium frequently decreased, serum 
sodium increased, BUN increased, uric acid increased, Lipid Fractionization  test abnormal and 
triglycerides increased. Suppl emental Support:  First utilize Magnesium Taurinate (ZI) - 5 at 
bedtime, increase to bowel tolerance, Arginine Complex  (ZI) -3 bid.  With adrenal hyperfunction 
add AD Hyper  (ZI) – 2 bid and Sympathetic Balance  (ZI) – 2 tid.

17 
 Essential  Hypertension  Continued:  
 
Diet with Essential Hypertension:  Use the Roadmap To Health diet and ensure the 
patient  drinks not less than 8 -10 glasses of pure water each day.  If the patient has adrenal cortical 
hyperfunction (common), sodium intake  should be  limited, Celtic sea  salt should be  used as their 
source of sodium. In any case,an increased level of exercise is desirable; however the patient should 
not exceed their metabolic capacity.  
Coronary Artery Disease/Atherosclerosis/Angina:  Alkaline phosphatase increased, 
apolipoprotein A -1 decreased,  apolipoprotein B increased,  apolipoprotein E (e4) increased, serum 
cholesterol increased, serum triglycerides increased, LDLNLDL cholesterol increased, serum 
selenium decreased (often with a serum zinc increase), lipoprotein (a) increased, serum creatinine 
increased in 60 percent of the patients, tissue plasminogen activator increased, C­ reactive protein 
increased, fibrinogen increased, serum folate decreased, Lipid Fractionization  test abnormal, 
vitamin B -12 decreased and uric acid increased.   
Supplemental Support:  Arginine Complex (ZI)  - 2 tid, 8x Pancreatin (ZI) – 1 qid on 
an empty stomach,  CircuPlus (ZI) - 3-4 bid, Niacin 250 (ZI)  - Begin with 1 per day and increase 
slowly to a maximum  of 1 tid, Selenomethionine (ZI) - 1 per day and L.P.A. Plus (ZI) - 2 tid. If 
the coronary artery disease, atherosclerosis  or angina is  due to  a genetic predisposition  add Vitamin 
E – as directed by the manufacturer, CoQ -10 – as directed by the manufacturer,  and B6/Bl (ZI) - 
1 tid. With decreased Co2 add C.G.F. (ZI) - 2 tid, and  HCL Complete (ZI). If more than 4 HCL 
Complete are needed to control symptoms, rule out zinc, thiamine and salt need.  Diet:  Use the 
Roadmap To Health diet and ensure the patient drinks at least 8 -10 full glasses of water each day. 
Increased level of exercise is desirable however, the patient should not exceed their metabolic 
capacity.  
 
Dysinsulinism  (Metabolic  Syndrome/Syndrome -X): See serum  triglycerides.  
 
Less Common Causes For Decreased HDL:  Excess use of tobacco, steroids, thiazides, beta­ 
blockers, pituitary hypofunction, cirrhosis of the liver, menopause, renal disease and with some 
cases of rheumatoid arthritis.  
 
Common Causes  For Increased HDL Cholesterol:  Increased HDL  cholesterol is  generally not 
considered to  be a pathologic finding, however it  is often found significantly higher than normal 
with alcoholism, von Willebrand's disease, autoimmune diseases and sometimes with primary 
thyroid hypofunction or thyroid hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary hypofunction.

18 
 Important  Considerations  With  Abnormal  HDL  Cholesterol:  
 
With coronary artery disease, atherosclerosis or angina ensure the patient uses only pure 
water that does not contain lead, fluoride or chlorine.  
 
One of the most effective ways to increase HDL cholesterol levels is with an increased 
level  of exercise however,  the patient  should not  exceed  their metabolic capacity (a  heart  monitor 
should be used whenever the patient exercises).  
If the patient has coronary artery disease, atherosclerosis  or angina and is maintaining a 
normal weight with normal serum lipids, ensure a C -reactive protein and serum or urinary 
homocysteine are  completed.  Arterial inflammation due  to increased levels  of homocysteine is  a 
common finding with this type of patient.  
 
For the healthy patient who  has a decreased HDL  cholesterol level  (frequently genetically 
pre-determined) C.G.F. (ZI) - 3 tid, SunFlax Complex (ZI) - 2 tid and a protein powder.  
 
Recent peer reviewed information indicates that HDL < 30 or>  100 is associated with 
infectious disease.  
 
See the section of this manual covering lipid electrophoresis for further information on 
HDL cholesterol.  
Lipoprotein  Sub-Fractionation  Profile  
 
The Lipid Fractionization Test separates lipoproteins by high -speed density gradient ultra­ 
centrifugation.  The analysis is performed on a serum sample.  The test evaluates LDL, HDL, VLDL 
cholesterol,  total cholesterol, total  triglycerides,  lipoprotein (a),  different sized HDL,  LDL and 
VLDL as  well as  other lipid tests.  This test  should be considered anytime one or  more of the 
values in the lipid panel (total cholesterol, total triglycerides, LDL and VLDL cholesterol) 
are increased more t 0 10 percent above the lab  values.

19 
 LOW  DENSITY  LIPOPROTEIN  CHOLESTEROL  
LDL,  LDLC,  LDL  Cholesterol,  Beta  Lipoprotein  
 
Discussion:  An association  exists between LDL and HDL  cholesterol.  As the LDL  increases the 
HDL will generally decrease; hence the association in the diagnosis of atherosclerosis, 
dysinsulinism, coronary artery disease and frank or developing diabetes.  In most cases the LDL 
level is a major part of the decision  relevant  to initiation  of pharmaceutical, dietary  therapy and/or  
supplemental  support.  Providing  the total  triglycerides  are below  400 mg/dL  the following 
formula can be used to determine LDL cholesterol levels: LDL equals the total cholesterol minus 
HDL plus triglycerides divided by five.  
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  indicated  in the section of  this manual  covering  HDL  cholesterol.  
 
Reference  Range:  Below  100 mg/dL  
 
Optimum  Range:  < 105 mg/dL;  complete  a Lipid  Fractionization  test when  increased.  
 
Possible Panic  Range:  > 150 mg/dL, especially  if the total  cholesterol  is > 250 mg/dL  and the 
HDL cholesterol  is< 50 mg/dL.  This pattern is  strongly associated  with coronary artery disease.  
 
Common  Causes  for Increased  LDL  Cholesterol:  See the section  of this manual  covering 
decreased HDL cholesterol.  
Important  Considerations  with LDL  Cholesterol:  
 
Good scientific evidence exists that indicates oxidized LDL cholesterol is taken up by 
macrophages forming the foam cells of atherosclerotic plaques and phenolic substances (red  wine, 
fruits and vegetables, etc. and vitamin E, alpha lipoic acid and broad -spectrum circulatory support  
prevent  the oxidation  of LDL  cholesterol.   Hence  the value  of supplementation  with 
L.P.A. Plus (ZI) - 2 tid,  CircuPlus  (ZI)- 3 bid , will help prevent and treat atherosclerosis.  
= 
At least one study  has shown that  LDL cholesterol  from diabetics has modifications  in the 
lipid and protein content that cause massive cholesterol accumulation in the aortic cells.  
See the section of this manual covering lipid electrophoresis for further information on LDL 
cholesterol.  
VERY  LOW  DENSITY  LIPOPTROTEINS  
VLDL  Cholesterol  
 
Discussion:  See information  above  on LDL  Cholesterol;  completed  a VAP  when  increased.  
 
Reference  Range:  Below  40 mg/dL  Optimal  Range:  Below 30  md/dL

20 
 APOLIPOPROTEIN  A AND  B 
Apo-A-1, Apo B, Apolipoprotein  A-1 
 
Discussion:  Apolipoproteins are the protein components of the various lipoprotein complexes. 
Apolipoprotein A -1 is the main protein component  of HDL cholesterol  and is thought  by many to 
be more useful than the measurement of HDL in predicting patients with a high risk for coronary 
artery disease.  Apolipoprotein B is the major component of LDL and VLDL cholesterol. The ratio 
of Apolipoprotein A -1 to Apolipoprotein B is more important than the relative  level of  each (in a  
healthy  patient  the level  of A-1 should  be about  twice  that of B). 
 
Related  Tests:  Triglycerides, cholesterol, HDL, LDL and VLDL cholesterol, Lipid Fractionization 
test, lipid electrophoresis, RBC, HCT, HGB, lipoprotein (a), uric acid and apolipoprotein  E. 
 
Reference  Range:  Use range  provided  by the Lipid  Fractionization  test 
 
Optimum  Range:  Use range  provided  by the Lipid  Fractionization  test. 
 
Possible  Alarm  Range:  When  apolipoprotein  B exceeds  the level  of apolipoprotein  A-1, 
coronary  artery disease must be  ruled out via  a Lipid Fractionization  test and other examinations.  
Common Causes For Increase In Apolipoprotein B With Decreases In Apolipoprotein A -1: 
Coronary artery disease due to atherosclerosis . Supplemental support and dietary requirements for 
patients with atherosclerosis can be found in the section of this manual covering HDL cholesterol.  
 
Important  Considerations  With  Abnormal  Apolipoprotein  A-1 to B Ratios:  
 
Apolipoprotein  ratios weighted to the apolipoprotein B side are common with Metabolic 
Syndrome/Syndrome -X and diets high in refined carbohydrates.  
The relative proportion of apolipoprotein A -1 to apolipoprotein B is more effective in 
differentiating patients with ischemic heart  disease than the measurement of triglycerides, total 
cholesterol, HDL, and LDL cholesterol.

21 
 APOLIPOPROTEIN  E 
APOE,  apo E, Apoprotein  E 
 
Discussion:  Apolipoprotein E binds LDL cholesterol and other receptors and thus, modulates LDL 
metabolism.  There are  multiple forms of Apolipoprotein E.  This polymorphism is  seen as e2, e3 
and e4.  An increase in e4 predisposes the patient to coronary artery disease and Alzheimer's 
disease. The mechanisms of action involve effects on cholesterol metabolism (coronary artery 
disease) and interaction with beta -amyloid (Alzheimer's disease).  
 
Related  Tests:  Triglycerides,  cholesterol,  HDL,  LDL  and VLDL  cholesterol,  lipid 
electro­phoresis, RBC, HCT, HGB, lipoprotein (a) and apolipoprotein  A-1 and B.  
 
Reference  Range:  Use laboratory  range.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Use laboratory  range.  
 
Possible  Alarm  Range:  Apolipoprotein  e4 levels  that exceed  the laboratory  range.  
 
Common  Causes  for Increase  in Apolipoprotein  e4: Coronary  artery  disease  (atherosclerosis) 
and a predisposition to Alzheimer's disease.  Supplemental  and dietary  requirements for patients 
with coronary artery disease (atherosclerosis) can be found in the section of this manual covering 
HDL cholesterol.  Supplemental and  dietary suggestions for  Alzheimer's can  be found in The 
Nutritional Protocol Manual published by Balancing Body Chemistry with Nutrition  Seminars  
LLC.  Patients  with an increase  in e4 should  not be on a keto diet (diet high in fat).  
 
Important  Considerations  With  Abnormal  Apolipoprotein  E (e4):  
 
Apolipoprotein  Eis produced largely in the liver, therefore whenever it  is found elevated 
supplemental  support for hepatic function should be considered.  
In all cases of increased apolipoprotein E, therapy to increase cholesterol to bile acid  
conversion  GB Complete  (ZI) - 2-3 tid, C-1000 (ZI) - Increase to bowel tolerance, A.H.F. (ZI) - 
3 bid and Magnesium Taurinate (ZI) - 5 at bedtime, increase every other evening to bowel 
tolerance.

22 
 LIPOPROTEIN  (a) 
Lp (a) 
 
Discussion:  Lipoprotein  (a) is a plasma  lipoprotein  with a lipid composition  very similar  to LDL 
cholesterol;  however this lipoprotein  is composed  of two proteins  linked by disulfide bonds.  
There is significant variation in concentrations of this lipoprotein from individual to individual, but 
for most individuals it tends to remain constant for long periods of time.  High lipoprotein (a) values 
in patients with high blood lipids (cholesterol  and triglycerides) is clearly an independent risk 
factor for coronary heart disease and possible cerebral infarction; however, the association is not 
clear in patie nts with normal serum lipid values.  
Related Tests:  Triglycerides, cholesterol, HDL, LDL and VLDL cholesterol, lipid electro­ 
phoresis, RBC, HGB, HCT, apolipoprotein A -1 and B, Lipid Fractionization test and apo­ 
lipoprotein E.  
Reference  Range:  Use laboratory  range.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Use laboratory  range.  
 
Possible  Alarm  Range:  Plasma levels above  30 mg/dL are reported to be associated  with a two 
to threefold increased risk for coronary artery disease.  
Common Cause For  Increase In Lipoprotein (a):  Increased risk for coronary artery disease. 
Supplemental support and  dietary requirements for patients  with coronary artery disease (athero­ 
sclerosis) can be found in the section of this manual covering HDL cholesterol.  
 
Important  Considerations  With  Increased  Lipoprotein  (a): 
 
Recent information from the peer reviewed literature suggests that quantification of apo­ 
lipoprotein B and lipoprotein (a) may be indicated in subgroups and patients with a history of 
premature coronary artery disease (atherosclerosis) or family histories  of coronary disease. Further, 
high concentrations of lipoprotein  (a) have a thrombogenic potential.  
 
LIPOPROTEIN -ASSOCIATED  PHOSPHOLIPASE   A2 
Lp-PLA2  
 
Lp-PLA2, also known as platelet activating factor (PAF -AH) is classified as an independent 
member of the phospholipase  A2 enzyme family. Lp -PLA2 circulates in the blood and binds 
primarily to LDL cholesterol.  It is considered a potent pro -inflammatory mediator involved in the 
vascular inflammation process.  It has been suggested that Lp -PLA2 is  partly responsible for 
atherosclerosis  and contributes to cardiovascular disease and stroke. According to the literature, 
increased levels  of Lp-PLA2 are  associated with a  two-fold increase in  risk of stroke.  The risk is 
present irrespective of other variables such as  smoking, high blood pressure, obesity, etc.  
To Decrease Lp -LPA -2: Follow the supplemental support listed for atherosclerosis under 
decreased HDL cholesterol.

23 
 SERUM  TRIGLYCERIDES  
TG, Triacylglycerols  
 
Discussion:  Serum triglycerides (TG) are a family of complex lipids composed of glycerol 
esterified  with three fatty  acids (saturated  and unsaturated)  of the same  or different  lengths. 
They are not soluble in blood and constitute 95 percent of the fat stored in adipose tissue. 
Triglycerides travel in the blood with cholesterol therefore, they should be drawn together and 
viewed together.  A patient who is correctly metabolizing their fats, proteins and carbohydrates will 
generally have about half as much triglyceride as cholesterol.  Example - if the serum cholesterol 
is 200 the triglyceride level should be around 100.  Classic research from the Framingham studies 
in the 1970s identified high serum cholesterol as a heart disease risk factor (above 200 mg/dL); 
however  subsequent Framingham studies as well as other peer reviewed studies (Helsinki, etc.),  
indicated that increased triglycerides in  conjunction with decreased HDL cholesterol (Metabolic 
Syndrome/Syndrome -X) was a more significant indicator for coronary arte1y disease than high 
serum cholesterol alone. The following is  based on a fasting sample.  
Related Tests:  Serum cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, LDLNLDL cholesterol, serum glucose, 
hemoglobin Ale, fructosamine, apolipoprotein A -1, B and E, lipoprotein (a), plasma glucagon, 
Lipid Fractionization test, blood insulin, the thyroid panel and cortisol.  
 
Reference  Range:  Below  149 mg/dL.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Between  40 and 60 percent  of the total cholesterol.  
 
Possible Panic Range:  Above 250 mg/dL is a  cause for concern, above 400 mg/dL is a certain 
cause for concern; in either case a Lipid Fractionization test is indicated.  
Common  Causes For  Increased  Serum  Triglycerides:  
 
Dysinsulinism (Metabolic Syndrome/Syndrome -X): Glucose is frequently increased 
above 95 mg/dL, HDL cholesterol  decreased, LDLNLDL  cholesterol increased, triglycerides will 
frequently be increased above the  total cholesterol (Type IV Hyperlipoproteinemia),  cortisol is  
frequently increased, blood insulin is  frequently increased, lipoprotein (a)  is increased and the 
apolipoprotein  A-1 to B ratio is generally  weighted  to the B side.  Supplemental  Support:  
C.G.F. (ZI)  - 3 tid, SunFlax Complex (ZI)  - 2 tid, Protein  powder  –AD Hyper (ZI)  – 2 
midmorning and 2 in the afternoon,  Berberine HCL (ZI) - 1 tid, Sympathetic Balance – (ZI) – 
2 tid,  Protein Powder  and HCL Complete (ZI)  - 1 tid in the middle of each meal . If more than 4 
capsules are needed to control symptoms, rule out zinc, thiamine and salt deficiency.  If primary 
thyroid hypofunction or thyroid hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary hypofunction is 
present, add supplements listed in the section of this manual covering thyroid stimulating hormone  
(TSH). Diet:  Use the Roadmap To Health diet and ensure the patient drin ks at least 8 -10 full 
glasses of pure water each day. Note:  Always conduct a Lipid Fractionization Test and serum 
insulin with dysinsulinism.

24 
 Alcoholism:  See the section  of this manual  covering  GGT.  
 
Diabetes:  See the section  of this manual  covering  serum  glucose.  
 
Primary  Thyroid  Hypofunction  or Hypofunction  Secondary  to Anterior  Pituitary  
Hypofunction:  See the section of this manual covering thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH).  
 
Coronary  Artery  Disease:  See the section  of this manual  covering  HDL  cholesterol.  
 
Less Common Causes for Increased Serum Triglycerides:  Pancreatitis, glycogen storage disease, 
genetic predisposition, gout, HIV -1 infection, Type I, II -A, II-B, III and IV Hyper­ lipoproteinemia, 
chronic renal disease, Down's syndrome, hypertension and toxemia during pregnancy.  
 
Common  Causes  for Decreased Serum  Triglycerides:  
 
Thyroid  Hyperfunction:  See the section  of this manual  covering  thyroid  stimulating 
hormone (TSH).  
 
Vegetarian Diets:  Cholesterol will also frequently be decreased;  total globulin will 
frequently be decreased below 2.2 or above 2.8 indicating a  probable need for hydrochloric acid 
use HCL  Complete  (ZI) - begin 1 tid in the middle of the meal  and increase to stomach tolerance . 
If more than 4  capsules are needed rule out a zinc,  thiamine and/or salt deficiency. Check the 
MCV/MCH. If either or both are increased above the metabolic level the needed for folate and 
vitamin B -12 is almost certain ( C.G.F. (ZI) contains both, use 3 tid. Rule out a need for H Cl. 
 
Autoimmune  Phenomenon:  Cholesterol will be n01mal to mildly decreased, triglycerides 
will be significantly decreased in relation to cholesterol (usually less than 30 percent of the total 
cholesterol) and the HDL cholesterol will be significantly increased in relation to the tota l 
cholesterol.  If the patient is not a vegetarian this pattern is often associated with tissue destruction  
due lo an autoimmune  problem or a hormonal imbalance due to an autoimmune problem.  Tissue 
destruction can generally be identified through the isoenzymes of CPK (CK), LDH (LD) or alkaline 
phosphatase (ALP) along with alpha 1 and alpha 2 globulin and alpha 1 glycoprotein.  Other tests 
used to confirm or rule out tissue destruction (neoplasm) are serum albumin and the lymphocytes 
of the white blood count and the various CEA tests.  If tissue destruction is not present, the 
autoimmune phenomenon is probably due to a hormonal  imbalan ce. Supplemental support and 
dietary intervention will depend upon the endocrine dysfunction identified through other testing. 
For further information on the autoimmune phenomenon see the section of this manual covering 
tissue destruction due to autoimmune  processes under serum protein electrophoresis (SPE).

25 
 Less  Common  Causes  For Decreased  Serum  Triglycerides:  Hyperparathyroidism,  genetic 
predisposition, cirrhosis of the liver, celiac disease, hepatic necrosis and postpartum depression.  
 
Important Considerations  With  Abnormal  Serum  Triglycerides:  
 
Increased  serum  triglycerides  are found  with over 75 percent  of patients  with gout.  
 
Exogenous estrogen and excess endogenous production of estrogen will increase serum 
triglycerides in most females.  Increases similar to those seen with oral contraceptives are seen 
normally during pregnancy.  
 
Increased triglycerides are a  common finding with the use of thiazide diuretics and beta­ 
adrenergic blocking agents.  
Increased or decreased triglycerides are infrequently the problem; they are simply an 
indication of another metabolic problem (dysinsulinism, diet, diabetes, lack of exercise, etc.). After 
investigation, a nexus for the abnormal triglyceride level cannot b e determined (possible genetic  
predisposition),  the following  should  be considered:   To increase  triglycerides  use 
C.G.F.  (ZI) - 2 tid and SunFlax  Complex  (ZI) - 2 tid. To decrease  triglycerides  use the 
protocol induced  for Metabolic Syndrome/Syndrome -X. 
 
Increased serum triglycerides tend to indicate poor utilization of fatty acids, decreased 
serum triglycerides tend to indicate poor tissue release of fatty acids.  
Plasma glyceride clearance is accomplished by the liver and adipose and muscle tissue. 
Hence; increasing muscle demand for energy by exercise is one of the most effective ways to 
decrease serum triglycerides.  
 
Under certain pathological circumstances, increased serum triglycerides may occur because 
the liver manufactures glycerides from carbohydrate, fatty acids mobilized from adipose tissue and 
from other two -carbon sources.  This circumstance that overpowers the ability to  clear these 
molecules from the plasma, results in increased plasma triglycerides.  This type of triglyceride 
increase is  common and results  from a  highly refined diet or  carbohydrate sensitivity as seen with 
dysinsulinism  (Metabolic Syndrome /Syndrome -X) 
 
See the section of this manual covering lipid electrophoresis for further information on 
serum triglycerides.

26 
 LIPID  ELECTROPHORESIS  
Lipoprotein  Phenotyping  
 
Discussion:  Although the lipid panel (triglycerides,  total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol and  HDL 
cholesterol) has replaced lipid electrophoresis, if the laboratory will supply the electrophoretic 
tracing, the lipid electrophoresis is still one of the best tests for determining certain metabolic 
problems such as an autoimmune phenomenon (see the se ction of the manual covering common 
causes for decreased serum triglycerides), patients at risk with fad diets and cardiovascular  disease.  
Electrophoresis causes th e separation of lipid molecules into the following four regions on the 
tracing:  
Chylomicrons:  These are fats that travel in  the blood stream for a limited period of  time 
following  a meal  containing fat.  They are typically  75 percent triglyceride  and 25 percent protein, 
cholesterol and phospholipids.  If chylomicrons are present in a fasting sample (8 -12 hours) a 
pathological  process is almost certain and this process may be genetic.  
 
The Pre-Beta Region:  This region is  about 80 percent triglyceride with protein, cholesterol 
and phospholipids making up the remaining 20 percent.  On the  tracing if  a split (double or triple) 
peak is  seen in this  region, the split suggests the presence of a pathological process.  Most often this 
will occur with an autoimmune phenomenon or a cardiovascular problem.  A split pre­ beta 
combined  with an increase of  CPK (CK) is suggestive  of a cardio -pulmonary problem.  
 
The Beta Region:  This region is about 50 percent cholesterol  with protein, triglyceride 
and phospholipids making up the remaining 50 percent.  
 
The Alpha  Region:  This region  is about  60 percent  phospholipids  (HDL  cholesterol) 
with LDL cholesterol and triglyceride making up the remaining 40 percent.  
 
Common  Types  of Hyperlipoproteinemia:  There  are several  subtypes  of 
hyperlipoproteinemia, however the following five are the major types generally seen:  
 
Type I:  This is the type of lipid disorder where the patient lacks the ability to clear 
chylomicrons from the plasma. Frequently this is  a familial problem and  along with  the increased 
chylomicrons  the patient  will geue1ally have  an increased triglyceride  level  and frequently a  split 
pre-beta region indicating the presence of a pathological process.  
Type II:  Characterized by an increase in  the beta region with an increase in total serum 
cholesterol.  The pre -beta region and triglycerides will be normal and the alpha region will be normal 
or increased.  If the Type II problem involves hepatic or pancreatic dysfunction, the  alpha region 
(HDL cholesterol) will be depressed.  A Type II pattern is frequently seen with excess carbohydrate 
ingestion, thyroid hypofunction, hepatic dysfunction and/or coronary disease.

27 
 Common  Type  of Hyperlipoproteinemia  Continued:  
 
Type I II: Characterized  by an increase of both triglycerides  and cholesterol  (both the beta 
and pre -beta regions will be elevated).  The alpha region (HDL  cholesterol)  will be normal or 
depressed.  Patients  with Type III commonly  suffer from premature coronary artery disease that 
can be confirmed with the isoenzymes  of CPK (CK) and LDH (LD).  
 
Type IV: This is the most common pattern encountered with lipid electrophoresis.  It is 
frequently associated with diabetes or pre -diabetes, atherosclerosis, primary thyroid hypo­ function 
or thyroid hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary hypofunction, carbohydrate sensitivity, 
dysinsulinism (Metabolic Syndrome/Syndrome -X), hepati c dysfunction and genetic predisposition. 
With Type IV the total triglycerides will be quantitatively increased in compar­ ison to cholesterol.  
The serum cholesterol may be no rmal, but the triglycerides will always be nearly as high or higher 
than the total cholesterol.  
 
Type V:  Type V is seen with acute metabolic disorders such as uncontrolled diabetes, acute 
pancreatitis, alcoholism and pathological liver/biliary  or renal disease.  The pre -beta and beta 
regions will be significantly  increased with a depression in the alpha region.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  Serum  Lipids:  
 
Lipids are not water -soluble  and biologically they  serve several different  functions such as 
structural components for membranes, storage and transport forms for energy fuels and metabolism, 
protective coating on cells and membranes and tissue immunity as cell recognition factors.  
 
After reviewing several thousand lipid panels and following many of  the patients for  over 
ten years, we have  arrived at  the following general conclusions. This information is not absolute; 
however in the majority we feel it is correct.  
 
When patients are properly utilizing their fats, proteins and carbohydrates, the tri­ 
glyceride  level will  be between 40 and 60 percent of the total cholesterol.  For example, if the total 
cholesterol is 200 mg/dL, the triglyceride level should be between 80 and 120 mg/dL.  
 
The patient with decreased triglycerides in  relation to  the total cholesterol is  not at 
great risk  for cardiac destruction;  however,  this pattern is  common with an  autoimmune  problem.  
 
The patient with increased triglycerides in relation to total cholesterol and decreased 
HDL cholesterol is  at high risk for cardiac destruction.  This pattern is  also commonly found with 
atherosclerosis, diabetes and primary thyroid hypofunction and thyroid hypofunction secondary to 
anterior pituitary hypofunction.  
 
As previously indicated, a split pre -beta fraction as seen on a lipid electrophoresis is always 
a warning for a pathological  process; it should never be taken lightly.

28 
 BLOOD  UREA  NITROGEN  
BUN  
 
Discussion:  BUN reflects the difference between production and clearance of urea.  Increased 
BUN may be due to increased  production or decreased  excretion.  Urea is  the chief end product 
of protein metabolism and is formed almost entirely by the liver from both protein metabolism and 
protein digestion.  It is removed  almost entirely  by the kidneys; however,  a significant amount 
travels from the liver to the colon and is acted upon by gut micro flora to recirculate nitrogen.  
Although many laboratories use the t erm blood urea nitrogen (BUN), most laboratories use serum 
or occasionally plasma, but never blood to determine BUN levels.  
Related Tests:  Serum creatinine, serum uric acid, urinary uric acid, blood electrolytes, liver 
enzymes, urinary creatinine clearance, serum amylase, serum albumin, serum calcium, serum 
glucose, HDL cholesterol, HCT/HGB, white blood count, parathyroid hormone (PTH), serum  
phosphorus, triglycerides, homocysteine, C -reactive protein, urinary micro -albumin and 
osteocalcin.  
Reference  Range:  6-24 mg mg/dL  (slight  increases  are seen in patients  over 52 years  of age).  
 
Optimum  Range:  10 to 15 mg/dL.  
Possible  Panic  Range:  BUN  over 50 mg/dL  is defined  as uremia  and requires  immediate 
attention.  
Common  Causes  For Increased  BUN:  
 
Chronic Renal Dysfunction:  Alpha -I glycoprotein increased (increases with increases in 
serum creatinine), serum albumin increased, alkaline phosphatase increased, serum amylase 
increased, serum calcium increased with chronic renal disease and decreased with acute renal 
disease, serum creati nine increased, C -reactive protein increased, urinary creatinine clearance 
decreased, urinary micro -albumin increased, HDL cholesterol decreased, homocysteine  increased, 
white blood cells decreased, osteocalcin increased, serum phospho rus increased, parathyroid  
hormone can be normal, increased  or decreased  depending  upon the stage of the renal disease, 
HGB/HCT decreased, uric acid increased and triglycerides increased. Supplemental Support:  
Riboflavin  300 (ZI) – 1 daily and Power Pill (ZI) – 1 daily  (riboflavin and thiamine generally 
reduce with  renal disease, especially with low  protein diets), SunFlax Complex (Zl)  - 2 tid, C.G.F. 
(ZI) 3 tid, Renal  support product , Potassiu m and Chinese Rhubarb (as directed by the 
manufacture) . Diet:  Eliminate citrus (except lemon), dairy products, gluten, alcohol, processed 
foods, hydrogenated fats and oils, refined carbohydrates and caffeine containing foods from the 
diet. Use a high complex carbohydrate diet (fruits and vegetables) until the renal dysfunction 
resolves. Note:  The above supplements and diet are indicated for chronic renal dysfunction. Acute 
renal failure requires immediate medical attention and probable hospitalization.  If the infection is 
reoccurring always add Zinc Orotate - 1 qid.

29 
  
 
Common  Causes  For Increased  BUN  Continued:  
 
Genital/Urinary Tract Infection:  Urinary bacteria, white blood cells, red blood cells, 
casts,  nitrite and leukocyte esterase are all frequently increased, alpha - I glycoprotein increased, 
C-reactive protein increased and urinary protein increased.  Supplemental Suppor t: Arginex – as 
directed by the manufacture , Immune Plus (ZI) – 3 bid , Oregano Oil Cap s (ZI)  – 5 tid - 5 tid for 
2 weeks then 3  tid for the following 3  weeks (after two weeks  add Saccharomyces Boulardii (ZI)  
- 1 bid.   If the patient is female and the infection is located in the vagina or lower genital/urinary 
tract, add  Complete Kare  Spray  (ZI) – 1 capful and  Oregano Oil  Blend  (ZI) –3 to 5 drops to 3 
ounces of pure water as a douche, 3 times per week (use rectal syringe and retain for 65 -8 minutes).  
The following to be used as a vaginal douche 3 times a week (Monday, Wednesday, Friday) for 4 
weeks (supplement al should  be placed in 2 -3 ounces of distilled  water and the douche  should be 
retained  for 6 -8 min utes. If the am urine p h is > 6.5 add Phos phorus  – as directed by the 
manufacture. If the am urine pH is < 6.5  consider adding Potassium .  Note:  If the patient is sexually 
active it is  prudent to ensure  that their partner is checked to insure,  they are not passing the infection  
back and forth.  If the infection is severe or the patient does not begin to respond to  the above 
program in 10  days or less, referral to a  doctor specializing  in genital/urinary tract problems  should  
be considered.  Note:  Cloudy  urine  does not always mean infection.  Phosphates and urates will 
cloud urine. Add some vinegar to a  sample of urine, if  it clears  the problem,  it is phosphates.  Heat 
a sample of  the urine to  140 degrees, if it clears the problem,  is urates.  
 
Renal  Hypertension:  The laboratory patterns, supplemental support and diet requirements 
are the same as those listed in the section of this manual covering essential hypertension under 
HDL cholesterol decreased; however, Chinese Rhubarb should be used as directed by the 
manufacture.  
 
Hypochlorhydria:  See the section of this manual covering total serum globulin for 
laboratory patterns, supplemental support and diet requirements.  BUN > 15, but <  20 generally 
indicates hypochlorhydria.  
 
Prescribed Diuretics:  Other tests pertaining to renal function are variable; however, BUN 
and serum potassium are frequently  abnormal.  Irrespective of the BUN or serum potassium levels 
with prescribed diuretic use, thiamine deficiency is very common; therefore, supplementation with 
B6/Bl  (ZI) should be considered.  
Dehydration:  See the section  of this manual  covering  total protein  for laboratory 
patterns, supplemental support and diet requirements.

30 
 Less Common Causes For Increased BUN:  Several types of cancer, diabetes, cirrhosis of the 
liver, congestive heart failure, antibiotic use, eclampsia and pre -eclampsia, benign prostate 
hypertrophy and rheumatoid arthritis.  
 
Common  Causes  for Decreased  BUN:  
 
Protein Malnutrition:  Laboratory patterns, supplemental support and diet requirements 
are listed under the section of this manual covering total protein.  
 
Less Common Causes For Decreased BUN:  Adrenal co1iical hypofunction, gluten sensitivity , 
cystic fibrosis, dysbiosis (complete a comprehensive stool and digestive analysis) and cirrhosis of 
the liver.  
Important  Considerations  With  Abnormal  BUN:  
Although BUN, creatinine and the serum electrolytes can be increased with edema, this 
problem is generally secondary to another metabolic problem (renal, cardiac, endocrine, food 
allergy/sensitivity, etc.); however,  the following supplemental program is generally useful in 
ameliorating the edema:  B6/Bl (ZI) - 1 bid, Horse Chestnut Herb - as directed by the manufacturer,  
Lymphatic Drainage (ZI) – 1 tsp bid.  Additional supplemental support and diet requirements  will 
be determined by the locus (cardiac, renal, allergy, etc.).  
 
BUN increased above 25 mg/dL generally indicates renal dysfunction, however if the 
creatinine is not increased the BUN increase may be due to hypochlorhydria or dehydration.  
In many cases, skin  problems of  unknown origin can  be due to renal dysfunction (kidneys 
are not processing waste correctly and the skin is being used as a secondary organ to eliminate 
toxins from the system).  
 
Kidney Stones (Renal Calculi)  will often cause an increase in BUN, serum creatinine 
and/or abnormal serum electrolytes however, in many cases these tests will be normal. Irrespective 
of the blood values, if a  known problem with kidney stones (renal calculi) is present (subjective 
indications or identification through urinalysis), the following supplemental support and diet 
requirements should be employed:  KI CAPS (ZI) - 1 daily B6/Bl  (ZI) - 1 tid and Magnesium 
Glycerophosphate Tablets (ZI) - at bedtime to b owel tolerance. If the composition of the urinary 
calculi is urate (can be determined by a microscopic examination  of the urine) add C.G.F. (ZI)  – 
3 tid.   Cystine stones are due to a genetic pre -disposition. Recent literature indicates that lipoic 
acid ( LPA Plus – ZI)  at 3 capsules tid is often helpful with cystine stones.  Renal product should 
be considered  – as directed by the manufacture. Eliminate citrus (except lemon), alcohol, gluten, 
dairy products, processed foods, purines (organ meats, shellfish , legumes, pork), parsley, rhubarb, 
spinach, beet tops, carrots, kale and celery.

31 
 SERUM  CREATININE  
 
Discussion:  Creatinine is a waste product formed by spontaneous decomposition of creatine which 
is an intrinsic substance required in the contraction of muscle; therefore patients with increased 
muscle mass may have slightly higher creatinine levels and patients with decreased muscle mass 
(children, older  adults,  men and women with below average muscle mass)  will have slightly lower 
levels of  creatinine.  Because of  increased glomerular filtrations rates,  creatinine is also slightly 
lower than normal during pregnancy. Creatinine differs from BUN in that it is generally not 
influenced by protein intake or sex and is not influenced by conditions that cause excess protein 
breakdown.  Note:  Concentration of creatinine only becomes significantly abnormal when one -
half or more of  the kidney nephrons have stopped functioning.  Thus, serum creatinine is not as 
sensitive an indicator of early renal disease as BUN which increases more rapidly than serum 
creatinine in the early stages of renal disease. Sexual activity, bic ycle riding and golf should be 
avoided for 72 hours prior to running the PSA.  
Related Tests:  BUN, serum uric acid, urinary uric acid, blood electrolytes, liver enzymes, urinary 
creatinine clearance, urinary micro -albumin, serum albumin, serum calcium, HDL cholesterol, 
HCT/HGB, WBC, serum phosphorus, C -reactive protein, PSA and free PSA.  
 
Reference  Range:  Female  .59-1.04 mg/dL;  Male  749-1.35 mg/dL.  Children,  geriatrics  and 
patients with below average muscle mass may normally have a value <  .49. 
 
Optimum  Range:  Same  as laboratory  range.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Above  2.5 mg/dl  indicates  a serious  metabolic  problem.  
 
Common  Causes  For Increased  Serum  Creatinine:  
 
Chronic  Renal  Dysfunction:  See the section  of this manual  cove ring BUN  for 
laboratory changes, supplemental support and diet requirements.  
Renal Hypertension:  See the section of this manual covering renal hypertension listed 
under blood urea nitrogen (BUN).  
Benign Prostate Hypertrophy:  PSA, free PSA and some of  the serum tests for prostate 
that are still under investigation,  may be normal or  abnormal and  all other renal indicators (BUN, 
uric acid, electrolytes, etc.) may be normal. However, if the creatinine is at 1. 4 or higher for a 
normally muscled male over 40 years of age, prostate hypertrophy should be ruled out  via a 
manual exam of the prostate (males with increased muscle mass frequently run levels that are 
normally > 1.4). Often  the creatinine will increase long before the  PSA/free PSA changes occur. 
Prostate hypertrophy can be confirmed by an increase in LDH isoenzyme #4, increased monocytes, 
microscopic examination of the urine for prostate cells, a urinalysis indicating infection and/or the 
most accurate test which is a m anual examination of the prostate.  Also, several subjective 
indications may be present s uch as frequent urination, loss of sex drive, inability to maintain an 
erection, pain on the inside of the ankles and urinary incontinence.

 Benign Prostate Hypertrophy/Prostate  Adenoma: Supplemental Support:   Pumpkin
