(ZI) can be used rectally (use a rectal syringe , at 1capful  in 2 ounces of distilled water every other 
day for 21 days).  The solution should be retained  for 5 -6 minutes.  Also, use Saw palmetto formula 
with lycopene  – as directed by the manufacture and  Arginex – as directed by the manufacture,  If 
the prostate  hypertrophy  is due to infection use, Immune Plus (ZI) – 3 bid, Lymphatic Drainage 
(ZI) – 1 tsp bid and SOD Granules  – as directed by the manufacturer.  If the infection  does not 
clear immediately  ensure  the patient is referred  to a doctor trained in the treatment of this condition.  
Diet:  Use the Roadmap To Health diet, ensure the patient drinks at least 8 -10 full glasses of water 
each day and completely avoids daily products and grams.  
Prostaso l 80 (available on the internet) will decrease PSA but, the evidence that it will 
decrease prostate adenoma is not conclusive.  
 
Less Common Causes For Increased Serum Creatinine:  Several types of cancer, diabetes, 
congestive heart failure, eclampsia and pre -eclampsia, ovarian/uterine dysfunction, acute 
pancreatitis, parathyroid hyperfunction and with acute gout.  
Common Causes For Decreased Serum Creatinine:  Serum creatinine is normally decreased 
with children, patients who have less than average muscle mass and geriatric patients with reduced 
muscle mass.  It is also reduced (normally) during pregnancy.  An abnormal decrease is sometimes 
found with thyroid hyperfunction, muscle wasting diseases (see CPK/CK),  alcoholism, anorexia 
nervosa and cirrhosis of the liver.  
It should  be noted that an increase  in creatinine is not uncommon  with uterine dysfunction  and if 
present C.G.F. (ZI)  – 3 tid,  KI Caps (ZI) -1 daily,  DIM Complex – 2 bid,  Argi nex – as directed 
by the manufacturer.  Micronized Bio -Identical Progesterone Cream (ZI) - ½ to 1 full pump bid 
and SunFlax Complex (ZI) - 2 tid.

prostate dysfunction.

 BUN/CREATININE  RATIO  
Urea  Nitrogen/Creatinine  Ratio  
 
Discussion:  The BUN/Creatinine ratio is useful when assessing patients with chronic renal 
dysfunction . However , the ratio may be skewed when a high normal BUN is present with a low 
normal creatinine or a high normal creatinine with a low normal BUN.  Therefore, the ratio is 
generally  not as valuable diagnostically as the quantitative BUN and creatinine.  
 
Related  Tests:  BUN  and serum  creatinine.  
 
Reference Range:  Ranges vary from laboratory to  laboratory however, most laboratories report 
the reference as between 10 and 22.  
 
Optimum  Range:  10 to 15. 
 
Possible  Panic Range:  Ratios> 30 strongly  suggests  serious renal dysfunction.  Ratios> 36 also 
point to  serious renal dysfunction but, can also indicate upper gastrointestinal bleeding.  
 
Common  Causes  For An Increased  BUN/Creatinine  Ratio:   Congestive  heart  failure, 
intestinal bleeding, shock, hypotension, dehydration and renal disease.  
Common Causes For A Decreased BUN/Creatinine Ratio:  Low protein diets, malnutrition, 
pregnancy (normal), inappropriate secretion of anti -diuretic hormone, certain drugs (cimetidine, 
and trimethoprim) and with antibiotic use.  
 
Important  Considerations  With  An Abnormal  BUN/Creatinine  Ratio:  
 
Inappropriate secretion of anti -diuretic hormone can be due to posterior pituitary dys­ 
function and if present the patient will also frequently have sensitivity to certain foods and to odors 
(perfume, exhaust gas, etc.).  
 
GLOMERULAR  FILTRATION  RATE  
GFR  
 
GFR is the rate at which an ultra-filtrate  of plasma  is produced  by glomeruli  per unit of time.  It 
is an  estimate of  the number of functioning nephrons or  functional renal mass.  The GFR can be 
calculated by several methods but  is generally calculated from the serum creatinine and BUN, the 
patient's age, gender, height and weight and race are used in the calculation.  Although a decreased 
GFR is  an indication of reduced filtering capacity of the kidneys it  is not as  accurate a marker for 
renal function as a urinary creatinine clearance and micro -albumin.  Therefore, when the GFR is 
decreased  more than 10 percent  below the laboratory  range, a creatinine clearance and  micro -
albumin shou ld be considered. GFR  can also be  decreased with  hypothyroidism,  gout, adrenal 
hypofunction, malaria, and hepatic failure.  It can be increased with several types of neoplasm, 
cerebral hemorrhage, bums and pituitary hyperfunction.

34 
 SERUM  URIC  ACID  
UA, Urate  
 
Discussion:  Uric acid is the principal  end product  of purine, nucleic acid and nucleoprotein 
metabolism (ash of the end product of protein utilization and deaminization in the liver).  It is stored 
in the kidneys,  hence the increase along with BUN and creatinine  in renal disease. Reduced oxygen 
levels will activate xanthine oxidase with the end product of xanthine oxidase activation being uric 
acid.  Therefore, reduced oxygen levels will result in increased uric acid levels.  Although purines 
(pork, organ meats, shellfish , legumes, etc.) will increase serum u ric acid, stress and inflammation 
are the most frequent findings with increased uric acid.  
Related Tests:  Serum creatinine, BUN, urinary uric acid, blood electrolytes, liver enzymes, 
MCV/MCH, sedimentation rate, C -reactive protein, gamma globulin, rheumatoid factor, ANA, 
food allergy testing, metal body burden analysis (RBC, hair, urine), urinary micro -albumin  and 
urinary creatinine clearance.  
 
Reference  Range:  Males  - 3.7 to 8.6 mg/dL  (serum)  
Females -2.5 to 7.1 mg/dL  (serum)  
Males  and Females  - 250 to 750 mg/24  hour urine.  
Note:  An increase  in serum  uric acid during  childhood  is normal.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Males - 3.5 to 5.9 mg/dL  (serum).  
Females  - 3.0 to 5.5 mg/dL  (serum).  
Note:  For urine  uric acid use the laboratory  range.  
 
Possible Panic Range:  Values< 3.0 mg/dL generally indicate either a chronic vitamin B -12 or 
molybdenum need and values> 9.0 mg/dL indicate severe hyperuricemia and require immediate 
attention.  
 
Common  Causes  For Increased  Serum  Uric  Acid:  
 
Gout:  Liver enzymes will be increased in the acute phase, serum creatinine increased, 
urinary creatinine clearance decreased, serum phosphorus decreased, white blood count  increased,  
serum  triglycerides  increased  in more than 75 percent  of the cases,  CRP  increased, and  BUN  
increased  with renal  failure,  however  the changes  in BUN  may be slow. Supplemental  Support:

juice daily),  Sympathetic Balance (ZI)  - 2 bid, C.G.F.  (ZI) - 3 tid, Lithium  Orotate  
(ZI) – 1 qid, 8X Pancreatin  (ZI) - 1 qid on an empty  stomach  for 7-10 days than 1 bid on 
an empty stomach,  Argi nex – as directed by the manufacturer,  Stress  HP (ZI) - 15 drops  tid and 
HCL  Complete  (ZI) - begin  with 1 in the  middle o f the meal  and increase every  other  day to 
stomach  tolerance.  If more than 4 are needed, rule out zinc, thiamine and salt need.  With  some  
patients  8X Pancreatin  at 2-3 qid on an empty stomach will by itself resolve gout. Diet:  Ensure 
all refined carbohydrates,  gluten, dairy products, foods high in starch, fruit juice, alcohol,

 TOTAL  SERUM  PROTEIN  
Total  Protein,  Serum  
 
Discussion:  Total protein is the combination of albumin and total globulin; therefore the total 
protein value will be affected by the albumin and total globulin.  It is possible to have a normal 
total protein with an abnormal total globulin or albumin.  Example - following an acute phase 
stimulus such  as infection or  trauma, many liver  derived proteins increase in  concentration,  while 
albumin decreases.  Thus, while the total serum protein concentration can remain the same in acute 
phase reactions, the composi tion of the albumin and globulin are affected.  
 
Related  Tests:  Albumin,  total serum  globulin,  liver enzymes,  WBC  and differential,  serum 
protein electrophoresis (SPE), serum gastrin, IgA, IgM, IgG, IgE, HCT and HGB.  
Reference  Range:  N01mal  ranges  vary,  but most laboratories  use 6.0 to 8.3 g/dL.  
 
Optimum  Range:  6.6 to 7.4 g/dL.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  5.9 g/dL  or above  8.8 g/dL.  
 
Common  Causes  for Increased  Serum  Total  Protein:  
 
Digestive  Dysfunction  (Hypochlorhydria  Due to Increased  Total  Serum  Globulin):  See 
the section of this manual covering total serum globulin for laboratory changes,  supplemental  
support and diet requirements.  
 
Dehydration:  Albumin increased (reason for total protein increase), serum chloride 
increased, serum creatinine increased, HGB and HCT increased, BUN increased, MCV/MCH 
sometimes increased.  Supplemental Support:  Increase pure water intake to not less than 8 -10 full  
glasses  daily and if  the patient  is unable  to maintain  the water  (frequent urination)  add S.O.S. (ZI) 
– 3 tid, L-Glutamine  – as directed by the manufacturer,  and 1 teaspoon daily of Hydrate 
II (ZI), to increase cellular hydration.  If the patient requires sodium add one teaspoon of Celtic 
Sea Salt daily to their diet.  
 
Less Common Causes For Increased Total Serum Protein:  Diabetes, adrenal cortical 
hypofunction, several types of cancer, liver/biliary dysfunction, rheumatoid arthritis, amino acid 
need , and hypochlorhydria.  Total protein is a combination of albumin and total globulin.  
Therefore, when the total protein is  increased, the cause may be due to  an increase in  total globulin 
therefore the nexus for the increase is either hypochlorhydria  or an increase in alpha 1,  2, beta or 
gamma globulin.

 SERUM  ALBUMIN  
Albumin,  Serum  
 
Discussion:  Albumin is produced almost entirely by the liver; therefore, liver function has a major 
influence on albumin production and serum albumin levels.  Albumin is responsible for about 80  
percent of  the colloid -osmotic  pressure between blood and tissue  fluids.  When albumin is 
decreased, osmotic pressure is disturbed.  Decreased albumin is always an indication of significant 
liver or  immune dysfunction and in  many cases;  decreased albumin indicates frank or developing 
free radical pathology  (neoplasm).  According to the peer reviewed literature, patients admitted to  
the hospital with decreased serum albumin have a  greater chance of  dying in the hospital than 
patients with normal serum albumin  
Related Tests:  Albumin/globulin ratio, total protein, total globulin, serum protein electro­ phoresis 
(SPE),  liver enzymes, WBC  and differential, alpha 1  glycoproteins,  CEA  and other  tests used to 
confirm neoplasm.  
 
Reference  Range:  3.5-5.0 g/dL.  
 
Optimum  Range:  4.0-4.5 g/dL.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  < 3.5 g/dL.  
 
Common  Causes  for Increased  Serum  Albumin:  
 
Dehydration:  See total protein.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  for Increased  Serum  Albumin:  Thyroid  and/or  adrenal  hypofunction.  
 
Common  Causes  for Decreased  Serum  Albumin:  
 
Liver/Biliary  Dysfunction:  See SGPT/ALT  and GGTP Free Radical Pathology (Neoplasm)

decreased from the patient's historical average (untreated with statin drugs). For further information concerning

 TOTAL  SERUM  GLOBULIN  
Globulin,  Total  
 
Discussion:  Total globulin  is a combination  of the alpha  1, alpha 2, beta and gamma fractions 
and most laboratories calculate the total serum globulin by subtracting the serum albumin from the 
total serum protein.  An increase or decrease in any of these fractions (alpha 1, alpha 2, beta and/or 
gamma) will cause an increase or decrease in the total globulin.  For this reason, care must  be 
taken  when  making  a diagnosis  based  upon  the total  globulin  alone.  Total  globulin is useful 
with other tests for assessing degenerative, inflammatory and infectious processes and wit h BUN, 
serum phosphorus, serum gastrin, urinary indican, subjective indicators and other  tests located 
below to confirm a need for HCl.  
 
Related Tests:  Albumin, A/G ratio, serum total protein, serum protein electrophoresis (SPE), 
serum gastrin, liver enzymes, sedimentation rate, WBC and differential, alpha 1 glycoproteins, 
BUN, urinary indican, C -reactive protein, CEA and other tests used to  confirm neoplasm.  
 
Reference  Range:  Most  laboratories  indicate  the reference  range  between  2.0 or 1.5 and 
4.5 g/dL.  
 
Optimum Range:  2.4-2.7 g/dL. Note:  Total globulin values below 2.4 or above 2.7 suggest a need 
for HCl or digestive inflammation secondary to a need for HCl.  The need for HCl or the presence 
of digestive inflammation  secondary  to a need for HCl should always be confirmed with subjective  
indications such as loss of taste for meat, gas, bloating, bad breath, etc.

above 3.5, consideration should be  given to  completing a  serum protein electrophoresis (SPE) to 
ascertain the location of the increase or decrease.

protein  normal  to decreased,  MCV increased above  89.9 with the MCH  sometimes increased

Heidelberg Gastro -Telemetry testing is the most accurate means of determining both hyper 
and hypochlorhydria.  
Increased urinary indican  is an excellent means  for determining protein putrefaction and 
carbohydrate fermentation.  Both protein putrefaction and carbohydrate fermentation will be 
present with HCl need as well as biliary and pancreatic insufficiency.  
 
According to Louis Rubel, M.D. (The G.P. and the Endocrine Glands) serum globulin will 
increase in protein malnutrition and HCl need for the following  reason:  Albumin is  formed in the 
liver and is the supply of available protein to the body cells.  As serum albumin is withdrawn from 
the peripheral cells in order to maintain an adequate supply of available protein in  the blood stream 
globulin, which is  a larger molecule, it  is also pulled from the protoplasm of the peripheral cells. 
Hence; there is a rise in the serum globulin levels.  Dr. Rubel indicated that when the serum globulin 
level was  at 3.0 g/100 mL,  or higher, the need for HCl supplementation and additional protein in 
the diet was certain.  Later research, using the Biochemical Blood Biopsy, i ndicated that Dr. Rubel's 
original research was probably conservative concerning increased globulin levels.  As indicated 
previously, our research suggests that when the serum globulin is<  2.4 or>  2.7, HCl need must be 
ruled out.  
 
Sodium, thiamine, and zinc  are required in  the production of hydrochloric  acid therefore, a 
long term need for hydrochloric  acid is frequently  due to a need for one or more of the following 
nutrients.  If long term need is present;  consider supplementing the patient with  Celtic sea salt, 
and C.G.F. (ZI ) - contains the thiamine and B complex co -factors) and Zinc Orotate (ZI) - 
Alkaline phosphatase or the zinc taste test (ZTT) can be used to identify zinc deficiency, CO2 and 
anion gap can be used to identify t hiamine need and serum chloride can be used to identify sea salt 
need.

46 
 ALBUMIN -GLOBULIN  RATIO  
A/G Ratio  
 
Discussion:  The value of  the A/G Ratio is  limited because of the countless number of  variables 
in the components comprising total globulin (alpha 1, alpha 2, beta and gamma). An abnormal 
A/G ratio,  often called a  suppressed, low  or reversed ratio,  is generally considered a  reflection of 
hepatic dysfunction.  
 
Related  Test:  Albumin,  total globulin,  serum  protein  electrophoresis  and the liver  enzymes.  
 
Reference  Range:  1.1 to 2.5 
 
Optimum  Range:  1.5 to 2.0 
 
Possible  Panic Range:  < 1.0 
 
Common Causes  For Increased  A/G Ratio:  An increased  ratio  is not considered  significant.  
 
Common Causes For Decreased A/G Ratio:  Liver/biliary dysfunction, chronic renal disease, 
several  types  of cancer, sarcoidosis, collagen diseases, severe infections, systemic inflammation, 
burns and digestive inflammation.  
 
Important  Considerations  With  An Abnormal  A/G Ratio:  
 
Some researchers feel that an  increased A/G Ratio suggests blood stasis and a decreased 
A/G Ratio suggests the blood is too thin.  
 
The most  precise A/G  Ratio  is obtained  by completing  a serum  protein  electrophoresis.

47 
 ALPHA  1 GLOBULIN  
 
Discussion:  See the section  of this manual  covering  serum  protein  electrophoresis  (SPE)  for 
information covering this fraction.  
Related Tests:  Albumin, alpha 2, beta and gamma globulin, serum protein electrophoresis,  total 
serum globulin, liver enzymes, C -reactive protein, WBC and differential, alpha 1 glycoprotein, 
AMAS, various CEA tests, acid phosphatase, alpha fetoprotein, HcG, alpha 1 antitrypsin factor, 
LDH and LDH isoenzymes, CPK and ALP isoenzymes.  
 
Reference  Range  (g/100  mL): 0.10-0.40 g/dL.  
 
Optimum  Range:  0.20-0.30 g/dL 
 
 
Possible  Alarm  Range:  Below  0.10 or above  0.35 g/dL 
 
Common Causes  for Increased  Alpha  1 Globulin:  
 
Tissue  Destruction  And Tissue  Destruction  Due to Neoplasm:  See serum  protein 
electrophoresis (SPE), serum albumin, serum cholesterol and lymphocytes.  
 
Severe  Tissue  Inflammation:  See serum  protein  electrophoresis  (SPE),  gamma 
globulin, sedimentation rate, C -reactive protein and basophils.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  Of Alpha  1 Globulin  Increase:  Peptic  ulcer,  renal  dysfunction, systemic 
lupus erythematosis (SLE), several types of rheumatoid arthritis, depression and catabolic protein 
loss. 
 
Common  Causes  for Decreased  Alpha  1 Globulin:  
 
Emphysema:   See eosinophils.  
 
Reduced  Alpha  1 Antitrypsin  Factor:  See eosinophils  for treatment of  emphysema.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  Of Alpha  1 Globulin  Decrease:   Hepatitis,  gout,  liver and renal 
dysfunction.

48 
 Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Alpha 1  Globulin:  
 
Alpha  1 Antitrypsin  normally  accounts  for about  60 percent  of the total  alpha  1 
globulin.  It inhibits trypsin and when greatly decreased can indicate the patient is  suffering with 
emphysema. Since Alpha 1 Antitrypsin  accounts  for about 60 percent  of the total alpha 1 globulin 
therefore, a decreased alpha 1 globulin is frequently due to a decreased Alpha 1 Antitrypsin.  
Therefore, a reduction in the alpha 1 globulin indicates a probable reduction in the alpha 1  
antitrypsin factor and trypsin containing supplements should be avoi ded. 
 
Alpha  1 Glycoprotein  accounts for less than 30 percent  of the total alpha 1 globulin; but 
is frequently responsible for an increase in the total alpha 1 globulin.  It is increased in severe 
inflammatory  problems, degenerative disease and in a number of different malignant diseases (see 
the section of this manual covering serum protein electrophoresis  for further information).

49 
 ALPHA  2 GLOBULIN  
 
Discussion:  See the section  of this manual  covering  serum  protein  electrophoresis  (SPE)  for 
information covering this fraction.  
Related Tests:  Albumin, alpha 1, beta and gamma globulin, serum protein electrophoresis,  total 
serum globulin, liver enzymes, C -reactive protein, WBC and differential, alpha 1 glycoproteins, 
alpha 1 antitrypsin factor, AMAS, several of the CEA tests, acid phosphatase, alpha feto -protein 
(AFP), HcG, LDH (LD), CPK (CK) and the isoenzymes of alka line phosphatase (ALP).  
 
Reference  Range  (g/100  mL):  0.40-1.20 g/dL 
 
Optimum  Range:  0.60 to  0.90 g/dL 
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  0.30 or above  1.20 g/dL 
Common  Causes  for Increased  Serum  Alpha  2 Globulin:  
 
Asthma:  See eosinophils  for supplemental  support.  
 
Tissue Destruction and Tissue Destruction Due To Neoplasm:  See serum protein 
electrophoresis (SPE), serum albumin, serum cholesterol and blood lymphocytes for laboratory 
changes, supplemental support and diet requirements (supplemental support and diet requirements 
are listed under the section of this manual covering serum albumin).  
 
Severe Tissue Inflammation:  See the section of this manual covering serum protein 
electrophoresis, gamma globulin, C -reactive protein, sedimentation rate and blood basophils for 
further information on inflammation.  For laboratory changes, supplemental support and diet 
requirements see the section of this manual covering C -reactive protein.  
Less Common Causes For Increased Serum Alpha 2  Globulin:  Diabetes, parathyroid hyper­ 
function, catabolic protein loss, peptic ulcer, liver dysfunction, renal dysfunction, SLE, 
dermatomyositis , rheumatoid arthritis and depression.  
Common  Causes  For Decreased  Serum  Alpha  2 Globulin:  Gout,  hepatitis  and other  liver 
dysfunctions.  
 
Important  Considerations  With  An Abnormal  Serum  Alpha  2 Globulin:  
 
Alpha 2 Macroglobulin  normally accounts for about 25 percent of the total alpha 2 
globulin.  It is generally increased in renal dysfunction, gastric inflammation or damage where 
protein loss is significant and with liver cirrhosis  and diabetes.

50 
 Important  Considerations  with  An Abnormal  Serum  Alpha -2 Globulin  Continued:  
 
Ceruloplasmin  is a copper oxidase enzyme that is part of alpha 2 globulin.  It is used in 
the transport of copper to tissues  and in the formation of hemoglobin.  It is increased in Wilson's 
disease (brain and liver), Menkes' syndrome and nutritional deficiency.  It is an acute phase reactant 
and as such is increased in infections, malignancy, pregnancy, with estrogen therapy and in trauma.  
 
Haptoglobin  accounts for about 25 percent  of the total alpha 2  globulin.  When the alpha 
2 globulin is increased the most common reason for the increase is an increase in haptoglobin. 
Haptoglobin is an acute phase reactant and increases in the presence of inflammation, tissue 
necrosis and tissue destruction.  
 
Alpha 1 Globulin and Alpha 2 Globulin Differences with Emphysema and Asthma:  
With emphysema  the alpha 1 globulin  will generally  be decreased  with a normal  alpha 2 globulin. 
With asthma the alpha 2 globulin will generally be increased with a normal alpha 1 globulin. 
Therefore, by using the alpha 1 and alpha 2 globulin a reasonable differentiation  between 
emphysema and asthma can be made.

51 
 BETA  GLOBULIN  
 
Discussion:  See the section of  this manual covering serum protein electrophoresis  (SPE) for 
information covering this fraction.  
 
Related Tests:  Albumin, alpha 1, alpha 2 and gamma globulin, serum protein electrophoresis, total 
serum globulin, liver enzymes, lipid electrophoresis, WBC and differential, LDH, CPK and ALP 
isoenzymes.  
 
Reference  Range:  0.60-1.30 g/dL 
 
Optimum  Range:  0.70-1.00 g/dL 
 
Possible  Alarm  Range:  Below  0.40 or> 1.40 g/dL.  
 
Common Causes for Increased Beta Globulin:  See the section in this manual covering serum 
protein electrophoresis (SPE) for information  concerning  increases in beta globulin and alpha 2 to 
beta globulin bridging as seen on the serum protein electrophoresis graph.  
 
Common Causes for Decreased Beta Globulin:  Sometimes with protein malnutrition and liver  
dysfunction.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  Beta  Globulin:  
 
Transferrin  is a glycoprotein that binds iron and is  part of the total beta globulin. It is an 
iron transport protein which binds iron released during hemoglobin catabolism as well as iron 
absorbed through the intestine and  transports it  to the liver and RES for storage.  It is responsible 
for 50 -70 percent of the iron binding capacity of the serum and is decreased in chronic 
inflammation, hereditary anemia, liver disease, several types of cancer and renal disease.  It is 
increased in iron anemia, in patients on exogenous estrogen and during late pregnancy (estrogen 
effect).  
 
Beta Lipoprotein  normally accounts for about 60 percent of the beta globulin.  It is 
responsible for transporting most of the serum lipids.  Because the protein content of Beta 
Lipoprotein  is low (about  25 percent),  marked  changes  can occur  in this value with little effect 
on the total beta globulin.  
 
Complement  Proteins  are part of the beta globulin and are discussed  in the section of 
this manual covering serum protein electrophoresis (SPE).  
 
An increase  of beta globulin  is seen  frequently  with demineralization of  bones  and soft tissue, 
possibly due to  an increase in the blood fats and C -Complement (inflammation).

52 
 GAMMA  GLOBULIN  
 
Discussion:  See the section  of this manual  covering  serum  protein  electrophoresis  (SPE)  for 
information covering this fraction.  
 
Related Tests:  Albumin, alpha 1,  alpha 2 and beta globulin, serum protein electrophoresis,  total 
serum globulin, liver  enzymes, WBC  and differential, LDH  (LD), CPK (CK), C -reactive Protein, 
fibrinogen, sedimentation rate and ALP isoenzymes. See SPE graphs if a  spike is present in the 
gamma range.  
Reference  Range:  0.60-1.60 g/dL 
Optimum  Range:  1.00-1.50 g/dL.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  0.50 or above 1.90  g/dL 
 
Common  Causes  for Increased  Serum  Gamma  Globulin:  
 
Non-Specific Inflammatory Conditions:  See alpha 1, alpha 2 and beta globulin, 
basophils, serum protein electrophoresis, sedimentation rate, serum albumin, total protein, 
fibrinogen, C -reactive protein and total serum globulin.  With non -specific inflammation the 
basophil count will almost always be increased (with inflammation, basophils deliver heparin to the 
effected tissue to prevent clotting).  The C -reactive protein will also be increased.  For supplemental 
support, laboratory changes and diet requirements see the section of this manual covering C -reactive 
protein.  
 
Hepatitis -Mononucleosis:  See the liver enzymes, WBC and differential  and the section of 
this manual covering serum protein electrophoresis.  Laboratory  changes, supplemental  support 
and diet requirements for hepatitis and mononucleosis  are covered  under the liver enzyme section 
of this manual.  
 
Digestive  Inflammation:  See serum  total protein.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  of Serum  Gamma  Globulin  increase:  Intestinal  parasites,  protein 
malnutrition, congestive heart failure, liver dysfunction, SLE and other free radical pathologies.  
Common  Causes  for Decreased  Serum  Gamma  Globulin:  
Chronic Immune Deficiency Due to a Chronic Bacterial Or Viral Infection:  Albu­ min 
decreased, HCT and HGB decreased, total WBC decreased,  MCV  increased,  platelets normal to 
decreased, lymphocytes normal to decreased.  Laboratory changes, supplemental support and diet 
requirements are covered under the total WBC section of this manual.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  for Decreased  Gamma  Globulin:  Renal  disease,  respiratory  distress 
with infection, depression, and several types of cancer.

53 
 Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal Serum  Gamma  Globulin:  
 
IgA, IgG,  IgM,  IgD and IgE are all fractions  of the total gamma  globulin.  
 
IgA normally  accounts for about 12 percent of the total gamma globulin.  This fraction may 
be estimated from the degree of depression on the serum protein electrophoresis graph between 
beta and gamma globulin.  IgA contains anti -toxins, anti -bacterial agents and isoagglutins. It is 
increased in hepatic dysfunction, diabetes, food sensitivity and moderately increased with 
inflammation.  
IgG normally  accounts for about 85 percent of the total gamma globulin. It is best estimated 
by the peak slightly to  the right of  center of  the total gamma globulin region as  seen on the serum 
protein electrophoresis graph.  Increases are seen with chronic inflammation, food sensitivity and 
proliferative disease such as pneumonia, T.B., cystitis, collagen disease, mononucleosis, hepatitis 
and some cases of intestinal parasites.  These elevations should not be confused with a monoclonal 
gammopathy (graph indic ates more than one gamma peak).  
 
IgE plays an important role in allergic response.  This protein is found in very low 
concentrations  in the serum and is also found on circulating basophils and mast cells (mast cells 
are a primary carrier for histamine).  It is increased in allergy/sensitivity and parasites.  
 
IgM and IgD will generally increase and decrease along with IgG in relation to 
inflammation.  
 
Organic EFAs (SunFlax Complex ( ZI) or Pumpkin Seed Oil (ZI) and thymus Immune 
Plus (ZI)  are generally effective for increasing gamma globulin.  This is especially true with 
children who suffer with chronic immune deficiency problems and inner ear infections.

54 
 SERUM  PROTEIN  ELECTROPHORESIS   
 
 
. . . .  . .. . .. . ....  .  .. .··........  ... . . .. , ..  . 
SPE, Serum  Electrophoresis , lmmunoelect rophoresis  
 
 
Discussion:  Modern  electrophoresis  has been  used extensively in  the healing  arts for the analysis 
of various  body  fluids  and tissues,  including  many  of the plasma  and serum  fractions  discussed  in 
this manual.  On the following  pages  we will limit our discussion  to those  fractions  widely  used,  
alpha  1, alpha  2, beta  and gamma  globulin  and their  components, the  specific  globulins of  the total 
protein complex.  
 
When ordering a serum protein electrophoresis (SPE) always request the  tracing and if  possible 
request  the laboratory  complete  the SPE manually.  The shape  and form  of the curves (see the 
pages that f ollow for examples of abnormal patterns) will often provide valuable  diagnostic 
information  not available from quantitative information alone. The  shape and form of the curves are  
much easier to see and interpret  on a tracing that  has been completed  manually.  
 
Electrophoresis is essentially a study of the migrating characteristics  of charged particles through 
conducting solutions in a controlled  voltage field.  On the graph, changes  in particle migration 
characteristics  are seen as slurring, bridging,  etc. That is, a portion of  the protein may be  slightly 
altered by metabolic dysfunction  and will then migrate at a slightly different speed.  The affected 
molecules  will be seen on the densitometer  graph  as a change  in the expected  peak,  slurring  of one 
peak into the following peak,  a dual peak rather than  a single peak, etc.  
 
On the tracing, the slowest  migration of  molecules is  in the  gamma region and the  fastest is  in the 
albumin region.  
 
With the exception of the albumin fraction of the SPE the graph can generally be viewed as a 
representation of inflammation and destruction in body  tissues . Elevations in the gamma region 
represent primarily inflammation and elevations in the alpha  1 region represent primarily 
destruction (exception - the alpha l  globulin  will elevate in severe inflammation).  This observation 
indicates  that molecules resulting from inflammation  migrate more slowly than  molecules  from tissue 
destruction . 
 
The following  chart indicates  the average percentage of tissue inflammation  and destruction seen 
with elevations  in the alpha  1, alpha  2, beta and gamma  regions.  Here  we are speaking  of the 
percentage  of protein  molecules  above  the normal  level,  not the ratios  of normal  protein 
concentration or the percentage of patients who represent elevations in these various regions with 
tissue inflammation or destruction.  Simply stated, elevations in  the gamma region are generally  
due to inflammation and elevations in the  alpha  1 region are generally due to destruction.  Neither  
 inflammation nor destruction  of the tissue can be found alon e, inflammation always has some 
destruction present and  destruction always has some infl ammation present.

55 
  
Destruction   Inflammation  
 
Alpha  I 70-90¾ 10-30% 
Alpha 2  55-65¾ 35-45%.  
Beta 40-50% 50-60% 
Gamma  10-30% 70-90% 
 
Most of the abnormal elevations in the alpha 1 region are due to the carbohydrate content of the molecule 
(proteins released into the blood stream by the tissue destruction bind a greater number of carbohydrate 
molecules than molecules released due to inflammation (gamma region).  Tissue inflammation represents 
an increase in antibody production in response to an antigen challenge.  
Protein released  into the  blood stream  by malignant_ tissue generally  contains a higher carbo -­ hydrate 
content (hexose, a six carbon sugar), than do proteins from non-malignant  tissue. Therefore,  
malignancy  will almost  always  produce  elevations  in the alpha -I and occasionally in the alpha -2 
region.  By using  the alpha  l glycoprotein  which  will bind more  hexose than the a1pha - l globulin, 
a differentiation between  benign  and malignant  destruction can  often be made; In other words,  jf the 
alpha 1 region is increased in conjunction with an increase in the alpha - I glycoprotein, the  possibility 
of malignancy  must be  ruled  out. 
 
C-Complement  Proteins  are more sensitive  to inflammation  than the globulin  (beta  globulin) 
they are a component  of. Therefore , if the C -complement  proteins are normal or decreased,  it is 
reasonable  to suspect that although  inflammation  may be present, the inflammation  is probably not  
acute. However,  if the C -complement  proteins are increased , acute inflammation  is almost certain and 
will generally be  confirmed by  a significant  increase in the  gamma globulin.  
 
After reviewing more than 20,000 different blood chemistries using the previously mentioned 
criteria, A. Furda, Ph.D and his group  of researchers. (The Biochemical Biopsy) classified  abnormal  
tissue  activity into  the areas indicated be1ow.  After  reviewing several thousand of  these chemistries, 
we interviewed sever al physicians who used the test and  although the  accuracy was not 100 percent , 
it proved to be high enough to warrant  further investigation when one of the  following  protein 
patterns was present.

56 
  
Susceptibility  Or Proneness  To Malignancy:  Three  criteria  are used in this 
determination and all must be present together.  They are:  
An increased  or high normal alpha 1  glycoprotein  (60 -75 mg percent).  
An increased  or high  normal  alpha  I globulin (above  0.30 but, below  0.35). 
An increased  or high normal  alpha  2 globulin  (above 0.60  but, below  0.95).  
The increased  or high normal  values  of these  proteins  are not due to elevated  protein  molecules;  
but, are due to an increased  ratio of hexose  to protein  in the molecules.  These  findings  may 
fluctuate  but, they must  be present  simultaneously  to identify  the malignant prone individual . This 
patient  may or may not develop  a frank  neoplasm as they get older. However, after following many 
of these patients over a 10 year period, we concluded that a significant number of the patients did 
develop neoplasm, but the number was lower in patients who after being advised they were malignant 
prone, qui t smoking, avoided a highly refined diet, exercised routinely and used stress control 
techniques.  
    
Premalignancy:  This pattern  presents  changes  that are slightly different  in degree  and constancy  
from  those seen  with the patient  who is susceptible  or prone  to malignancy .  The findings 
generally do not fluctuate and as time goes o n, they will  become more  apparent (unless treatment 
has been initia ted and is  successful).  Ultimately (unless treated), the pattern will most often progress  
to the  criteria seen  with frank malignancy.  These  findings may fluctuate, but they must be present  
simultaneously to identify the  patient with  a premalignancy.  
Alpha  glycoprotein  increased  above  75 mg percent. 
Alpha 1 globulin increased above 0.35.  
Alpha  2 globulin  increased  above  0.95.  
In those cases where this pattern  was observed, treatment frequently allowed the blood values to 
return  to a normal level.  
 
Presence  Of Malignancy:  Irrespective of  whether  the malignancy has  been  identified,  if the 
following  pattern  is present, further investigation is warranted.  This pattern has been seen 
frequently with patients later identified with a frank malignancy.   
Alpha  l glycoprotein  increased.  above  l00 mg percent. 
Alpha  1 globulin  increased  above  the reference range. 
Alpha  2 globulin increased above the  reference  range.  
When  these findings  present simultaneously, the doctor should  take further action to  rule out 
malignancy  (the various CEA tests, acid  phosphatase,  alpha fetoprote in, Anti-Malig nin Antibody 
(AMA), human chorionic  gonadotrophin  and other  tests designed  to identify  malignancy).  The 
location of  the malignancy can often be determined  through an examination of  the CPK (CK) or 
LDH (LD)  isoenzymes  which correlate with a destructive process.  The isoenzymes of ALP  more 
closely relate to inflammation  and although useful  in locating the suspected lesion,  they are not 
reliable as the isoenzymes of  CPK (CK) and LDH (LD).

57 
 - .  
Tissue  Necrosis  Due.  To Abscess:  This problem  will generally  produce  a marked  increase 
in the haptoglobin  region  of alpha  2 globulin  with a normal  or slightly  increased  alpha  1 globulin. 
Location  of the abscess  can often  be made  by examination  of the CPI(  (CK),  LDH  (LD)  and ALP 
isoenzymes,  
 
Benign  Tumor  Activity:  Benign tumor  activity  (benign  space  occupying lesion) should 
be suspected when the following criteria are present:   
Borderline  increase  of alpha  l globulin.  
Moderate  increase  of alpha  2 globulin.   
These changes are due to pressure created by the space occupying lesion (tumor, cyst, etc.), on surrounding tissue.  
Localization of the lesion can frequently be made by an assessment  of the CPK (CK),  LDH  (LO) and ALP  
isoenzymes.  
Tissue Destruction Due To Auto -Immune Processes:  Tissue destruction to due 
autoimmune  problems  is most reliably determined  by review  of the Lipid  electrophoresis.  In an 
autoimmune  problem there is generally a marked increase in the alpha region of the lipid 
electrophoresis  along  with decreased  or low normal  cholesterol  (beta  region) and  a decreased  or 
low normal  triglycerides  (pre beta region).  In other  words,  with a destructive  autoimmune  
process,  the HDL  (alpha  region) will be increased (in relation  to the total cholesterol) and the 
cholesterol  and/or  triglycerides  will be decreased or low normal.  
Hormonal dysfunction  Due To Auto -Immune Processes:  HDL makes up about 70 
percent  by weight of  the cell membrane and about  40 percent by weight  of the  myelin  sheath  
and is required  in the formation and  transport  of hormones.  Phospholipids  (HDL)are  also carriers  
for cholesterol  and triglycerides.  The  most  common  pattern  observed  with hormone  dysfunction  
due to  an auto -immune  problem is  a normal to  low normal  cholesterol  with the triglycerides  
significantly reduced in relation  to the cholesterol and the  HDL  cholesterol significantly  
increased in relation  to the cholesterol.  The phospholipid  (HDL)  carrier  is present, but  the 
substance to be carried (hormones)  is insufficient .  This pattern  does not identify  the location  
of specific  hormone (s) insufficiency  only that there  is a hormonal  problem . 
• 
 
 
 
Bone,  muscle  and hemolytic  involvement  in autoimmune  destruction  can generally  be 
identified as follows:   
Bone  Involvement:  Increased  ALP bone  isoenzyme.  
Muscle  Involvement:  Increased  CPK  (CK)  muscle  isoenzyme  
Hemolytic  Involvement:  Increase  in the first and second  isoenzyme  of LDH  (LD).

58 
  
Diseases  Of The Digestive  System:  Dysfunction  in the digestive  tract will always 
produce the  following changes:  
Depression  of the haptoglobin  region of alpha  2 globulin. 
Increase in  the intestinal isoenzyme  of ALP.  
If there  is an increase  in alpha  1 globulin,  we know  that a destructive  process  is present , if there  is 
an increase  in the gamma  globulin,  we know  inflammation  is present.  If only the gamma  globulin 
is increased  the problem is most  likely still  in an inflammatory phase  and there is probably  no 
active  tissue  damage, or  ulceration ( normal  alpha  l globulin)  The presence  of severe  tissue  
inflammation, tissue damage or ulceration can be confirmed with serum gastrin.  
Liver  Dysf unction Due to Fatty Changes or Congestion :  Polyclonal patterns in the 
gamma  globulin tracing  combined  with increase  in the slow -moving  liver isoenzyme  of ALP 
(ALP  al), suggests  a fatty  or congested liver.  Liver congestion will also produce a decrease 
in serum  albumin .  I f  the liver dysfunction is due to biliary obstruction , the fast-moving  
liver isoenzyme of  ALP (ALP a2) will often be present . If the problem is chronic, there 
will be bridging  between  the beta and gamma  globulin  fractions  on the SPE tracing.  
 
Disease Of The Gall Bladder And Biliary T ree: If the following criteria are present, 
disease  of the gall bladder,  pancreas  or Common  bile duct is probable  : 
normal  gamma  globulin,  increased  haptoglobin  region  of alpha  2 globulin. 
Increase  in the transferrin region  of beta globulin.  
If this pattern  is present  with an increase  in the third  and fifth isoenzyme  of LDH  (LD)  gall 
bladder  disease  is probable.  If this pattern  is present  with an increase  in the first and fifth 
isoenzyme of LDH -(LD),  disease  of the common  bile duct is probable . If this pattern  is present  
and the fast liver isoenzyme  of ALP (ALP  a2)is  present,  biliary  obstruction is probable.  
Disease  Of The Pancreas:  An increase  in the haptoglobin  region  of alpha -2 -globulin  and the 
transferrin region of  beta globulin will be present.  In many cases, bridging on the  serum protein 
electrophoresis tracing  between alpha l  and alpha 2 globulin will  also be present.  
Hepatitis:  Hepatitis is  best determined  by the various blood tests used to identify  this 
problem; howev er, the following  additional information can be  used to track  the progression of 
the disease.  Generally,  there  will be  a peaking in  the gamma globulin region.  The peak  can be 
used to monitor  progression  of the problem  from  the acute  phase  to either  the chronic  phase  (very 
dangerous) or resolution.  In uncomplicated cases  the gamma  globulin  region  will begin to  
normalize  in about  30 days or less depending upon  the supplemental program  used.  However,  if 
the gamma globulin peak broadens and develops into a polyclonal tracing , a persistence of 
inflammation  is indicated.  Lymphatic  infiltration  in this region  is responsible  for the  change  from 
a single peak to the polyclonal peaks.  When the infectious process progresses to liver 
parenchymal cell necrosis, the fifth isoenzyme of  LDH (LD) will begin to increase.  As the  
necrosis subsides, it will  begin to  return to  normal.

59 
 Mononucleosis:  Mononucleosis produces changes in the gamma globulin region  that are 
similar to those seen with hepatitis.  Differentiation between mononucleosis and hepatitis can be 
made through blood tests designed to identify mononucleosis.  
 
 
 Corona ry Artery Disease : The following changes  will generally be present : A "split pre -
beta" pattern on the  lipid electrophoresis graph  (a split in the pre-beta curve) will be present. There 
will be a  broadening of  the alpha  2 globulin  region if angi na is present . The alpha 2 globulin  may 
be increased , decreased  or normal;  but the broad  alpha-2 curve  will be present.   There will be a 
mild increase in the first isoenzyme of  LDH/LD (it will be even with or slightly higher than the third 
isoenzyme of LDH/LD).  A rise in heart isoenzyme of CPK occurs as the usually remains within 
normal limits until the heart attack occurs.  
Rheumatic  Heart  Disease:  Indicated by an increase  of alpha  2 globulin,  a mild increase 
in the fifth  isoenzyme of  LDH/LD and the presence of a "split pr e-beta”  curve on the lipid 
electrophoresis tracing  The CPK heart  isoenzyme  will increase  when the disease process is active 
with this change  differentiating the active from the dormant stage of rheumatic  heart disease.  
 
 Congestive  Heart  Disease:  Sub-acute  or very early  congestive  heart  failure  will generally 
produce a "split pre-beta” curve on the lipid electrophoresis  and a  mild increase of the first  and 
fifth isoenzyme of  LDH/LD.  As the disease  progresses,  the heart isoenzyme of  CPK will increase  
and a decrease will be seen in the serum albumin and in the beta  .and gamma globulin regions of   
the serum  protein electrophoresis.  Electrophoretic  changes  consistent  with renal , liver,  auto­ 
immune  or thyroid  dysfunction  may be present and suggest  that the congestive  heart  disease  is 
secondary to one of these problems.  
 
Hyperestrogenim:  ln addition  to the information available from  plasma  estrogens,  the  
thyroid panel , salivary hormonal panels and 2 -hydroxyestrone to  4 and  16-hydroxyestrone ratios , 
the following pattern is also generally present with hyperestrogenism:  
T3 is decreased.   
T4  is increased . 
Alpha  I globulin  is increased.  
A post albumin slu r is present on the  serum protein electrophoresis  graph. 
The transferr in region  of beta globulin  is increased.  
This pattern  is commonly  seen with the use of birth  control  pills,  other  exogenous  forms  of 
estrogen  and with  some  feminizing  tumors.

60 
 Estrogen Sensiiivity:  In addition to the information available  from  plasma estrogens and 
salivary hormonal  panels, the  following pattern  is also generally present  with estrogen sensitivity:  
Alpha  1 globulin  increased.  
The haptoglobin region  of alpha -2 globulin  increased. 
Beta globulin increased.  
A post albumin  slur is present  on the serum  protein  electrophoresis  graph.  
In addition  to the above, ovarian problems will often produce an increase in the  alpha region of the  
lipid electrophoresi s graph and this e levation  seen with  the criteria for hyper estrogenism or  estrogen 
sensitivity is strongly suggestive of ovarian tumor or cyst.  
 
Sarcoidosis : In mo st cases the SPE will show a progressive increase in the spec ific proteins.  In 
other words the alpha 2 globulin  will be higher than alpha 1, beta globulin will be higher than alpha 2 
and gamma globulin will be higher than beta globulin . This pattern  is called ,  ''the sarcoid  steps"  .

62 METASTATlC  CARCINOMA:  
1.Severe  depression  of albumin 1 especially,  if the liver is involved.
2.Increas ed alpha  l globulin.
3.Alpha  2 globulin  is frequently  increased .
4.Alpha  2 Haptoglobin  is decreased  if the liver is involved.
5.Beta  globulin  is decreased  in the transferrin  and C-Complement  regions.

63 ESTROGENIC  CONDITlONS:  
,. 
Estrogen  sensitiv ity from exogenous estrogen  or systemic  dysfunction.  
1.Prominent  increase  in alpha 1 globulin.
2.Increase  in Transferrin  (beta  globulin ).
3.Bridging  between  albumin  and alpha  1 globulin  (post  albumin  slur)

64 SUB-ACUTE OR CHRONIC  COLLAGEN  DISEASES : 
Rheumatoid  Arthritis,  Lupus,  etc, 
1.Pattern  is similar  to that found  with acute  hypersensitivity.
2.lgM significantly  increased,  IgG increased,  1gA decreased.
3.Albumin  often  decreased  with an increase  in fibrinogen .
4.Alpha  2 globulin  increased
5.Gamma  globulin  increased.

65 LYMPHOSARC OMA AND  LYMPHATIC  LEUKEMIAS:  
1.Increased  alpha  2 globulin.
2.Decreased  gamma  globulin  (often  severe).
3.Occasionally  a spike  will be present  in the gamma  globulin  region.
4.Increase  in the C-Complement  (beta  globulin).
5.Decrease  in albumin.
Note:  There  is often  a marked  decrease  in the imm une globulins.  This
decrease presents the  patients  with their  most  serious  problem(s),
susceptibility  to staph,  pneumonia  and septicemia . Research  has revealed tha t
many of these patients have changes in their  immune globulins years before
serious  symptoms  become  evident

66 MYELOMA  AND  WALDSTROM'S  MACROGL OBULINEMlA : 
1.Sharp peak or spike (M-Component)  usually  in the gamma globulin
region;  but, may  be present  in the Alpha  2 or beta globulin  regions
(rarely  are two spik s present).
2.Bence  Jones  proteins  or heavy  protein  chains  present  as determined
by immuno -diffusion  (Franklin's  Disease).

67 NEPHRO TIC SYNDROME:  
1.Severe  depression  of albumin  and gamma  globulin.
2.Marked  increase  of alpha  2 globulin.
3.Broadening  of alpha  2 globulin  due to a marked  increase  in Alpha 2 Macroglobulin.
4.Bridging  between  beta and gamma  globulin  due to an increase  in
Beta Lipoprotein.  _
5.Decre ase in the  C-Complement  region  of beta globulin.

68 BILIARY  DISORDERS:  
Biliary  disorders  involving  the gall bladder,  pancreas  or commo n bile duct.  
1.Broad  beta globulin  peak.
2.Bridging  between  alpha  2 and beta globulin.
3.Frequently another  peak  will appe ar between alpha 2 and beta globulin.

69 CHRONIC  LIVER  DISEASE:  
1.Marked  increase  - in gamma  globulin .
2.Bridging between bet and gamma globulin.
3, Decreased  albumin  and Alpha 2  Haptoglobin .

70 HYPERSENSITIVITY REACTIONS:  
1.Marked  increase  in gamma  globulin.
2.Depression  of the  C-Complement  portion  of beta globulin  (right side of
the beta globulin  region)

71 ACUTE  INFLAMMATION:  
Inflammation  resulting  from abscess,  bacterial  infection,  etc. 
l.Peaking  and broadening  of alpha  2 globulin.
2.Occasionally  a moderate  increase  in gamma  globulin.
3.The Macroglobulin  component  of alpha  2 globulin will be significantly
increased  during  an active infection.

72 ACUTE  TISSUE  NECROSIS:  
Malignancy  and necrosis  secondary  to .inflammation  or hypersensitivity.  
1.Similar  to acute  inflammation;  but, often  with an increase  in alpha 1 globulin.
2.Alpha  2 Macroglobulin  is usually  increased,  especially  if a tumor  is present.

73 SERUM  SODIUM  
Na+ 
Discussion:  Sodium is the most abundant  cation in the extra -cellular fluid.  It is most important 
in osmotic regulation of extra -cellular fluid balance, acid -base balance and renal, cardiac and 
adrenal function.  Sodium helps to maintain slightly acidic urine and is required for maintenance 
of the sodium -potassium pump (adrenal function).  
Related Tests:  BUN, creatinine, serum potassium, CO2, serum chloride, calculated osmolality, 
blood lithium, serum uric acid, serum anion gap, urinary sodium and urinary chloride.  
Reference  Range:  135-145 mmol/L.  
Optimum  Range:  135-142 mmol/L.  
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  120 mmol/L  or above  155 mmol/L.  
Common  Causes  For Increased  Serum  Sodium  (Hypernatremia):  
Chronic  Renal  Dysfunction:  See the section  of this  manual  covering  BUN  for 
laboratory changes, supplemental support and diet requirements.  
Dehydration:  Hypernatremia can  occur from loss of water or from sodium retention and 
the most common reasons are insufficient water intake or diuretic use.  
Water  Softeners:  Many  water softeners  use sodium  to soften  the water.  
Less  Common  Causes  For Increased  Serum  Sodium  (Hypernatremia) : Adrenal  cortical 
hyperfunction, diabetes, congestive heart failure, hepatic failure and vomiting.  
Common  Causes  For Decreased  Serum  Sodium  (Hyponatremia):  
Adrenal  Cortical  Hypofunction:  See the section  of this manual  covering  serum  
potassium for laboratory changes, supplemental support and diet requirements.  
Increased Serum Triglycerides:  See dysinsulinism in the section of this manual covering 
serum triglycerides for laboratory changes, supplemental support, and diet requirements.  Note:  
Increased serum triglycerides can result in "pseudohyponatremia".  With pseudohyponatremia, 
serum sodium is decreased  but the serum is not hypotonic (serum osmolality is normal or even 
increased). This can occur as the result of triglycerides replacing water in relation to sodium.  
Another cause of pseudohyponatremia can be incre ased serum globulins as seen with 
Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia.  Further information on Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia can 
be found in the section of this manual covering serum protein electrophoresis (SPE).  
Less  Common  Causes  For Decreased  Serum  Sodium  (Hyponatremia) : Diabetes,  thyroid 
hypofunction, anterior pituitary hypofunction, congestive heart failure, peptic ulcer and diarrhea.

74 
 Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  Serum  Sodium:  
 
To determine electrolyte balance add chloride and CO2 and subtract this figure from the 
sodium value.  The result should be between 9 and 18  for good electrolyte balance.  
 
Decreased serum sodium (hyponatremia) on admission to a hospital is associated with poor 
prognosis.  
 
Decreased serum sodium (hyponatremia)  may manifest lethal neurological complications 
(water intoxication with brain edema).  
 
With renal failure requiring kidney dialysis, the electrolyte balance will not be within 
the metabolic range and the BUN, creatinine, urinary micro -albumin and urinary creatinine 
clearance will be significantly  abnormal. Trace mineral support . In our experience using C.G.F. 
(ZI) - 3 tid, SunFlax  Complex  (ZI) - 2 tid, Fe/Cu Free Multi Mineral product & C o Q 10 – as 
directed by the manufacturer . 
This therapy is  effective in approximately 50 percent of cases.  If no improvement is seen in the 
patient after 45 days on the program, discontinue.

75 
 SERUM  POTASSIUM  
K+ 
 
Discussion:  Potassium is  the chief ion found in the intracellular fluid.  Only a small part of the 
total body potassium stores is contained in the serum/plasma.  The concentration inside the red 
blood cell is at least 15 to 20 times greater than the serum/plasma.  While only a small part is found 
in the serum, proper serum values are critical to normal physiology, especially adrenal, heart and 
kidney functions.  Potassium is also essential to maintenance of pH (blood and urine) and 
maintenance of osmotic pressure.  When potassium is drawn the use of very small needles and fist 
clenching should be avoided.  Both fist clenching and small nee dles can falsely increase serum 
potassium levels. Potassium should always be viewed in relation to  the other electrolytes.  
 
Related Tests:  Plasma or salivary cortisol, blood aldosterone, plasma renin, serum calcium, serum 
chloride, serum sodium, CO2 and anion gap; HGB, HCT and RBC, serum BUN, serum creatinine, 
serum or red blood cell magnesium, serum, urinary or salivary dehydro­ epiandroster one (DHEA) 
and pregnenolone and urinary 17 ketosteroids.  
 
Reference  Range:  3.5-5.5 mmol/L.  
 
Optimum  Range:  4.0-4.5 mmol/L.  
 
Possible Panic Range:  Below 3.0 mmol/L or above 6.0 mmol/L.  When serum potassium is below 
3.0 mmol/L or  above 6.0 mmol/L an EKG, CK with  Isoenzymes and Troponins should be 
completed to rule out heart muscle dysfunction/destruction.  
 
Common Causes  for Increased  Serum  Potassium  (Hyperkalemia) : 
 
Adrenal Cortical Dysfunction : Aldosterone decreased, sodium and chloride normal to 
decreased, plasma, urinary and/or salivary cortisol decreased, plasma renin increased, urinary 17 
ketosteroids decreased, DHEA generally decreased.  Supplemental Support:  AD Complex (ZI) 
– 2 in  the am and 2 at noon with S.O.S. (ZI) – 2 tid for hypofunction.  AD Hyer (ZI) - 2 
midmorning  and 2 midafternoon, S.O.S. (ZI) – 2 tid, and Sympathetic Balance (ZI) – 2 tid.  If the 
systolic blood pressure drops more than 10 mm from the recumbent to  the standing position or the 
overall systolic blood pressure is  decreased (below 105 mm),  add B6/B1  (ZI) – 1 tid. If the DHEA  
is decreased  below the  midline  of the laboratory range add DHEA  and Pregnenolone (ZI) - 1 bid.  
In either case (hypo or hype ) consider using Stress H P (ZI) – 15 drops tid  Diet:  Use the Roadmap 
To Health diet and ensure that patient does not snack between meals if attempting to lose weight.  
 
Renal  Dysfunction:  See the section  of this manual  covering  BUN  for laboratory  
changes, supplemental support and diet requirements.  
 
Systemic Acidosis:  See the section of this manual covering CO2  for laboratory changes, 
supplemental support, and diet requirements.

76 
 Less Common Causes For Increased Serum Potassium (Hyperkalemia):  Respiratory  distress, 
bradycardia, massive tissue destruction, diabetes, use of potassium -sparing diuretics, heparin 
therapy, non -steroidal anti -inflammatory drugs, dehydration, exercise, pregnancy, diets high in 
refined foods and hyperventilation.  
 
Common  Causes  for Decreased Serum  Potassium  (Hypokalemia):  
 
Diarrhea:  Serum chloride increased, HCT  and HGB increased, serum sodium increased, 
BUN increased.  Supplemental Support:  Citrus Pectin (ZI)  - 7 capsules  with a full glass of 
water, followed by a full glass of water,  Saccharomyces boulardii (ZI) - 1 tid and GI Complex 
(ZI) – 2-3 tid.  Diet:  Use the Roadmap To Health diet and ensure the patient drinks at least 8 full 
glasses of pure water daily.  
 
Drug Diuretics:  Most diuretic drugs are potassium sparing however serum potassium will 
often be  found decreased with  the use  of these drugs.  BUN and creatinine will  frequently be 
increased.  Do not assume potassium need because a  drug diuretic is  being employed.  Potassium 
should only be used if  a deficiency can be demonstrated.  Supplemental Support:  If the serum 
potassium is decreased use Potassium  – as directed by the manufactur er and B6/Bl  (ZI) - 1 tid as 
thiamine  and vitamin B6  deficiency  is a very common  finding with drug diuretic use.  Diet:  Use 
the Roadmap To Health diet and ensure that patient drinks at  least 8 -10 full glasses of pure water 
each day.  
 
Less Common Causes For Decreased Serum Potassium (Hypokalemia):  Hype1iension, several 
types of anemia, diets high in refined carbohydrates, familial periodic paralysis, malnutrition, 
excessive perspiration, alcoholism and folic acid deficiency.

77 
 Important  Considerations  With  Abnormal  Serum  Potassium:  
 
Bradycardia  is common with increased potassium.  Consider B6/Bl (ZI)  - 1 tid , Power 
Pill (ZI) = 1 in the am  and Sympathetic Balance (ZI)  –2 tid.   
Essential hypertension is common with decreased potassium (cortisol, renin and other 
indicators may be normal).  See information listed in the section of this manual under high density 
lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL) for laboratory patterns, supplemental support, and diet requirements 
for hypertension; add Potassium  if needed.  
 
An excellent indication of potassium need is  a dry mouth.  Dry mouth is  also a common 
subjective finding with nerve inflammation and drug use (both prescription and recreational).  
 
The following signs and symptoms frequently indicate adrenal hypofunction is present - 
dizziness, chronic fatigue, craving for salt, low systolic blood pressure, food and environmental 
sensitivity, chronic fatigue after a cold or the flu, respiratory distr ess, extreme fatigue after exercise, 
failure to sweat upon exertion, sparse leg and arm hair.  
 
The following signs and symptoms frequently indicate adrenal hyperfunction is present - 
excessive hair growth on face or body (female), increased blood pressure, blurred vision, increased 
triglycerides,  decreased HDL cholesterol and increased LDLNLDL cholesterol.  
 
Increased potassium suggests a  congestive heart problem;  decreased potassium suggests  a 
fatigued heart muscle.  
 
A high -energy soup  is often helpful with  adrenal hypofunction.  See information covered 
under total WBC for soup ingredients and cooking instructions.  
 
With  unresponsive adrenal cortical hypofunction,  pure licorice  extract, Iron  Plus (ZI), 
B6/Bl  (ZI), high levels of C-1000 (ZI) are often helpful.  
 
Because it is an adaptogen , Ashwagandha  should be considered with both adrenal cortical 
hypofunction and adrenal cortical hyperfunction.  
 
As previously  indicated, only  a small part of the total body  level of potassium  is contained  
in the serum/plasma.  The concentration  inside the RBC is at least 15 to 20 times greater  than that 
found  in the serum/plasma.  Normal values for RBC potassium are 78 -97 mEq/L and the RBC 
potassium should be at least 90 mEq/L.  If the serum/plasma level of potassium is normal, but 
kidney, adrenal or cardiac dysfunction is present, the cost to complete RBC potassium is justified.

78 
 SERUM  CHLORIDE  
Cl- 
 
Discussion:  Chloride is the principal  anion found in the serum.  The chloride level along with 
sodium, potassium and CO2, are important in evaluating acid -base relationships, state of hydration, 
as well as  adrenal and renal function.  Chloride concentration usually varies  inversely with CO2; 
hence, increased chloride is commonly associated with metabolic acidosis and decreased chloride 
with metabolic alkalosis.  Chloride is one of the elements required for the production of  HCl by the 
chief cells of the stomach.  
Related Tests:  Plasma or salivary cortisol, aldosterone, renin, serum calcium, serum potassium, 
serum sodium, CO2 and anion gap, HGB, HCT and RBC, BUN, creatinine, serum or red blood 
cell magnesium (RBC preferred), DHEA and urinary 17 ketosteroids . 
 
Reference  Range:  97-106 mmol/L.  
 
Optimum  Range:  100-106 mmol/L.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  90 mmol/L  or above  115 mmol/L.  
 
Common  Causes  for Increased  Serum  Chloride:  
 
Renal  Dysfunction:   See BUN  
 
Primary  CO2  Deficit:  See Co2. 
 
Less  Common  Causes  for Increased  Serum  Chloride:  Salicylate  poisoning,  excess intake  of 
salt (water softeners), adrenal hyperfunction,  dehydration, parathyroid hyperfunction.  
 
Common  Causes  for Decreased  Serum  Chloride:  
 
Renal  Dysfunction:  See BUN.  
 
Primary  CO2  Excess:  See CO2.  
Hypochlorhydria:  See total serum  globulin,  BUN,  and serum  phosphorus.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  for Decreased  Serum  Chloride:  Pyloric  spasm,  diabetes,  adrenal 
cortical hypofunction, respiratory distress, vomiting and sometimes with diuretic therapy.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  Serum  Chloride:  
 
Increased chloride can  indicate bladder dysfunction,  and decreased chloride can  indicate  a 
bowel dysfunction.

79 
 Chloride will often be  abnormal with pyloric spasm.  If present, consider  GI Complex 
(ZI) – 2 tid  Sympathetic Balance ( ZI) - 2 tid,  and SunFlax Complex (ZI) - 2 tid. 
 
If chloride  is reduced to  below 100 with the total serum globulin < 2.4 or >2.8, serum 
gastrin < 45 and the serum phosphorus< 3.0, hypochlorhydria is almost certain.  
Measurement of chloride levels via sweat is an excellent test to confirm the diagnosis of 
cystic fibrosis.  
 Serum Chloride < 100 is one of the major indicators of hypochlorhydria.

80 
 CARBON  DIOXIDE  
CO2,  CO2T,  tCO2  
 
Discussion:  CO2 is  the amount of base bound as bicarbonate in  the blood that is  available for  the 
neutralization of fixed acids such as lactic acid and hydrochloric acid.  CO2 refers only to base 
bound as bicarbonate and not the total base of the blood.  CO2 represents the reserve of alkali 
readily available for the neutralization of acids.  Conditions involving primary CO2 excess and 
deficit cannot be determined by CO2 alone, serum chloride must be checked for inverse values 
when metabolic acidosis or  metabolic alkalosis is  suspected, however irrespective of  the chloride 
value  when  the CO2 is 25  or less,  the probability  of systemic  acidosis  is very  high.  
Related  Tests:  Serum  potassium  and sodium,  urinary  chloride  and anion  gap. 
 
Reference  Range:  20-31 rnrnol/L.  
 
Optimum  Range:  26-30 mmol/L.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  < 15 rnrnol/L  or> 40 rnrnol/L.  
 
Common  Causes  For Increased  Carbon  Dioxide:  
 
Metabolic  Alkalosis:  Serum  chloride  decreased,  serum  calcium  decreased,  serum  
potassium decreased and BUN normal to  increased. Supplemental Support:  
Phosphatidylcholine (ZI), 2 tid, HCL Complete (ZI) - 1- with meals. If more than 4 are needed 
to control symptoms, rule out a need for zinc, thiamine and salt .  Renal product,  Potassium  – 
as directed by the manufacturer.  Note : Metabolic alkalosis is a  very serious problem and 
requires immediate  attention and frequently hospitalization. Always  rule out 
hypochlorhydria.  
Less  Common  Causes  For Increased  Carbon  Dioxide:  Fever,  hot baths,  loss of HCl  through 
vomiting, adrenal cortical hyperfunction and respiratory distress.  
 
Common  Causes  For Decreased  Carbon  Dioxide:  
 
Diabetes:  See the section  of this manual  covering  serum  glucose  for supplemental 
support, laboratory changes and diet requirements.  
 
Thiamine Deficiency:  Anion gap is generally increased, glucose can be normal to 
increased, HCT/HGB normal to decreased and RBC thiamine decreased.  Supplemental Support : 
Benfotiamine  (ZI) – 1 daily  and C.G.F. (ZI) – 2-3 tid and  S.O.S. (ZI)  - 2-3 tid.  If the systolic blood 
pressure is reduced below 105 mm or drops more than 10 mm from the recumbent  to the standing  
position,  add AD Complex (ZI) – 2 in the am and 2 at noon. Diet:  Us the Roadmap To Health diet 
available from Zorex International.  If the patient is overweight and they do  not have renal 
dysfunction, ensure  their daily carbohydrate intake does  not exceed 60 grams.  No snacking  
between meals.

81 
 Common  Causes  For Decreased  Carbon Dioxide  Continued:  
 
Metabolic Acidosis:  Serum chloride increased, serum calcium decreased, serum 
potassium increased, and anion gap increased.  Supplemental Support:  C.G.F. (ZI) - 2-4 tid . 
Diet:  Roadmap To Health.  
Systemic Acidity:  Along with decreased CO2, serum calcium serum/RBC magnesium will 
often be decreased; serum alkaline phosphatase will generally be decreased with a positive Zinc 
Taste  Test (ZTT).  BUN may be increased, serum phosphorus decreased and/or serum total globulin 
increased or decreased indicating a need for HC l. Supplemental Support:  P o w e r  P i l l  ( Z I )  
– 1  i n  t h e  a m ,  C.G.F. (ZI) - 3 tid, If the chemistry or subjective indications for HCl need are 
present use HCL Complete (ZI) - 1 in the middles of each meal, increase to stomach tolerance.  
If more than 4 capsules are needed, rule out the need  for zinc, thiamine and salt need.  It should 
be noted that hypochlorhydria is a common problem with systemic acidity.  Diet:  Roadmap To 
Health.  Alkaline ash foods are helpful, but correcting hypochlorhydria is often the 1st step in 
correcting systemic  acidity.  
Less  Common  Causes  For Decreased  Carbon  Dioxide:  Renal  dysfunction,  sub-acute  and 
acute dehydration.  
Chemical Sciatica:  Structural sciatica is not well defined with laboratory tests alone, 
however if  the problem is  due to a chemical imbalance causing the build -up of lactic acid on  the 
sciatic nerve, the blood chemistry will generally reflect an increased serum chloride, decreased 
serum calcium, decreased CO2, and increased anion gap.  Irrespective of the blood chemistry 
findings, if  the patient is  obese or is  on a diet high in carbohydrates  or consumes a  high intake of 
alcohol, chemical sciatica should be assumed.  Consider the  following supplemental support for 
chemical sciatica: 8X Pancre atin (ZI) – 1 qid on an empty  stomach, C.G.F. (ZI) - 3 tid, SunFlax 
Complex (ZI) - 2 tid, and additional Potassium – as directed by the manufacturer.   
Diet:  Roadmap To Health.  
 
Structural  Sciatica:  C.G.F. (ZI) 2 tid and  S.O.S. (ZI) – 2-3 tid.  
 
In either  chemical  or structural  sciatica,  if the patient  is sympathetic  dominant  use 
Sympathetic Balance (ZI) -2-3 tid.

82 
 ANION  GAP  
Electrolyte  Gap,  Gap,  Ion Gap 
 
Discussion:  Anion Gap is a calculation from sodium, potassium, CO2 and chloride to ascertain 
the level of unmeasured  anions and cations.  Unmeasured anions include protein and organic acids 
and unmeasured cations include calcium and magnesium.  The methods for calculating the anion 
gap are as follows:  The total of sodium plus potassium  subtracted from the total of chloride and 
CO2 equals the anion gap, or sodium minus the total of chloride and CO2 can also indicate the 
anion gap.  The method using sodium as the only cation is used most frequently, however  the 
method  using  sodium,  potassium,  chloride,  and CO2  is the formula  used  in this manual t o 
determine  the anion gap.  
Related  Tests:  Serum  sodium,  potassium,  chloride,  Co2,  blood  lactic  acid,  urinary  ketones, 
serum creatinine and blood alcohol.  
Reference  Range:  Most  laboratories  use 8-16 mmol/L  as their  reference  range  however,  this 
can differ depending upon methodology.  
 
Optimum  Range:  8-12 mmol/L.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  4 mmol/L  or above  25 mmol/L.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  Anion  Gap:  
 
Thiamine  Deficiency:  See CO2  for supplemental  support.  
 
Less Common  Causes  for Increased  Anion  Gap:  Diabetes,  lactic acidosis, dehydration,  toxin 
ingestion, metabolic acidosis, renal dysfunction.  
 
Common  Cause  for Decreased  Anion  Gap:  
 
Renal  Dysfunction:  See BUN.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  for a Decreased  Anion  Gap: Lithium  toxicity,  neoplasm,  increased 
serum calcium and/or magnesium.  
 
Added  Diagnostic  Information:  
 
Although the  test is expensive, red blood cell thiamine is  an excellent test  for determining 
thiamine deficiency.  
Even if the CO2, anion gap and serum thiamine are normal if one or more of the following 
subjective indicators are present, supplementation with thiamine B6/Bl  (ZI) and/or Power Pill (ZI ) 
should be considered. Subjective indicators are listed on the  following page.

83 
 Cyclic  personality.  
Hypoglycemia.  
Low blood  pressure.  
Increased sense  of taste,  smell,  or hearing. 
Unwarranted fear of impending doom.  
Chronic  need  for hydrochloric acid. 
Carbohydrate sensitivity.  
Excessive  use of alcohol,  drugs,  or refined  foods.  
If a chronic need  for thiamine is  present,  rule out a  need for  thiamine cofactors (manganese, zinc. 
sulfur, magnesium, unsaturated fatty acids , Celtic Sea salt,  and other Krebs  cycle nutrients), 
consider C.G.F.  (ZI) - 2-3 tid and SunFlax Complex (ZI) - 2 tid.  
 
Always rule out toxic  mercury exposure (hair -mineral analysis, urinalysis or red blood cell 
analysis) with  a chronic need for thiamine. Mercury will inhibit thiamine levels  in the Kreb s Cycle 
and prevent the production of energy (ATP). With toxic  mercury exposure consider L.P.A. Plus 
(ZI) - 1 every 3 hours during the day and 1 every 4 hours at night.  Use this for 5  days in a row 
with two days off. Use this protocol for 5 -6 weeks then do a serial check for the level of mercury 
exposure. This is a very difficult  protocol for the patient to follow but, is successful . 
 
 
If the thiamine deficiency is severe consider using Benfotiamine (ZI)  1-2 daily for the first 
10 days of supplemental therapy and then C.G.F. (ZI) - 2 tid.

84 
 SERUM  CALCIUM  
Blood  Ca, Total  Calcium  
 
Discussion:  Calcium is absorbed from the upper part of the small intestine. The amount of 
absorption depends upon the acidity of the intestinal contents and the amount of phosphate present.  
Calcium relates to  bone metabolism, the drawing of fats through the intestinal wall and protein 
absorption.  The amount of protein in the blood affects the calcium level.  Calcium provides a  
mobilizing factor in  trauma, infections, stress and is  used rapidly for repair of  tissue  in conjunction 
with vitamin A, vitamin C, magnesium, phosphorus, iodine and unsaturated fatty acids.  Calcium 
exists in the ionized form (about 55 percent) and the non -diffusible  form (about 45 percent), which 
is bound to protein (chiefly albumin).  Note:  In the diagnosis of hyper­ calcemia, serum calcium 
should be measured at least three (3) times because serum calcium can change significantly  when 
the albumin is increased or decreased.  
Related  Tests:  Parathyroid  hormone (PTH), thyroid panel, serum magnesium, RBC  magnesium, 
serum phosphorus, serum albumin, total globulin and total protein, serum  potassium, urinary 
calcium, ionized calcium.  
 
Reference  Range:  8.5-10.2 mg/dL.  
 
Optimum  Range:  9.4-10.0 mg/dL.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  7.0 mg/dL  or above 12.0 mg/dL.  
 
Common  Causes  for Increased  Serum  Calcium:  
 
Parathyroid Hyperfunction:  Ionized calcium increased, parathyroid hormone (PTH) 
increased, serum acid phosphatase increased, serum phosphorus decreased, serum alkaline 
phosphatase (ALP) increased, serum magnesium normal to decreased, RBC magnesium normal  to 
decreased, serum cholesterol decreased, serum chloride increased, osteocalcin increased,  serum 
zinc increased and serum gastrin increased.  Supplemental Support:  Magnesium 
Glycerophosphate  Tablets (ZI)  - at bedtime to bowel tolerance, SunFlax Complex (ZI)  - 2 tid 
and Always examine the neck area for space occupying lesions .  Diet:  Use the Roadmap To 
Health diet. Ensure the patient drinks at least 8 -10 full glasses of water  each day.  
 
Less Common Causes Of Calcium Increase:  Several types of cancer, thyroid hypofunction 
adrenal cortical hypofunction, ovarian hypofunction, epilepsy, some cases of osteoporosis, 
hypervitaminosis D, idiopathic scoliosis and chronic renal failure.  
 
Common  Causes  for Decreased  Serum  Calcium:  
 
Parathyroid Hypofunction:  Parathyroid hormone (PTH) decreased, alkaline phosphatase 
normal to decreased, ionized calcium normal to decreased, serum phosphorus increased, and red 
blood cell magnesium increased.  Supplemental Support:  Calcium Orotate (ZI) – 3 tid, D-3 
5000 (ZI) – 1 bid  and parathyroid tissue product, as directed by the manufacture.

85 
 Lithium Orotate  (ZI) - 1 tid and SunFlax  Complex  (ZI) - 2 tid. Diet: Use the Roadmap  To 
Health  diet and ensure  the patient  drinks  at least 8-10 glasses  of pure water each  day. 
 
Pregnancy:  Serum calcium is normally decreased in late pregnancy along with the 
following normal changes: albumin decreased, serum cholesterol increased, creatinine decreased, 
HGB and HCT decreased, MCV and MCH increased, T -3 Uptake decreased, neutrophils increased, 
and lymphocytes decreased (late), total protein decreased, T -4 increased, total WBC increased 
(late), uric acid decreased and prolactin increased.  Supplemental Support:  The following 
program is  suggested for normal, uncomplicated  pregnancy.  If the blood chemistry is 
significantly altered, or the patient expresses any difficulty, she should be referred to her OB/GYN  
for evaluation:  Prenatal Multi  vitamin  – as directed by the manufacturer.  If additional iron is 
needed add Iron Plus (ZI ) - 2 teaspoons full daily.  If digestive distress is present add HCL 
Complete (ZI)  - 1 per meal and GB Complete  (ZI) - 2 tid.  If the total serum protein is decreased 
add protein  powder or amino acids   - a s  d i r e c t e d  b y  t h e  m a n u f a c t u r e r .   If nausea of 
pregnancy  is present add C.G.F. (ZI) – 2 tid and Ginger Tea, as directed by the manufacturer.  
Digestive  Dysfunction  (Hypochlorhydria) : See total serum  globulin.  
 
Renal  Dysfunction:  See BUN.  
 
Low Normal Total Protein or Albumin:  Slight decreases of calcium are common with 
low total protein or albumin. Serum calcium  measures  total calcium, about half of which is bound 
to plasma proteins; therefore, ionized levels may be normal; but, if the total protein or albumin is 
decreased, the total calcium value may also be decreased.  Conversely, if the total protein or 
albumin is increased, the total serum calcium may also be increased.  
Less Common Causes For Decreased Serum Calcium:  Ovarian hypofunction, vitamin D 
insufficiency, protein malnutrition, osteoporosis, metabolic acidosis, several types of cancer,  acute 
pancreatitis and metabolic acidosis.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  Serum  Calcium:  
 
In those cases where  previously indicated supplements  have not provided relief for  nausea 
of pregnancy,  consider  phosphorus.  When phosphorus is used  during pregnancy, it should  be 
buffered  with calcium , Calcium Orotate (ZI) and Magnesium Orotate (ZI) . 
 
Many in the healing arts feel that calcium deficiency is widespread and almost everyone 
would  benefit from a daily  calcium supplement.  Our experience  indicates  that the inability  to 
use calcium available in the diet is far more widespread than simple calcium deficiency. When a 
calcium need is  identified through subjective indications or through laboratory analysis, the lack of 
synergists or metabolizing agents may be locus to the problem.  Always rule out the need for 
magnesium,  phosphorus,  vitamin  A, B, C and D,  unsaturated  fatty acids,  vitamin  K and boron , 
manganese, iodine, silicon, lysine, strontium citrate and the inability to absorb calcium from the 
diet(hypochorhydria) as the possible reason for the calcium need . Excess calcium in our diet is 
one of the reasons that atherosclerosis is increasing.

86 
  
Many doctors feel that increased serum calcium indicates poor fat emulsification and 
decreased serum calcium indicates poor fatty acid utilization.  
 
Common subjective indications of calcium need are:  Frequent skin rashes or hives, muscle 
cramps at rest (especially  leg or toe cramps while sleeping), soft fingernails,  frequent nose bleeds, 
increased  fever with a mild cold or virus, frequent  hoarseness,  irritability  and high or low blood 
pressure.  
 
Make certain that urinary calcium levels are checked anytime serum calcium levels are 
significantly increased or decreased.  
 
According to the peer -reviewed  literature, octacosanol will  help to prevent  spontaneous  
abortion.  
 
Reactive hypoglycemia, hyperinsulinism, sub -acute thyroid and/or anterior p1tmtary 
hypofunction, adrenal hyper and hypofunction, ovarian and uterine dysfunction, should all be ruled 
out with a history of spontaneous abortion.

87 
 IONIZED  CALCIUM  
Calcium,  Ionized  
 
Discussion:  Total serum calcium remains the first line test for the evaluation of calcium status. 
However, ionized calcium is often ordered where hypocalcemia is probable or suspected.  Calcium 
in the serum exists as ionized calcium and calcium bound to organic anions such as phosphate  and 
citrate and to proteins, primarily  albumin.  Measurement  of serum ionized calcium provides 
insight into  the effect  of total protein and albumin on  serum calcium levels.  As noted  in the section 
of this manual  covering serum calcium, a patient can have  high total calcium, with normal ionized 
calcium and increased total protein and/or albumin (as seen with dehydration or neoplasm). Ionized 
calcium  is the physiologically active portion of serum  calcium  and represents  about  55 percent  
of the  total  calcium.  
 
Related  Tests:  See serum  calcium.  
 
Reference  Range:  4.80- 5.50 mg/dL  or 1.12 - 1.32 mmol/L.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Same  as reference  range.  
 
Possible  Alarm  Range:  < 0.70 mmol/L.  
 
Increased  In: See serum  calcium.  
 
Decreased  In: See serum  calcium.  
 
Suggested  Supplemental  Support:  See serum  calcium.  
 
Added  Diagnostic  Information:  See serum calcium.

88 
 PARATHYROID  HORMONE  
PTH,  Parathormone,  Immunoreactive  PTH  
 
Discussion:  PTH is a polypeptide compound of 84 amino acids produced in the parathyroid glands.  
PTH is one of the major factors in the regulation of calcium concentration in extra­ cellular fluid.  
A decrease in the level of ionized calcium is the primary stimulus for PTH secretion, while an 
increase in serum calcium inhibits PTH secretion.  Parathyroid hyperfunction  is a serious  
metabolic  problem  that should  be evaluated  by a doctor qualified to diagnose  and treat 
parathyroid  dysfunction.  
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under the  section  of this manual  covering  serum  calcium.
