Reference  Range:  Use the  range  provided  by the laboratory,  usually  10-65 pg/mL.  
 
Optimum  Range:   Same  as the laboratory  range.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value  more  than 30 percent  above  or below  the reference  range.  
 
Common  Causes  For An Increased  PTH:  
 
Parathyroid  Hyperfunction:  Common  chemistry  changes,  supplemental  support  and 
diet requirements are listed in the section of this manual covering serum calcium.  
Less Common Causes For  An Increased PTH:  Renal dysfunction, benign or neoplastic space 
occupying lesions on one or more of the parathyroid glands, excess ingestion of vitamin D and 
Graves' disease.  
 
Common  Causes  For A Decreased  PTH:  
 
Parathyroid  Hypofunction:  Common  chemistry  changes,  supplemental  support  and 
diet requirements are listed in the section of this manual covering serum calcium.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  For A  Decreased  PTH:  Osteomalacia,  AIDS,  several  types  of cancer, 
30 percent of the cases with thyroid hyperfunction, renal failure and osteoporosis.  
 
Important  Considerations  With  An Abnormal  PTH:  
 
Parathyroid cancer should be ruled out when the patient has a  palpable neck mass, bone, or 
renal disease, and marked increases of PTH and serum calcium.  
If the PTH and serum calcium are increased and the serum phosphorus is decreased  but, 
an examination of the parathyroid glands reveals no space occupying lesions or cancer, 
bronchogenic, breast and renal cancer should be ruled out.

89 
 SERUM  PHOSPHORUS  
Blood  P04,  Serum  Phos  
 
Discussion:  Several factors are important in regulating serum phosphorus, including the 
parathyroid hormone  (PTH) and the functional state of the kidneys.  PTH is mostly responsible for 
increased serum calcium and decreased serum phosphorus hence there is a reciprocal relationship 
between the two.  Phosphorus is  very important in  the physiology of bone and in  the fmmation of 
active compounds such as phospholipids, nucleic acids, ATP, creatine phosphate  and complexes 
required for the utilization of glucose.  Serum phosphorus decreased below 3.0 and gastrin below 
45 should be considered gold standard indicators for hypochlorhydria. Increased  or decreased  
total globulin  <2.2 or> 2.8), BUN>  15 and MCV  > 81.9 and/or  MCH  > 
31.9 should  also be considered  for hypochlorhydria.  
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under the  section  of this manual  covering  serum  calcium.  
 
Reference  Range:  2.8-4.1 mg/dL.  Note:  Serum  phosphorus  will often  normally  be above 5.0 
with children up  to 17 years of age (bone growth) and during bone repairs  (fractures).  
 
Optimum  Range:  3.4-4.0 mg/dL.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  2.0 mg/dL  or above  5.0 mg/dL.  
 
Common  Causes  for Increased  Serum  Phosphorus:  
 
Parathyroid  Hypofunction:  See serum  calcium.  
 
Acute  and Chronic  Renal  Dysfunction:  See BUN.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  For Increased  Serum  Phosphorus:  Sarcoidosis,  several  types  of cancer, 
edema, ovarian hyperfunction,  diabetes, excess intake of  vitamin D  and liver dysfunction (portal).  
 
Common  Causes  for Decreased  Sermn  Phosphorus:  
 
Parathyroid  Hyperfunction:  See serum  calcium.  
 
Digestive  Dysfunction  (Hypochlorhydria):  See indicated  above  in bold.  
 
Less Common Causes For  Decreased Serum Phosphorus:  Ovarian hypofunction, diabetes, 
vitamin D anemia, liver dysfunction, protein malnutrition, several types of cancer, Wilson's 
disease, alcoholism, liver cirrhosis and asthma.

90 
 Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  Serum  Phosphorus:  
 
Although it is the opposite of what you would expect to find, serum phosphorus 1s 
frequently decreased with diets high in refined sugars.  
 
Although the serum phosphorus may be within the optimum range, supplemental 
phosphorus  is frequently indicated with emphysema and polycythemia.  
Because phosphorus tends  to reduce  serum viscosity, supplemental phosphorus should be 
used with caution if the patient is anemic or on blood thinning agents.  
The most frequently seen subjective indication for supplemental phosphorus  need is joint 
stiffness upon arising, cold hands and feet, or joint soreness/stiffness  after inactivity (sitting for  over 
30 minutes) that is improved with movement.  
 
Inspective of the serum phosphorus value  is often effective with the  subjective problems 
associated with thyroid hypofunction (see T -3 Uptake for a list of subjective indications).

91 
 SERUM  MAGNESIUM  
RED  BLOOD  CELL  MAGNESIUM  
Serum  Mg, RBC  Mg 
 
Discussion:  Magnesium is one of the most frequently encountered intracellular ions.  Only 
potassium occurs in higher amounts inside the cell; hence, the value of measuring intracellular 
(RBC) magnesium versus extra -cellular (serum) magnesium to determine magnesium needs. 
Magnesium plays an important role in numerous enzyme systems.  Magnesium, like calcium, is 
partly protein bound; therefore, slightly decreased values are often seen with decreased total serum 
protein or serum albumin.  Conversely, if the total protein or serum albumin is inc reased, the  serum  
magnesium  may also be increased.  Magnesium  supplementation  should  be used with  caution  
with  renal  disease  and under  the direction  of a licensed  health  care provider.  
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  serum  calcium.  
 
Reference  Range:  Serum  magnesium:  1.7-2.4 mg/dL.  
RBC  magnesium:  4.2-6.8 mg/dL.  
 
Optimum  Range:   Serum  magnesium:  > 2.2-2.9 mg/dL.  
RBC  magnesium:  Not less than 6.0 mg/dL  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:   Serum  magnesium:  Below  1.2 mg/dL.  
RBC  magnesium:  More  than 20% above  or below  the lab range.  
NOTE:  If the  RBC magnesium  is< 6.0 consider  Taurine  along  with magnesium  therapy.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  RBC  or Serum  Magnesium  
 
Renal  Dysfunction:  See BUN.  
 
Parathyroid  Hypofunction:   See serum  calcium.  
 
Less Common Causes Of Magnesium Increase:  Thyroid hypofunction, adrenal hyperfunction,  
excessive use of antacids containing magnesium.  
 
Common  Causes  for a Decreased  RBC  or Serum  Magnesium:  
 
Epilepsy:  Ceruloplasmin  normal to increased, serum cam1tme decreased, CRP  increased, 
folate normal to decreased, GGT frequently increased and vitamin B -6 frequently decreased 
(SOOT/AST below 10  and/or MCV/MCH decreased with  a normal or increased serum iron.  
Supplemental Support:  Prior to initiating supplemental support, rule out toxic element exposure  
and intestinal  parasites.  In any  case support  with C.G.F.  (ZI) - 2-3 tid, and Magnesium 
Glycerophosphate Tablets (ZI) - begin with 4 at bedtime and increase  to bowel  tolerance.  If the 
RBC  magnesium  is < 6.0  use Magnesium  Taurinate  (ZI) - in lieu of Magnesium  
Glycerophosphate Tablets (ZI). Begin at 5 at bedtime and increase to bowel tolerance.

92 
 Muscle Spasm:  The laboratory results with muscle spasm are variable; however, decreased 
serum or RBC magnesium is a common finding. Supplemental Support:  Magnesium  Taurinate 
(ZI) – at bedtime to bowel tolerance,  Note:  If the toes turn up or the leg turns out during  cramping . 
Always rule out anemia as a nexus  with elderly patients.  
Muscle/Soft  Tissue Inflammation  (Fibromyalgia):  See basophils, sedimentation  rate, 
CRP, and fibrinogen.  
Less Common Causes Of  Magnesium Decrease:  Hepatitis, adrenal hyperfunction,  parathyroid 
hyperfunction, liver dysfunction, renal dysfunction, digestive inflammation and a diet high in 
refined foods.  
Important  Considerations with  Abnormal  RBC  or Serum  Magnesium  
Magnesium deficiency and calcium and iron excess should always be ruled out with 
atherosclerosis and arteriosclerosis.  
Magnesium deficiency is common with hypertension; consider Magnesium Taurinate 
(ZI) - 5 at bedtime, increase to bowel tolerance and add Arginine Complex (ZI) – 2-3 tid.  
Magnesium will bind with fat in the G.I. therefore, when possible,  it should be dosed at 
bedtime when the presence of fat in the G.I. is reduced.  
Although the blood chemistry values with Carpal Tunnel Syndrome are variable consider 
supplementation with B6/Bl (ZI) - 1 tid, Zinc Orotate (ZI) - 1 tid and Magnesium Orotate 1250 
(ZI) - at bedtime to bowel tolerance.  Supplemental  s u p p o r t  should be given 60 days to provide 
beneficial results before surgery is considered.  When supplements fail, rule out hypochlorhydria as 
nexus to carpal tunnel.  
 
Always rule out magnesium deficiency with M.S., psychological problems, upper 
respiratory problems. constipc1tion  and all musculoskeletal problems . 
 
When magnesium is increased in a hair mineral analysis and decreased or low no1mal in 
the serum, it will generally  be decreased (< 6.0) in the RBC.  This is  often due to a deficiency of 
one of the major magnesium carriers  into the RBC, taurine.  This picture is also seen with a patient  
who develops  diarrhea on very  low doses  of magnesium  (< 400 mg). If this is the case, use 
Magnesium  Glycerophosphate Tablets (ZI).  
 
For patients  who develop diarrhea or loose stool on low dose oral magnesium  (less than 
400 mg a day), use Magnesium Glycerophosphate Tablets (ZI). Glycerophosphate has the 
highest bowel tolerance of all magnesium salts (carriers) in common use.  
 
Oral  magnesium  should  always  be dosed  to bowel  tolerance.

93 
 SERUM  LACTIC  DEHYDROGENASE  
LDH,  LD, Lactic  Acid  Dehydrogenase  
 
Discussion:  LDH is found in the serum and in all tissues.  It represents a group of enzymes involved  
in carbohydrate  metabolism.  LDH represents active exchange across the cell membrane of 
chloride with glucose and glucose with zinc and sodium (glycolysis); hence LDH activity is 
associated with pancreatic function and glucose metabolism.  LDH enzymes  participate in lactate 
and pyruvate utilization and are found chiefly in heart, kidneys, liver, skeletal  muscle, and red 
blood cells.  It follows that damage and secondary inflammation  to any of these areas will increase 
LDH in the serum. Any patient with a significant increase in total serum  LDH  is a candidate  for 
an LDH  isoenzyme  study.  
 
Related Tests:  Serum ALP and ALP isoenzymes, LDH isoenzymes, Serum CK and CK 
isoenzymes, SGPT/ALT, SGOT/AST, GGTP, serum glucose, WBC and differential, RBC and 
indices, total serum globulin, total protein, serum albumin, serum bilirubin, serum protein 
electrophoresis  (SPE).  
Reference  Range:  Below  15 years  of age: 140-300 IU/L 
Males above 15 years of age: 140 -250 IU/L 
Females above  15 years  of age: 140-280 IU/L  
 
Optimum  Range:  Below  15 years of  age: 150-250 IU/L 
Males above 15 years of age: 140 -220 IU/L 
Females above  15 years  of age: 140-210 IU/L  
Alarm  Range:  More  than 30 percent  above  or below  the laboratory  range  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  Serum  LDH:  
 
Liver/Biliary  Dysfunction:   See SGPT/ALT  and GGTP.  
 
Several  Types  of Anemia:  See serum  ferritin,  serum  iron and MCV/MCH.  
 
Cardiac  Dysfunction:  See SGOT/AST,  LDH  isoenzymes  and SPE.  
Tissue Destruction Due To Neoplastic Activity:  See LDH isoenzymes, serum protein 
electrophoresis (SPE), serum albumin, lymphocytes, total serum cholesterol, alpha 1 glyco­ protein.  
 
Common  Cause  for a Decreased Serum  LDH:  
 
Reactive  Hypoglycemia:  See serum  glucose  for supplemental  support.

94 
 Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  LDH:  
 
Total  serum  LDH  is frequently  increased  with the use of exogenous  estrogen  (birth 
control pills, etc.). not estriol (E -3) alone.  
Total serum  LDH  will frequently  increase  during an active  infection  due to increase  in 
LDH isoenzymes 1 or #2.  
With  thyroid  hypofunction,  the total serum  LDH  will frequently  be high normal  or 
increased with the ALP decreased below the midline of the laboratory range.  
 
With mono,  LDH  is usually  more  elevated  than SGOT/AST  and SGPT/ALT;  but with 
viral hepatitis SGOT/ALT and SGPT/AST are much more elevated than LDH.

95 
 LACTIC  DEHYDROGENASE  ISOENZYMES  
LDH  Isoenzymes,  LD Isoenzymes,  Lactic  Acid  Dehydrogenase  Isoenzymes  
 
Discussion:  The five LDH Isoenzymes are  located in  the alpha 1 and alpha 2  globulin regions of 
the serum protein electrophoresis (SPE). Increases in the total serum LDH or any of the five 
isoenzymes is almost always due to  some destructive process.  The total serum LDH may be 
within normal limits; however, any increase in  one or  more of  the isoenzymes, although not 
sufficient to increase the total serum LDH above the reference range, IS GENERALLY 
INDICATIVE OF A DESTRUCTIVE PROCESS WHICH INVOLVES THE SPECIFI C 
TISSUE  THAT  CORRELATES  WITH  THE  INCREASED  ISOENZYME.   Therefore,  in 
many cases, early diagnosis can be made by correct interpretation  of the LDH Isoenzymes. 
Specific increases and decreases  in LDH isoenzyme  #1 through #5 along with patterns common to 
specific increases and decreases are listed in this section.  Patterns where less scientific information, 
but a great deal of clinical and empirical evidence exists are listed in the Added Diagnostic 
Information section.  
 
Related Tests:  Total serum LDH, serum ALP and ALP isoenzymes, serum CPK and CPK 
isoenzymes, SGPT/ALT, SGOT/AST, GGT, serum glucose, WBC and differential, RBC and 
indices, total serum globulin, total protein, serum albumin, serum bilirubin, serum protein 
electrophoresis  (SPE).  Lab ranges for total LDH vary slightly from lab to lab.  
 
Reference Range:  Figures indicated are percent of  total serum LDH.  
LDH Isoenzyme #1: 22 -36 percent.  
LDH  Isoenzyme  #2: 35-46 percent.  
LDH  Isoenzyme  #3: 13-26 percent.  
LDH  Isoenzyme  #4: 3 -10 percent.  
LDH  Isoenzyme  #5: 2-12 percent.  
 
Optimum Range:  Figures indicated are  percent of  total serum LDH. 
LDH Isoenzyme #1: 10 -34 percent.  
LDH  Isoenzyme  #2: 30-45 percent.  
LDH  Isoenzyme  #3: 13-27 percent.  
LDH  Isoenzyme  #4: 2-14 percent.  
LDH  Isoenzyme  #5: 6-15 percent.  
 
 
 
Alarm Range:  For patients not known to have pernicious  anemia or hemolytic anemia, myocardial 
damage is almost certain when LDH Isoenzyme #1 is equal to or greater than LDH Isoenzyme #2.  
If LDH Isoenzyme #5 is > 18 percent, the probability of myocardial damage increases significantly. 
If this pattern persists following acute myocardial infarct,  reinfarction  is very probable.

96 
 Tissue  Designations  For LDH  Isoenzymes:  
 
LDH  Isoenzyme  #1: Heart,  red blood cells.  
LDH  Isoenzyme  #2: Heart,  lymph,  red blood  cells.  
LDH Isoenzyme #3: Pulmonary, spleen, adrenal, kidney.  
LDH Isoenzyme #4:  Hepatic,  skeletal muscle, prostate/uterus. 
LDH Isoenzyme #5: Hepatic, skeletal muscle.  
 
Increased  In: 
Viral Hepatitis:  LDH  Isoenzyme  #4 is significantly  increased.  
Infectious  Mononucleosis:  LDH  Isoenzyme  #1, 2, 3 and 5 increased.  
Leukemia:  LDH  Isoenzyme  #1, #2 and #3 increased,  #5 decreased.  
Vitamin B -12/Folic Acid  Anemia:  LDH  Isoenzyme #1  and #2 will be  significantly  increased 
(acute M.I. must also be ruled out).  
Acute Myocardial  Infarction:  LDH Isoenzyme #1 is equal to or greater than LDH Isoenzyme 
#2 with LDH Isoenzyme #5 increased.  
Chronic  And Acute  Liver  Necrosis:  LDH  Isoenzyme  #4 increased,  #5 signifi -cantly  increased.  
Asthma:  LDH  Isoenzyme  #3 and #5 increased.  
Pulmonary  Embolism  And Infarction:  LDH Isoenzyme  #3 increased  without  bleeding  into 
the lungs.  With bleeding into the lungs, LDH Isoenzyme #1 and #2 will be increased along with 
LDH Isoenzyme #3.  
Benign Prostate Hypertrophy/Uterine  Hypertrophy:  LDH Isoenzyme #4 will be increased. 
Extrahepatic  Biliary  Obstruction:  LDH  Isoenzyme  #4 increased,  #5 will be moderately 
increased.  
Pancreatitis:  LDH  Isoenzyme  #4 increased.  
 
Decreased  In: See Added  Diagnostic  Info1mation.  
 
LDH  Isoenzymes  Continued:  
Added  Diagnostic  Information:  
Infrequently an additional isoenzyme band will appear next to LDH Isoenzyme #5.  It is called LDH  
Isoenzyme  #6 and  will occur  with severe  liver disease.  When  present,  it generally indicates a 
grave  prognosis for the p atient.  
 
When an infectious process in the liver progresses to liver parenchymal cell necrosis, LDH 
Isoenzyme #5 will increase.  This change occurs during active cellular necrosis.  As the necrotic 
process begins to  subside and cirrhotic fibrosis begins  to occur, LDH Isoenzyme #5 will return to 
normal.  
 
An increase in the total white blood count (WBC) will be reflected in an increase of LDH Isoenzyme 
#1 or #2.  
 
With thyroid  hypo -function  secondary  to hypofunction  of the anterior  pituitary  (TSH < 2.0), LDH 
Isoenzyme #1 will often be<  20 percent.

97 
 LDH  Isoenzyme  #3 will frequently  increase  with adrenal  cortical  dysfunction.  
 
With  gall bladder  disease, LDH  Isoenzyme #3  and #5 will increase.  With  disease  of the common 
bile duct, LDH Isoenzyme #1 and #5 will increase and if  the disease process is  significant, total 
serum ALP will be increased along with an increase in GGTP.  
 
Long -term  insidious  exposure  to noxious  gases  (carbon  monoxide,  etc.),  will often  result  in 
a decreased  LDH  Isoenzyme  #5 (< 6 percent).  If this finding  is encountered  in any patient 
with unexplained illness, fatigue, loss of memory, etc., the exhaust system in their 
automobile as well as all gas appliances in their home and workplace should be checked for leaks.  
The following supplemental support should be considered for any patient exposed to non-medicinal 
gases:  GB Complete (ZI)  - 2-3 tid, E.N.V. (GBLV) (ZI) – 15 drops tid,  GI Complex (ZI) 
2 tid,  and Selenomethionine  (ZI)- 1 daily . 
 
A decreased LDH Isoenzyme #5 (< 6 percent) can also indicate a heavy metal body burden.  A 
mineral analysis should be  completed.  See MCH for  suggested supplemental  support.

98 
 SERUM  ALKALINE  PHOSPHATASE  
ALP,  Alk. Phos.  
 
Discussion:  ALP is a member of a family  of zinc metalloprotein  enzymes that function  to split 
off a terminal phosphate group from an organic phosphate ester; therefore, a decreased serum ALP 
is frequently  associated with zinc deficiency. ALP causes hydrolysis of monophosphate at an 
optimal pH of 9.0 to 10.0.  Tissues with a high concentration of this enzyme are liver, bone, 
intestinal mucosa and placenta.  It will be  increased with problems in  any of  these areas  and with 
many types of cancer. ALP is normally increased with bone growth (children) and bone repair 
(fractures). ALP is  also normally increased 2 -4 hours  after a fatty meal and with  patients who  are 
Lewis Positive  Secretors of blood type O or B. Any patient with a significant  increase  in the 
total serum  ALP  is a candidate  for an ALP  isoenzyme  study.  
Related Tests:  Isoenzymes of ALP, LDH and LDH isoenzymes, total bilirubin, SOOT/AST. 
SGPT/ALT, GGTP, serum gastrin, total serum protein, serum albumin, total serum globulin, SPE,  
urinary hydroxyproline  and other  test to determine bone  loss, WBC  and differential, thyroid panel, 
serum/ionized calcium, phosphorus and magnesium, RBC magnesium, CRP, osteocalcin, IGF -1 
and imaging for bone loss.  
Reference  Range:  Ranges  vary according  to age and sex. Use the range  provided  by the lab. 
 
Optimum  Range:  Above  the midline  of the lab range  to the maximum  of the lab range.  
 
Possible  Alarm  Range:  30 percent  above  or below  the laboratory  range.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increase in  ALP:  
 
Osteoporosis/Osteomalacia:  ALP  bone  isoenzyme  increased,  serum  calcium  normal  to 
decreased,  serum  and RBC  magnesium  normal  to decreased,  serum  phosphorus  normal,  serum 
manganese normal to decreased, urinary calcium normal to increased, vitamin K normal to 
decreased,  hair-mineral  calcium  increased  (indicates  poor utilization  of calcium),  hair-mineral 
boron n ormal to decreased, radiological studies indicate increased bone loss, urinary 
hydroxyproline  excretion  increased (urinary hydroxyproline  increases  as ALP bone  isoenzyme 
increases  and the bone  loss becomes  more  severe ). Supplemental  and Dietary  Support:  
SunFlax Complex  (ZI) - 2 tid, D-3 5000 – 1 bid , AD Complex (ZI) – 2 in the am and  2 at noon, 
C.G.F. (ZI) 3 tid  and  HCL  Complete  (ZI) - 1 capsule in  the middle of  each meal, increase 
every other day to  stomach tolerance.  If more than 4 capsules are needed, rule out a zinc, 
thiamine  or salt need .  Use a osteoporosis with calcium/magnesium/potassium at a 1 to 1 ratio 
formula( so triad stays in balance).  Use the Roadmap To Health diet. 
 
Paget's  Disease:  The highest levels of total serum ALP are seen with Paget's Disease. The 
ALP bone isoenzyme will be significantly increased and other urinary/blood/imaging markers for 
bone loss will be significantly increased; however other blood markers (serum calcium, 
phosphorus, magnesium, etc.), may be normal. Supplemental supp ort and dietary suggestions are 
the same as those listed under osteoporosis/osteomalacia.

99 
 Rheumatoid  Arthritis:  See serum  uric acid.  
 
Biliary Obstruction:  Total ALP is  often normal with gall bladder disease; however, it is 
frequently increased along with GGT in disease of the common bile duct, pancreas and with biliary 
obstruction (common bile duct calculi).  See GGT for the remaining blood chemistry indicators 
and supplemental support.  
Less Common Causes for Increased  ALP:  Thyroid hyperfunction, excess ingestion of vitamin D, 
rickets, alcoholism, liver dysfunction (ci rrhosis), Gilbert's syndrome, hepatitis and mononucleosis, 
cancer, adrenal hyperfunction, phlebitis, brucellosis, renal dysfunction, pancreatic dysfunction, 
shingles, AIDS, M.S. and active rheumatoid arthritis.  
 
Common  Caused  for Decreased  ALP:  
 
Zinc Deficiency:  WBC or RBC zinc decreased, decreased  or low normal total WBC, Zinc 
Taste Test positive. Suspect zinc deficiency when magnesium deficiency is present. The Zinc Taste  
Test uses a  0.1 percent zinc  sulfate solution.  A small amount is  placed in  the patient's mouth.  If 
the patient cannot taste the solution within 10 seconds, it is determined the patient is zinc 
insufficient.  When the total ALP is below the midline of the optimum range and other indications 
of zinc need are present (white spots on finger nails, reduced sense of taste or smell, cuts heal 
slowly, acne, susceptible to colds, flu or infections, prostate hypertrophy , recurring genital  urinary  
infections,  macular  degeneration,  etc.), zinc supplementation  Zinc Orotate (ZI) - 1 qid until the 
biochemical and subjective indications of zinc need are resolved.)  Note:  With zinc anemia and 
zinc supplementation it may take up to 24 months for the ALP to return to the optimal range.  
Progesterone and Vitamin C  Deficiency:  Several peer reviewed studies have used ALP as 
the marker for progesterone  and vitamin C deficiency.  If the zinc deficiency  cannot be defined 
via the ZTT, laboratory, or  clinical indicators, suspect either a  progesterone or  vitamin C need  and 
consider  Micronized/Bio -identical  Progesterone  Cream  (ZI) and C-1000  (ZI).  
Less Common Causes Of ALP Decrease:  Thyroid hypofunction, pernicious anemia, protein 
malnutrition, adrenal hypofunction, certain prescription drugs especially those containing estrogen 
or estrogen in combination with androgens, hypophosphatasia (confirmed with urinary 
phosphoethanolamine) an d HgH deficiency (see IGF -1). 
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  ALP:  
 
Although a  specific blood test (Brucellosis Agglutinins) for brucellosis (undulant fever) is 
available, total serum ALP will frequently be increased with the total WBC increased, monocytes 
increased, lymphocytes increased, and neutrophils decreased. IgG, IgM and SGPT/ALT are  also 
frequently increased.  Irrespective  of a positive Brucellosis Agglutinins test, if the other blood 
indicators are present and the clinical signs are present (cyclic fever, chronic fatigue  and diarrhea  
in the early  phase),  supplement al support  should  be initiated  as follows : C.G.F.(ZI) 3 tid  and 
Immune Plus (ZI) – 3 bid.

100 
 Herpes  Zoster  (Shingles)  is a viral  problem  often  resulting  in an increased  serum  ALP. 
Although the  sedimentation rate, C -reactive protein and basophil percentage will often be 
increased indicating inflammation, the  total WBC, viral titters  and the  SGPT/ALT will often be 
normal.  Herpes  Zoster  (Shingles)  is best determined  from  physical  examination  of the patient. 
The following  supplemental support  should  be considered  alone  or with prescribed medications , 
Immune Plus (ZI) – 3 bid,  HCL  Complete (ZI) - begin with 1 in the  middle  of each  meal  
and increase  every  other  day to stomach  tolerance, if more than 5 are needed per meal then zinc, 
thiamine or salt deficiency  needs to be ruled out. 8X Pancreatin  (ZI) -1 qid on an empty  
stomach,  C.G.F.  (ZI)- 2 tid, Swedish Bitters topically  on the lesions, Lithium Orotate  (ZI)- 1 
tid, Immune Plus (ZI) – 3 bid,  Stress H P (ZI)- 15 drops tid, and  Viral H P (ZI) – 15 drops tid  
2 tid. UV light  applied  to the area twice  a day  for 10 minutes  each treatment.  Note:  Although  
C.G.F.  (ZI) is effective  for vitamin  B-12 needs, vitamin B -12 in jections may be required to 
resolve  the problem. This is an extensive and expensive program however it  generally 
produces results and singles is an extremely difficult problem to resolve.  
 
Rib-head displacement will generally cause intercostal nerve inflammation.  In many cases,  if 
the rib -head displacement is not corrected via manipulation i mmediately , and the intercostal nerve  
inflam mation is  prolonged, HERPES ZOSTER WILL DEVELOP.  After the  rib-head has 
been manipulated and returned to its correct position, the following supplemental program should 
be followed for 14 days to help stabilize the rib -head and to minimize the inflammation: 8X 
Pancreatin (ZI) - 1 qid on an empty stomach, and KI Caps  (ZI) – 1 per day.

101 
 ALKALINE  PHOSPHATASE  ISOENZYMES  
ALP  Isoenzymes,  Isoenzymes  of Alk. Phos.  
 
Discussion:  Children under 18 years of age have a very high level of ALP bone isoenzyme; hence 
the increased total serum ALP during bone growth.  The increase peaks at puberty and rapidly 
declines.  Serum from healthy adults under 50  years of  age usually is  predominantly liver isoenzyme 
with little or no bone isoenzyme.  Adults over 50 years of age begin to manifest skeletal changes 
that result in an increased bone isoenzyme.  Men usually have lower levels of bone isoenzyme than 
women.  The isoenzymes of ALP are excellent tools for differentiating benign from cancerous liver 
conditions and for identifying liver, bone and bowel disease WITH OR WIT HOUT AN 
INCREASE IN THE TOTAL SERUM ALP.  The various ALP isoenzymes are described below:  
Liver Isoenzyme a2:  The major ALP liver isoenzyme is a2 and is the  isoenzyme most 
frequently increased with an increased total serum ALP.  Liver isoenzyme a2 increases in the blood 
early in liver disease, often before other functional tests reveal abnormal results.  A wide group of 
conditions result in increased liver isoenzyme a2.  They include: hepatitis, ci rrhosis, fatty liver, 
drug induced  liver disease, biliary  obstruction,  duct stricture, biliary  cirrhosis and liver cancer.  
Liver disease associated with an increased isoenzyme a2 is frequently associated with abnormal 
vitamin D metabolism with subsequent osteomalacia.  S.O.S. (ZI)  – 3 tid , Phosphatidylcholine 
(ZI), GB Complete  (ZI) and E.N.V./GBLV -HP (ZI) should be considered with an increased ALP 
a2 isoenzyme.  
Liver Isoenzyme al:  This isoenzyme of ALP is also called the "fast liver" isoenzyme. ALP 
isoenzyme al  has been identified in cases of metastatic cancer to the liver, viral hepatitis, alcoholic 
cirrhosis  and other liver  diseases.  The data available on  ALP isoenzyme al  suggests it is  strongly 
associated with metastatic liver cancer.  When ALP isoenzyme al  is increased  with an  increased 
GGTP, alcoholic cirrhosis  of the liver should be ruled out.  See alpha  1 globulin and serum protein 
electrophoresis for further information on tissue destruction due to neoplasm and GGTP for 
information concerning alcoholic cirrhosis of the liver.  
 
Bone Isoenzyme:  ALP bone isoenzyme increases with increased osteoblastic activity; 
hence, the increase with bone growth and the healing of fractures.  Increased ALP bone isoenzyme 
is common with Paget's disease, rickets, bone cancer, osteomalacia, osteoporosis, primary 
parathyroid hyperfunction and in some cases of sprue.  As the ALP bone isoenzyme increases, 
urinary hydroxyproline excretion also increases.  This is especially true with primary parathyroid 
hyperfunction, osteoporosis and osteomalacia.  See seru m calcium and PTH for further information 
on parathyroid hyperfunction and serum ALP for further information on osteoporosis, osteomalacia 
and Paget's disease.

102 
 Intestinal Isoenzyme:  The ALP intestinal isoenzyme is seen normally in the serum of 
subjects with type B or O blood, especially after a fatty meal.  It is generally increased with 
perforation of the bowel, ulcerative disease of the intestine and sometimes with liver cirrhosis. 
Acute infarction of the intestine will cause an increase of the ALP intestinal isoenzyme.  Large 
erosive or ulcerative lesions in the stomach, duodenum , and other  areas of the small intestine and 
colon will also cause the ALP intestinal  isoenzyme to increase; hence, the increase seen with peptic 
and duodenal ulcers.  Lesions associated with malabsorption will cause an increase in  the ALP 
intestinal isoenzyme only if there is erosion or ulceration.  Erosion and ulceration will also cause 
the serum gastrin to increase significantly (Zollinger -Ellison Syndrome).  See serum total protein 
for further information on digestive inflammation and serum gastrin for further information on 
ulcers.  
Placental Isoenzyme:  This isoenzyme is  increased normally in pregnancy.  It appears in 
the first trimester and increases as the pregnancy  progresses.  Infarction  of the placenta in toxemia 
of pregnancy will cause the ALP placental isoenzyme to increase significantly.  Placenta isoenzyme 
can also be increased with seminoma, choriocarcinoma  and ovarian cancer.  
 
Regan/Regan -Variant/Nagao/PA:  These  isoenzymes  of ALP are associated  with several 
different types of cancer.  Regan has been associated with lung cancer, colon cancer and ovarian 
cancer.  Regan -Variant has been associated with hepato -cellular  cancer.  Nagao has been associated 
with metastatic carcinoma of  the pleural surfaces and with  cancer of  the pancreas.  PA has been 
associated with cancer of the pancreas.  
Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  ALP  Isoenzymes:  
 
Although the blood chemistry findings with Multiple Sclerosis (MS) are variable, total 
serum cholesterol and total ALP will frequently  be increased  with a decrease in the ALP intestinal 
isoenzyme, 25 OH vitamin D -3 and a decrease in the lymphocyte percentage. Predisposing factors 
include genetic predisposition, toxic element exposure, systemic and/or intestinal parasites, 
bacterial or viral infection, allerg y/sensitivity, exposure to chemicals, environmental toxins, 
pollution and other xenobiotics.  After the predisposing factors have been ruled out, the following 
supplemental support should be considered irrespective  of other  treatment –S.O.S. (ZI)  – 3 tid, 
SunFlax Complex (ZI) - 2 tid, C.G.F. (ZI)  - 3 tid, Biotin (ZI) - Up to 4 per day, E.N.V./GBLV 
HP (ZI) - 15 drops tid  and D-3 5000 (ZI) - 1 bid and octacosanol as directed by manufacture . If 
the patient has access to hyperbaric oxygen this is also helpful for most patients.  Note:  In many 
cases the first signs  of MS are reduced  vision and loss of abdominal muscle strength. With M.S. 
Biotin is often helpful but should be discontinued for  seven days before running a thyroid panel 
(it will not  harm the thyroid but, will change the values on the serum test).

103 
 ASPARTATE  AMINOTRANSFERASE  
SERUM GLUTAMIC  OXALOCETIC  TRANSAMINASE  
SGOT/AST,  Serum  GOT,  L-Aspartate  
 
Discussion:  SGOT/AST is functionally similar to  SGPT/ALT; however, it is not increased as much 
as SGPT/ALT in liver problems.  With cardiac problems, SGOT/AST will not return to normal as 
quickly as SGPT/ALT.  SGOT/AST is more specific for the detection of cardiac problems than for 
biliary tree or liver problems.  In decreasing order, SGOT/AST is found pri­ marily in the heart, 
skeletal muscle, brain, liver and kidneys.  SGOT/AST acts as a catalyst in amino acid metabolism 
(during glycolysis) with resultant energy release.  
Related  Tests:  SGPT/ALT,  GGTP, total serum  bilirubin,  serum  alkaline  phosphatase  (ALP) 
and ALP isoenzymes, serum LDH and LDH isoenzymes, total serum globulin, serum protein 
electrophoresis (SPE), serum amylase and lipase, serum gastrin, comprehensive stool and digestive 
analysis (CSDA), serum iron, serum ferritin, WBC and differential,  EBV and CMV titers, hepatitis 
A, B and C titers, mononucleosis, serum albumin, BUN, lipid electrophoresis, serum uric acid, 
serum and RBC magnesium.  
 
Reference  Range:  8-45 U/L 
 
Optimum  Range:  10-30 U/L. 
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Above  100 U/L. 
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  SGOT/AST:  
 
Congestive Heart Failure:  SGPT/ALT increased; however, it  is not normally  not as  high 
as SGOT/AST, GGTP normal to increased, serum ALP increased, serum CO2 decreased, ESR 
increased, gamma globulin increased, total serum globulin normal to increased, serum LDH 
increased, LDH Isoenzyme #1 and #5 increased, serum uric acid increased, a  "split pre -beta" is 
frequently  present on the lipid electrophoresis tracing, CPK Isoenzyme  CK:MB (heart) increased, 
often proceeded by an increase in CPK Isoenzyme CK:MM (muscle). Renal, hepatic, thyroid or 
autoimmune dysfunction may be present.  If present, congestive  heart failure may be secondary to 
one of these metabolic conditions.  See the se ction of this manual covering the SPE for further 
information on congestive heart failure.  Supplemental support and diet requirements are listed in 
the section of this manual covering HDL cholesterol (coronary artery disease, 
atherosclerosis/angina).  A Lipid Fractionization  test should be ordered for this patient.  
 
Common  Causes  For An Increased  SGOT/AST  Continued:  
 
Coronary Artery Insufficiency:  LDH isoenzyme #1 (heart) increased, total serum 
cholesterol normal to increased, HDL cholesterol and apolipoprotein A -1 are both decreased, 
Apolipoprotein  Band LDL cholesterol increased, serum triglycerides increased, CPK Isoenzyme 
CK:MB (heart) increased, often proceeded by  an increase in  CK:MM (muscle), RBC  magnesium 
decreased,  a broadening  of the alpha  2 globulin  will be seen on the SPE tracing,  SGPT/ALT  will

104 
 be increased; however, it is normally not as high as SGOT/AST, serum uric acid increased, a "split 
pre-beta" is frequently present on the lipid electrophoresis tracing.  See the section of this manual 
covering the SPE for further information on coronary artery disease.  Supplemental support and 
diet requirements are listed in the section of this manual covering HDL cholesterol (coronary artery 
disease/atherosclerosis/angina). A Lipid Fractionization test should be ordered  on this patient.  
Acute Myocardial Infarct (Acute M.I.):  The blood chemistry changes are similar to those 
seen with congestive heart failure with the following additional changes; serum CPK significantly 
increased with an increase in CPK isoenzyme CK:MB (heart), LDH isoenzyme #5 (liver)  
significantly increased, the  blood viscosity  is often  increased (increased fibrinogen), total WBC 
increased, LDH isoenzyme #1 will be equal to or greater than LDH isoenzyme #2 and troponin will 
be increased. See the section of this manual cov ering the SPE for further information on heart 
disease.  Supplemental support and diet requirements (after the patient is discharged from the 
hospital) are listed in the section of this manual covering HDL cholesterol.  
A Lipid Fractionization test should be ordered on this patient either in the hospital or after discharge 
from the hospital.  
Myocarditis:  Serum CPK increased with CPK isoenzyme CK:MB  (heart) mildly 
increased, serum LDH increased with LDH isoenzyme #1 (heart) mildly increased, eosinophils 
increased, neutrophils increased, alpha 2 globulin increased, gamma globulin increased, C­ reactive  
protein  increased  and the sedimentation  rate will frequently  be increased. Supplemental 
Support:  8X Pancreatin  (ZI) - 1 qid on an empty stomach,  CircuPlus (ZI)  - 3-4 bid and SunFlax 
Complex (ZI)  - 2 tid.  
 
Other Causes For An Increased SGOT/AST:  Hepatitis, mononucleosis,  liver cirrhosis, acute 
and chronic liver disease, acute and chronic pancreatitis, several types of cancer, acute and chronic 
biliary dysfunction, alcoholism, diabetes, essential hypertension, influenza, asthma, rheumatoid 
arthritis, dermatomyositis.  See GGTP  for further information on  conditions involving the biliary 
tree and SGPT/ALT for further information on conditions involving liver disease.  
 
Non-Alcoholic  Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD):  Generally, with liver disease the SGPT/ALT will 
be increased above the SGOT/AST  however , with NAFLD the SGOT/AST will often be twice that 
of the SGPT/ALT.  If NAFLD is diagnosed (imaging, t ransaminases ), consider GB Complete  (ZI) 
- 2-3 tid,  Phosphatidylcholine (BR) - 6 tid,  DIM Complex (ZI)  – 2 bid,  and E.N.V/GBLV H P 
(ZI) - 15 drops tid. See SGPT/ALT for further information on hepatic dysfunction. According to 
Mayo and Cleveland Clinics, more than 30 percent of the U.S. population have this problem 
and the percent increases as girdle weight in increases. Diet: Use the Roadmap  To Health diet 
and ensure the patient drinks at least 8 -10 glasses of pure water each day. The diagnosis of  NAFLD 
can be confirmed with the FibroSure NASH test, code 550140, available from Professional Co -Op 
Services a division of Lab Corp.  Description of the components  of the tests and costs can  be 
obtained  from  Lab Corp of Professional  Co-Op Services (they have a web site).

105 
 Common  Cause  for a Decreased  SGOT/AST:  
 
Vitamin B -6 Anemia:  Generally decreased below 10 and almost always decreased more 
than SGPT IALT and GGTP. Common chemistry changes, supplemental support and diet 
requirements are listed in the section of this manual covering MCH.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  For A Decreased  SGOT/AST:  Uremia  and alcoholism.  
 
Important Considerations  with  an Abnormal  SGOT/AST:  
 
Erythrocyte Glutamic Oxalocetic Transaminase (EGOT)  can be used to determine 
vitamin  B-6 need.  A sample  of EGOT  is taken  and the patient  is given  150 mgs of Pyridoxal  5- 
phosphate B6/Bl (ZI) - 1 tid for 10 days. After ten days a serial check of the EGOT is 
completed.  If the EGOT  value  increases,  vitamin  B-6 anemia  is assumed.  
 
Any patient on exogenous estrogen (birth control pills, Premarin, etc.) is a candidate for 
vitamin  B-6 supplementation.  Exogenous  estrogen is known to reduce  systemic stores of vitamin 
B-6, zinc and magnesium.  See the section of this manual covering estrogen for further information . 
 
Oxalic acid (the O in SGOT) is produced as a by -product of the breakdown of sex 
hormones in the liver and gonads. Therefore, if no other reason can be determined for a 
decreased or increased SGOT/AST, gonadal hypofunction or hyperfunction should be 
investigated.  
Angina Pectoris  is often difficult to differentiate from musculoskeletal problems.  With true 
angina pectoris, the pain, shortness of breath, etc. will exacerbate with increased physical activity.  
Also, with true angina pectoris, CPK isoenzyme CK:MB  (heart) will frequently be increased but, 
the CPK isoenzyme CK:MM (muscle) will be normal.  If the pain, discomfort, shortness  of breath,  
etc. increases  while  the patient  is at rest,  pseudo -angina, secondary  to biliary dysfunction, hiatus  
hernia,  functional or  pathological pulmonary hypertension, diaphragm spasm, rib  fixations, or 
hypochlorhydria,  should be considered. This is  especially true if  the pain, discomfort, etc., occurs 
after ingesting fried foods or a meal where protein and carbohydrate are consu med together.  For 
true angina use the dietary and supplemental program for atherosclerosis, listed in the section of 
this manual covering HDL cholesterol.

106 
 ALANINE AMINOTRANSFERASE  
 SERUM  GLUTAMIC  PYRUVIC TRANSAMINASE  
SGPT/ALT,  2-0xoglutarate  Aminotransferase  
 
Discussion:  SGPT/ALT is functionally similar to SGOT/AST; however, it is not increased as much 
as SGOT/AST in cardiac problems. With liver dysfunction, SGPT/ALT will not return to normal 
as quickly as SGOT/AST.  SGPT/ALT is more specific for the detection of hepatocyte injury than 
for biliary tree dysfunction and is more specific than SGOT IAST for liver disease/injury.  
SGPT/ALT is found primarily in the liver, kidneys, heart and skeletal muscle.  
 
Related  Tests:  Sarne as  those  listed  under  SGOT/AST.  
 
Reference  Range:  7-56 U/L 
 
Optimum  Range:  0-30 U/L. 
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Above  100 U/L. 
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  SGPT/ALT:  
 
Cirrhosis Of The Liver:  SGOT/AST and GGT increased, serum albumin decreased, 
serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) increased, ALP liver isoenzyme  al and a2 increased, alpha 2 
globulin increased, serum amylase increased, total serum bilirubin increased, total serum 
cholesterol decreased, total  serum globulin increased, sedimentation rate  increased, serum gastrin 
increased, CRP Increased, serum LDH increased, LDH isoenzyme  #5 increased, serum and RBC 
magnesium decreased. See the section of this manual covering the serum protein electroph oresis 
(SPE) for serum globulin changes with cirrhosis of the liver. Supplemental Support:  A 
Cleanse /detox should be used . Then us e with the following  supplements:  GB Complete (ZI) - 3 
tid and Phosphatidylcholine ( ZI), 7 tid. After 15 days use the Roadmap To Health diet, continue  
with Phosphatidylcholine ( ZI) - 5 tid, GB Complete  (ZI) - 2 tid and add SunFlax  Complex  
(ZI) - 2 tid, E.N.V./GBLV  HP (ZI) - 15 drops tid and S.O.S. (ZI)  - 4 tid. If the subjective 
indications or lab indicators are present indicating a need for HCl use HCL Complete (ZI) - 1 
capsule in the middle of each meal (increase by 1  capsule every other day until the patient 
experiences a  burning in  the stomach and then reduce). Diet:  Use the Roadmap To Health diet as  
indicated above and ensure the patient drinks  at least 8 -10 glasses of pure water each day. Note:  If 
the patient is constipated add Magnesium Glycerophosphate Tablets (ZI) - at bedtime to bowel 
tolerance and one -half of a raw  thinly sliced potato sprinkled with Celtic sea salt  also at bedtime.  
If the patient has diarrhea add Citrus Pectin (ZI)  - 5 tid and Saccharomyces Boulardii (ZI)  – 1 
bid. 
Acute  And Chronic  Liver  Necrosis:  In general  the same  increases  and decreases 
indicated  for cirrhosis  of the liver will be present  with the  following  additional  changes:  Alpha 1 
globulin decreased, beta globulin increased, serum iron increased (the degree of increase will 
parallel the  degree of necrosis), serum triglycerides increased, ALP liver isoenzyme a2  increased 
in the early stages with ALP liver isoenzyme al  increasing in  the acute phase.  See the section of 
this manual covering the serum protein electrophoresis (SPE) for serum globulin changes with 
acute and chronic liver necrosis.

107 
 Hepatitis/Mononucleosis:  With hepatitis the alpha 2 globulin will be decreased, with 
mononucleosis it will be increased. The remainder of the changes will be similar and are as follows: 
SGOT/AST and GGTP increased, ALP increased with ALP liver isoenzyme a2 increased, total 
WBC inc reased in  the early stage and decreased in  the chronic stage,  serum LDH increased with 
LDH isoenzyme #5 increased, IgM significantly increased, total serum bilirubin increased,  gamma  
globulin  increased.  In uncomplicated  cases of he patitis and mononucleosis, the gamma globulin 
will return to  normal in  about 30 days; however, if  the gamma globulin peak broadens and develops 
into a polyclonal pattern on the tracing, a persistence of inflammation is indicated.  Note:  Several 
specific tests for hepatitis are available and include surface antigens, recombinant polypeptides, 
core antigens, gene testing to determine if recently developed drugs  are applicable for the patient 
(Hep C) and total viral load.  These tests should be completed to ascertain the  type of hepatitis (A, 
B, C,  D, E or G)  along with the gamma globulin, liver enzymes and total viral load to determine 
the status of  the hepatitis.  Hepatitis B  and C  are known to cause chronic viruses . Hepatitis A and 
mononucleosis generally do not cause chronic virus however, unless the hepatitis A and 
mononucleosis are completely controlled in the initial and follow -up treatment, they frequently  
return and are diagnosed  as Epstein Barr virus or Cytomegalovirus later  in the patient's  life. 
Supplemental  Support:  Immun e Plus (ZI) - 3 tid,  GB Complete (ZI)  - 3 tid, Quercetin (ZI)  
- 2-3 tid, Olive  Leaf (ZI),  2 tid, C 1000 (ZI) -, begin at 2 bid, increase to bowel tolerance, S.O.S.  
(ZI) - 3 tid, Magnesium Glycerophosphate Tablets (ZI) - begin with 4 at bedtime, increase to 
bowel tolerance, E.N.V./GBLV H P (ZI) and Viral  HP (ZI) - at 10-15 drops  each tid.  If the patient 
has hepatitis B add vitamin E . Note:  Once the patient is asymptomatic and the liver enzymes, 
gamma globulin and viral load have normalized, the supplemental program should be  reduced by 
one-half and maintained at  that level for another 90 days.  After 90 days, the patient should continue 
Immune Plus (ZI) at 3 daily, GB Complete  (ZI)- 1 daily, Quercetin (ZI)  - 1 tid for the remainder 
of their life.  Diet:  Use the Roadmap To  Health diet and drinks 8 -10 glasses of pure water each 
day. Note:  IV vitamin  C at 30 -45 grams, 3 times a week is often effective with hepatitis.  
 
Epstein -Barr Virus (EBV) And Cytomegalovirus (CMV):  All viral (WBC and 
differential) and hepatic (SGPT/ALT, SGOT/AST, GGTP, serum alkaline phosphatase  [ALP]  and 
serum LDH) tests may be normal with  the presence of EBV or CMV; however, if  any of the tests 
are abno1mal, it generally will be SGPT/ALT or Serum Iron (increased).  If one of the patient's 
subjective complaints is chronic fatigue and a reason for the problem cannot  be identified,  the EBV 
and CMV titers should  be completed.  If one or more of the titers are positive, the supplemental 
program and diet requirements covering virus listed under the total WBC should be employed.

108 
 Other Causes For  An Increased SGPT/ALT And Less Common Causes For An  
Increased SGPT/ALT:  Acute and chronic pancreatitis, several types of cancer, acute and chronic 
biliary dysfunction,  alcoholism, diabetes,  congestive heart  failure,  chronic  ischemic heart disease, 
acute myocardial infarct, essential hypertension, influenza, rheumatoid arthritis, asthma, 
myocarditis, dermatomyositis.  See GGTP for further information on conditions involving the 
biliary tree  and SGOT/AST for further information on  conditions involving cardiac  dysfunction.  
Important  Considerations  With  An Abnormal  SGPT/ALT:  
 
If hemorrhoids  or varicosities  are present use Butcher's Broom Herb, as directed by the 
manufacture,  Quercetin  (ZI) - 2 tid, Complete  Kare  Spray  (ZI) topically  tid, C 1000  (ZI) 
- 1 tid and GB Complete (ZI)  - 2 tid. Insure the patient drinks at  least 8 -10 full glasses of pure 
water daily. Use the Roadmap  To Health  diet and avoid spicy  foods.  Also, check the patient for 
adrenal dysfunction.

109 
 SERUM  GAMMA  GLUTAMYL  TRANSFERASE  
GGTP,  GGT,  Gamma  Glutamyl  Transpeptidase  
 
Discussion:  GGTP is a more sensitive and specific indicator of liver dysfunction than serum 
alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and in some conditions than SGPT/ALT.  It is increased in all common 
forms of liver/biliary dysfunction and is generally increased above SGPT/ALT and SOOT/AST 
with biliary tree problems (gall bladder, common bile duct, and pancreas),  obstructive disease and 
alcoholism.  
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  SOOT/AST.  
 
Reference  Range:  9-48 U/L 
 
Optimum  Range:  9-30 U/L. 
 
Possible  Panic Range:  Above  100 U/L. 
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  GGTP:  
 
Biliary Obstruction:  GOT, serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and total serum bilirubin 
are significantly increased; SGPT/ALT and SOOT/AST will be  increased but, not proportionally 
as increased as GOT and serum ALP. Serum amylase increased, serum LDH increased, alpha 2 
globulin increased, LDH isoenzyme #3 and #5 will be increased if the obstruction is in the gall 
bladder, LDH isoenzyme #1, #5 and ser um ALP, will be increased if the obstruction is in the 
common bile duct.  Haptoglobin and transferrin  (fractions of alpha 2 and beta globulin) will 
consistently be increased.  Note:  If the GOT is  above 150  U/L in  conjunction  with a total serum 
bilirubin above 2.8 mg/dL, the patient should be immediately examined by a doctor qualified to 
diagnose and treat biliary obstruction.  Supplemental Support:   B6/Bl (ZI)  - 1 bid,  Magnesium 
Glycerophosphate Tablets (ZI)  - At bedtime to bowel tolerance, GB Complete (ZI) -3 tid, KI 
Caps  (ZI) - 1 daily and C-1000 (ZI) - Begin with 2 tid and increase to bowel tolerance.  After the 
patient is asymptomatic,  ensure they remain on this program at one -half the indicated dose for 
another 60 days.  Diet: Use the Roadmap To Health diet. Ensure  the patient drinks at least 8 -10 
full glasses of pure water each day, lightly steams all fruits and vegetables and eats one serving 
(two cups) daily of raw grated beets covered with the juice of one -half a lemon and two tablespoons 
full of unprocessed flax  seed oil.  
 
Alcoholism:  GOT and serum triglycerides significantly increased. SOOT/AST and 
SGPT/ALT increased; however, the GOT will generally be significantly higher than the 
SGPT/ALT and SOOT/AST.  Total serum bilirubin normal to increased, serum uric acid increased, 
alkaline phosphatase (ALP) isoenzyme al  increased, plasma and salivary cortisol can be increased 
or decreased depending upon the stage of the alcoholism (frequently cortisol is increased in the 
early stage and decreased in the late stage).  Liver caffeine c learance is also frequently abnormal.  
Supplemental Support:  First use a cleanse/detox program  and the Roadmap To Health Diet. 
After  continue diet and add Lithium Orotate (ZI)  - 1 qid. If the patient  has adrenal  
hyperfunction  use AD Hyper  (ZI) - 1 in the a.m. and 2 at noon.

110 
 If the patient has adrenal hypofunction use AD COMPLEX  (ZI) - 3 in the a.m.  and 3 at 
noon along with E.N.V./GBLV -HP (ZI) - 15 drops tid,  Stress H P (ZI) - 15 drops tid. If the 
patient is not able to sleep add Sympathetic Balance  (ZI) - 1-3 at bedtime. If the patient is 
debilitated use Arginine Complex  (ZI) - 1 tid and  C.G.F. (ZI)  - 5 tid and  protein powder/ amino 
acids . Diet:  Use the Roadmap To  Health diet. Ensure the patient drinks at least 8 -20 full glasses 
of water daily and is enrolled  in some type of prevention program (Alcoholics Anonymous). Be 
certain to check the patient's thyroid and vitamin D status and support as needed.  If the patient 
smokes allow them to continue until the alcoholism is  controlled (AA information).  
Cholangitis/Cholecystitis (Bile Duct And Gall Bladder Inflammation)/Biliary 
Insufficiency/Biliary Stasis:  GGT is frequently increased; but may be normal with biliary 
insufficiency or biliary stasis.  Serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) increased, SGPT IALT normal to 
increased, SGOT/AST normal to increased, serum total protein normal to increased, serum albumin 
decreased, ESR increased, CRP increased, urinary urobilinogen increased, neutrophils increased, 
basophils increased, total serum cholesterol incre ased, alpha lipoprotein increased, fecal fat 
increased. With gall bladder inflammation, LDH isoenzyme 3 and 5 will be increased, with  bile 
duct inflammation,  LDH  isoenzyme  1 and  5 will be increased.  If biliary  stasis or biliary 
insufficiency are suspected, always check for the presence of subjective indications (gas, bloating, 
pain between the shoulder blades, pain over the eyes, light colored stool, etc.)  Frequently the 
laboratory findings will be normal; however, the subjective indications will be present.  Treatment 
should be initiated if one or more of the subjective indicators are present. Supplemental  Support:  
GB Complete  (ZI) - 3 tid, HCL Complete (ZI) - Begin with 1 -2 in the middle  of each meal and 
increase to stomach tolerance and Phosphatidylcholine (BR) - 3 tid.  Diet:  Same as that indicated 
under biliary obstruction in this section of the manual.  Note:   Magnesium  Tauri nate (ZI) - 2 tid 
can be helpfu l with biliary stasis.  
 
Acute  And Chronic  Pancreatitis/Pancreatic  Insufficiency:  See serum  lipase.  
 
 
Other Causes For An Increased GGTP And Less Common Causes For An Increased  GGTP:  
Brucellosis, hepatitis, mononucleosis, several types of cancer, bacterial and viral infection, 
occasionally with parasites, diabetes, congestive heart failure, chronic ischemic heart disease, acute 
myocardial infarct, essential hypertension, influenza, rheumatoid arthritis, dermatomyositis, 
asthma, myocarditis, acute a nd chronic liver dysfunction.  See SGPT/ALT for further information 
on conditions involving the liver and SGOT/AST for further information on conditions involving 
cardiac dysfunction.

111 
 Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  GGTP:  
 
Increased GGT with increased serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) indicates a probable 
liver/biliary problem.  A normal GGT with an increased serum ALP indicates a probable bone 
problem.  
With biliary insufficiency, biliary stasis, or biliary obstruction (stones), fat -soluble  vitamin 
absorption will be reduced.  Therefore, after the biliary problem is cleared, supplementation with 
fat-soluble vitamins, manganese, and selenium (manganese and selenium are sensitive to biliary 
emulsification), should be considered. Use C.G.F.  (ZI) -3 tid. 
See important considerations  listed in  the section of this manual covering SGPT/ALT for 
information on hemorrhoids, varicosities, diarrhea, and constipation.  These problems are 
frequently present, secondary to liver or biliary dysfunction.  See the section of this manual 
covering the serum protein electrophoresis (SPE) for serum protein changes with biliary, liver, and 
pancreatic dysfunction.  
As stated  previously,  food allergy/sensitivity  is common  with biliary  dysfunction.  
 
If diet modification and supplementation  does not provide the desired results with biliary 
stasis, investigate the possibility of a hidden spleen problem.  
 
With common bile duct obstruction, the SGPT/ALT, SGOT/AST, GGT and  Alkaline  
phosphatase  will all be increased; however,  the GGT and Alkaline Phosphatase will be 
considerably more elevated that the SGPT/ALT and SGOT/AST.

112 
 SERUM  BILIRUBIN  
Total  Bilirubin  
 
Discussion:  Bilirubin is the end -product of hemoglobin breakdown by the spleen, liver kupfer cells  
and the  bone marrow (RES).  The liver alters bilirubin to  a form that  is excreted through the bile  or 
by the  kidneys.  Bilirubin is  increased in  and responsible for  the various  types of  jaundice. Bilirubin 
is classified as:  
 
Total  Bilirubin - A combination of  direct  and indirect  bilirubin. 
Direct Bilirubin - Post hepatic, water soluble.  
Indirect  Bilirubin  - Pre hepatic,  water  insoluble.  
 
Many laboratories report only total bilirubin and although this is  an important diagnostic value, 
where possible, the direct and indirect bilirubin should also be obtained.  This will assist in the 
determining if  the increased total bilirubin is  pre or post hepatic.  If either the direct or indirect 
has been  reported,  the missing  value  can be ascertained  by subtracting  the given  value from 
the total serum bilirubin.  
Related Tests:  GGT, SGPT/ALT, SOOT/AST, serum ALP and ALP isoenzymes, urinary bile, 
urobilinogen, RBC and indices, serum LDH and LDH isoenzymes.  
Reference  Range:  Total  Bilirubin  - 0-1.9 mg/dL.  
Direct Bilirubin - 0-0.3 mg/dL. 
Indirect  Bilirubin  - 0.1-1.6 mg/dL.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Same  as reference  range.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Total  Bilirubin  > 2.6  mg/dL.  
Direct Bilirubin > 0.8 mg/dL 
Indirect  Bilirubin  > 2.0 mg/dL.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  Bilirubin:  
 
Liver/Biliary  Dysfunction:  See SGPT/ALT  and GGTP.  
 
Several  Types  of Anemia:  See serum  ferritin,  serum  iron and MCV/MCH.  
 
Biliary  Obstruction:  See SGPT/ALT  and GGTP. Note: The total and direct bilirubin and 
total serum ALP are significantly increased, and the increases are out of proportion to the 
SGPT/ALT and GGT increases.  
Less  Common  Causes  for an Increased  Bilirubin:  Hepatitis  C, coronary  artery  disease  and 
chronic renal failure.  
 
Total/Direct/Indirect  Bilirubin  Decreased  In: None  significant.

113 
 Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Bilirubin:  
 
Increased  total bilirubin,  HGB,  HCT  and RBC  suggests  liver or thymus  dysfunction.  
 
Total  bilirubin  < 0.1, HCT  < 12.5 and RBC  < 4.00,  with serum  iron>  100, suggests 
spleen dysfunction.  
Gilbert's Syndrome  involves a  mild increase in  unconjugated  bilirubin due  to a decrease 
in one of the liver pathway enzymes and is the only significant chemistry abnormality  present with 
this syndrome. This is important clinically as a mild increase in bilirubin is often misdiagnosed as 
chronic hepatitis. The problem, presumably lifelong, is most often detected in young adults  with 
vague or  nonspecific complaints.  Some family members may be  affected; but, the peer reviewed 
literature differs on whether a  clear genetic predisposition is present.  In some cases, GB Complete 
(ZI), an increase in foods in the cabbage family and the elimination of all refined foods, alcohol, 
tobacco and caffeine, Is effective in reducing the mild elevation (2.0 to 4.0 mg/dL) of total bilirubin 
to normal.

114 
 SERUM  CREATINE  KINASE  
CPK,  CK, Serum/Total  Creatine  Phosphokinase  
 
Discussion:  CPK is an enzyme involved in catalyzing the breakdown of phosphocreatine to 
phosphoric acid and creatine.  CPK acts in the cell by liberating high energy phosphate from 
creatine phosphate.  This reaction furnishes energy for muscle contraction and nerve tissue 
function.  CPK is found primarily in skeletal muscle, brain and myocardial tissue; therefore, 
damage to any of these tissues will result in an increased  serum CPK.  Since CPK is released from 
the source tissue primarily during the destructive  process, inflammatory  processes without tissue 
damage will cause a minimal increase in the total serum CPK or specific  CPK  isoenzymes.  
Any patient  with  a significant increase in  total serum CPK is  a candidate for a CPK isoenzyme 
study.  
 
Related Tests:  CPK isoenzymes, serum ALP and ALP isoenzymes, serum LDH and LDH 
isoenzymes, SGPT/ALT, SGOT/AST, GGTP, WBC and differential, serum protein electrophoresis 
(SPE), serum and urinary creatinine, urinary ketosteroids , serum phosphorus,  total serum 
cholesterol, serum triglycerides, serum uric acid and ceruloplasmin.  
 
Reference Range:  22-198 U/L.  Females will normally have levels 20 -25 percent less than males, 
infants (up to one year of age) may have levels up to two times the adult range and total serum CPK 
will frequently be moderately increased during pregnancy. CPK can increase after moderate -
intensity exercise and with some patients on statin drugs (rhabdomyolysis).  
 
Optimum  Range:   30-180 U/L 
 
Possible Panic Range:  > 250 U/L (Complete the isoenzymes if there is no known cause for the 
increase.  
Common  Cause  for an Increase  in Total  CK/CPK:  
 
Muscular Dystrophy:  Both total CPK and the CPK Muscle Isoenzyme will be  increased, 
SGPT/ALT and SGOT/AST are generally increased, total serum LDH normal to increased, urinary 
creatinine decreased, urinary ketosteroids  decreased, serum  creatinine norm al to decreased. 
Supplemental Support:  This is  an extremely difficult metabolic problem, one  that does not 
frequently respond to supplemental and/or homeopathic therapy. However, after considering the 
pre-disposing factors and diet suggestions indicated in the Balancing Body Chemistry w/Nutrition 
LLC Protocol Manual the following sh ould be considered. S.O.S.  (ZI) 2 tid, SunFlax  Complex  
(ZI) - 2 tid, CircuPlus  (ZI) - 3 bid, and Phosphatidylcholine (ZI) - 2 tid  and amino acids.  
Additional supplementation and support will be determined by the pre -disposing factors identified 
(toxic element exposure, chemicals, parasites, stress, infection, etc.). Diet - Use the Roadmap To 
Health diet.

115 
 CREATINE  KINASE  ISOENZYMES  
CPK  Isoenzymes,  CK Isoenzymes,  CK Isoforms  
 
Discussion:  Total serum CPK can be  separated into three isoenzymes by electro -phoresis: 
CK:MM - Derived from skeletal muscle.  
CK:MB  - Derived  from  heart muscle  tissue.  
CK:BB  - Derived  from  brain  and nerve  tissue.  An increased  CK:BB  has also been 
reported to be a marker for cancer of the prostate, breast, ovary, colon, lung and digestive tract.  
 
Related Tests:  Total serum CPK, serum ALP and ALP isoenzymes, serum LDH and LDH 
isoenzymes, SGPT/ALT, SGOT/AST, serum protein electrophoresis (SPE), serum and urinary 
creatinine, urinary ketosteriods, serum phosphorus, serum cholesterol, serum triglycerides,  serum 
uric acid and ceruloplasmin.  
 
Reference  Range:  CK:MM  - 100 percent  of total.  
CK:MB  - Zero.  
CK-BB - Zero.  
Note:  Occasionally  an additional  migrating  isoenzyme  will be seen between  CK:MM  and 
CK:MB. This is  a normal finding and should not be confused with a pathological process.  
 
Alarm  Range:  CK:MB  > Zero.  
CK:BB  > Zero.  
 
Increased  In: See total serum  CPK.  
 
Decreased  In: See total serum  CPK.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  the CK/CPK  Isoenzymes:  
 
A split or  fractionation of the CK:MM isoenzyme as  seen on  the electrophoretic  tracing is 
often present with pancreatic dysfunction.  If the serum beta globulin is increased, liver dysfunction 
is also possible and should be ruled out.  
 
An increase  of CK:MB  occurs as the heart disease  progresses,  proceeded  by an increase 
in CK:MM. Total serum CPK often remains within the normal range until the myocardial infarct 
(MI) occurs.  
Brain  damage and inflammation will  cause both  the total CPK as  well as  brain  isoenzyme 
to increase along with SGPT/ALT and SGOT/AST.  Cholesterol and triglycerides are generally not 
increased, but the uric acid is often increased.  
Total CPK and CK -MM will be increased after moderate -intensity exercise bad with  some 
patient who do not tolerate statin drugs (rhabdomyolysis).

116 
 Total CPK and CPK:MM will often increase with muscle atrophy.  The serum creatinine 
will generally also increase in the initial stage of the atrophy and decrease as the atrophy mcreases.  
An increase in total CPK and CPK:BB has been reported in the literature to be a marker for 
cancer of the prostate, breast, ovary, lung and digestive tract.

117 
 WHITE  BLOOD  COUNT  
Leukocyte  Count,  Total  WBC,  White  Count  
 
Discussion:  Leukocytes (white blood cells) of the peripheral blood are divided into two groups, 
the granulocytes and the non -granulocytes.  Cells in these categories are:  
 
Granulocytes:  Polymorphonuclear  Neutrophils  (Segmented  and Bands).  
Eosinophils.  
Basophils.  
 
Non-Granulocytes:  Lymphocytes  
Monocytes  
 
Granulocytes originate in the bone marrow.  Monocytes (Non -Granulocyte)  also originate in  the 
bone marrow.  Lymphocytes originate from lymphoblasts in the spleen, lymph glands, tonsils, 
thymus, intestine and possibly the bone marrow and appendix. An increase or decrease in the  total 
number of white blood cells is the result of an increase or decrease in one or more of the above 
fractions; therefore, it is essential that a differential count be taken in addition to the total white 
blood count to ascertain where the increase or de crease is located.  The total WBC is a valuable 
tool in screening the system's defense mechanism against infection (virus, bacterial, fungal and 
parasitic) and inflammation. A significant ly increased or decreased total WBC is justification to 
conduct further immune testing (T and B lymphocyte subset assay, immunoglobulins, C -reactive 
protein, etc.).  
 
Related Tests:  WBC differential, serum albumin, serum protein electrophoresis (SPE), T  and B 
cell assay, C -reactive protein, RBC and indices, sedimentation rate, viral or bacterial cultures, 
comprehensive stool and digestive analysis (CSDA).  
 
Reference Range:  4.0-10.5xl0E3/uL Note:  Any stressful situation that leads to an increase in 
epinephrine production can  cause an  increase in  the total WBC.  In infants and  young children the 
WBC count from different sources (capillary versus venous versus arterial) should not be 
considered equivalent.  Also,  in the evaluation of  infection in  infants and children, several counts 
should be  taken from the  same source as  crying infants  and children will often show  leukocytosis 
with the differential falsely indica ting a bacterial infection.  
 
Optimum Range:  4500 -8,000 xl0E3/uL.  Note:  The total WBC will frequently  be slightly below  
the optimum range  for patients on  a diet high  in raw foods and slightly above the optimum range 
for patients on a highly refined diet.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  2,500  or above  15,000

118 
 Common  Causes  for an Increased  Total  WBC:  
 
Childhood Diseases (Measles, Mumps, Chicken -Pox, Rubella, etc.):  Total WBC is 
increased early in the disease process, decreased late.  Lymphocytes decreased early, increased late.  
Neutrophils increased early, decreased late.  The C -complement is increased in the acute phase and 
decreases in later stages. Gamma globulin and amylase are increased with mumps.  This is  the 
pattern commonly found; however, because of increases and decreases in  other WBC fractions 
(eosinophils, monocytes, basophils, etc.), the findi ngs relative to the WBC differential are variable.  
Supplemental Support:  Immune Plus (ZI) - 3 tid, Olive  Leaf (ZI)  - 1 bid, Viral  Hp (ZI) - 5 drops 
tid and Calcium Orotate  (ZI) - 1 daily, increase with fever greater than 101 degrees. If the child is coughing 
use Tiny Tots Cough Syrup (ZI) . After the child is asymptomatic continue with Immune Plus  (ZI) - 1 
daily and Olive Leaf  (ZI) - 2 tid.  Diet:  Increase fluid intake (avoid citrus juices), increase raw foods, 
vegetable juices and quality protein; avoid all mucous producing foods such as  dairy and gluten.  Note:  
Consultation with a doctor  trained to  treat  childhood diseases should be  considered as  bed rest  and 
quarantine may be required.  With mumps bed rest is  essential as  the incidence of orchitis and pancreatitis 
increases with excess activity.  
Active Viral Or Bacterial Infection:  Sedimentation rate increased, total serum globulin 
increased (the gamma globulin increases with inflammation and the alpha 1 and/or alpha 2 globulin 
will increase with tissue destruction and/or inflammation), C -complement increased, lymphocytes 
decreased with  the neutrophils increased, LDH Isoenzyme #1 increased, C -reactive protein 
increased, monocytes will increase during the recovery phase and band cells will be increased in 
the active phase.  Note:  Band cells are an excellent means of differentiating active from chronic 
infection; they will increase in the active phase and normalize i n the chronic or recovery phase.  
Supplemental Support:  Use the following alone or with antibiotic therapy (if indicated) 
irrespective of the  type of infection;  Oregano Oil Caps  (ZI) – 3 tid,  Immune Plus(ZI)  - 3 tid, 
Olive Leaf (ZI) - 2 tid, C 1000 (ZI) - 2 bid, increase to bowel tolerance . If the infection is bacterial  
add Saccharomyces  Boulardii (ZI) - 1 bid and Berberine  HCL (ZI) - 1 tid. If the infection  is 
virus  add Viral -HP (ZI) - 15 drops, tid .  Note: If the secretory IgA  is decreased ensure 
Saccharomyces boulardii (ZI), Immu ne Plus (ZI) are used regardless of the type of infection. 
Diet:  Use the Roadmap To Health diet and ensure the patient drinks at least 8 -10 glasses of pure 
water each day.  
 
Less Common Causes For An Increased Total WBC:  Intestinal parasites, several types of 
cancer, infectious mononucleosis, acute and chronic myelocytic leukemia, adrenal dysfunction, 
late pregnancy, pelvic inflammatory disease, asthma, emphysema, polycythemia and influenza 
with secondary bacterial infecti on.

119 
 Common  Causes  for a Decreased  Total  WBC:  
 
Chronic Viral or Bacterial Infection:  Frequently  the pattern seen with chronic infection will be opposite 
of that seen with active infection.  For example, the  total WBC will be decreased, the  lymphocyte count will 
be increased with  the neutrophils decreased and  the gamma globulin will be decreased, LDH Isoenzyme #1 
will be decreased due to a decrease in the total WBC and the monocytes will often be increased as  seen with 
recovery from an active infection. Supplemental Support:  Bacterial:  Use the program indicated for 
active bacterial infection. Viral:  Use the program indicated for active viral infection. Diet:  Use the diet 
recommendations listed for active viral or bacterial infection.  
Systemic Lupus Erythematosis:  Alpha -I acid glycoprotein increased (very reliable 
indicator), serum albumin decreased, antinuclear antibodies (ANA) positive with a speckled 
pattern (very reliable  indicator), C -complement proteins decreased, C -reactive protein increased, 
sedimentation rate increased, interleukin -6 increased, LDH increased, blood lymphocytes 
increased, blood neutrophils decreased, plasma progesterone decreased, BUN increased, and the  
rheumatoid factor  increased.  Supplemental Support:  Use the following after  consultation with  a 
doctor trained  in the treatment  of SLE; Immune Plus (ZI) - 4 tid, S.O.S. (ZI)  - 2 tid and  Arginex . 
Diet:  Use the Roadmap To Health diet and ensure the  patient drinks  at least 8-10 full glasses of  
water a  day. Note:  Adrenal dysfunction (hyper or hypo), sun sensitivity and food 
allergy/sensitivity are very common with SLE.  These problems should be investigated and treated 
it found to be present with the patient.  
Less Common Causes For  A Decreased Total WBC:  Hepatitis, several types of cancer, vitamin 
B-12, vitamin  B-6 and folate anemia, adrenal dysfunction, anterior pituitary dysfunction, 
parathyroid hyperfunction, intestinal parasites (chronic), rheumatoid arthritis.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Total  WBC:  
 
Several  prescribed  drugs can have an effect on the total WBC and differential.  Always 
investigate this possibility before initiating supplemental support.  
Females  over 40 years  of age tend to  run a low normal  total WBC  (hormonal  influence).  
 
Most viral and bacterial infections will result in adrenal fatigue.  Adrenal support in the 
form of S.OS. (ZI), C.G.F. (ZI), and ashwagandha  should  be considered during both the active 
and chronic or recovery phase of the infection.  
 
The following high -energy soup  is often helpful in restoring adrenal function during the 
active, chronic and recovery phase of viral and bacterial infections:  
1 package  of green beans, 1 cup of chopped celery, 1  sliced zucchini,  1 medium chopped onion,  
1cup of tomato juice,1 cup of spring water, 1 tablespoons  of raw honey,1 teaspoon of paprika, 1cup 
of chicken broth, pepper to taste.  Combine  ingredients  and simmer  for one hour or until vegetables  
are tender.

120 
 Childhood Inner Ear Infections  will frequently cause an increase in the total WBC (acute 
phase) or a decrease in the total WBC (chronic phase). Supplemental Support:  Use the following 
supplemental program with or without prescribed support; Immune Plus  (ZI) - 6 tid (use increased 
level in the acute phase), 8X Pancreatin  (ZI) - 1 bid  on an empty  stomach,  SunFlax Complex  
(ZI) - 2  bid and Olive Leaf (ZI)  - 1 bid.  If antibiotic therapy is  being employed, or  has been 
employed, add Saccharomyces Boulardii ZI)  - 1 bid. Diet: Eliminate all  hydrogenated fats  and 
oils, fruit juice, dairy products, gluten, canned, processed and refined foods from the child's diet. 
Use only pure water for drinking and cooking.  For supplemental therapy to be effective all 
dairy products must be removed from the child's diet.  
Note:  The lower level of  the nutrients indicated above should be  used for  children under 3  years 
of age and the higher  level  for children  over 3 years of age.  For infants (under  1 year of age), use 
one-half of the lowest level indicated.  
 
As previously indicated under serum albumin, an increased or decreased total WBC in 
conjunction with a lymphocyte count under 20 percent, untreated total cholesterol significantly 
below the historical  average and a  serum albumin below 4.0 is  a pattern that  frequently  indicates 
a frank or developing neoplasm.  
 
Zinc Orotate (ZI), SunFlax Complex (ZI), and Lithium Orotate (ZI) will frequently 
normalize a decreased total WBC  when previously mentioned supplementation is not effective.  
 
BIO-FILMS  
 
Organized communities of bacteria that adheres to the surface  surrounded by a  mesh like matrix  
of extracellular  polymeric substances  (EPS)  that contain  single bacterial species  or multiple  
bacterial  species. EPS is  a slimy filmlike  substance produced by the bacteria of  the biofilm  and is 
composed of polysaccharides, proteins and nucleic acids.  
The following supplements have been shown to be helpful in removing biofilm : Oregano Oil  
Caps  (ZI) – 2  tid, Mold Antigen HP (ZI) - 15 drops tid and 8X Pancreatin (ZI)  - 1 qid on an 
empty stomach.

121 
 NEUTROPHILS  
Segs  
 
Discussion:  The chief  function  of the neutrophil  is that of phagocytosis.  
 
Related  Tests:  See the tests listed  under  WBC  total.  
 
Reference  Range:  35-65 percent  of total  WBC.  
 
Optimum  Range:  40-60 percent  of total WBC.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  15 percent  of total WBC  or above  80 percent  of total WBC.  
 
Common Causes and Less Common Causes for an Increased Neutrophil Percentage:  In general, 
neutrophils are increased in active viral or bacterial infections.  For further information see the 
section of this manual covering total WBC.  
Common  Causes  and Less Common  Causes for a Decreased  Neutrophil  Percentage:  In general, 
neutrophils are decreased  in chronic viral or bacterial infections.  For further  information see the 
section of this manual covering total WBC.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Neutrophil  Percentage:  
 
Neutrophils originate in  the bone marrow;  therefore, if  supplemental feeding  for infection 
(see total WBC) is unsuccessful in increasing the neutrophil count,  consider adding Osteo -B Plus 
2 tablets, 3 times a day to the patient's program.  
 
Calcium  and magnesium  (Ca/Mg  Zyme  - BR) are required  to produce  a strong phagocyte 
(phagocytosis is the chief function of the neutrophil).  
 
Neutrophil hypersegmentation index  is an excellent test for determining folate need.  If 
positive (below 3), folic acid supplementation using C.G.F. (ZI)  at 2 tid  should  he considered.  
Because of the substantial body of research indicating that folic acid deficiency is common with 
birth defects, a neutrophil  hyper segmentation  index should be  completed on  any female who is  
considering pregnancy or is of child bearing age.  
 
Lithium  Orotate  (ZI) - 1 tid is often helpful when other supplementation is ineffective for 
increasing neutrophils as seen with chronic viral or bacterial infections.

122 
 NONSEGMENTED  NEUTROPHILS  
Bands  
Discussion:  Nonsegmented  neutrophils ( metamyelocytes ) are the youngest forms that are 
normally found in the peripheral blood.  They are also known as "bands".  These forms are increased 
with acute infection, with or without an absolute increase in the total WBC.  An increase in the 
bands constitutes a shift to the left as described by Shilling.  
Related  Tests:  See the tests listed  under  WBC  total.  
 
Reference  Range:  0-5 percent  of the total WBC.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Below  2 percent  of total WBC.  
 
Alarm  Range:  Above  10 percent  of total WBC.  
 
Common  Cause  For An Increased  Non-Segmented  Neutrophil  Percentage : A c t i v e  infection.  
See the section of this manual covering the total  WBC for supplemental support, diet requirements 
and other laboratory changes.  
 
Important  Considerations  With  An Increased  Non-Segmented  Neutrophil  Count:  
 
Irrespective of the supplemental program used, when the band cells are increased,  
additional  thymus  (Immune Plus - ZI) at 3 tid and C-1000  (ZI)- 2 bid, increase  to bowel  
tolerance,  should  be used  for a two to three  week  period.

123 
 LYMPHOCYTES  
Lymphs  
 
Discussion:  Lymphocytes  help to destroy  the toxic  products  of protein  metabolism.  
 
Related  Tests:  See the  tests listed  under  WBC  total.  
 
Reference  Range:  14-46 percent  of total WBC.  
 
Optimum  Range:  24-39 percent  of total WBC.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  20 percent  of total  WBC  or above 75  percent  of total WBC.  
 
Common  Causes and Less Common  Causes for an Increased  Lymphocyte  Percentage:  In many 
cases the  lymphocyte percentage is increased in  chronic viral and bacterial infections.  For further 
information see the section of this manual covering total WBC.  
Common  Causes  and Less  Common  Causes  for a  Decreased  Lymphocyte  Percentage:  In 
many cases the lymphocyte percentage is decreased in active viral and bacterial infections.  For 
further information see the section of this manual covering the total WBC.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Lymphocyte  Percentage:  
 
Lymphocytes are an indication of the system's ability to handle toxins; when increased, 
excessive systemic toxins are possible, when decreased, active infection is possible.  
Frequently proteolytic enzymes 8X Pancreatin (ZI)  - 1 qid on an empty stomach will 
help to normalize  the lymphocyte count with  chronic  viral  problems.  Increased vitamin C  as 
C-1000  (ZI) - 2 bid, increase  to bowel  tolerance, Quercetin  (ZI) - 2 tid and lithium (Lithium 
Orotate (ZI) - 1 tid, increased Immune Plus  (ZI) - 9 tid Lymphatic Drainage (ZI)  - 2 tsp tid 
and Viral -HP (ZI)- 15 drops tid  are also helpful  in some  cases  of chronic  virus.  
Lymphocytes will tend to increase with chronic viral conditions.  Often the 
lymphocytes will increase to a level equal to or  exceeding the neutrophil level.

124 
 MONOCYTES  
Monos  
 
Discussion:  Monos  phagocytize some bacteria, particulate matter and protozoa.  In the 
inflammatory process neutrophils predominate for about three days then they break up and the
