monocytes  remain to phagocytize  fragments of cells, etc.  This is the reason you will often find an 
increase in the monocytes during the recovery  phase of an infection.  
 
Related  Tests:  See total WBC.  
 
Reference  Range:  4-13 percent  of total WBC.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Below  7 percent  of total WBC.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Above  17 percent  of total WBC.  
 
Common  Causes  and Less  Common  Causes  for an Increased  Monocyte  Percentage:   In general 
the monocyte percentage is increased with recovery from an infection, with chronic infection, with 
prostate hypertrophy and with ovarian or uterine dysfunction.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Increased  Monocyte  Percentage:  
 
Always  rule out liver dysfunction with  increased monocytes. 
Increased monocytes indicate excessive tissue breakdown.  
An increase in the monocytes with an increase in the basophils (above 1.0) and even a mild 
increase in the eosinophils (above 3.0) is  reason to suspect intestinal parasites.  
The monocyte percentage will frequently increase with a decrease in the lymphocyte 
percentage with Hodgkin's disease and several other forms of cancer.  
 
An increase in  monocytes will cause and increase in  fo1m cells  with a  resulting initiation 
or increase in atherosclerosis.  In this case L.P.A. Plus (ZI) - 2 tid and CircuPlus (ZI) - 3-4 bid 
should be considered.

125 
 T AND  B CELL  LYMPHOCYTE  SUBSET  ASSAY  
Lymphocyte  Marker  Studies,  Lymphocyte  Receptor  Studies,  
T And B Cell Typing, Lymphocyte Subset Analysis  
 
Discussion:  Lymphocytes  can be divided  into two major subpopulations,  T and B lymphocytes. 
T cells are acted upon by the thymus and are concerned with cell -mediated immunity.  B cells 
become  antibody -producing  cells.  The combined  activity  of the  T and  B cells provides immunity  
against infectious agents, foreign tissue and oncogenic  agents.  Since the level of T cells correlates  
with the functional status of cell -mediated  immune systems and the level of B cells correlates  with 
the functional  status of the hurnoral  immune  system, quantification can aid in the assessment of 
the immune competence of patients suffering from chronic immune dysfunct ion. 
 
Related  Tests:  See the tests listed  under  WBC  total.  
 
Reference  Range:  T Cells:  60-80 percent.  
B Cells:  5-15 percent.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Sarne  as reference  range.  
 
Possible Panic Range(s):  Depletion of the CD -4 lymphocytes is the single most significant 
surrogate marker used to study the progression of human immunodeficiency  virus (HIV).  When 
the CD -4 values drop more than 10 percent below the laboratory  range or  the CD-4 to CD -8 ratio 
is less than 1.0 to 3.5, progression to clinical AIDS is probable.  CD-4 counts are also useful in 
predicting the course of Cryptosporidiurn infections.  
 
Note:  T and  B cell lymphocytes  are divided  into several  subsets  such as CD -2, CD-3, CD-5, 
CD-7, CD -8, etc.  Absolute levels and ratios are generally provided by the laboratory with the T and 
B cell lymphocyte subset assay and are invaluable in the diagnosis of chronic immune dysfunction.  
Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  T And  B Cell Lymphocytes:  
T cells are found  in the alpha  1 globulin  region  of the serum  protein  electrophoresis 
(SPE) and B cells are found in the gamma globulin region of the SPE.  
 
Immune Plus  (ZI) and Viral -Homeopathic  (ZI) should  be considered for all cases 
where the CD-4 lymphocytes are decreased.  
 
T and B cell lymphocytes  will frequently  be abnormal with patients  who are taking 
steroids, immune suppressive drugs or have recently had surgery requiring anesthesia.

 EOSINOPHILS  
Eos, Eosin  
 
Discussion:  Eosinophils  have  an important  role in detoxification  and the breakdown  and 
removal of protein.  
Related  Tests:  Comprehensive  stool  and digestive  analysis (CSDA) to include ova and parasites, 
food allergy/sensitivity testing, food elimination plans, IgE, total WBC and  differential, RBC and 
indices, hemagglutination  inhibition (amoebas), LDH (LD) and methylene blue dye tests (useful 
with the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis).  
Reference  Range:  0-7 percent  of total WBC.  
 
Optimum  Range:  0-3 percent  of total  WBC.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Above  15 percent  of total WBC.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  Eosinophil  Percentage:  
 
Intestinal Parasites:  IgE increased, basophils normal to increased, monocytes normal to 
increased, CSDA positive for parasites or ova, serum iron normal to decreased, HGB and HCT 
normal to decreased and LDH increased with amoebic infections (will return to normal in 
approximately  92 percent of the cases when a complete cure is achieved). The laboratory tests may 
be normal (especially with  amoebic parasites); however, if  one or more  of the following risk factors 
or subjective indications are present  and a reason(s) for the problem cannot  be determined,  a 
comprehensive  stool and digestive  analysis (CSDA) to include parasitology, should be 
accomplished to rule out the presence of parasites. Risk Factors:  Owns house pets, works around 
farm animals, family members previously diagnosed with parasites, symptoms began after foreign 
travel, has used untreated water, eats head lettuce, eats raw meat and/or fish. Subjective 
Indications:  Chronic allergy/sensitivity,  skin disorders, dry or scaly skin, itchy skin, dull or pallid 
complexion, dark circles under the eyes, lack of muscle tone, loose "crepe paper" skin, prematurely  
aged skin, burning or itching anus, chronic gas or bloating, chronic  constipation or diarrhea, 
reduced or excessive appetite, difficulty gaining or losing weight,  normal weight with large 
abdomen, chronic fatigue, wakes up groggy or fatigued, chronic depression, attention deficit 
disorder, hyperactivity (especially chil dren), bites nails, picks nose, deep nocturnal cough 
(unproductive),  dull eyes.  These are only a  small number of  the myriad of symptoms that can be 
present with undetected intestinal parasites. When in doubt, complete a stool analysis for ova and 
parasites.  Supplemental Support:   Oregano Oil Caps  (ZI) – 3 tid, HCL  Complete  (ZI) - 1-2 tid 
in the middle of  the meal,  8X Pancreatin  (ZI) 1 qid on an empty  stomach,  MSM  Plus (ZI) - 
1 tid, and Para Comp (ZI), 1 tsp bid (most important supplement). In the third  week  of treatment  
add Saccharomyces  Boulardii  (ZI) - 1 bid. Diet:  Use the Roadmap To Health diet.

inflammation  test (FIT) positive, basophils  normal to increased, total serum globulin  below 2.4

Important  Considerations  with  an Increased  Eosinophil  Percentage:  
 
A random pattern of increased and decreased mineral values on  a hair-mineral analysis is

129 
 Intestinal parasites should be ruled out with any chronic ICV problem. 
Intestinal parasites should be  ruled  out with all chronic  low back  disc problems.  
When ordering a stool analysis for ova and parasites always use a laboratory that specializes 
in this type of examination.  
With intestinal parasites (especially amoebic) always complete a stool analysis for ova  and

be placed on prescription  drugs to eradicate the parasitic infestation.  Often, neither supplemental 
support nor  prescription drugs  will eliminate an  amoebic problem.  If this is the  case,  one of the 
anti-malaria drugs  should be  considered along with  the supplemental  support.

130 
 BASOPHILS  
Basos  
 
Discussion:  During  inflammation,  basophils  deliver  heparin  to the  inflamed  tissue  to prevent 
clotting; therefore, basophils will almost always be increased with tissue inflammation.  
 
Related  Tests:  C-reactive  protein,  erythrocyte  sedimentation  rate (ESR),  serum  protein 
electrophoresis  (SPE), WBC and differential, total protein, RBC and indices, fibrinogen.  
 
Reference  Range:  0-3 percent  of total WBC.  
 
Optimum  Range:  0-1 percent  of total WBC.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Above  5 percent  of the total WBC.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  Basophil  Percentage:  
 
Tissue  Inflammation:   See C-reactive  protein.  
 
Intestinal  Parasites:  See eosinophils.  
 
Childhood  Diseases:  See total WBC.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  of Basophil  Increase:  Polycythemia,  influenza,  thyroid  hypofunction.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Increased  Basophil  Percentage:  
 
Complete  a CDSA  to rule  out intestinal  parasites if the basophils  are increased  with no 
indication of inflammation.  
When  CRP  or the sed rate is not  available,  a basophil  percent  greater  than 1 should  be 
considered as a primary marker for inflammation.

131 
 BLOOD  PLATELETS  
Platelet  Count,  Thombocyte  Count  
 
Discussion:  Platelets are involved with the clotting of blood and with the retraction of clots. 
Platelets are generally 2 -3 microns in diameter; but large forms appear when production is 
increased.  Production is  controlled by thrombopoietin.  Platelets survive an  average of  8-10 days 
and are subject to circadian rhythms with the highest count occurring during the midday.  
Related Tests:  WBC and differential, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C -reactive protein, total 
cholesterol, HDL, LDL and VLDL cholesterol,  triglycerides, serum protein electrophoresis,  RBC, 
HGB, HCT, MCV, MCH, MPV and fibrinogen.  
Reference  Range:  150,000 -450,000  cu.mm.  
Note:  Platelet  counts  above  500,000  are often present  with healthy  children.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Same  as reference  range.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  50,000  or above  600,000  cu.mm.  
 
Common Causes For  An Increased Blood Platelet Count:  Arteriosclerosis, several types of cancer, 
inflammatory arthritis, several types of anemia, polycythemia, during pregnancy (slight increase), 
with the use of oral contraceptives and during marrow regeneration after bleeding.  
 
Common  Causes  For A Decreased  Blood  Platelet  Count:  Several  types of  cancer,  several 
types of  anemia, liver dysfunction, and with several prescribed drugs such as quinidine, heparin, 
gold salts, sulfas and digitoxin which result in bone marrow suppression. Prior to initiating 
supplemental  support to increase the platelet count, insure your patient is questioned  regarding the 
use of any drug that is known to decrease platelet production.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Blood  Platelet  Count:  
 
An increased or decreased platelet count is found with several metabolic conditions; 
however, when the reason for the abnormal platelet count cannot be determined, the following 
program  should  be utilized  to increase  or decrease  the platelet  count:  SunFlax  Complex  (ZI) 
- 2 tid, Olive  Leaf  (ZI) - 2 tid, Lithium  Orotate  (ZI) - 1 tid, Magnesium 
Glycerophosphate (ZI)  -at bedtime to bowel tolerance and chlorophyll.  
 
With purpura  or petechiae (spider veins)  the platelet count will often be increased or 
decreased depending upon the severity of the condition.  Consider the following supplemental 
support  for purpura  or petechiae:  C-1000  (ZI) - 2 bid, increase  to bowel  tolerance, C.G.F. 
(ZI) -4 tid, Quercetin  (ZI)-2 tid, SunFlax Complex (ZI )-2 bid, 8X Pancreatin (ZI)  -1 bid 
on an empty stomach and  chlorophyll.

132 
 Mean Platelet Volume (MPV, PDW, Platelet Indices):  Mean Platelet Volume (MPV) 
indicates platelet sizing.  It is currently used in  the diagnosis of  certain hematological diseases, to 
assess platelet function, in the evaluation of thrombocytopenia and as a guide for platelet 
transfusion. Normal ranges vary depending upon the patient's age and sex; therefore laboratory 
ranges should be  considered as  metabolic ranges.  Most laboratory manuals indicate that MPV is 
generally unreliable if the platelet count is decreased and, in most cases,  the MPV will only be 
abnormal when the platelet count is abnormal. Several laboratory  manuals also indicate  that by 
itself MPV is  "a test in search of a disease ."

133 
 RED  BLOOD  COUNT  
RBC,  Erythrocyte  Count,  Red Blood  Cell Count  
 
Discussion:  The adult  erythrocyte  (RBC)  is a carrier  of oxygen  by reason  of the hemoglobin 
(HOB) it contains.  
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those listed  in the section  of this manual  covering  hemoglobin  (HOB).  
 
Reference  Range:  Males:  4.20-6.00 million  cu/mm.  
Females:  3.90-5.50 million  cu/mm.  
Note:  The RBC  is normally  higher  for individuals  residing  at high altitudes.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Males:  4.20-4.90 million  cu/mm.  
Females:  3.90-4.50 million  cu/mm.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Males:  Below  3.50 or above  6.00 million  cu/mm.  
Females:  Below  3.00 or above  5.50 million  cu/mm.  
 
Common  Causes For  An Increased  Red Blood  Count:  
 
Polycythemia:  See the section  of this manual  covering  hemoglobin  (HOB)  for 
laboratory changes, supplemental support, and diet requirements.  
 
Respiratory  Distress (Asthma/Emphysema) : See the section of this manual  covering 
hemoglobin (HOB) for laboratory changes, supplemental support, and diet requirements.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  For An Increased  Red Blood  Count:  Adrenal  hyperfunction, cystic 
fibrosis, several types of cancer, several hereditary anemias, essential hypertension and shock.  
 
Common  Causes For  A Decreased  Red Blood  Count:  
 
Iron  Anemia:  See the section  of this manual  covers  serum  iron for laboratory  
changes,  supplemental  support . 
 
Less Common Causes For A Decreased RBC:  Vitamin B -12, vitamin B -6, folate or molybdenum  
anemia, liver and renal dysfunction,  several  hereditary  anemias and several types of cancer.  
 
Important  Considerations With  An Abnormal  Red Blood  Count:  See the section  of this 
manual covering serum iron, serum ferritin, percent of saturation, MCV, MCH, HOB and HCT.

134 
 RETICULOCYTE  COUNT  
Tic Count,  Retie  Count  
 
Discussion:  The normal erythrocyte (RBC) is a non -nucleated round cell that originates in the bone 
marrow from a nucleated  cell (erythroblast).  Although  the nuclei are normally not present in the 
circulating blood, a few cells, when stained with vital blue, retain a blue reticulum in the circulating 
blood.  These are  called reticulocytes.  This is  an excellent test  for confirming chronic microscopic  
bleeding.  Note:  This  test is underutilized,  especially  when  one considers  it is at a pivotal 
decision -making juncture.  
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  in the section  of this manual  covering  hemoglobin  (HGB).  
 
Reference  Range:  0.5-1.5 percent  of 1000  red blood cells.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Same  as reference  range.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Above  3.0 percent  for adults.  
 
Common  Causes  For An Increased  Reticulocyte  Count:  
 
Microscopic Internal Bleeding:  TIBC and transferrin increased, serum iron normal to 
decreased, serum ferritin normal to decreased, HGB and HCT normal to decreased.  If the 
reticulocyte count is increased with a decreased TIBC or transferrin, the probability of microscopic 
internal bleeding is high.  This patient should be referred to a doctor qualified to diagnose  and treat 
internal  bleeding.  Supplemental  Support:  Iron Plus (ZI), to level needed to control iron anemia, 
C.G.F. (ZI) - 3 tid and HCL  Complete  (ZI) - 1- 2 in the middle of each meal.  Add protein powder 
and chlorophyll.  Diet:  Use the Roadmap To Health diet. Note:  As indicated previously,  this 
patient  should  be evaluated  by a doctor  trained  to treat  microscopic internal bleeding.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  For an Increased  Reticulocyte  Count:  Several  types  of cancer, 
hereditary anemias, vitamin C  anemia, heavy metal body burdens, renal and liver dysfunction.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  For A Decreased  Reticulocyte  Count:  Vitamin  B-12, vitamin B -6 and 
folate anemia, adrenal hypofunction , and anterior  pituitary hypofunction.  
 
Important  Considerations  With  An Abnormal  Reticulocyte  Count:  
 
The reticulocyte count is an excellent means for measuring the effect of therapy with 
microscopic internal bleeding (it  will decrease if  the therapy is  successful) and  for measuring the 
efficacy of supplementation in cofactor anemias (if the reticulocyte count is decreased, it will 
increase when supplementation with vitamin B -12, vitamin B -6 or folate is  successful).

135 
 HEMOGLOBIN  
HGB,  Hb 
Discussion:  Hemoglobin (HGB) is the major component of the red blood cell (RBC) and functions 
in the transport of oxygen.  It also acts to buffer carbon dioxide formed during metabolic activity. 
There are considerable physiological variations in the HGB levels of healthy individuals.  Infants 
tend to have higher levels of HGB with the levels declining to levels somewhat  below adult levels 
throughout  childhood.  Levels in the elderly  will often  be somewhat below  the adult normal range  
and levels  for patients above 5,000  feet may be  normally increased, but still within the laboratory  
range.  HGB should be evaluated with HCT, RBC, MCV, MCH, serum ferritin, serum iron and 
TIBC or transferrin and percent of saturation to determine the cause of anemia and the type of 
anemia.  
Related  Tests:  HCT,  RBC,  MCV, MCH, serum  iron, serum  ferritin,  TIBC  or transferrin, percent 
of saturation, total serum globulin and phosphorus  (HCl need), reticulocyte  count, alpha  1 and 
alpha 2 globulin (asthma and emphysema), total protein and albumin (dehydration).  
Reference  Range:  Female:  11.5-15.0 g/dL 
Male:  12.5-17.0 g/dL 
Female  above  5,000  feet: 12.0-16.0 g/dL 
Male above  5,000  feet: 13.0-18.0 g/dL 
 
Optimum  Range:  Female:  13-2-14.5 g/dL 
Male:  13.9-15.8 g/dL 
Female  above  5,000  feet: 13.2-15.5 g/dL 
Male  above  5,000  feet: 13.9-17.0 g/dL 
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  10.0 or above  18.0 g/dL.  
 
Common  Causes  for Increased  Hemoglobin:  
 
Dehydration:   See total protein.  
 
Emphysema:   See eosinophils.  
Asthma:  See eosinophils.  
 
Polycythemia:  HCT increased, MCV and MCH normal to  decreased, serum iron normal 
to decreased, total bilirubin increased, total WBC increased, serum uric acid increased, basophils 
increased, eosinophils increased, alkaline phosphatase (ALP) increased, blood platelets  increased, 
neutrophils increased and serum vitamin B -12 increased. The following information also applies 
to polycythemia vera.  The Vera form is a primary disease that requires intense medical treatment,
