Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  Hemoglobin:  See the sections  of this manual 
covering serum iron, transferrin, percent of saturation, serum ferritin, MCV, MCH and HCT.

137 
 HEMATOCRIT  
HCT,  Microhematocrit,  Packed  Cell Volume,  PCV  
 
Discussion:  The packed cell volume (HCT) is the percentage of the total volume occupied by 
packed red blood cells (RBC) when a given volume of whole blood is centrifuged at a constant 
speed for a constant period -of-time.  The HCT along with HGB are two of the most reliable 
indicators for determining the degree of  anemia or polycythemia. Note:  Patients residing at high 
altitudes will frequently have an increased HCT.  This is a normal finding.  
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  in the section  of this manual  covering  hemoglobin  (HGB).  
 
Reference  Range:  Male:  36.0-50.0 percent  
Female:  34.0-44.0 percent  
Male  above  5000  feet: 37.0-55.0 percent  
Female above  5000  feet: 35.0-49.0 percent  
 
Optimum  Range:  Male:  40.0-48.0 percent.  
Female:  37.0-44.0 percent.  
Male  above  5000  feet: 40.0-52.0 percent  
Female  above  5,000  feet: 37.0-48.0 percent  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  32 percent  or above  52 percent.  
 
Common  Causes  and Less  Common  Causes  for an Increased  Hematocrit:  See HgB.  
 
Common  Causes  and Less  Common  Causes  for a Decreased  Hematocrit:  See HgB.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Hematocrit:  
 
See the sections  of this manual  covering  serum  iron, serum ferritin,  MCV  and MCH.  
 
HCT above the optimum range can indicate spleen hyperfunction; HCT below the optimum 
range can indicate thymus hypofunction.  
 
Except for patients residing at altitudes more than 5,000 feet above sea  level, HCT levels 
increased above 50 percent have been associated with morbidity and mortality from cardio­ 
vascular disease.

138 
 MEAN  CORPUSCULAR  VOLUME  
MCV  
 
Discussion:  The MCV indicates the volume in cubic microns occupied by an  average single red 
blood cell.  A MCV increase or decrease along with an increase or decrease in the MCH is a 
significant finding for vitamin B -12, folate, iron, molybdenum, copper or vitamin B -6 anemia. 
MCV and MCH should normally be viewed together to  ascertain a  possible vitamin B -6, vitamin 
B-12 or folate anemia.  The suspicion of vitamin B -6, vitamin B -12 or folate anemia should be 
confirmed with a  serum or urinary methylmalonic acid and homocysteine.  
 
Related  Tests:  Serum  or urinary  methylmalonic  acid and homocysteine,  MCH,  serum  iron, 
serum ferritin, HGB, HCT, RBC and TIBC or transferrin.  
 
Reference  Range:  80.0-98.0 fL 
 
Optimum  Range:  82.0-89.9 fL 
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  76.0 or above  99.0 fL 
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  MCV:  
 
Vitamin B -12/Folate Anemia:  Urinary or serum methylmalonic acid and/or urinary or 
serum homocysteine increased, MCH increased above 31.9,  HGB and HCT  normal to  decreased, 
LDH Isoenzyme #1 (heart) increased, serum iron normal to increased, serum gastrin increased with 
digestive inflammation and decreased with hypochlorhydria, serum uric acid will be decreased with  
chronic  vitamin B -12 and folate anemia, reticulocytes normal to  decreased. Note:  If the MCV is  
above 89.9  in conjunction with  the MCH  above 31.9, the probability of  vitamin B - 12 or folate 
anemia is very high.  This finding should be confirmed with a serum or urinary methylmalonic acid 
(vitamin B -12) and serum or  urinary homocysteine (folate and vitamin B -6). Supplemental 
Support:  C.G.F. (ZI) - 4 tid (contains needed B complex containing hydroxocobalamin  with the 
porcine stomach parenchyma and intrinsic factor, P -5-P, benfotiamine  and methyl -folate),  GB 
Complete (ZI) - 2 tid and HCL Complete (ZI) - 1-2 in the middle of each  meal (h ypochlorhydria  
is a common finding with vitamin B -12 anemia and is  often nexus to the anemia). Diet: Use the 
Roadmap To Health diet. If the methylmalonic acid and/or the homocysteine indicate a need for 
vitamin B -12 and folate and oral supplementation does not normalize the MCV/MCH within 30 
days, I V B-12 and may be required to resolve the problem. Note:  Anytime a patient is  
supplementing with  vitamin B -12, the  serum cobalamin (vitamin B -12) will normally be high 
or increased above the lab range.  
 
Dehydration:  See serum  total protein,  other  serum  indictors  and physical  signs.  
Less Common Causes For An Increased MCV:  Several types of hereditary anemia, high altitude, 
thyroid hypofunction, alcoholism, several types of cancer, vitamin C anemia, multiple sclerosis 
(MS), liver disease, hypochlorhydria and problems involving gut inflammation.

139 
 Common  Causes  for a Decreased  MCV:  
 
Iron  Anemia:  See serum  iron. 
 
Microscopic  Internal  Bleeding:  See reticulocyte  count.  
 
Less Common Causes For A Decreased MCV:  Intestinal parasites, several types of cancer, 
vitamin C anemia, vitamin B -6 anemia (serum iron will be normal with B -6 anemia), toxic element 
exposure, iron anemia secondary to digestive inflammation or hypochlorhydria,  thyroid 
hyperfunction, several hereditary anemias,  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  MCV:  
 
Sympathetic Balance  (ZI) at 3 tid should  be considered  in all cases  of nerve 
inflammation, nerve degeneration and nerve damage secondary to diabetes.  
An iron to copper ratio of less than one to one on a hair mineral analysis indicates a possible 
vitamin B -12 or folate need.  
 
If vitamin B -12, vitamin B -6 or folate is being provided, but the expected results are not 
being obtained, consider the possibility  of a cofactor deficiency  (magnesium,  essential fatty acids, 
copper and/or molybdenum).  
 
If the serum  iron and serum ferritin  levels are normal  and the MCV, MCH, HCT and HGB 
are all decreased, toxic element exposure should be ruled out (complete a hair mineral analysis, 
urinalysis, or red blood cell analysis).  If toxic element exposure is present, consult the document 
written by Balancing Body Chemistry with Nutrition LLC (available from 
zorexinternational@gmail.com).  
 
An increased  MCV  can cause  an increase  in Ale. This is not  a common  finding, however 
if serial checks of the serum glucose are normal with an increase in MCV, MCV  increase should 
be ruled out as the cause of the increased  Ale.

140 
 MEAN  CORPUSCULAR  HEMOGLOBIN  
MCH  
Discussion:  MCH indicates the weight of hemoglobin in a single red blood cell.  MCH increase or 
decrease along with an  increase or decrease in MCV is  a significant finding for vitamin B -12, 
folate, iron, copper and vitamin B -6 anemia.  MCV and MCH should generally be viewed together 
to ascertain a possible vitamin B -6, vitamin B -12 or folate anemia.  The suspicion of vitamin B -6, 
vitamin B -12 or folate anemia should be confirmed with a serum or urinary methylmalonic acid 
and serum or urinary homocysteine.  
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  indicated  under  MCV.  
 
Reference  Range:  27.0-34.0 micro -micro  grams.  
 
Optimum  Range:  27.0-31.9 micro -micro  grams.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below 24.0  or above  34.0 micro -micro  grams.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased MCH:  
 
Vitamin  B-12/Folate  Anemia:  See MCV.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  For An Increased  MCH:  Several  types of hereditary  anemias,  thyroid 
hypofunction and myasthenia gravis.  
 
Common  Causes  for a Decreased  MCH:  
 
Iron  Anemia:  See serum  iron. 
 
Internal  Bleeding:  See reticulocyte  count.  
 
Toxic Element Exposure:  MCV decreased, HGB, HCT and RBC decreased, fifth iso­ 
enzyme of LDH decreased, uric acid increased, total bilirubin increased, BUN increased. With 
cadmium, the serum calcium will increase and the serum phosphorus will decrease.  The serum 
level of the element in  question  will be increased  with a  significant  body  burden; however,  with 
a sub -acute  problem,  the element  may still be within the reference  range.  A hair mineral, urine 
or red blood cell analysis should be conducted to  confirm or rule out the  toxic e lement exposure. 
Sources of  the various  metals  and treatment options can be  found in  the information published by 
Balancing Body Chemistry with Nutrition Seminars LLC. Document is available from 
zorexinternational@gmail.com  
Vitamin B -6 Anemia:  SGOT/AST frequently below 10, RBC and HCT  decreased, HGB 
normal to increased, MCV decreased, reticulocytes normal to decreased, serum iron normal to 
increased.  With iron anemia the MCV and MCH are frequently decreased with a decreased HGB, 
HCT, serum iron and ferritin. With vitamin B -6 anemia, the MCV and MCH are also decreased  
with a decreased  HCT;  however,  the serum  iron and ferritin  are normal  with the SGOT/AST 
generally  decreased below 10.

141 
 Conclusion:  To differentiate  iron from vitamin B -6 anemia always check the  serum iron  
(decreased with iron  anemia,  normal with  vitamin B -6 anemia).  Vitamin B -6 anemia should 
always be confirmed with a serum or urinary homocysteine (serum and urinary homocysteine will 
frequently be increased with vitamin B -6 anemia).   Supplemental  Support:   B6/Bl  (ZI) - 1 
tid, SunFlax  Complex  (ZI) - 2 tid, and C.G.F.  (ZI) - 2 tid (contains  vitamin  B-6 and synergists).  
Diet:  Use the Roadmap  To Health  diet. 
 
Less Common Causes For a Decreased MCH:  Intestinal parasites, several types of cancer, 
vitamin C anemia, rheumatoid arthritis, thyroid hypofunction and problems involving intestinal 
inflammation.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  MCH:  
 
Caution should be  exercised in  any attempt to reduce toxic element exposure.  If the hair 
mineral, urine, or red blood cell analysis indicates the element to be greater than two standard 
deviations  above normal, consideration  should be given to referring the patient to a doctor trained 
in IV chelation/DMPS.  
 
See the sections of this manual covering serum iron, serum ferritin and MCV for further 
information on vitamin B -12, folate, iron, molybdenum, and vitamin B -6 anemia.  
The pattern described above for vitamin B -6 anemia is  seen commonly with an increased 
C-reactive  protein (CRP) that is unresponsive to anti -inflammatory supplementation, diet, etc. For 
this problem use B6/Bl (ZI) - 1 tid.

142 
 MEAN  CORPUSCULAR  HEMOGLOBIN  CONCENTRATE  
MCHC  
 
Discussion:  Indicates  the average  hemoglobin  concentration  per unit volume  (100 mL) of 
packed red blood cells.  
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  MCV  and MCH.  
 
Reference  Range:  32.0-36.0 percent.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Same  as reference  range.  
 
Common  And Less  Common  Causes  for an Increased  MCHC:  See the sections  of this 
manual covering MCV and MCH for laboratory changes, supplemental support and diet 
requirements.  
Common  And Less  Common  Causes  for a Decreased  MCHC:  See the sections  of this manual 
covering MCV and MCH for laboratory changes, supplemental support and diet requirements.  
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  MCHC:  See the sections  of this manual 
covering  MCV,  MCH,  serum  iron and serum  ferritin.

143 
 RED  CELL  SIZE  DISTRIBUTION  WIDTH  
RDW  
 
Discussion:  The RDW is an electronic measurement of anisocytosis (red cell variability).  An 
arbitrary  value of 10 plus or minus 1.5 has been assigned.  A value  below the expected  normal has 
no significance  other than to indicate that all cells judged  are the same  size. A RDW increase is 
primarily indicative of iron  deficiency anemia; however, it can also be increased with vitamin B -
12 and/or folate anemia.  
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  serum  iron, serum  ferritin  and MCV.  
 
Reference  Range:  11.7-15.0 percent.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Below  13.0 percent.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Above  16.0.  
 
Common And Less Common Causes for an Increased RDW:  See the sections of this manual 
covering serum iron, serum ferritin, MCV and MCH for laboratory changes, supplemental  support 
and diet requirements.  
 
Important  Considerations with  an Increased  RDW:  See the sections  of this manual covering 
serum iron, serum ferritin, MCV and MCH.

144 
 SERUM  IRON  
Total  Serum  Iron,  Serum  Iron  Inorganic,  Fe 
 
Discussion:  A common mistake made by many doctors when ordering a red blood count and 
indices is not ordering a  serum iron, serum ferritin, TIBC and percent of saturation. Without the 
serum iron or ferritin value, the amount of inorganic iron (serum iron) or stored iron (ferritin) 
available to convert to hemoglobin (organic iron) is unknown.  If the serum iron is normal or 
increased  with a decreased  RBC, HGB or HCT, an inability  to convert inorganic  iron to HGB 
due to a need for vitamin B -12, vitamin B -6, folate, molybdenum, riboflavin and/or copper  should 
be investigated (cofactor anemia). Patterns associated with cofactor anemia are outlined under 
MCV and MCH.  If the serum iron  is decreased with  a decreased RBC, HGB  or HCT, iron anemia 
or internal bleeding should be investigated.  In any case  of increased or  decreased serum iron, a  
serum ferritin and total iron binding capacity (TIBC) and percent of saturation should be completed 
to rule out either iron excess (iron overload/hemochromatosis) or iron insufficiency due to a need 
for iron or microscopic internal bleeding.  If microscopic bleeding is suspected, complete a 
reticulocyte count.  
Related Tests:  RBC, HGB, HCT, MCV, MCH, serum ferritin, total serum globulin, serum 
phosphorus and BUN (HCl need), TIBC or transferrin, transferrin percent of saturation and the 
reticulocyte count.  
Reference  Range:  Male:  40-155 ug/dL  
Female:  35-155 ug/dL  
 
Optimum  Range:  50-100 ug/dL  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  15 ug/dL  or above  250 ug/dL.  Note:  Anytime  the serum  iron is 
> 250, serum ferritin, TIBC and percent of transferrin saturation should be completed to rule out 
hemochromatosis or iron overload.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  Serum  Iron:  
 
Hemochromatosis/lron  Overload:   See ferritin.  
 
Hepatic  Dysfunction:  See the  sections  of this  manual  covering  the transaminases...  
Less Common Causes For an Increased Serum Iron:  Cofactor anemias (vitamin B -12, folate, 
vitamin B -6, copper, riboflavin and/or molybdenum deficiency), renal dysfunction, hereditary 
anemias, iron containing supplements, iron cooking utensils, iron fortified foods, excess iron in the 
water supply and zinc  or copper deficiency.  
 
Common  Causes  for a Decreased  Serum  Iron:  
 
Iron Deficiency Anemia:  Serum ferritin normally decreased, total iron binding capacity 
(TIBC/transfe1Tin)  normally increased, MCV,  MCH and  MCHC normally decreased (especially 
the MCV),  HGB,  HCT  and RBC  normal  to decreased,  neutrophils  decreased  and if the iron

145 
 deficiency  anemia is  due to  a need for HCl,  the total serum globulin will be decreased below 2.4 
or increased above 2.8, the  serum phosphorus will be decreased below 3.0, gastrin below 45 and 
the BUN  will be increased  above  15. Supplemental  Support:  Iron -Plus (ZI) -, as need to 
correct the iron anemia,  C.G.F. (ZI)  - 3 tid, S.O.S.  (ZI) 2 tid, C-1000  (ZI) - 2 bid, increase  to 
bowel tolerance (ensure this product is taken with  the iron). If  the subjective or blood chemistry 
indication of hypochlorhydria are present add HCL Complete (ZI) - 1-2 capsules in the middle of 
each meal, increase to stomach tolerance if needed.  Diet:  Use the Roadmap  To Health  diet and 
eliminate  foods  that inhibit  iron uptake such as  foods containing oxalic acid (except spinach), 
foods high in  fiber and phytate containing foods.  Drink at  least 8 -10 full glasses of  pure water 
daily and increase foods high in  iron such as red meat, spinach, leaf lettuce, non -GMO corn and 
organ meats.  Also, increase foods that enhance iron uptake such as  citrus and foods high in lysine, 
histidine, cysteine and methionine.  
Less  Common  Causes  For A Decreased  Serum  Iron: Menses,  several  types  of cancer, vitamin 
C anemia, hepatic dysfunction, renal dysfunction, intestinal parasites, Crohn's disease and other 
problems involving intestinal inflammation and sometimes with acute and chronic infection.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Serum  Iron:  
 
Iron, zinc, copper, manganese, and molybdenum oppose one another and cooperate with 
one another; therefore, an increase or decrease in any of these minerals is reason to suspect an 
increase or decrease in one of the other minerals. A decrease in zinc with an increase  in iron is the 
most common pattern seen.  
 
The patient's water supply, iron cooking utensils and/or the use of iron -containing food 
supplements are often the reasons for increased serum iron and ferritin . 
 
Serum  iron values  will often  be decreased  with  increased  blood  loss during  menses.  
 
An iron to copper ratio of less than one to one on a hair -mineral analysis indicates a 
probable need for vitamin B -12 or folate.  
 
An increased serum iron is sometimes the first biochemical abnormality observed 
with hepatic dysfunction (often serum iron will increase before the liver transaminases 
increase).  
Many doctors, especially those involved in IV chelation have implicated excess serum iron 
as a problem mineral with arteriosclerosis  (free radical initiator).  
 
Iron anemia often occurs  because  of excess  salicylate (aspirin) use  leading to  microscopic 
intestinal bleeding.  
 
Blue sclera (white portion of the eye), a desire to chew ice or dirt and an inability to tolerate 
cold are all excellent indicators for iron need.

146 
 After reviewing several thousand blood chemistries, it is our opinion that patients with low 
normal serum iron, serum ferritin, HGB and HCT are generally more active and healthier than 
patients with high normal or increased values (exception is patients wh o are at high  altitude).  
Increased blood viscosity due to increased iron (organic and inorganic) values is a problem 
associated with cardiac stress, stroke and vascular inflammation.  
George Goodheart, Jr., D.C. has published several excellent articles on fast and slow 
muscle function (aerobic and anaerobic).  These articles contain excellent information on iron 
utilization with muscle problems.  These articles can be purchased from the ICAK.  
 
Exogenous  estrogen (birth  control  pills,  etc.) will frequently  increase serum  iron values.  
 
Iron  overload  and hemochromatosis  are cover  under  serum  ferritin.  
 
 
PERCENT  OF TRANSFERRIN  SATURATION  
TIBC  Percent  of Saturation  
 
The percent  of transferrin saturation can be calculated by multiplying the total serum iron value by 
100 and dividing the result of this  multiplication  by the  total iron binding capacity (TIBC).  If the 
resulting  value is greater than 50 percent  then iron overload/hemochromatosis should  be ruled out 
(complete a  serum ferritin). Iron containing supplements, increased iron from cooking utensils, 
water or iron containing foods, hepatic dysfunction, thalassemia major and exogenous estrogen 
can also cause an increase in the percent of transferrin saturation (increase due to increased serum 
iron). All of these variables should be considered and if present, eliminated before serial tests are 
completed.  A decrease in the percent of transferrin saturation is seen with several types of cancer, 
iron anemia and in some cases of inflammatory disease.  Percent of saturation greater than 50 
percent is a serious finding (see ferritin for iron overload and hemochromatosis). Percent  of iron 
saturation  > 50 is the "gold  standard"  test for determining iron overload and/or  
hemochromatosis .

147 
 TOTAL  IRON  BINDING  CAPACITY  
TIBC,  Iron  Binding  Capacity,  Transferrin  
 
Discussion:  TIBC  is a chemical  approximation  of transferrin.  Transferrin  is responsible  for 50 
to 70 percent  of the iron  binding capacity  of the serum.  Since  other  proteins  bind iron, transferrin  
is not the same as  TIBC.  TIBC and transferrin  are useful in the  differential  diagnosis of anemia, 
especially  with iron anemia  where the MCV  is decreased.  TIBC  and transferrin levels increase 
with iron deficiency and decrease with iron overload.  The combination of decreased serum iron, 
increased TIBC or transferrin and decreased serum ferritin supports the finding of iron deficiency 
anemia.  This pattern is also associated with gastrointestinal bleeding from ulceration or ulceration 
due to neoplasm.  
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  serum  iron. 
 
Reference  Range:  Use the reference  range  provided  by the laboratory.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Same  as reference  range.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value  30 percent  above  or below  the reference  range.  
 
Common  Causes  For An Increased  TIBC:  
 
Iron  Anemia:  See the section  of this manual  covering  serum  iron for laboratory  
patterns, supplemental support and diet requirements.  
Microscopic Internal Bleeding:  See the section of  this manual covering the reticulocyte 
count for laboratory patterns, supplemental support, and diet requirements.  Conduct a reticulocyte 
count if internal bleeding is suspected.  If the TIBC or transfe rrin-in is increased with an increased 
reticulocyte count, internal bleeding is probable.  
 
Common  Cause  For A Decreased  TIBC:  
Hemochromatosis/Iron  Overload:  See the section  of this manual  covering  serum 
ferritin for laboratory patterns, supplemental support and diet requirements.  
 
Important  Considerations  With  An Abnormal  TIBC:  
 
TIBC  and transferrin  are frequently  increased  with the use of exogenous  estrogen 
compounds (oral contraceptives, etc.).  
 
 
SILVER Bullet:   TIBC will be increased with iron anemia and decreased with iron overload or 
hemochromatosis.  If the percent of iron saturation, ferritin and or the serum iron are decreased, the TIBC 
should be increased.   However, if the TIBC is normal or decreased a spa ce occupying lesion must be ruled 
out.

148 
 SERUM  FERRITIN  
 
Discussion:  Ferritin  is the second most abundant  iron-bearing  protein in the body, surpassed only  
by hemoglobin.  It is found intracellular  as cytoplasmic  granules and microscopically visible  
conglomerates called hemosiderin.  Ferritin functions as  an iron storage depot in  the liver, spleen, 
and bone marrow. In the blood stream it plays a role in the regulation of hepatic transferrin 
synthesis. Circulating ferritin levels appear to reflect the distribution of iron between the 
reticuloendothelial system (RES) cells and blood cell s. Three factors generally determine serum 
ferritin levels:  
1. The iron  content  of the body  tissues.  
2. The rate of ferritin  dispersal  from the  tissues.  
3. The rate  of ferritin  extraction  from  the blood.  
Aberrations in the latter two regulatory processes are present in many free radical diseases (cancer,  
rheumatoid  arthritis, etc.).  In these conditions,  serum ferritin  may not reflect  overall iron storage; 
however, in the normal individual, serum ferritin correlates well with tissue iron stores (adequate, 
inadequate, or excessive).  
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  serum  iron. 
 
Reference  Range:  Female:  13-150 ng/mL  
Male:  30-400 ng/mL  
 
Optimum  Range:  Males:  30-190 ng/mL.  
Females:  Before  menopause  - 20-110 ng/mL. 
After menopause -20-200 ng/mL.  
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  8 ng/mL  or above  500 ng/mL.  Note:  Serum  ferritin  levels  in 
hemochromatosis are commonly increased above 500 ng/mL.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  Serum  Ferritin:  
 
Iron Overload/Hemochromatosis:  Hematocrit (HCT) normal, hemoglobin (HGB) nor­ 
mal, serum iron frequently increased above 220 ng/mL, TIBC decreased, liver enzymes and serum 
bilirubin increased with liver involvement, percent of transferrin saturation increased  above 50 
percent, blood lead sometimes increased, serum vitamin E decreased, and serum triglycerides 
increased. Diet:  Use only bottled water for drinking and cooking (no well water or city water), 
avoid food high in iron such as red meat, organ meats, spinach, soybeans, wheat,  com, and leaf 
lettuce.  Avoid food supplements that enhance iron uptake such as ascorbic acid, fructose, citric 
acid and citrus containing foods, lysine, histidine, cysteine and methionine. Increase foods that 
inhibit iron uptake such as foods containing oxalic acid (except spina ch), foods high in fiber and 
phytate containing foods (except wheat).  Supplemental Support:  Fe-X (ZI)  3-4 bid and Fe/Cu  
Free Multi  Mineral product  use a s  d i r e c t e d  b y  t h e  m a n u f a c t u r e r .

149 
 Iron  Overload/Hemochromatosis  Continued:  The supplemental  program  indicated  on 
the previous page should be used alone or with  chelation (deferoxamine, etc.,  or phlebotomy 
phlebotomy  is the preferred  method).  Note:  Iron overload  and/or  hemochromatosis  are often  
silent (no symptoms) and can result in liver cirrhosis, bacterial infections, dementia, 
arteriosclerosis, diabetes, bronzing of the skin, arthritis, and stroke.  If iron overload or 
hemochromatosis is suspected, a health care professional qualified to treat either of these problems 
should be consulted. Further, if the percent of saturation remains at over 50 percent  after 
supplemental/dietary support gene testing should be initiated to differentiate iron overload from 
hemochromatosis  (2 genes or more positiv e indicates hemochromatosis and requires that all first -
degree relatives also be tested).  
 
Other Common Causes for an Increased Serum Ferritin:  HIV infection, inflammation, 
hepatitis, several types  of cancer, alcoholism, several inherited anemias (thalassemia, sickle cell, 
etc.), hepatic disease, renal disease, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis and acne (increased serum iron 
with decreased serum zinc). As previously stated under Percent of Saturation, Percent of 
Saturation above 50 percent is the "gold standard test" for iron overload and 
hemochromatosis  however, if the serum ferritin is above 500, hemochromatosis  should be 
ruled out, even with a normal serum iron or  percent of  saturation below 50 percent . 
 
Common  Causes  for Decreased  Serum  Ferritin:  
 
Iron  Deficiency  Anemia:  See serum  iron. 
 
Other Common Causes for Decreased Serum Ferritin:  Several types of cancer, intestinal 
inflammation/ulceration  and protein deficiency. A pattern revealing an  increased serum iron  with 
a decreased serum ferritin can be associated with  free radical problems (as  previously indicated), 
or can be associated with zinc insufficiency or copper excess (both limit the amount of iron 
extracted from the blood for tissue stores).  Also, as previously  indicated lead body burdens can be 
locus to the increased serum iron and decreased serum ferritin pattern.  
 
Important  Considerations with an Abnormal  Serum  Ferritin:  See the section of this manual 
covering serum iron, TIBC and percent of transferrin saturation.  
 
 
After 45 days if the percent of saturation, serum iron and/or ferritin normalize, wait 60 days and 
order a serial iron panel.  If the percent of saturation is again > 50 percent, complete gene testing to 
determine if the problem is iron overload (one gene positive), or hemochromatosis (two or three 
genes positive).  In either case the rate of phlebotomy must be determined and supplemental support 
discontinued.

150 
 T-3 UPTAKE  
Resin  Triiodothyronine  Uptake,  T3RU,  T3U 
 
Discussion:  In spite of  its name, T -3 uptake has  nothing to  do with  actual serum T -3 levels.  The 
T-3 uptake test in  an indirect measure of thyroid binding globulin (TBG) which measures the 
unsaturated binding sites  on the thyroid proteins.  The use of  T-3 uptake is  limited to  testing with 
total thyroxine (T -4) to calculate the free thyroxine index (FTI). T -3 uptake is not as reliable as 
total or free T -3 since major illnesses, high doses of salicylates and cortisone and the use of heroin 
and other drugs may alter the TBG which in tum alters the T -3 uptake. Note:  Most authorities have 
abandoned T -3 uptake in favor of free or total T -3 which are more accurate measurements of the 
serum triiodothyronine (T -3) level.  Contraindications:  T-3 uptake cannot be completed after 
administrat ion of therapeutic or diagnostic radioactive material.  
Related Tests:  Serum triiodothyronine (free or total T -3), serum thyroxine (free or total T -4), free  
thyroxine index  (FTI),  thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH),  thyroid binding globulin (TBG), 
antithyroid peroxidase antibody (anti -TPO), thyroid antibodies, serum triglycerides, serum 
cholesterol, serum calcium, serum phosphorus, RBC magnesium, serum albumin, HCT, HGB, 
cortisol and serum gastrin.  Note:  In any case of unresponsive  thyroid hypofunction  (common) 
or thyroid hyperfunction (not  common) anti -TPO and  anti-thyroglobulin  ab, should be  completed 
to rule out Hashimoto's. Anti -TPO and anti -thyroglobulin ab should be completed prior to and 
during pregnancy, because if increased either can cause fetal abnormality.  
Reference  Range:  24-39 percent  of uptake  
 
Optimum  Range:  27-39 percent  of uptake.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Below  20 percent  of uptake  or above 41 percent  of uptake.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  T-3 Uptake:  
Thyroid  Hyperfunction:  T-4 normal to increased, TSH decreased generally below 0.450, 
serum albumin decreased, TBG increased, serum calcium normal to decreased, serum gastrin 
increased, HGB  and HCT  decreased,  RBC  magnesium decreased, serum  triglycerides and 
cholesterol normal to  decreased, bone isoenzyme of  alkaline phosphatase (ALP) increased, anti­ 
TPO infrequently increased, serum ferritin increased and serum glucose frequently increased. TSH 
is the best single serum test for determining thyroid hyperfunction therefore, supplemental support  
and diet requirements  for thyroid  hyperfunction  are located  under TSH.  
Use of Thyroxine  and Desiccated  Thyroid  Preparations:  T-3 uptake will  normally  be 
increased with the use of exogenous thyroxine.  
 
Use of Triiodothyronine:  T-3 uptake will normally be increased with the use of exogenous 
triiodothyronine preparations.  
Less  Common  Causes  For an Increased  T-3 Uptake:  Renal  dysfunction,  heavy  doses 
of salicylates, protein malnutrition, major diseases (especially those involving the liver) and in 
cases where a hereditary change in TBG is present.

151 
 Common  Causes  for a Decreased  T-3 Uptake:  
 
Thyroid Hypofunction:  T-4 normal to decreased, TSH increased above 4.50 with primary 
thyroid hypofunction; however, thyroid hypofunction is probable anytime the TSH is increased 
above 2.5 and symptoms are present. If the TSH is decreased below 2.5, but greater than 0.5 and 
symptoms are present, thyroid hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary hypofunction is 
probable.  Other changes that are commonly present are serum albumin increased, serum gastrin 
decreased, serum calcium increased, RBC magnesium increased, LDH increased in about 60 
percent of the patients, alkaline phosphatase (ALP) decreased, serum triglycerides and  cholesterol 
normal to increased with the triglycerides frequently quantitatively higher than cholesterol. TSH 
is the best single serum test for determining primary thyroid hypofunction and hypofunction 
secondary to anterior pituitary hypofunction therefore, su pplemental support and diet requirements 
for thyroid hypofunction are located under TSH.  
 
Use Of Exogenous  Estradiol  Containing  Compounds  (Premarin,  Birth  Control  Pills):  
In addition to changes frequently present with the use of exogenous estradiol (ALP decreased, 
LDH increased, SOOT often decreased due  to a vitamin B -6 need,  etc.),  the following changes will 
frequently be  present:  T-3 uptake will be  decreased with a  normal or  increased T -4 and a normal 
free thyroxine index. Supplemental Support:  Exogenous estradiol generally decreases systemic 
stores of vitamin B -6, magnesium and their synergists.  To ameliorate these insufficiencies 
Magnesium Orotate (ZI), KI Caps (ZI), DIM Complex (ZI),  B6/Bl (ZI) and SunFlax Complex 
(ZI) should be used.  Diet:  Avoid soy, commercially raised chicken and other foods known to 
promote or increase systemic estradiol levels.  
Less  Common  Causes for a Decreased  T-3 Uptake:  Pregnancy,  use of several  prescribed  and 
illicit drugs and prescribed therapy used to correct thyroid hyperfunction.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  T-3 Uptake:  
 
The patient's average axillary temperature (underarm) will frequently be below  97.8 with 
thyroid hypofunction, or thyroid hypofunction secondary to hypofunction of the anterior pituitary.  
The axillary temperature should be  taken  for 10 minutes  before leaving bed  and ideally should be 
taken for five days in a row and averaged.  The test is considered to be invalid if the patient expends 
any energy  prior to taking the axillary temperature. Reduced axillary  temperature is also common 
with adrenal dysfunction, thiamine deficiency, diets that are low in essential fatty acids and protein 
malnutrition. Note:  Correct supplemental and/or hormonal support will generally resolve the 
subjective indications associated with primary or secondary thyroid hypofunction however, the 
axillary temperature will not always increase to  a level much above 97.8.  Slightly low axillary 
temperature can be  a normal finding for many healthy people. Low axillary temperature is often 
also found with other, endocrine hypofunction.  
Difficulty losing weight, reduced initiative, fatigue, sensitivity to  cold, dry,  or scaly skin, 
ringing in  the ears, low blood pressure,  impaired hearing, constipation, an  inability to  work under 
pressure, loss of the outside portion of the eyebrows, facial edema (myxedema), muscle cramps 
while at rest, headaches in the morning that wear off during the day, red hair, left handedness, and 
depression are all excellent clinical indications of thyroid hypofunction.

152 
 Always rule out liver/biliary and or intestinal dysfunction with primary thyroid dysfunction 
or thyroid dysfunction secondary to anterior pituitary hypofunction. Often the  thyroid problem 
may simply be an inability to  conjugate and/or eliminate thyroid hormones.  
 
Grave's disease (thyroid hyperfunction) is frequently due to virus, toxic element  exposure, 
bacteria, excess of or lack of iodine or the effect of inoculations. However, the major reason is  
trauma (physical or psychological)  sometime in  the patient's recent past.  Supplemental support 
will sometimes normalize the thyroid function, however if there is no change in 40 days or less, 
medical intervention is required.  
 
The following is a list of substances, xenobiotics, etc., that will alter thyroid function. This 
list will help to answer the question of why there are so many patients with thyroid dysfunction:  
 
Thyroid hormones  undergo  enterohepatic circulation therefore, any  gut, or hepatic 
problem causing dysbiosis could easily alter thyroid hormone reabsorption or 
elimination.  
Dilantin  and tegretol  can both decrease  T-3 and T-4 production.  
Lithium is  converted by  the thyroid and  inhibits  the formation and  release of 
thyroid hormones.  
Iodine  containing  drugs  (there  are several)  will alter thyroid  function.  
Chloride, bromine and  fluoride  (halogens) act  as inhibitors  of thyroid peroxidase 
(TPO) and thyroid iodide organification.  
Antidepressants  cause  an inhibition  of TPO.  
Red dye #3 increases  reverse T -3 and decreases  T-3. 
PCB  and PBB  are known  to cause an  increase  in anti-TPO.  
Phythalate  esters and metabolites found in water polluted from coal cause a 
decrease in  thyroid hormone production (is  it the goiter belt  or the coal belt?). 
Pyridines from the conversion of coal and cigarette smoke.  
Selenium  deficiency  resulting  in under -conversion  ofT-4 to T-3. 
An out of control stress  response which  causes  an increase in  cortisol and a 
decrease in the conversion of T -4 to T -3. 
The use of bromine  as a commercial  dough  conditioner  and in hotel  hot tubs.  
 
The above  are only  a small  number  of the  reasons  we see so many  patients  with thyroid  hyper 
and hypofunction.  
Thyroxine  (T-4) to triiodothyronine (T -3) conversion:  One of the most overlooked and 
perhaps most important considerations  in the treatment of thyroid hypofunction is  T-4 to T-3 
conversion.  It is important to note where the T -3 level falls within the laboratory or metabolic 
range and where the T -4 falls within the laboratory  or metabolic range.  Frequently  you will find 
a decreased or low normal T -3 with a normal or increased T -4. Use of exogenous estrogen 
compounds, or  ovarian or adrenal hyperfunction can b e locus to  this problem; however, in many 
cases  it is simply  a lack of the nutrients  (selenium,  iodine,  etc.),  required  to produce  the

153 
 peripheral  conversion  of T-4 to T-3. In-respective  of the locus,  KI Caps  (ZI)- 1 daily  should  be 
used to help normalize  the under -conversion  problem.  
There is no current  evidence that high dose biotin will alter thyroid function . However , there is 
evidence that high dose biotin (25-100 mg a day or more as used with M.S, etc..), will alter the 
thyroid lab values.  Biotin  (ZI) should  be discontinued  7 days before a thyroid  panel  is completed.

154 
 TRIIODOTHYRONINE  (Free  and Total)  & REVERSE T -3 
T-3 (RIA),  Total  T-3, Free  T-3, R/T-3 
 
Discussion:  T-3 is a thyroid hormone produced mainly from peripheral conversion of  thyroxine 
(T-4). Approximately one -third of T -4 is converted to active T -3, 10 -18 percent is converted to 
Reverse T -3 and the remainder is converted to a sulfate form or T -3 and T -3 thyroacetic acid. Both 
are inactive until they are acted upon by the gut f lora and returned to  active T -3; hence the 
importance  of healthy gut flora with primary  or secondary  thyroid  hypofunction.  T-3 has a higher 
biological activity than T -4 and will bind to protein (thyroid binding globulin, transthyretin, and 
albumin) less efficiently  than T -4. T-3 and T -4 exist in the serum  in both bound and free forms. 
Free T -3: Less than 0.5 percent of the total T -3 is in the free form.  Free forms are regulated by 
feedback systems and appear to parallel rates of cellular uptake.  As the serum concentrations  of 
the binding proteins increase, the total T -3 also increases, while the free T -3 generally remains the 
same. Therefore, free T -3 and TSH are  the best  tests to help determine the functional status of the 
thyroid. Reverse T -3 is an inactive form of T -3 that can now be measured by most laboratories.  
Reverse T -3 is frequently caused by the result of increased cortisol production by the adrenal 
cortex.  In this situation, total serum T -3, free T -3 and T -3 uptake will frequently be normal; 
however, symptoms of  thyroid hypofunction will generally be present. T -3 supplementation may 
be helpful in ameliorating the patient's subjective complaints; but the correction for the problem is 
generally through therapy directed at decreasing cortisol levels. Reverse T -3 will  also be increased 
when thyroid hormone replacement is excessive.  
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  indicated  under  T-3 uptake.  
 
Reference Range:   Free T-3, 19 years  of age and younger:  2.3-5.0 pg/mL 
Free T -3. 20 years of age and older: 2.0 -4.4 pg/mL 
Total T -3: 71 -180 ng/dL  
Reverse  T-3, 15 years  of age and younger: 190 -880 pg /mL 
Reverse T -3 16 years of age and older: 90 -350 pg/mL  
 
Optimum  Range:  Free T-3: 2.4-5.5 pg/mL  
Total  T-3: 80-190 ng/dL  
Reverse  T-3, 15 years  of age and younger:  Below  800 pg/mL 
Reverse T -3, '16  years of age and older: Below 325 pg/mL  
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value that  is more  than 30 percent  above or  below the  laboratory 
range.  
Common And Less Common Causes For An Increased Serum T -3: See the section of this manual  
covering  T-3 uptake  for laboratory changes.  Supplemental support and  diet requirements are listed 
in the section of this manual covering TSH.  
 
Common And Less Common Causes For A Decreased Serum T -3: See the section of this manual  
covering  T-3 uptake for  laboratory changes.  Supplemental support and  diet requirements are listed 
in the section of this manual covering TSH.

155 
 Common Causes for an Increased Reverse T -3: Many of the symptoms are the same as those 
associated with thyroid hypofunction (hair loss, fatigue, muscle aches and pains, etc.) However, 
the most common reasons for an increase in Reverse T -3 are excess use of thyroid hormone 
replacement  and adrenal  cortical  hyperfunction.  
Important Considerations with an Abnormal Serum T -3: Important considerations with an 
abnormal serum T -3 are located in the sections of this manual covering T -3 uptake, TSH and serum 
T-4.

156 
 SERUM  THYROXINE  (Free  and Total)  
T4, T4 (RIA),  Thyroxine by  RIA,  Tetraiodothyronine,  Free  T-4 
 
Discussion:  T-4 is the major hormone  secreted  by the thyroid  gland.  It is transported  through 
the blood bound to thyroxine binding globulin (TBG), prealbumin and albumin.  Alterations in 
binding capacity or the quantity of TBG may increase or decrease total T -4 without causing 
symptoms.  T-4 secretion is stimulated  by thyroid  stimulating  hormone  (TSH).  Free T -4 is a 
very small portion of total thyroxine (generally less than 0.04 percent); however, it is the 
metabolically  active fraction.  The development  of free T -4 was initiated because total T -4 and 
the free thyroxine index (FTI) failed to reliably reflect the patient's thyroid status with euthyroid 
sick syndrome.  Although  free T-4 and free T-3 are expensive  when  compared  to total  T-4 
and total  T-3 or T-3 uptake,  the free forms  are the most  accurate.  
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  indicated  under  T-3 uptake.  
 
Reference  Range:  Total  thyroxine:  4.5-12.0 ug/dL  
Free thyroxine:  .83-1.77 ug/dL  
 
Optimum  Range:  Total  thyroxine:  6.0-12.5 ug/dL  
Free thyroxine:  1.00-1.95 ug/dL  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  More  than 30 percent  above or  below  the laboratory  range.  
 
Common And Less Common Causes For An Increased Serum T -4: See the section of this manual  
covering  T-3 uptake for  laboratory changes.  Supplemental support and  diet requirements are listed 
in the section of this manual covering TSH.  
 
Common And Less Common Causes For A Decreased Serum T -4: See the section of this manual  
covering T -3 uptake for  laboratory changes.  Supplemental support  and diet requirements are listed 
in the section of this manual covering TSH.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Serum  T-4: 
 
Androgen Steroid Use:  Androgen steroid use can cause a myriad of changes in normal 
chemistries (liver enzymes, etc.) however, the following changes will almost always be present: 
T-4 will be decreased  with an increased T -3 uptake  and a normal free thyroxine  index (FTI). This 
pattern is also seen frequently with protein malnutrition, acute stress and sometimes with severe 
liver disease. T -3 Uptake increased with a  decreased total  T-4 is the opposite pattern seen with 
exogenous estrogen use.  
Inability  to Increase T -4 with Iodine and Tyrosine:  Always rile out a need for vitamin B -
6 (B6/Bl  (ZI) and rubidium ). An insufficiency  of either  nutrient  can alter the thyroid's ability 
to use iodine and tyrosine.

157 
 FREE  THYROXINE  INDEX  
FTI,  FT4I  Index,  T-7 
 
Discussion:  The FTI is an estimate, calculated from total T -4 and T -3 uptake.  It is usually 
proportional to actual free T -4. It is an imperfect measurement as it is quite possible to obtain a 
normal FTI with an abnormal T -3 uptake or serum T -4 (pregnancy, contraceptive use, and 
abnormal serum proteins).  The FTI may also be normal for some patients with an abnormal 
thyroxine binding globulin (TBG).  FTI is often found to be decreased with healthy elderly people.  
 
Related  Tests:  Same as  those  listed  under  T-3 uptake.  
 
Reference  Range:  The reference  range  for FTI varies  from  major  laboratory  to maJor 
laboratory; therefore  the reference range provided by the laboratory should be used.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Same  as the laboratory  range.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value  significantly  above  or below  the laboratory  range.  
 
Common  And Less  Common  Causes  For An Increased  Free  Thyroxine  Index:  See the 
section of this manual covering T -3 uptake for laboratory changes.  Supplemental  support and diet 
requirements are listed in the section of this manual covering TSH.  
 
Common  And Less  Common  Causes  For A Decreased  Free  Thyroxine  Index:  See the section 
of this manual covering T -3 uptake for laboratory changes.  Supplemental  support and diet 
requirements are listed in the section of this manual covering TSH.  
 
Important  Considerations  With  An Abnormal  Free  Thyroxine  Index:  See the information 
listed under T -3 uptake and TSH.

158 
 SERUM  THYROXINE  BINDING  GLOBULIN  
TBG,  T-4 Binding  Globulin  
 
Discussion:  TBG is  the most important determinant of  the overall binding of  T-4 and provides a 
good approximation of the thyroxine -binding capacity of the blood.  Serum thyroid binding proteins 
include albumin, transthyretin (thyroid binding prealbumin) and most importantly thyroxine 
binding globulin (TBG).  TBG binds  70-80 percent of  the total T-4. The major reasons for TBG 
testing are to determine  a hereditary  deficiency  of TBG and  to differentiate  between true thyroid 
hyperfunction (increased T -4) or an increased total T -4 due to increased binding capacity.  
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  T-3 uptake.  
 
Reference  Range:  Use range  provided  by the laboratory.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Same  as reference  range.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value significantly  above  or below  the laboratory  range.  
 
Common  And Less  Common  Causes  For An Increased  Thyroxine  Binding  Globulin:  See 
the section of this manual covering T -3 uptake for laboratory  changes.  Supplemental  support and 
diet requirements  are listed in the section of this manual covering TSH. TBG is also increased with 
many cases of cancer.  
Common  And Less  Common  Causes  For A Decreased  Thyroxine  Binding  Globulin:   See the 
section of this manual  covering T -3 uptake for laboratory  changes.  Supplemental  support and 
diet requirements are listed in the section of this manual covering TSH.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Thyroxine  Binding  Globulin:  See the 
information listed under T -3 uptake and TSH.

159 
 SERUM  THYROID  STIMULATING  HORMONE  
TSH, sTSH,  Thyrotropin,  Ultrasensitive  TSH  
 
Discussion:  Like the gonads and adrenal cortex, the thyroid participates with the anterior pituitaiy 
and the hypothalamus in a  classic type of feedback control.  The hypothalamus secretes thyrotropin -
releasing  hormone (TRH) that acts  on the anterior pituitary to  release TSH, which in­ tum 
stimulates the  thyroid gland to  release T -3 and T -4. T-3 and T-4 then suppress the  release of TSH 
by means of a negative feedback mechanism.  Simply stated, with normal thyroid and anterior 
pituitary/hypothalamus function, a reduction of T -3 and T -4 causes an increase in TSH and an 
increase in  T-3 and T -4 causes a decrease in  TSH.  The TSH assay was  originally used to confirm 
or rule out prima ry thyroid hypofunction;  however, the new sensitive TSH (sTSH) assays permit 
recognition of  thyroid hyperfunction as well.  Sensitive TSH (sTSH) has become the best single 
test for determining thyroid hypo and hyperfunction.  
 
Related  Tests:  T-3 Uptake, free or total  triiodothyronine (T -3), free  or total  thyroxine  (T-4), 
free thyroxine index (FTI), thyroxine binding globulin (TBG), antithyroid peroxidase antibody 
(Anti -TPO), thyroglobulin antibodies, TSH antibodies, serum triglycerides, serum cholesterol, 
thyrotropin -releasing hormone (TRH), serum calcium, serum pho sphorus, serum potassium, serum 
sodium, RBC or serum magnesium, HCT, HGB, serum albumin, serum gastrin, salivary, urinary 
or plasma cortisol, luteinizing  hormone (LH), follicle stimulating hormone (FSH),  serum estradiol 
(E2), serum or 24 hour urine samples  for estrogens (El, E2 and E3), renin, prolactin, progesterone, 
human growth hormone (use IGF -1 to make determination), DHEA, urinary ketosteroids, serum 
and free testosterone and serum or plasma aldosterone.  
 
Reference  Range:  .450-4.50 ulU/L  
 
Optimum Range:  If the patient exhibits the subjective indications of thyroid hypofunction and the 
sTSH is between 0.5 and 2.5 ulU/L thyroid hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary 
hypofunction should be considered first. If the patient exhibits the subjective indica tions of thyroid 
hypofunction and the  sTSH is greater than 2.5 mlU/L, but below 4.50, sub -acute thyroid 
hypofunction  should  be considered  first. In other  words,  if sTSH  is below  2.5 and the symptoms  
are present,  first support  the anterior  pituitary  function.  If sTSH  is above  2.5 and  the 
symptoms  are present,  first support  the thyroid  function.   If the sTSH  is below  
0.450 ulU /L, thyroid hyperfunction must be ruled out and if the sTSH is above 4.50 ulU/L 
primary thyroid  hypofunction  probably  present.  The subjective  indications  of thyroid hypo 
and hyperfunction are  listed under important considerations  with an abnormal T -3 uptake.  Note:  
By itself (without symptoms) sTSH is only valuable when the values are below 0.450 ulU/L 
(thyroid hyperfunction) or above 4.50 ulU/L (thyroid hypofunction).  
 
Possible Panic Range:  Below 0.3 ulU/L or above 20.0 ulU/L. Note: sTSH will often be 
reduced below 0.3 in the presence of thyroid hormone replacement.  When below 0.3 Reverse 
T-3 should be checked.  If the thyroid hormone replacement  is excessive the Reverse T -3 will 
be increased if  not, the hormone replacement is being correctly applied.

160 
 Common  Causes  for an Increased  Thyroid  Stimulating  Hormone:  
 
Primary and Sub -Acute Thyroid Hypofunction:  The sTSH will almost always be 
increased above 2.5 and  the anti-TPO/antibodies  may be  increased. See  T-3 uptake  for laboratory 
changes.  Supplemental Support:  If the sTSH is  above 2.5 but  below  7.5 use Thyroid  (ZI)-1 
bid,. If the sTSH  is above  7.5, but below  12.5  use Thyroid (ZI ) – 2 per day. If the sTSH is above  
12.5 but below 20 use  Thyroid (ZI) – 3 per day . KI Caps  (ZI) – 1or more per day should 
always be used with thyroid dysfunction and if the T -3 to T -4 ratio is 
weighted to the T -4 side selenium should be considered as  
Selenomethionine(ZI)  1 per day (selenium is the heart of 5’Deiodinase,  
SunFlax  Complex (ZI)  - 2 tid, Note:  If cellular resistance to T -3 is present or suspected use 
rubidium -as directed by the manufacturer.  Diet:  Use the Roadmap To Health  diet, cook,  
drink  and bathe  only with pure water  (drink  at least  8-10 full glasses  a day) and avoid foods  in 
the cabbage family and  millet.  Note:  If the patient does  not respond  to supplemental support  
in 45 days or less, rule-out Hashimoto's and  consider referring  the patient for hormonal 
replacement.  
 
Less Common Causes for an Increased Thyroid Stimulating Hormone:  Liver dysfunction, 
severe debilitating illness, dopamine therapy, anterior pituitary tumor (usually benign), HIV 
infection, pre -eclampsia, toxic and non -toxic goiter, increased prolactin, and breast cancer.  
 
Common  Causes  for a Decreased  Thyroid  Stimulating  Hormone:  
 
Thyroid Hyperfunction:  The sTSH  will almost always be  decreased below 0.450  ulU/L. 
See T -3 uptake for other laboratory changes.  Supplemental Support:  Immune Plus (ZI)  – 4 
tid, Lithium Orotate (ZI) - 1 qid, Zinc  Orotate (ZI) - 1 qid , C.G.F. (ZI) - 3 tid and SunFlax 
Complex (ZI)  - 2 tid. Iodine (Kl Caps  (ZI) can also be considered however it should be used 
with care.  Iodine can help with most cases of thyroid hyperfunction but can also exacerbate the 
problem with a small minority. Complete an iodine excretion test to ascertain the need for iodine.  
Diet:  Use the Roadmap To Health diet and increase foods in  the cabbage family and millet. 
Ensure the  patient  drinks at  least 8 -10 full glasses of pure water each day.  Note:  If the patient 
does not respond to supplemental support and diet changes in 45 days or less, they should be 
referred to a doctor qualified to treat this problem.  
Thyroid Hypofunction Secondary to Anterior Pituitary Hypofunction:  If the 
subjective indications of thyroid hypofunction are present (see important considerations with an 
abnormal T -3 uptake for common subjective indications), the  T-3 uptake, serum free or  total T -3 
and serum free or total T -4 are in or near the normal range and the sTSH is above 0.450 ulU/L and 
below 2.5 ulU/L, thyroid hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary hypofunction is probable.  
With thyroid hypofunction secondary to anterior pit uitary hypofunction the  following tests may 
also be abnormal: serum calcium increased, serum cholesterol increased, serum triglycerides 
increased, cortisol increased (hyperadrenia) or decreased (hypoadrenia), FSH decreased,  LH 
decreased,  total and/or  free testosterone  decreased,  human  growth  hormone

161 
 decreased, HGB decreased, HCT  decreased, plasma aldosterone decreased, progesterone normal 
to decreased.  Note:  Anterior pituitary hypofunction is a common problem and one that is 
frequently  mistaken for thyroid hypofunction (the subjective indications are usually identical,  and 
the patient's axillary  temperature  will frequently  be below normal).  Supplemental  Support:  
Immune Plus(ZI) - 2 tid, KI Caps (ZI) - 1 daily, SunFlax  Complex  (ZI) - 2 tid, AD Complex 
(ZI) – 3 in the am and 3 at noon.  S.O.S.  (ZI) – 2 to 3 tid and Sympathetic Balance (ZI)  – 2 tid.   
Note: Additional selenium is not needed as 200 mcg  of Selenomethionine  is contained  in each 
tablet of KI Caps  (ZI). If the serum free or total T -4 is below the optimum  range add  B6/Bl  (ZI) 
- 1 bid,  L-Tyrosine  and rubidium as directed by the manufacturer.  Note:  With thyroid 
hypofunction secondary to anterior pituitary hypofunction the patient will often exhibit nausea, 
dizziness, motion sickness type symptoms and/or bowel changes when the anterior pituitary begins 
to normalize and influence its target glands (thy roid, adrenals and sex glands).  The patient should 
be advised of  this possibility  prior to initiating therapy .  Anterior Pituitary and Hypothalamus 
are contained in  AD Compl ex (ZI).  Diet:  Same as that indicated for primary thyroid 
hypofunction.  
 
Less Common Causes for a Decrease In Thyroid Stimulating Hormone:  Toxic nodular goiter, 
nontoxic goiter, anterior pituitary lesion (usually benign), bulimia, benign or malignant thyroid 
nodules, pregnancy, protein malnutrition and toxic element exposure.  
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Thyroid  Stimulating  Hormone:  
 
Unresponsive anterior pituitary hypofunction is  often caused by  a toxic  element  exposure 
(aluminum, mercury and cadmium are the most common.)  
 
The Pituitary Drive Technique developed by members of the International College of 
Applied Kinesiology (ICAK) is an excellent muscle test for differentiating pituitary from other  
glandular dysfunction.  
 
Although scientific information is not available, clinical research using Electro­ 
Acupuncture  According to Voll (EAV) has shown that anterior pituitary hypofunction is  common 
with genital herpes.  
 
Hashimoto's thyroiditis (increased anti -TPO) is a common problem with thyroid 
hypofunction.  Therefore, the anti -TPO should be completed in any case where there isn't a 
reasonable response to supplemental support for thyroid hypofunction.  
 
Overcoming Thyroid Disorders and Iodine: Why you Need It, Why You Can't Live 
Without It are two excellent books written by David Brownstein, M.D.  Both books will 
increase your understanding of thyroid function and can be purchased through Dr. 
Brownstein's web site  or zorexinternational@gmail.com

162 
 ANTITHYROID  PEROXIDASE  ANTIBODY  
Anti -TPO,  Thyroperoxidase,  TPO -Ab, Thyroid  Antimicrosomal  Antibody  
 
Discussion:  TPO  is the major  antigen  in the antigen -dependent  cell-mediated  cytotoxicity 
associated  with thyroid  disease.  Chronic  autoimmune  thyroiditis  may be subclinical  or may be 
present  with normal  thyroid  values  (frequent),  hypothyroidism  (frequent)  or hyperthyroidism 
(infrequent) and/or toxic or nontoxic  goiter.  Thyroid antibodies include thyroglobulin antibodies 
and anti-TPO.  The measurement  of anti-TPO  is the most  sensitive  test for the diagnosis  of 
autoimmune thyroiditis and frequently negates the requirement to  complete other antibody tests. 
About 60 percent of the patients with diffuse goiter have antithyroid  antibodies, while about 95 
percent have TPO antibodies. Although the peer literature does not reflect this, the treatment  of 
autoimmune  thyroiditis  with iodine  is effective  in 90 percent  of the cases.  Irrespective  of the 
usefulness of  iodine with thyroiditis, it  should not  be used until iodine need is  demonstrated  with 
a urine  iodine  excretion  test. The patient  should  be monitored  closely  to ensure  iodine  
supplementation is  not exacerbating the problem and the desired result is being achieved. Note:  
The incidence  of Hashimoto’s  in the U.S.  population  is growing,  and the use of iodine  is 
not, therefore  it makes  little  sense  to indicate,  irrespective  of the peer  literature,  that 
Hashimoto's is caused by increased iodine use.  
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  T-3 Uptake.  
 
Reference  Range:  Use laboratory  range.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Use laboratory  range.  
Possible  Panic  Range:  Values  increased  to more  than twice  the reference  range.  
 
Common  Cause  For An Increased  Anti -TPO:  
Autoimmune Thyroiditis:  An increase in anti -TPO can be present with both normal 
thyroid function, thyroid hyperfunction and thyroid hypofunction. However, the increase is almost 
always seen with hypofunction and normal thyroid values.  See T -3 uptake for other laboratory 
changes normally associated with thyroid hyper and hypofunction.  In addition to the supplemental  
support indicated under TSH for thyroid hypofunction  and thyroid hyperfunction, if the anti -TPO  
is increased,  add Selenomethionine (ZI)  - 1 daily  D3-5000  (ZI)  1 bid,  Olive Leaf (ZI)  1 tid, 
Immune Plus (ZI)  2 tid, 8X Pancreatin  (ZI) – 1 qid on an empty stomach and vitamin E as 
directed by the manufacture . Irrespective  of the thyroid function normal, hyper or hypo, when an 
increased anti -TPO is present, virus, toxic element exposure, toxicity from inoculations, 
inflammation from allergy (especially gluten) and/or yeast problems must be ruled out as  nexus 
to the increased anti -TPO.  Physical examination as  well as radiographic studies if  needed should 
be conducted to ensure  there are no space occupying lesion(s) causing the increased anti -TPO. The 
literature indicates a need to restrict iodine intake however, clinically we have found that iodine 
supplementation  is useful in more than 90 percent of the cases.  If iodine supplementation is  
considered use  KI Caps  (ZI) - 1 per day and discontinue Selenomethionine  as each KI Caps  (ZI) 
contains 200 mcg of Selenomethionine . If iodine increases the Anti -TPO discontinue it 
immediately.

163 
 Less Common Causes For An Increased Anti -TPO And Supplemental Support For SPE:  
Depression, hepatitis C, insulin dependent diabetes, sarcoidosis and some cases of autoimmune 
hemolytic anemia.  With sarcoidosis, laboratory changes will generally indicate inflammation 
(ESR, C -reactive protein, basophils, etc.), and the serum protein electrophoresis (SPE) will 
generally reflect "the sarcoid steps" (this pattern is explained in the section of this manual covering 
the SPE).  Supplemental support should include KI Caps (ZI) – 1 daily, 8X Pancreatin (ZI) - 1 
qid on an empty stomach, D3-5000  (ZI) 1 bid . Pulmonary involvement is common with sarcoidosis 
and if present, consider Organik -15, Immune Plus (ZI) – 3 bid. 
 
Important  Considerations  With  An Increased  Anti -TPO:  
 
Antibodies to the thyroid can cause thyroid injury that leads to transient thyroid hyper­ 
function and long -term thyroid hypofunction, hence the cyclic increase and decrease of TSH often 
seen with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.  
 
TPO antibodies are detectable in about 90 percent of the patients with Hashimoto'  s 
thyroiditis (thyroid hypofunction) and less than 15 percent of the patients with thyroid hyper­ 
function (Grave's).  This indicates that thyroid antibodies are most common with thyroid 
hypofunction and less common with thyroid hyperfunction.  
 
About 77  percent of  pregnant females  who are hypothyroid have  increased concentrations 
of anti -TPO and this can result in damage to the fetal brain.  
 
The literature indicates that iodine restriction (less  than 100 micrograms per day) is  often 
effective in reducing anti -TPO, however we have also found that in the vast majority of cases 
increasing  iodine to 12.5  milligrams  or more a day  is also effective.  High dose iodine should only 
be utilized by doctors familiar with this therapy and only after an iodine excretion test is completed 
to ascertain iodine need.  
 
If the above supplementation  for an increased Anti -TPO is unsuccessful always consider 
one or more of the following as nexus to the Anti -TPO increase.  
 
Adrenal cortical hyperfunction 
Reduced  gut immunity  (secretory  IgA) 
Virus  
Toxic  Element  Exposure 
Nanobacteria  problem  
As stated  previously  gluten  sensitivity

164 
 SERUM  GASTRIN  
Gastrin  
Discussion:  The mucosal cells in the gastric antrum, the distal non -acid secreting segment of the 
stomach, normally produce gastrin.  Upon release from these cells, the hormone is  absorbed into 
the blood stream and carried to the fundic cells causing them to release hydrochloric acid.  In 
addition to stimulating HCl secretion, gastrin evokes the secretion of pepsin and the intrinsic factor 
in the stomach, increases antral motility, stimulates enzyme secretion by the pancreas and increases 
bile flow from the liver.  Therefore, increased gastrin levels are associated with hyperchlorhydria 
and decreased gastrin levels are associated with hypochlorhydria and  subsequent pancreati c and 
biliary insufficiency.  
Related Tests:  GGTP, SGPT/ALT, SGOT/AST, total serum globulin, serum phosphorus, serum 
alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and ALP isoenzymes, HGB, HCT, RBC, MCV and MCH, serum or 
urinary methylmalonic acid and homocysteine, serum chloride, potassium and CO2, serum iron, 
serum fe rritin, total iron binding capacity (TIBC) or transferrin, serum protein electrophoresis 
(SPE), comprehensive stool and digestive analysis (CSDA), BUN, reticulocyte count and 
helicobacter pylori (H. pylori).  
Reference  Range:  Fasting:  up to 100 pg/mL.  
 
Optimum  Range:  45-90 pg/mL.  < 45 pg/mL  is a "silver  bullet"  for hypochlorhydria.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Above  100 pg/mL  and below  150 pg/mL  = possible  gastric  ulcer.  
Above  150 pg/mL  and below  200 pg/mL  = possible  peptic  ulcer.  
Zollinger -Ellison Syndrome above 200 pg/mL. Levels up to 3000 
pg/mL are not uncommon. Note:  Up to 25 percent of the patients with Zollinger -Ellison Syndrome 
(serum gastrin above 200)  also have  multiple endocrine neoplasm (pituitary, pancreas, adrenal), 
and up to 60 percent of the positive Zollinger -Ellison Syndrome patients will test positively for 
gastric cancer.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  Serum  Gastrin:  
Gastric Ulcer:  SGOT/AST increased, if intestinal bleeding is present TIBC and transferrin  
will be increased,  serum  iron and serum ferritin will  be normal  to decreased,  HGB and HCT will 
be normal to decreased and the reticulocyte count will be increased.  MCV and MCH will be 
increased due to vitamin B -12 and folic acid deficiency, serum albumin decreased, gamma globulin 
will be increased, the haptoglobin region of alpha 2 globulin will be decreased, ALP intestinal 
isoenzyme will be increased and if active tissue damage or ulceration is present, alpha 1 globulin 
will be increased.  Note:  If only the gamma globulin fraction is increased, and the alpha 1 globulin 
fraction is still within the normal range, the problem is probably still inflammatory, with no active 
tissue damage or ulceration.  If the ulcer is due to a heli cobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection, IgG 
and IgA antibodies specific for H. pylori will be present.

165 
 Gastric Ulcer Continued:  Supplemental Support for Ulcers and H -Pylori:  GI­ 
Complex (ZI), 2-3 tid with meals, i f bleeding  is present  add a cleanse/detoxification product 
and always run the iron panel and RBC with indices to confirm or rule out a need for iron 
and iron co -factors . If a bacterial infection (H. pylori) is present add a  H pylori product . With a 
H. pylori infection or ulcer, after the bleeding is stopped and the inflammation  is controlled, add 
Oregano  Oil Caps (ZI) - 5  tid. After two weeks on th e Oregano Oil add Saccharomyces 
Boulardii (ZI ) - 1 tid with meals. Diet:  Drink at least 8 -10 full glasses of pure water daily (no 
well water or water containing fluoride or chlorine), eliminate all grains, dairy products, 
processed foods, hydrogenated fats and oils, caffeine, alcohol, lettuce, spicy foods and foods in 
the cabbage family (cabbage is contraindicated; however, cabbage j uice is helpful for resolving 
the inflammation).  Until the inflammation  and bleeding are controlled  use lightly steam fruits 
and vegetables and limit pork and beef (use veal, skinless chicken and fresh fish in lieu of beef 
and pork).  Note:  The initial caus e for H -pylori ulcers (both gastric and peptic) is frequently  due 
to hypochlorhydria  (protein putrefaction  and carbohydrate  fermentation) resulting in the 
formation  of sulfur compounds, lactic and pyruvic acid which tend to irritate the stomach and 
intestines.  Therefore, supplementation  with HCl (HCL Complete (ZI) is generally required after 
the bleeding and inflammation are controlled. Further with hypochlorhydria  nexus to ulcer or H -
pylori, biliary insufficiency and pancreatic insufficiency are almost always present indicating a 
need for GB Complete (ZI) and 8X Pancreatin (ZI).  
Peptic Ulcer:  The findings are similar to gastric ulcer except the serum gastrin will 
generally be above 150 pg/mL, ESR will be increased, serum chloride will be decreased, and if 
pyloric  obstruction  is present, CO2 will be increased,  serum sodium  will be decreased,  and serum 
potassium will be decreased.  If the ulcer is due to H. pylori infection, IgG and IgA antibodies 
specific for H. pylori will be present.  Supplemental Support/Diet:  Same as the information 
indicated under gastric ulcer.  
 
Zollinger -Ellison  Syndrome:  The findings are similar to  gastric and peptic ulcer except 
the serum gastrin will generally be greater than 200 pg/mL (findings up to 3000 pg/mL are not 
unusual).  This is a serious metabolic problem requiring immediate medical attention.  The 
supplemental support and diet requirements indicated under gastric ulcers should be considered 
after medical care has been initiated  
Less  Common Causes For  An Increased Serum Gastrin:  Several types  of cancer, parathyroid 
hyperfunction, anterior pituitary dysfunction (benign tumor), adrenal hypofunction, ovarian 
hyperfunction, epilepsy, osteoporosis, excess ingestion of vitamin D and heavy metal body 
burdens.

166 
  
Common  Cause  for a Decreased  Serum  Gastrin:  
 
Hypochlorhydria:  Common chemistry changes, supplemental support and diet 
requirements are listed in the section of this manual covering total serum globulin. Serum gastrin 
less than 45 pg/mL is strongly associated with a need for HCl supplementation.  
 
Less Common Causes For A Decreased Serum Gastrin:  Parathyroid hypofunction, ovarian 
hypofunction, vitamin D anemia, protein malnutrition, renal dysfunction, metabolic acidosis, 
pregnancy, osteoporosis, pancreatic dysfunction, pituitary hypofunction and thyroid  hypofunction.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Serum Gastrin:  
 
The optimum values indicated for  serum gastrin are  based  on over 10,000 patient samples 
conducted over a ten -year period. Although current  laboratory manuals and the peer reviewed 
literature do not substantiate serum gastrin below 45 pg/mL as a laboratory indicator for 
hypochlorhydria,  our clinical con -elation with hypochlorhydria has been too high to ignore.  
 
No consistent relationship has been established between increased serum gastrin and H. 
pylori infection.  If the symptoms of gastric or peptic ulcers are present, H. pylori infection should 
be ruled out irrespective of the serum gastrin level.  
 
Although the peer literature does not agree, we have found that more than 90 percent 
of ulcer or H -pylori problems/infections, are secondary to hypochlorhydria. Although HCl 
therapy is needed, it must not be used until the inflammation and bleeding have be en 
controlled.

167 
 SERUM  HELICOBACTER  PYLORI  (H. PYLORI)  
Campylobacter  pylori  
 
Discussion:  According to recent peer reviewed literature, people  who have peptic ulcers are users 
of non -steroidal  anti-inflammatory agents or have  infection  with H. pylori.  H. pylori  is also 
strongly associated with duodenal ulcers, gastric ulcers and chronic gastric inflammation. Serum 
findings for H.  pylori only provide evidence of  past or  present infection. The sensitivity  of the 
serum tests range from 59  to 100 percent. After antibiotic or supplemental support some patients 
will continue to have positive titters  for IgG and IgA antibodies specific for H. pylori; ho wever, if 
the treatment is successful, the titers will be decreased, and the patient should be symptom free. 
Food  high in nickel  (corn , cauliflower,  peas,  mushrooms  and onions)  should  be removed 
from  the patient's  diet. Removal  will facilitate  healing.  
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  serum  gastrin.  
 
Reference  Range:  Undetectable  or lower  than the cutoff  limit  (serum).  Salivary  tests and 
breath tests (carbon -13 labeled urea breath tests) are also believed to be reasonably accurate. 
According to the peer reviewed literature, a strong correlation exists between the breath test and 
serum testing for IgG antibodies.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Same  as reference  range.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value  50 percent  above  the reference  range.  
 
Common  Causes  For An Increased  H. Pylori:  
 
Peptic Ulcers, Gastric Ulcers, Zollinger -Ellison Syndrome, Gastritis, Leaky Gut  
Syndrome,  Colitis,  Ileitis,  JBS And  Crohn's  Disease:  Common chemistry changes,  supplemental 
support and diet requirements for  peptic ulcers, gastric ulcers  and Zollinger -Ellison Syndrome are 
listed in the section of this manual covering serum gastrin.  Common chemistry changes, 
supplemental support and diet requirements for gastritis, leaky gut syndrome, colitis, ileitis, IBS, 
small intestine bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) and Crohn's disease are listed in the section of this 
manual covering total serum pro tein. Without regard to  the name of the problem, always complete 
an iron panel and reticulocyte count to rule out bleeding and a need for iron.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  For An Increased  H. Pylori:  Acute  MI, angina,  gastric  cancer  and 
Guillain -Barre Syndrome.  
 
Important  Considerations  With  An Increased  H. Pylori:  
If non -steroidal anti -inflammatory drugs have been ruled out as the cause of the ulcer or 
inflammation, the presence of hypochlorhydria and H. pylori infection should be assumed 
(irrespective of the serum H. pylori test).  
Without regard to other supplemental support and diet,  H pylori formula -as directed by the 
manufacturer, should be used with any positive  test for  H-pylori.  See Serum  Gastrin  for other 
supplemental  support.

168 
 HIGHLY  SENSITIVE  C-REACTIVE  PROTEIN  
Cardiac  CRP,  Acute  Phase  Reactant  
 
Discussion:  C-reactive protein (CRP) is a pentameric globulin with mobility near the gamma 
region.  It rises rapidly, but nonspecifically in response to tissue injmy and inflammation.  CRP is a 
more sensitive  indicator  of inflammation  than the erythrocyte  sedimentation  rate or the basophil  
percentage.  CRP is an excellent test to monitor the efficacy of supplements or prescribed drugs on 
systemic inflammation or injury.  
Related Tests:  Erythrocyte sedimentation (SED) rate, WBC and differential, serum protein 
electrophoresis, T and B cell assay, RBC and indices, serum albumin, viral or bacterial cultures, 
fibrinogen, antinuclear antibody (ANA) and uric acid.  
 
Reference  Range:  Varies from  lab to lab, generally  2.00 to  3.00 mg/dL  
Optimum  Range:  0-1.00 mg/L  
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value  more  than twice  the laboratory  range.  
 
Common  Causes  for Increased  C-Reactive  Protein:  
 
Viral  And Bacterial  Infection:  See total WBC  and WBC  differential  and total protein.  
 
Non-Specific Tissue Inflammation Or Injury:  Sedimentation rate increased, gamma  and 
beta globulin increased, fibrinogen increased, alpha 1 globulin increased with significant 
inflammation and subsequent tissue damage, alkaline phosphatase (ALP) increased with liver, bone 
or gastric inflammation, liver enzymes increased with liver or biliary tree inflammation, serum uric 
acid frequently increased with systemic inflammation and serum total protein and gastrin increased  
with gastric inflammation.  Supplemental  Support:  8X Pancreatin  (ZI) - 1 qid for 7 days on an 
empty  stomach then 1 bid on an empty stomach,  AHF  ( Z I ) - 3 bid, C-1000 (ZI) - 2 bid, increase 
to bowel tolerance, Quercetin  (ZI) – 2-3 bid , D3-5000 (ZI)  1 daily.  Additional  supplemental  
support  will be determined  by the site of the inflammation  and/or trauma (heart, lung, intestinal, etc.).  Diet:  
Roadmap To Health available from Zorex International at no  charge with  an order. Patients should also be 
advised to drink at least 8 -10 full glasses of water each day and to exercise moderately (do not exceed their 
metabolic  capacity). In any case where the above supplements and /diet are not successful add B6/Bl (ZI) - 
1 tid (each capsule contains  50 mg of P -5-P, 5 mg  of thiamine as benfotiamine,  100 mg of magnesium 
citrate, 10 mg of zinc citrate, 150 mc g of molybdenum  citrate and 50 mg of magnesium  citrate ).

169 
 Common  Causes  for Increased  C-Reactive  Protein  Continued:  
Coronary  Artery  Inflammation/Atherosclerosis:  See HDL  cholesterol.  
 
Rheumatoid  Arthritis:  See uric acid.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  for Increased  C-Reactive  Protein:  Several  types  of cancer,  cystic 
fibrosis, pancreatitis, systemic lupus (SLE), osteoporosis, burns and Sjogren's syndrome.  
Important  Considerations  with  Increased  C-Reactive  Protein:  
C-reactive protein is an excellent early warning test along with increased monocytes, 
increased LDL cholesterol and increased triglycerides to help identify developing arterio­ 
sclerosis/atherosclerosis.  
Patients who present with an increased fibrinogen, C -reactive protein and ESR are  patients 
who are at higher risk for stroke.  Supplemental support to reduce the risk to stroke (see fibrinogen) 
should be considered.  
 
Although the C -reactive protein, basophil percentage, sedimentation rate, fibrinogen and 
gamma globulin will often increase with soft tissue, muscle, tendon/bursa, vein/artery and sinus 
inflammation or trauma, the following conditions are generally more re liably diagnosed by 
subjective and physical findings (reduced range of motion, sinus discharge, extreme muscle, or soft 
tissue pain upon palpitation, etc.). After the diagnosis has been established the following 
supplements should be considered:  
Acute Tendonitis/Bursitis:  HCL­Complete (ZI), 1 per hour, C.G.F.  (ZI)- 2 every 
waking hour,  Sympathetic  Balance  (ZI) - 1 every  other  waking  hour and 1 tablet  per hour.  This 
program should be used until the patient begins to yawn and then the program for chronic 
tendonitis/bursitis should be used.  With some patients IV vitamin B12 is effective.  
Chronic  Tendonitis/Bursitis:  Sympathetic Balance  (ZI)- 2 tid (source of B -12 
and other Krebs cycle nutrients, magnesium and lithium , phosphorus . 
Phlebitis:  Magnesium Orotate 1250 (ZI)  - Begin with 4  at bedtime and  increase 
every other evening to bowel tolerance, SunFlax Complex (ZI)  - 2 tid, 8X Pancreatin (ZI)  - 1 
qid on an empty stomach.

170 
 Important  Considerations  With  Increased  C-Reactive  Protein  Continued:  
 
Fibromyalgia:  Oregano Oil Caps (ZI) – 5 tid, C.G.F. (ZI) - 2-3 tid, SunFlax 
Complex (ZI) - 2 tid, Power Pill (ZI)  -1 per day in the am  and Lithium  Orotate  (ZI) - 1 tid.

Food and environmental allergy/sensitivity should always be ruled out with any of the

With any of the above conditions, refined carbohydrates, packaged foods, gluten, dairy
