 ERYTHROCYTE  SEDIMENTATION  RATE  
ESR,  Sedimentation  Rate,  Westergren  Sed Rate  
 
Discussion:  The ESR is similar  to C-reactive  protein  because  it is not  a test for a specific disease 
but, is used to determine the level of inflammation or destruction with any disease process.  It is 
useful in following the course of an established condition.  It will increase as the condition 
exacerbates and decrease as the condition abates.  Fibrinogen increases the ESR and albumin 
decreases the ESR.  Since the liver is the seat of albumin synthesis, liver damage will result in an 
increased ESR with a decrea sed albumin.  
Related Tests:  C-reactive protein, serum protein electrophoresis (SPE), WBC and differential, 
RBC and indices, albumin, fibrinogen, total protein, alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and the iso­ 
enzymes of ALP (liver, bone and intestine).  
 
Reference  Range:  Male:  
 
Female:  
 
Optimum  Range:  Male:  
Female:  Below  50 years  of age - 0-15 mm/hour. 
Above  50 years  of age - 0-20 mm/hour. 
Below  50 years  of age - 0-25 mm/hour. 
Above  50 years  of age - 0-30 mm/hour.  
 
Below 5  mm/hour.  
Below  10 mm/hour.  
Note:  Anemia  will invalidate  the ESR results.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Above  45 mm/hour.  
 
Common  Causes  For An Increased  Sedimentation  Rate:  
 
Tissue Inflammation:  See the  section of this  manual covering C -reactive protein for 
laboratory  changes,  supplemental  support,  and diet requirements.  Note:  ESR  can be increased 
in various para -proteinemias, which often do  _not provoke an acute inflammatory result 
such as that seen with an increased CRP.  ESR can also be increased with a normal CRP 
with SLE and systemic sclerosis.  
 
Tissue Destruction:  See the section of this manual covering alpha 1 globulin and serum 
protein electrophoresis (SPE) for laboratory changes with tissue destruction.  See the section of 
this manual covering serum albumin for supplemental support and diet requirements.  
 
Important  Consideration  With  An Abnormal  Sedimentation  Rate:  
 
Phosphatidylcholine (ZI) - 2-3 tid, 8X Pancreatin  (ZI) - 1 qid on an empty stomach, 
Quercetin  (ZI) - 2 tid and SunFlax Complex (ZI)  - 2 tid, are often helpful in normalizing an  
increased ESR  when other means are not been successful.

172 
 ANTINUCLEAR  ANTIBODY  
ANA, ANF, FANA  
 
Discussion:  The antinuclear  antibody  (ANA) test detects auto -antibodies that are directed against 
a variety of antigens which reside mainly in the cell nucleus.  Such auto -antibodies are found in a 
wide variety of connective tissue diseases; especially systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), 
progressive systemic sclerosis, Sjorgren's syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, autoimmune thyroid, 
and mixed connective tissue  disease (MCTD).  The specific  antibody detected  (speckled, 
homogenous, atypical speckled, etc.) can be helpful in dist inguishing between these and alter­ 
native  diagnosis.  Speckled  is found  in more  than 95 percent  of SLE  patients.  
 
Related  Tests:  Anti-DNA,  serum  protein  electrophoresis (SPE),  serum  albumin,  C-Reactive 
Protein, C -Complement proteins and WBC with differential.  
 
Reference  Range:  Negative.  Reference  ranges  vary from  lab to lab; however,  a positive  ANA 
is cause for further investigation.  Note:  Two percent of the apparently "normal population" 
demonstrates serum ANA, usually in low titter . 
Optimum  Range:  Same  as reference  range.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  ANA:  
 
Systemic  Lupus  (SLE):  See total WBC  and SPE 
 
Rheumatoid  Arthritis:  See Uric Acid.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  for an ANA  Increase:  See Discussion  section  above.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  ANA:  
 
Salicylates, Dilantin, Tegretol, etc. (check your PDR or Goggle) can cause ANA to 
increase. ANA can also be slightly increased in a small percentage of healthy people with no known 
or diagnosable problem.

173 
 DEHYDROEPIANDROSTERONE  
DHEA,  DHEA -S, Prasterone  
 
Discussion:  DHEA is a major adrenal hormone. Aging in humans is accompanied by a progressive 
decline in the secretion of DHEA and DHEA -S, paralleling that of insulin like growth factor -1 
(IGF -1) the accepted measurement for human growth hormone. Opinions vary widely concerning 
the benefits and risks of using DHEA as a nutritional supplement however, doctors who routinely 
employ DHEA as an anti -aging nutrient and for endocrine dysfunction feel it is quite safe. Based 
upon the  current peer reviewed literature, our opinio n is that DHEA should not be used  if the patient 
has a  personal or family history  of feminizing  or prostate  cancer (DHEA is a known precursor to 
both estrogen and testosterone).  According to the literature, the 7 -keto form of DHEA will not 
transmute to estrogen or androgens. In clinical practice we have not this to always be true.  
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  TSH.  
 
Reference  Range:  The laboratory  range  varies  depending  upon  the age and sex of the patient.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Above the  midline  of the laboratory  range.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value  30 percent  above  or below  the reference  range.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  DHEA:  
 
Adrenal  Cortical  Hyperfunction:  Common  laboratory  patterns,  supplemental  support 
and diet requirements are listed in the section of this manual covering serum potassium.  
Less  Common  Causes  for an Increased  DHEA:  Pituitary  tumors,  ovarian,  uterine,  and 
testicular dysfunction and adrenal tumors.  
 
Common Causes  for a Decreased  DHEA:  
 
Adrenal  Cortical  Hypofunction:  Common  laboratory  patterns,  supplemental  support 
and diet requirements are listed in the section of this manual covering serum potassium.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  for a  Decreased  DHEA:  Ovarian  or testicular  dysfunction  (DHEA  can 
be used at up to 25 mg a day with low testosterone), exogenous estrogen and pituitary hypofunction.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  DHEA:  
See the information listed under the section of  this manual covering serum potassium.

174 
 CORTISOL  
Compound  F, Hydrocortisone  
 
Discussion:  Cortisol (a glucocorticoid) is synthesized in the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex.  
Secretion is controlled by adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH) which stimulates cortisol 
response to circadian rhythm or stress and restricts cortisol through negative feedback inhibition.  
Plasma or serum cortisol is not useful for determining  the dosage with adrenal cortical steroid 
therapy.  In our experience the most useful tests to determine adrenal cortical function are  urine,  
saliva, or  a fasting a.m.  serum  sample. Dexamethasone  suppression tests  assist in distinguishing 
the reason for increased cortisol levels. Dexamethasone  is a synthetic steroid that will suppress 
ACTH secretion.  After administration, decreased cortisol levels will be  present if the feedback  
mechanism  from the pituitary/hypothalamus is intact.  This generally rules out Cushing's 
syndrome.  If there is no suppression, a pituitary tumor should be ruled out.  
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed under the section  of this manual  covering  TSH and serum 
potassium.  
Reference  Range:  The laboratory  range  varies  depending  upon  the age and sex of  the patient.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Above  the midline  of the laboratory  range  but should  be highest  in the a.m. 
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value  30 percent  above  or below  the reference  range.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  Cortisol:  
 
Adrenal  Cortical  Hyperfunction:  See serum  potassium.  
 
Dysinsulinism  (Metabolic  Syndrome/Syndrome -X): See serum  triglycerides.  
Emotional  Stress  and Depression:  Urinary  ketosteroids,  serum aldosterone  and serum 
cholesterol, serum triglycerides,  serum total protein, LDL cholesterol, BUN, uric acid and alpha  
1 and 2 globulin are all generally increased.  Glucose is  increased in  about one -half of  the cases. 
Supplemental Support:  C.G.F. (ZI), 2-3 tid, SunFlax Complex (ZI) - 2 tid, Stress  HP (ZI)- 
15 drops tid , Lithium  Orotate  (ZI) - 1 tid, Magnesium  Glycerophosphate  Complex  (Zl) 
- at bedtime  to bowel  tolerance and  Sympathetic Balance  (ZI) - 3 bid in the a.m. and at noon.  
If the adrenal cortical hyperfunction is  severe add AD Hyper (ZI) - 1 midmorning and 2 early 
afternoon  along with S.O.S.(ZI)  – 2-3 tid.  Diet:  Roadmap To Health.  
If the patient has insomnia change the dosing time for Sympathetic Balance  (ZI) - 2 two hours 
before bedtime and 2 at bedtime.

175 
 Less Common Causes for an Increased Cortisol:  Pregnancy, renal dysfunction, hypo, or 
hyperglycemia (hyper most common with c01iisol increase), insomnia, Wilson's Syndrome 
(increased reverse T -3 is often due to adrenal cortical hyperfunction), severe illness, adrenal 
adenoma, Cushing's disease, alcohol ism, anorexia nervosa, Crohn's disease, excess levels of 
thyroid hormone replacement, and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Most common causes for  an 
increase  in reverse  T-3 are adrenal  cortical  hyperfunction  and excess  use of thyroid hormone 
replacement.  
 
Common  Causes  for a Decreased  Cortisol:  
 
Adrenal  Cortical  Hypofunction:  See serum  potassium.  
 
Anterior  Pituitary  Hypofunction:   See TSH.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  For A Decreased  Cortisol:  Respiratory  distress,  asthma,  headaches 
(primarily with males) and renal dysfunction.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Cortisol:  
 
Cortisol testing should be considered for any patient with Metabolic Syndrome/Syndrome -
X, chronic fatigue or stress, depression (also conduct serum thyroid testing), insomnia, 
osteoporosis, long -term illness, decreased sex drive (especially males) and other problems where 
a nexus cannot be determined.  
When considering adrenal function review aldosterone, cortisol and DHEA (sex 
hormones). Under adrenal stress there is an increased production of one of these with deficiency 
in the others.  Pregnenolone  (mother hormone)  is the common precursor to all three and under 
stress the pathways shift primarily to cortisol with resultant decrease in DHEA and aldosterone, 
this is commonly called the pregnenolone steal.

176 
 FIBRINOGEN  
Factor  1, Fibrinogen  Level,  Quantitative  Fibrinogen  
 
Discussion:  Fibrinogen is a precursor of fibrin, a major contributor to the meshwork of blood clots.  
In addition to  being the  focal point in  the coagulation process,  fibrinogen is  an acute phase reactant 
(it will increase in most acute phase responses).  As such, it  will frequently  be increased in any 
disease process involving tissue damage or inflammation.  Increased fibrinogen is an important 
early warning marker for impending stroke and other vascular problems.  
Related Tests:  C-reactive protein, sedimentation rate, clot retraction, thrombin time, INR 
(International Normalization Ratio) serum albumin, basophils, and the serum protein electro­ 
phoresis (SPE).  
 
Reference  Range:  150-400 mg/dL  
 
Optimum  Range:  150-350 mg/dL  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value  30 percent  above  or below  the reference  range.  
 
Common Causes  for an Increased  Fibrinogen:  
 
Inflammation  (Vascular  and Tissue):  See C-reactive  protein,  sedimentation  rate and 
basophils.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  for an Increased  Fibrinogen:  Pregnancy,  increased  estrogen  (oral 
contraceptives, ovarian hyperfunction),  acute phase reactions and several types of cancer.  
 
Common  Cause  for a Decreased  Fibrinogen:  
 
Intravascular  Coagulation:  This  patient  should  be referred  immediately  for 
evaluation by a hematologist or internist.  
Less  Common  Causes  for a Decreased  Fibrinogen:  Liver  disease,  protein  malnutrition  and 
some patients who are genetically predisposed to decreased fibrinogen levels.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Fibrinogen:  
To Lower Fibrinogen (Stroke Prevention):  SunFlax Complex (ZI) - 2 tid,  C.G.F. 
(ZI) – 3 tid,  8X Pancreatin (ZI)  - 1 qid on an  empty stomach,  B6/Bl (ZI)  1 bid and TomKat 
(ZI) - 4 in the a.m. (early  peer reviewed  literature  indicates that testosterone will lower 
fibrinogen).  The patient should also be advised to  increase their pure water intake  to not less than 
8-10 full glasses daily and to  discontinue any use of  tobacco. Do not use this program if the 
patient is on a prescribed blood thinner.

177 
 Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Fibrinogen  Continued:  
 
In some cases, supplemental and dietary changes are not always successful in decreasing 
fibrinogen levels.  In these cases,  IM porcine heparin should be considered.  
 
Increased fibrinogen should always be investigated as a causative factor with migraine 
headaches that do not respond to supplemental support (Riboflavin 300 (ZI) – 1 per day , 
Magnesium Taurinate (ZI) – at bedtime to bowel tolerance  and if the patient is male rule out 
adrenal cortical hypofunction  (S.O.S. (ZI) should be considered .

178 
 INSULIN -LIKE  GROWTH  FACTOR  1 
Somatomedin -C, IGF-1, Sm-C, Sulfation  Factor  
 
Discussion:  Somatomedin -C (IGF -1) is a polypeptide hormone produced by the liver and other 
tissues, with effect on growth promoting activity and glucose metabolism (insulin -like activity). 
IGF-1 is carried in the blood bound to a carrier protein which prolongs its half -life. Since secretion 
of human growth hormone (HGH) is episodic and pulsatile, a single fasting human growth hormone  
level is of limited  value. Levels of IGF -1 in the blood are more constant  than that of HGH. IGF -1 
is generally more accurate for determining HGH activity than HGH alone. Note:  If the patient is 
suffering with m alnutrition, the IGF -1 may be decreased with a normal HGH.  
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  the section  of this manual  covering  TSH.  
 
Reference  Range:  The laboratory  range  varies depending  upon  the age and sex of the patient.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Above  the midline  of the laboratory  range.  
 
Possible  Alarm  Range:  Any value  more  than 30 percent  above  or below  the reference  range.  
 
Common Causes for an Increased IGF -1: Adolescence, true precocious puberty, pregnancy, 
acromegaly, diabetic retinopathy, several types of cancer, cirrhosis of the liver, thyroid hyper­ 
function, pituitary adenoma and adrenal cortical hyperfunction.  
 
Common  Causes for  a Decreased  IGF-1: 
Growth Hormone Deficiency:  Urinary albumin decreased, apolipoprotein B increased, 
serum cholesterol increased, LDL cholesterol increased, osteocalcin decreased and free T -3 
decreased. Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and the ALP bone isoenzyme will be decreased in 
children  with HGH  deficiency.  Supplemental  Support:  C.G.F.  (ZI) - 2 tid, SunFlax  Complex  
(ZI)- 2 tid, AD Complex  (ZI) - 3 in the a.m. and 3 at noon  and. If present, the increased blood lipids 
should be supported as indicated in the section of this manual  covering  serum triglycerides  (dysinsulinism).  
Diet:  Use the Roadmap To Health diet and ensure the patient drinks at least 8 -10 glasses of pure water 
each day.  
 
Thyroid  Hypofunction  Secondary  to Anterior  Pituitary  Hypofunction:  See TSH.  
Less Common Causes for a Decreased IGF -1: Insulin and non -insulin dependent diabetes, cystic 
fibrosis, obesity, anorexia nervosa, cirrhosis of the liver, osteoporosis, and trauma (with trauma 
IGF-1 is decreased with an increased HGH).

179 
 Important  Considerations  With  An Abnormal  IGF-1: 
 
During deep sleep, HGH production is one of the hormones responsible for tissue repair; 
therefore, patients who awaken with increased muscle pain  (not joint pain associated with 
osteoarthritis or a cheap mattress) are generally producing less than optimum levels of HGH. 
Supplemental support with  C.G.F. (ZI)  - 3 before bedtime, is  frequently effective in  reducing or  
eliminating the increased muscle pain.  
 
Starvation increases HGH and obesity decreases HGH, hence the decreased HGH 
commonly seen with dysinsulinism  and other problems frequently associated with obesity.

180 
 PROGESTERONE  
17-Alpha  Hydroxyprogesterone  
 
Discussion:  Progesterone  is a steroid hormone secreted  by the  corpus  luteum of  the ovary and to 
a minor extent by the adrenal cortex in both males and females.  Salivary and urinary progesterone 
have been shown to be an acceptable means of measuring progesterone levels and allows for a 
more comprehensive evaluation of ovarian progesterone production than a limited number of 
serum assays.  
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under the  section of  this manual  covering  TSH.  
 
Reference Range:  Use range provided by the laboratory.  Note:  Progesterone produced by the 
ovaries is  low during the first  (follicular) phase of  the menstrual cycle.  After  the LH surge at  the 
time of ovulation, progesterone rises for 4 -5 days and then falls.  First trimester progesterone levels 
above 20 ng/mL indicate that gestation will probably be normal.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Above  the midline  of the laboratory  range.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value  30 percent  above  or below  the reference  range.  
 
Common  Causes  For An Increased  Progesterone:  
 
Use Of Topical  Progesterone  Products:  Serum,  salivary  and urinary  progesterone 
levels  will almost always be increased with the use of  topical progesterone products.  
Ovarian  Cysts:  Common  chemistry  changes,  supplemental  support  and diet 
requirements are listed in the section of this manual covering estrone/estradiol/estriol.  
 
Benign Prostate Hypertrophy:  Common chemistry changes, supplemental support and 
diet requirements are listed in the section of this manual covering serum creatinine.  
 
Less Common  Causes For An Increased  Progesterone:  Pregnancy, emotional  stress, reduced 
body fat in women (below 12 percent), several types of feminizing cancer and liver disease.  
 
Common  Causes  For A Decreased  Progesterone:  
Ovarian  Hypofunction:  Common  chemistry  changes,  supplemental  support  and diet 
requirements are listed in the section of this manual covering estrone/estradiol/estriol.  
 
Anterior  Pituitary  Hypofunction:  Common chemistry  changes,  supplemental  support 
and diet requirements are listed in the section of this manual covering TSH.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  For A Decreased  Progesterone:  Several  types  of feminizing  cancer, 
postpartum depression, convulsions (female), bulimia and threatened abortion.

181 
  
Important  Considerations  With  An Abnormal  Progesterone:  
In those cases where the patient is suffering with the symptoms of menopause or menstrual 
dysfunction or. has been found to have an increased serum estradiol level, supplemental  support 
with progesterone is  often effective in  helping to  ameliorate the  symptoms and normalize the  
estradiol level. Use Micronized Bio -Identical Progesterone Cream (ZI) - ½ to 1 full pump bid.  
This product contains no harsh chemicals, only progesterone and agents that are known to support 
progesterone utilization.  
 
Anytime testosterone (micronized, topical, sublingual or TomKat (ZI) is used, 
progesterone levels should be measured.  Frequently progesterone will be decreased (males and 
females) with a decreased testosterone.  
 
Always  check  thyroid function when progesterone insufficiency is  found.  Thyroid hypo­ 
function will frequently result in progesterone deficiency (thyroxine and triiodothyronine are 
required for progesterone production).  
 
Serum  alkaline  phosphatase  is frequently  decreased  with progesterone  need.  
 
Any time taking progesterone, estrogens, testosterones or other hormone therapies,  you should always use a 
aromatize inhibitor, CHRYSIN (ZI) -  2-3 tid.

182 
 TESTOSTERONE  
Free  Testosterone  
 
Discussion:  Testosterone is the major androgen responsible for sexual differentiations and 
secondary male sex characteristics.  Testosterone  is synthesized in the interstitial cells of Leydig in 
the testicles.  Testosterone exists in both free (40 percent) and bound (60 percent) to albumin and 
to sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG).  Free testosterone is the active form.  Usual testosterone 
assays measure both the free and bound forms.  With certain problems, total testosterone  can be 
normal while free testosterone  is increased  or decreased. Controversy  exists in the healing mis 
concerning the most effective way to measure testosterone (free or total). However, most clinicians 
will complete both tests and use the fol lowing to dete rmine bioavailable testosterone: Albumin -
Bound Testosterone (approximately 40 percent of the Total Testosterone) Plus Free 
Testosterone = Bioavailable Testosterone). The major androgens for females include DHEA and 
androstenedione, both of which are weak androgens. Both are derived from the adrenal glands as 
well as the gonads and can be converted to testosterone.  Testosterone output is regulated by the 
anterior pituitary. Note: Testosterone is loosely bound to albumin and tightly bound to SHB G. 
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  the section  of this manual  covering  TSH.  
 
Reference  Range:  Use range  provided  by the laboratory.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Above the  midline  of the laboratory  range.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value  30 percent  above  or below  the reference  range.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  Testosterone:  
 
Benign  Prostate  Hypertrophy:  See serum  creatinine and  PSA.  
 
Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD):  Androstenedione increased, DHEA increased, 
estradiol decreased (especially with obese females), cortisol frequently increased, FSH variable, 
insulin increased (PCOD is frequently found with dysinsulinism), LH variable and serum 
triglycerides frequently  increased.  Supplemental  Support:  Use the same support as listed under 
Triglycerides for Metabolic Syndrome and Complete Kare Spray  (ZI) – 1tsp in 2 ounces of 
distilled water as a douche, 3 times a week for 4 weeks (retain for 7 -8 minute ) Diet:  Use the 
Roadmap To Health diet and ensure the patient drinks at least 8 -10 full glasses of pure water each 
day.

183 
 Less  Common  Causes  For An Increased  Testosterone:  Adrenal  tumors,  thyroid  hypo­ 
function, ovarian tumors, testicular tumors, several types of cancer and female acne.  
 
Common  Causes  for a Decreased  Testosterone:  
 
Testicular Hypofunction/Decreased  Testosterone:  Melatonin decreased, estradiol 
frequently increased, HGB and HCT normal to decreased, TSH normal to decreased and sex 
hormone binding globulin (SHBG) increased.  Supplemental Support:  C.G.F. (ZI)  - 3 tid,  
SunFlax  Complex (ZI)  - 2 tid, TomKat (ZI)  - 4 in the a.m.   If the DHEA is decreased or below 
the reference range add DHEA - support the adrenals with the appropriate support S.O.S. (ZI) 2-3 
tid, and AD Complex (ZI) -2 in the am and 2 at noon.  Always check the FSH and LH to rule out 
pituitary dysfunction as  locus  to the testicular hypofunction. Diet:  Use the Roadmap To  Health 
diet and ensure the patient drinks at least 8 -10 full glasses of pure water each day.  
Note:  Adrenal and progesterone insufficiency  are common with are common with decreased 
testosterone . Consider Micronized Bio -Identical Progesterone  Cream (ZI)  - ½ to 1 full pump 
bid. 
 
Anterior  Pituitary  Hypofunction:  See TSH,  LH and FSH.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  For Decreased  Testosterone:  Alcoholism,  anorexia  nervosa,  cardiac 
dysfunction, thyroid hypofunction and HIV.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  Testosterone:  
 
With testicular hypofunction  always rule out some type of anemia (iron, folate, vitamin B -
12 or vitamin B -6). 
 
With  testicular hypofunction always rule  out excess use  of alcohol, excess use of  tobacco, 
diets high in refined carbohydrates, diets low in protein and insufficient water intake.  
Oxalic acid (the O in SGOT) is produced as a by -product of the breakdown of sex hormones 
in the liver.  Therefore, if no other reason can be determined for a decreased or increased 
SGOT/AST, gonadal hypofunction or hyperfunction should be investigated.  
 
With males, in almost every case where the bioavailable testosterone is reduced, SHBG 
will be increased.

184 
 SERUM  LUTEINIZING  HORMONE  
LH, Follitrophin,  Interstitial  Cell Stimulating  Hormone  (ICSH)  
 
Discussion:  LH is  a glycopeptide synthesized in  the basophilic gonadotroph cells  of the  anterior 
pituitary.  Production and release are controlled by the hypothalamus,  which is under the negative -
feedback influence  of estradiol  for females  and testos -terone  for males.  For females, the target 
tissue of LH is the ovary.  For males, the main action of LH is related to testosterone production 
through its  role in  stimulating testicular interstitial cells.  In both females and males, LH works in 
concert with follicle stimulating hormone (FSH).  
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  TSH.  
 
Reference Range:  Females:  6-30 mIU/mL.  Postmenopausal:  30-200 mIU/mL. 
Males:  7-24 mIU/mL.  
Note:  The midcycle peak for  the follicular or luteal phase can be 
over four times as high as the baseline value.  
Optimum  Range:  Same as  reference  range.  
 
Increased  In: 
Menopause  And Post -Menopausal States  (Hot  Flashes):  LH increased,  FSH increased, serum, 
salivary and urinary  estradiol decreased,  urinary ketosteroids and cortisol can be decreased with 
hypoadrenia and increased with hyperadrenia.  Note:  Always check adrenal function with hot 
flashes.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  Of LH Increase:  Thyroid  hyperfunction,  ovarian  space  occupying 
lesions.  
Decreased  In: 
Anterior  Pituitary  Hypo -function:  See TSH.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  ofLH  Decrease:  Benign  prostate  hype1irophy.  
 
Suggested  Supplemental  Support:  
 
Menopause/Hot Flashes:  C.G.F.  (ZI) - 3 tid, Sympathetic Balance (ZI)  - 2 tid,  Micronized Bio-
Identical Progesterone Cream (ZI)  - ½ to 1 pump  bid and SunFlax Complex  (ZI) - 2 tid 
Additional  iodine KI Caps – 1  daily,  If a testosterone  insufficiency  is present or suspected, add TomKat 
(ZI) - 4 in the a.m.  In some  case high dose vitamin  C (C 1000  ZI) - 2 tid, increase  to bowel  tolerance 
will help to resolve hot flashes, If  the urinary estrogens  indicate  a decrease in estradiol (E -3) add Bio-
Identical/Natural USP Micronized Estrogen Cream (ZI) - ½ to 1 pump bid (cream contains only E -3 and 
synergists, no E -1 or E -2). In almost every case LH will be increased with menopausal hot flashes resulting 
in a need for pituitary and adrenal support.  Consider S.O.S. (ZI)  – 1-3 tid and AD Complex (ZI)  – 2 in the 
am and 2 at noon.

185 
  
Added  Diagnostic  Information:  
Because the reasons for menopausal symptoms/hot flashes can be multiple, in some cases the 
symptoms can be difficult to resolve with the supplemental programs indicated above.  In these 
cases, the following areas should be ruled out as locus to the symptoms:  
Adrenal  cortical hyper -function. 
Adrenal cortical hypo -function.  
Excess refined carbohydrates in  the diet and/or carbohydrate sensitivity. 
Thyroid hypofunction.  
Thyroid hyper -function  due to increased stimulation by the  anterior pituitary. 
Vitamin C/bioflavonoid deficiency.  
Liver/biliary dysfunction (inability  to conjugate  hormones). 
Testosterone deficiency.  
Folic  acid and/or  vitamin  B-12 (consider  C.G.F.  -ZI).

186 
 SERUM  FOLLICLE  STIMULATING  HORMONE  
FSH  
 
Discussion:  FSH is a glycopeptide hormone secreted in conjunction with luteinizing hormone 
(LH), by the gonadotroph cells of the anterior pituitary.  Together FSH and LH constitute the 
gonadotrophins  and stimulate the  function and development of the gonads.  Release of FSH and 
LH from the anterior pituitary is  controlled by the hypothalamus.  
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  TSH.  
 
Reference  Range:   Use range  provided  by the laboratory.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Same  as reference  range.  
 
Alarm  Range:  Males:  > 30 mIU/mL.  
Females:  Premenopausal: > 60 mIU/mL. 
Postmenopausal:  > 200 mIU/mL.  
 
Increased  In: 
Menopause  And Post  Menopausal  States  (Hot  Flashes):  See LH. 
 
Decreased  In: 
 
Anterior  Pituitary Hypo -function:  See TSH.  
 
Suggested  Supplemental  Support:  
 
Menopause/Hot  Flashes:  See LH. 
 
Anterior  Pituitary  Hypo -function:  See TSH.  
 
Added  Diagnostic  Information:  Se LH.

187 
 TOTAL ESTROGEN  
ESTRONE/ESTRADIOL/ESTRIOL  
E-1, E-2, E-3 
 
Discussion:  Estrogens are useful in  the evaluation of menstrual irregularities,  feminizing tumors 
of the ovaries, as well as adrenal and testicular hypofunction. Oral contraceptives can cause an 
alteration in serum estrogen levels.  
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  the section  of this manual  covering  TSH.  
 
Reference  Range:  The laboratory  range  varies  depending  upon  the age and sex of the patient.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Use the laboratory  range; however the patient's  value should  be considered 
increased if it greater than the midline of the laboratory range.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value  30 percent  above  or below  the reference  range.  
 
Common  Causes  for Increased  Estrogens:  
 
Ovarian Hyperfunction (Ovarian/Uterine Space Occupying Lesions must be ruled  
out):  Thyroxine  binding  globulin  (TBG)  increased,  ceruloplasmin increased,  serum  cholesterol 
decreased,  serum  phosphorus  increased,  serum  copper  increased  and serum  calcium  increased. 
Supplemental Support:  After  the patient has  been  examined and  the possibility of  neoplasm 
has been ruled out, consider Complete Kare Spray (ZI) , 1 tbsp in 2 ounces of distilled water 
as a douche once every three days for 4 weeks .  SunFlax  Complex (ZI) - 2 tid, DIM Complex 
(ZI) - 2 bid,  Micronized/Bio -Identical Progesterone Cream (ZI) - ½ to 1 full pump bid .  If 
the ovaries  remain  in hyperfunction  after 45 days  add KI Caps (ZI) - 1 daily.  If benign  cysts  or 
other  space  occupying  lesions  are present  add 8X Pancreatin  (ZI) - 1 qid on an empty stomach 
and D3-5000  (ZI) 1 daily  (be sure to check  serum 25 -OH vitamin D -3 levels  after 30 days on 
this dose). Note:  Adrenal cortical hyperfunction is a  common finding with increased estrogen 
levels (excess conversion of DHEA  to estrogen).  Diet:  Use the Roadmap To  Health diet. And 
ensure  the patient uses  only pure  water  for drinking,  bathing  and cooking  and. Note:  The 
patient  should  also be advised  to check  their cosmetics  and prescription drugs  as both can contain  
estradiol.  
 
Testicular  Hypofunction:  See testosterone,  FSH and LH. 
 
Less Common Causes for Increased Estrogens:  Hepatic dysfunction (inability of the liver to 
eliminate estrogens through the bile tract), pregnancy, thyroid hypofunction, aromatization of 
testosterone to estrogen (need for Chrysin -ZI and DIM Complex -ZI) and convulsions. Note:  The 
incidence of epileptic seizures in women is generally higher during the part of the menstrual  cycle 
when estrogen levels are increased.

188 
 Common  Cause  for Decreased  Estrogens:  
 
Ovarian Hypofunction:  Serum calcium decreased, ceruloplasmin decreased, serum 
chloride increased, serum cholesterol increased, serum sodium increased, serum phosphorus 
decreased, progesterone decreased, thyroxine binding globulin (TBG) decreased.  Supplemental  
Support:  C.G.F.  (ZI)- 2-3 bid, Sympathetic Balance  (ZI) – 2 bid, Bio-Identical  USP 
Micronized  Estrogen  Cream  (Z) - ½ to 1 full pump  bid (product contains  only estriol  [E-3] 
and no estradiol) and SunFlax Complex (ZI)  - 2 tid, S.O.S. (ZI)  – 2-3 tid and AD Complex (ZI)  
2 in the am and 2 at noon.  Diet:  Use the Roadmap To Health diet. Ensure that the patient  drinks, 
bathes in and cooks only with pure water.  
Less  Common  Causes  for Decreased  Estrogens:  Complicated  pregnancy,  thyroid  hyper­ 
function, eclampsia, reduced body fat levels (below 12 percent) and low fat diets.  
Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  Estrogens:  
 
The principal naturally occurring estrogens routinely measured for the evaluation of ovarian 
function are estrone (E 1), estradiol (E2) and estriol (E3).  At the present time, the significance of  
the concentrations  of these fractions in  non-pregnant urine is  not well established. However, the 
following formula (originated by He nry Lemon, M.D.) devised from quantitative totals for these 
three fractions has proven useful in many  cases to help to determine the predisposition  to or 
presence of feminizing tumors.  The quantitative levels of E 1, E2 and E3 are obtained from 24 -hour 
urine or dried spot urine (Dutch test) and if the patient is still having menstrual  cycles, the urine 
should  be collected  between day 19 and day 23 of their cycle (day  1 of the cycle being the first 
day of menstrual bleeding).  
Estriol [E3]  divided by (estrone [El]  plus estradiol [E2]). 
If the result is above 1.0 the risk is low.  
If the result is  between 0.8  and 1.0 the risk  is moderate. 
If the result is below 0.8 the risk is increased.  
 
When the result is below 0.8 DIM Complex  (ZI) 2 bid, Chrysin (ZI) – 3 bid and KI Caps  
(ZI) - 1 daily, Bio-Identical  USP Micronized  Estrogen  Cream  (Z) - ½ to 1 full pump  bid 
(product contains  only estriol  [E-3] and no estradiol) are often effective  in increasing  the ratio to 
1.0 or higher.  
It is an accepted scientific fact that exogenous synthetic estrogen  (Premarin, birth  control 
pills, etc.), decreases systemic stores of vitamin B -6, zinc and magnesium and tends to alter thyroid 
function (T -3 uptake decreased, T -4 increased). If present the following should be considered for 
any patient on  exogenous synthetic estrogen and for one year after the estrogen is discontinued. 
Use C.G.F. (ZI) - 3 tid, SunFlax Complex (ZI) - 2 tid and KI Caps  (ZI) - 1 daily.

189 
 Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  Estrogens  Continued:  
 
Urine samples and total serum estrogens can be used to measure 2 -hydroxyestrogen  (often 
called the good estrogen) and 4 and/or 16 -hydroxyestrogen (often called the bad  estrogens) levels. 
The level of 2-hydroxyestrogen should be higher than the level of 4 and/orl  6- hydroxyestrogen 
(indicates a reduced risk to feminizing tumors and cancer).  If the ratio is weighted to the 4 and/or 
16-hydroxyestrogen side use DIM Complex (ZI) 2 bid, Chrysin (ZI) – 3 bid  and KI Caps  (ZI) - 
1 daily, Bio-Identical  USP Micronized  Estrogen  Cream  (Z) - ½ to 1 full pump  bid (cream 
contains only E -3 which is beneficial in these cases and contains no estradiol) and an increase in 
Brassica (cabbage) family foods will frequently cause the ratio to change and be weighted to the 2 
side. Diet: Use the Roadmap To Health diet with an increase in cabbage family foods. Urine 
samples to identify this ratio should be completed on any patient who has feminizing tumors as 
well as their first­ degree relatives.  
Endometriosis  is the presence of endometrial tissue in the pelvic area, small intestine, 
appendix, abdominal wall, surgical scars, diaphragm and primarily in  the vagina or urinary tract. 
This tissue reacts to estrogen, testosterone, and progesterone; therefore, these hormone levels must 
be ascertained before treatment is  initiated. After the correct supplemental support and diet has  
been initiated to normalize hormonal levels insure 8X Pancreatin (ZI) is used at 2 qid on  an empty 
stomach, D-3 5000 (ZI)  - 1 daily (ensure a  serum 25 -OH vitamin D -3 level is completed after 30 
days), TomKat  (ZI) 4 in the a.m.,  Complete Kare Spray  (ZI), 1 tbsp  in 2 ounces of distilled  
water as a douche (3 times a week for four weeks. Note:  If the endometriosis  is not pathological  
and the patient  is attempting  to get  pregnant, the  patient should be  advised that  medical treatment 
generally delays the  possibility of pregnancy  by the duration of the therapy. Diet: Use the 
Roadmap To Health diet and ensure the patient drinks at least 8-10 glasses of pure water each 
day.

190 
 SERUM  OR PLASMA  ALDOSTERONE  
Aldosterone  
 
Discussion:  Aldosterone  is synthesized  from progesterone  in the glomerulosa  cells of the adrenal  
cortex.  Its action  is on the renal  distal  tubules where  it increases  the resorption  of sodium and 
water at the expense of increased potassium excretion.  Primary aldosteronism is found in less than 
one percent of patients with hypertension.  
 
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  TSH.  
 
Reference Range:  The reference range varies from lab to lab, and according to the patient's sodium 
intake, time of day the sample was drawn, the source of the specimen (peripheral vein, adrenal 
vein) and the patient's posture when the blood was drawn (upright posture will result in increased 
values).  
Optimum  Range:  Use the laboratory  range.  
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value  30 percent  above  or below  the laboratory  range.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased Serum  Aldosterone:  
 
Adrenal  Cortical  Hyperfunction:  See serum  potassium  for supplemental  support.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  for an Increased  Aldosterone:  Renal  dysfunction,  pregnancy,  alco­ 
holism, emotional stress, cirrhosis of the liver and adrenal tumor(s).  
 
Common  Causes  for a Decreased  Aldosterone:  
Adrenal  Cortical  Hypofunction:  See serum  potassium  for supplemental  support.  
 
Anterior  Pituitary  Hypofunction:  See TSH  for supplemental  support.  
 
Less Common Causes Of Aldosterone  Decrease:  Diabetes, pre -eclampsia and several types of 
cancer.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Aldosterone:  
 
Aldosterone is  synthesized from progesterone and progesterone is  synthesized by thyroid 
hormones, therefore if the aldosterone is  decreased, rule out thyroid hypofunction.  
Primary aldosterone is  always characterized by decreased serum potassium.  Conversely, 
increased serum potassium acts  to decrease aldosterone production. Consider Potassium .

191 
 PLASMA  RENIN  
Plasma  Renin  Activity  (PRA)  
 
Discussion:  Renin is an enzyme of renal origin, which acts on Angiotensinogen (an alpha 2 
globulin) to form Angiotensin I, a decapeptide.  Angiotensin I is then converted in the lungs to 
Angiotensin II.  Angiotensin II is  a potent vasopressor, frequently responsible for hypertension of 
renal origin.  Upright posture at  the time the blood is drawn, administration  of diuretics and low­ 
sodium diets all stimulate renin release.  
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  TSH.  
 
Reference  Range:  Use the range provided  by the laboratory.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Same as  the reference  range.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  Renin:  
 
Renal  Hypertension:   See BUN.  
 
Adrenal  Hypofunction:   See serum  potassium.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  for an  Increased  Renin:  Pregnancy,  thyroid  hyperfunction  and severe 
liver dysfunction.  
 
Common  Causes  for Decreased  Renin:  
 
Adrenal  Hyperfunction:  See serum  potassium.  
 
Anterior  Pituitary  Hypofunction:   See TSH.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  for Decreased  Renin:  Diabetes,  thyroid  hypofunction,  chronic  renal 
disease, pre -eclampsia, and eclampsia.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  an Abnormal  Renin:  
 
See the information  listed  under  aldosterone,  BUN,  and serum  potassium.

192 
 SERUM  PROSTATE  SPECIFIC  ANTIGEN  (TOTAL  AND  FREE)  
PSA,  hK3,  fPSA,  Free  PSA  
 
Discussion:  Prostate Specific  Antigen (PSA) is increased  in most men with prostate cancer and is 
sometimes increased with benign prostate hypertrophy (BPH).  Also, PSA can be within the normal 
range even  with advanced prostate cancer.  PSA increases the  rate of detection of  prostate cancer, 
but some of the cancers it detects are biologically insignificant.  PSA is most accurate when  it is 
collected  prior  to a digital  rectal  examination,  bicycle riding and/or ejaculation.  PSA is very 
useful when serial measurements are taken.  When the serial measurements increase (double over 
a 3 to 12 months) this  generally indicates prostate cancer is  present.  If the patient is symptom free 
and the PSA (not increasing) is between 4 ng/mL and 10 ng/mL, free PSA should be considered.  
Free PSA to total PSA percent is lower in patients with prostate cancer and is typically above 25 
percent in patients with BPH.  If the percentage  of free PSA is below 25 percent and the total PSA 
is above 4 ng/mL then further investigation should be considered.  PSA is an indispensable 
predictor for recurrent adenocarcin oma in patients who have undergone prostate surgery, radiation 
treatment, seed implants and/or cryosurgery.  
Related  Tests:  Same  as those  listed  under  serum  creatinine.  
 
Reference  Range:  Zero -4.0 ng/mL  for total PSA and>  25 percent  for free PSA.  
 
Optimum  Range:  < 2.0 for total PSA and>  25 percent  for free PSA.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  > 10.0 ng/mL  for total PSA.  
 
Common Cause for Increased Total PSA and Decreased Free PSA:  Benign prostate hyper­ trophy  
and prostate  adenocarcinoma. See the section of this manual  covering  serum  creatinine for 
supplemental support and other laboratory changes associated with benign prostate hypertrophy 
and prostate adenocarcinoma.  Total PSA will also increase with prostate infection.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  Total  PSA  and Free  PSA:  
 
Approximately  25 to 50 percent of  the men with benign prostate hypertrophy will have  an 
increased total PSA.  
The 4K Score Test is a test that combines total PSA, free PSA, intact PSA and human 
Kallikrein (hK2). Peer literature and clinical feedback indicate this is an excellent test for 
differentiating benign hypertrophy  from adenoma.  The test should  be considered anytime there is 
a suspicion of prostate cancer and if present, the aggressive state of the cancer/  
New tests to detect prostate adenocarcinoma such as Early Prostate Cancer Antigen or 
EPCA -2 and 3 -MicoRNA (uCaP) in cell free urine, are currently under development and show 
great promise (EPCA -2 correctly identified 94 percent of prostate cancers while total PSA finds 
only about 80 percent).  However, until the next generation  tests are routinely  available continued 
use of PSA,  free PSA,  ,the 4K test, serum creatinine, prostate manual examination and subjective 
indications will have to suffice.

193 
 PREGNENOLONE  
 
Discussion:  Pregnenolone is a steroid hormone produced by the adrenal glands.  It is 
formed from cholesterol and is required in the production of cortisol, DHEA, progesterone,  
testosterone and the estrogens  (E-1, E-2 and E -3). Pregnenolone is  also formed in the brain. 
The levels in the brain are generally higher than in the peripheral tissues and have been 
shown to affect many neurotransmitters.  
Related Tests:  DHEA, E -1, E-2 and E -3, progesterone, several of  the neurotransmitters, 
free and total testosterone, potassium and cortisol.  
Reference  Range:  The laboratory  range  varies  depending  upon  the age of the patient.  
 
Optimum  Range:  Use the laboratory  range,  however  for an adult  the level  should  be 
well above the midline of the range.  
 
Common Causes for a Decreased Pregnenolone:  Depression, arthritis, fatigue states and 
memory  loss. Supplemental  Support:  Pregnenolone (ZI) - 1 bid, do not exceed 100 
mg a day.  
 
Common Causes for an Increased Pregnenolone:  Although the studies on pregnenolone 
are limited, several animal and human studies indicate that even large doses are reasonably 
safe. In some cases, acne and drowsiness were reported as  side effects.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  Pregnenolone  Therapy:  
 
In all cases where cortisol, DHEA, progesterone, estrogen or testosterone are  found  
to be decreased,  a serum  pregnenolone  should  be completed  to rule out a deficiency of 
pregnenolone sometimes called the "mother hormone".  
 
When considering adrenal function consider aldosterone, cortisol and DHEA. 
Under adrenal stress there is  an increased production of one of these with a deficiency in 
the others.  Pregnenolone is the common precursor to all three and under stress the pathways 
shift primarily to c ortisol with resultant decrease in DHEA and aldosterone.  This is 
commonly called the pregnenolone shunt or steal.  
 
Pregnenolone  (ZI) - should be used with any estrogen or androgen decreased.

194 
 PROLACTIN  
PRL  
 
Discussion:  Prolactin (PRL), one of the pituitary hormones, is so named because it initiates 
and maintains lactation.  The hypothalamic secretion of dopamine inhibits the release of 
PRL and thytrophin -releasing hormone (TRH), vasoactive intestinal peptide  and other 
peptides are  thought to stimulate the release of PRL.  PRL is  secreted in pulses and  a number 
of physiologic stimuli (sleep, exercise and  hyperglycemia)  cause  short -term increases in 
PRL.  
 
Related  Tests:  TSH,  TRH, dopamine  and glucose.  
 
Reference Range:  The laboratory range varies depending upon the age and sex of the 
patient and the status of the female patient (pregnant, lactating, non -pregnant or not 
lactating).  
Optimum  Range:  Use the laboratory  range.  
 
Common  Cause  for a Normal  Increased  Prolactin:  Pregnancy  and lactation.  
 
Common  Cause  for an Abnormal  Increased  Prolactin:  
 
Pituitary Adenoma (at the 90 Percent confidence it  will be benign):  Supplemental 
Support:  B6/Bl (ZI) - 1 tid, C.G.F.  (ZI) - 2 bid, Magnesium Orotate 1250  (ZI) - 4 at 
bedtime,  increase  to bowel  tolerance  and Quercetin (ZI)-2 tid. 
Less  Common  Causes  for an Increased  Prolactin:  Several  types  of cancer,  thyroid 
hypofunction, acromegaly, HIV, alcoholism, liver cirrhosis, seizures and diabetes.  
 
Common  Cause  for a Decreased  Prolactin:  Pituitary  hypofunction,  see TSH.  
 
Less Common Causes for a Decreased Prolactin:  Several types of cancer, paranoid states, 
male rheumatoid arthritis, anorexia, and seasonal affective disorder (SAD).  
 
Patients who are attempting to become pregnant and are unable to do so should have 
their prolactin levels checked.  Even a slight increase in prolactin (below the level 
where breast milk is produced), will cause the system to believe the patient is 
currently pregnant or  lactating and not allow pregnancy.

195 
 VITAMIN  D-3 
25-0H Vitamin  D-3 
 
Discussion:  Vitamin D -3 is a fat -soluble secosteriod.  It is converted to calcidiol in the liver  
and part  of the calcidiol is  converted to  calcitrol, the  biologically active form, by the 
kidneys. In humans it functions as a prohormone and can be synthesized from sun exposure.  
Currently we  are being warned by many in  the healing aids that even moderate sun exposure 
will cause skin cancer and sun -blocking agents are required to prevent skin cancer.  For this  
reason, the  vast majority of  the population is  found to  be below  the range used by most 
laboratories for 25 -OH vitamin D -3 (the most useful test for measuring vitamin D levels in 
the body) and for this reason, irrespective of sun exposure, supplemental  vitamin D is 
generally needed to maintain adequate serum levels.  
Related Tests:  Serum calcium, serum/red blood cell magnesium, serum phosphorus, 
parathyroid hormone (PTH) and blood tests used to determine free radical disease, bone 
problems, T.B., M.S., alcoholism, infections and a  host of other problems where vitamin D 
has been found to be below the laboratory range.  
 
Reference  Range:  32-100 ng/mL  
 
Optimum  Range:  60-110 ng/dL  
 
Common  Cause  for Increased  Vitamin  D-3: 
 
Hypervitaminosis  D: Check  serum  calcium,  serum/red  blood  cell magnesium 
and PTH.  Ensure the patient is not taking excess levels of supplemental  vitamin D.  
 
Common  Causes  for Decreased  Vitamin  D-3: 
Vitamin D -3 Anemia:  Supplement with  D-3 5000 (ZI) - 1 bid, or higher as 
indicated by a licensed health care provider/ Always conduct a  serum 25 -OH Vitamin D3 
test after the patient has been on high levels of the supplement for 40 days.  
Multiple  Sclerosis:  See important  considerations  under  alkaline  phosphatase 
1soenzymes.  
Osteoporosis/Osteomalacia:  See serum  alkaline  phosphatase.  
 
Less  Common  Causes  for Decreased  Vitamin  D-3: T.B.,  virus,  bacterial  infections, 
free radical pathology, cardiovascular disease, neurodegenerative diseases, skin and hair 
health and although not seen routinely in the free world, rickets.  
 
Important  Considerations with Decreased  Vitamin  D-3: With free radical  disease, M.S., 
cardiovascular  disease, infections and neurodegenerative  disease,  the blood level of vitamin 
D-3 should be kept between 85 and 110 ng/dL  
 
Clinical results have shown D3 to be an important component in the treatment of endometriosis.

196 
 SEX  HORMONE  BINDING  GLOBULIN  
SHBG  
 
Discussion:  Sex Hormone Binding Globulin (SHBG) is  a glycoprotein that binds to  the two sex 
hormones; androgen and estrogen.  Other steroid hormones such as progesterone, cortisol and other 
corticosteroids are bound by transcortin.  Testosterone and estradiol circulate in the blood stream 
loosely bound to albumin (approximately 40 percent) and tightly bound to SHBG (approximately 
60 percent). SHBG levels are higher in pre -pubertal children than in adults and with the fat mass 
during e arly puberty they begin to fall as androgens begi n to rise. A genetic variant of SHBG 
(Asp327>Asn) causes an  increase ofup to 20  percent in individuals that tend to have increase 
SHBG levels.  
 
Related  Tests:  Testosterone  (free  and total)  and estrogen.  
 
Reference Range:  The unit  of measurement varies from laboratory to laboratory, however most 
laboratories  use nmol/L.  The adult range for males using nmol/L  is 10-57 and for adult females 
it is 18 -144. 
 
Optimum  Range:  Use the laboratory  range.  
 
Possible  Panic  Range:  Any value  more  than 30 percent  above  the reference  range.  
 
Common  Causes  for an Increased  SHBG:  
 
Hepatitis  and Other  Hepatic  Dysfunction:   
See ALT/SGPT,  GGT,  WBC  and Differential  
 
Toxic Element  Exposure:  Covered  in Toxic Element  Exposure  Document  Created  by 
Balancing Body Chemistry w/Nutrition, LLC from Zorex (800-679-3027 ) 
 
Anorexia:  Covered in  the Balancing Body Chemistry w/Nutrition LLC  Protocol Manual 
(800-679-3027 ). 
 
Hyperthyroidism:  See TSH,  T-3 and T-4 
 
HIV: See WBC  and Differential  and T-Cell Evaluation  
 
Testicular  Hypofunction:  See Total  and Free Testosterone  and Estrogens  
 
Less  Common  Causes  for Increased  SHBG:  Alcoholism,  Nontoxic  Goiter,  Thyroid  Nodule, 
Acute Myocardial Infarct, Hypertension.

197 
 Common  Causes  for Decreased  SHBG:  
 
Obesity:  Covered in the Balancing  Body  Chemistry  w/Nutrition  LLC Protocol  Manual 
(800-679-3027 ) 
 
Hypothyroidism:  See TSH,  T-3 and T-4 
 
Agromegaly  (Excess  Production  of HgH):  See IGF-1 
 
Type  2 Diabetes:  See Glucose,  Ale and Glycated  Albumin  
 
Polycystic  Ovary  Disease:  See Free and Total  Testosterone  
 
Less Common Causes for Decreased SHBG:  Cushing's Disease, Alcoholism (SHBG can be 
increased or decreased with alcoholism), Hirsutism, Ovarian and/or Adrenal Hypergonadism, 
Hypertension.  
 
Important  Considerations  with  Abnormal  SHBG:  
 
If bioavailable testosterone is decreased with increased SHBG, aromatization of 
testosterone to estrogen must be ruled out.  
 
In all cases of decreased bioavailable testosterone with increased SHBG, insufficient 
stimulation of the interstitial cells of Leydig  in the testicles (check FSH/LH).  
 
The most common reason for an increase in SHBG and a decrease in bioavailable 
testosterone is testosterone hypofunction (supplemental support listed under Free and total 
Testosterone).

Product Profile  
L.P.A. Plus  delivers comprehensive antioxidant support through a synergistic combination of 100 
mg alpha lipoic acid, 51.6 mg vitamin C (as ascorbic acid, Mg ascorbate), and 28.57 mg vitamin E 
(mixed tocopherols) per capsule. This advanced formulation provides both w ater-soluble and 
fat-soluble antioxidant protection while supporting cellular energy production, antioxidant 
recycling, and detoxification pathways through multiple complementary mechanisms.  
Clinical Applications:  
• Diabetic neuropathy and metabolic complica tions  
• Heavy metal detoxification protocols  
• Cardiovascular health and endothelial function  
• Liver protection and detoxification support  
• Neurodegenerative disease prevention  
• Antioxidant network enhancement  
• Metabolic syndrome and insulin resistance  
Zorex Inter national Quality Advantage  
Manufacturing Excellence  
• Premium Alpha Lipoic Acid : High -potency 100 mg dose optimized for therapeutic 
efficacy  
• Synergistic Antioxidant Network : Vitamin C and E enhance ALA's recycling and 
protective effects

Clinical Applicatio ns & Protocols  
Primary Indications

Diabetic Neuropathy and Metabolic Support  Alpha lipoic acid provides direct neuroprotective 
effects through multiple mechanisms including antioxidant activity, metal chelation, and 
enhancement of glucose metabolism. The c ompound demonstrates both insulin -mimetic 
actions and protection against glucose -induced oxidative damage. Clinical studies show 
significant improvements in neuropathic symptoms and metabolic parameters with regular 
supplementation.  
Heavy Metal Detoxificati on The formulation supports safe mobilization and elimination of toxic 
metals through ALA's unique chelation properties and the protective effects of vitamins C and E. 
Alpha lipoic acid binds to mercury, lead, cadmium, and other heavy metals while antioxi dant 
cofactors prevent oxidative damage during the detoxification process. Research demonstrates 
enhanced excretion with specialized pulsed -dosing protocols.  
Cardiovascular Health Enhancement  The antioxidant network supports endothelial function, 
reduces L DL oxidation, and enhances nitric oxide bioavailability. Alpha lipoic acid improves 
insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism, addressing key cardiovascular risk factors. Combined 
with vitamins C and E, the formulation provides comprehensive protection ag ainst 
atherosclerotic processes.  
Liver Protection and Detoxification  Alpha lipoic acid enhances hepatic glutathione synthesis, 
supports phase II detoxification, and protects against oxidative liver damage. The compound 
demonstrates particular benefit for a lcohol -related liver dysfunction and non -alcoholic fatty 
liver disease. Antioxidant cofactors provide additional hepatoprotective effects during 
detoxification processes.  
Dosing Protocols  
Standard Antioxidant Support : 1-2 capsules three times daily with me als Heavy Metal 
Detoxification : 1 capsule every 3 hours during waking hours and every 4 hours at night for 5 
days, then 2 days off, continuing for 5 -6 weeks Diabetic Neuropathy : 2 capsules twice daily, 
preferably before meals Cardiovascular Support : 1-2 capsules twice daily as part of 
comprehensive protocol Liver Protection : 2 capsules twice daily during detoxification phases  
Timing Considerations:  
• Take at least 30 minutes before meals for optimal absorption  
• Avoid taking with  high -carbohydrate meals which may reduce bioavailability  
• Evening doses may be beneficial for overnight antioxidant protection  
• During detoxification protocols, maintain consistent timing for optimal metal 
mobilization

• Consider with selenium and other suppo rtive nutrients for enhanced effects  
Combination Strategies  
With CircuPlus : Enhanced cardiovascular protection and endothelial support With 8X 
Pancreatin : Anti -inflammatory support for comprehensive metabolic protocols With Arginine 
Complex : Synergistic ca rdiovascular and metabolic benefits With Selenomethionine : Enhanced 
antioxidant protection and heavy metal detoxification support

Safety Considerations for Practice  
Contraindications  
• Known hypersensitivity to alpha lipoic acid or components  
• Thiamine deficiency (may be exacerbated by ALA)  
• Pregnancy/lactation (limited safety data available)  
• Severe renal impairment (adjust dosing as needed)  
Monitoring Recommendations  
• Initial Phase : Weekly assessment for first month, especially for diabetic patients  
• Detoxification : Close monitoring during intensi ve protocols  
• Long -term : Quarterly evaluation of therapeutic response and safety markers  
Drug Interactions  
Exercise caution with:  
• Insulin and oral hypoglycemic medications (enhanced glucose -lowering effects)  
• Thyroid medications (potential interference with hormone metabolism)  
• Chemotherapy agents (may reduce effectiveness of some treatments)  
• Alcohol (enhanced hepatotoxicity risk during heavy consumption)  
Mechanisms of Action  
Antioxidant Activity  
Alpha lipoic acid functions as both a direct free radical scaven ger and an antioxidant recycler, 
regenerating vitamins C and E, glutathione, and coenzyme Q10. Its unique amphiphilic 
properties allow function in both aqueous and lipid environments, providing comprehensive 
cellular protection.

Metal Chelation  
The dithiol ane ring structure of alpha lipoic acid forms stable complexes with toxic metals 
including mercury, lead, and cadmium. This chelation activity, combined with enhanced 
glutathione synthesis, supports safe mobilization and elimination of heavy metals.  
Metabo lic Enhancement  
Alpha lipoic acid serves as a cofactor in mitochondrial energy production while also enhancing 
glucose uptake through both insulin -dependent and insulin -independent mechanisms. The 
compound activates AMPK and other metabolic pathways involv ed in energy regulation.  
Anti -inflammatory Effects  
ALA inhibits NF -κB activation and reduces production of pro -inflammatory cytokines. This anti -
inflammatory activity occurs through modulation of redox -sensitive signaling pathways and 
contributes to cardiovascular and neuroprotective benefits.
